column2: The great event in the athletic world to-day is the annual championship meeting of the Intercollegiate Athletic Association, which takes place on the Berkeley Oval at Morris Dock, beginning at 2:30 P.M. The oval can be conveniently reached by the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad.

NEW-HAVEN, May 25.--John E. Bassett, the Chapel-street hardware merchant, made an assignment late this afternoon. The house is one of the oldest business concerns in New-England. Previous to the assignment the store and fixtures were attached by the Merchants' National Bank for $40,000.

Mr. Daly is still critically ill.

Davis, aged thirty-three years, a Pennsylvania Railroad brakeman, wrote in a letter to her husband ten days ago. Sarah Bernhardt has got rid of her lion's whelps. Their terrible mauvaise odeur was a reason why they were sent away. The Lyceum Theatre company ended its regular season on Saturday evening with its performance in Brooklyn. MONTREAL, May, 26.--Oscar Landreville, a young French Canadian, had been reading medicine on his own account lately and, meeting some friends of his on a street car to-day, he undertook to show them the progress he had made in his studies by opening a vein in his leg with his penknife. By mistake he opened an artery and bled to death before the occupants of the car could do anything to help him.

BERLIN, May 26.--King Humbert attended mass privately this morning in the Hedwigs Kirche. He was not noticed by the clergy, although other sovereigns are always received with ceremony. In passing about the leading streets in almost any city in America today one will most with but few ladies who have older complexions. Many persons have tried to account for this sad fact because of the severe climate of America, but such reasoning is wrong. A bad complexion is caused by impure blood, and no lady can be really beautiful and no man ruddy who has diseased of impure blood.

The Brooklyn Jockey Club will have two extra races on Memorial Day, making eight in all, so that all will have a chance to get their fill of racing. The Sport will begin at 2 o'clock, a half hour earlier than usual, so as to give ample time to run off the extra races.

Orleman, United States Army, (retired.) has been relieved from duty at the Florida Agricultural College, Lake City, and detailed for duty at Peekskill Military Academy, New-York.

ROME, May 29.--The public was startled today by a report of the death of the Pope. The rumor reached the Houses of Parliament and caused much excitement among the Senators and Deputies. On inquiry it was learned that there was no foundation whatever for the rumor. His Holiness is enjoying good health and attends daily to the duties of his office.

PITTSBURG, May 29.--For the first time in the fifteen years' existence of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers there will be no conference this year with the manufacturers on the annual wage scale.

CLEVELAND, May 29.--H. Melville Fay, the well-known spirit medium and husband of Anna Eva Fay, has just died in hospital here of cancer of the tongue. He was forty-eight years old.

CHICAGO, May 29.--Coroner Hertz adjourned the Cronin inquest this morning to Monday morning next. No evidence was heard. The adjournment was taken at the suggestion of State's Attorney Longenecker, who was of the opinion that the taking of evidence in public might hamper the police in their work of investigating clues.

Capt. Geroge Washburn, formerly of the Twentieth Precinct, whose reinstatement on the police force was ordered by the General Term of the Supreme Court, served upon the Police Commissioners yesterday a certified copy of the order. He was directed to report to Superintendent Murray until the next meeting of the board, when some definite action will be taken, either to assign him to duty or to take the case to the Court of Appeals.

The movement begun by the Rev. Father O'Hare of St. Anthony's Church against the Greenpoint saloon keepers has taken a new aspect. Last Sunday Father O'Hare personally visited the saloons, surprised the keepers, and ordered them to close up.

ST. PAUL, May 29.--It is likely now that there will be a lively struggle for business between the lake and rail and all rail routes. There have been signs of a storm for several days and word was sent out yesterday that "something would drop" to-day.

The jury that for several days has been investigating the death of Washington Irving Bishop, under the direction of Coroner Levy, finished its labors yesterday, finding that death was due to coma. In regard to the autopsy the jurors said in their verdict that, while acting in good faith, Dr. Irwin, through overzealousness, had been somewhat hasty.

As the season advances the rush to Europe increases, and every steamer that leaves this port goes out with full lists of cabin-passengers. This season ocean travel has been great, owing doubtless to the Paris Exposition. Four of the largest steamers left port yesterday, each carrying a full load of passengers.

Gov. Hill and his military secretary, Col. Judson, arrived at the Hoffman House last evening from Albany. The Governor will review the military parade to-day, mend his political fences, and return to Albany to-morrow morning to grind away on the 400 legislative bills now awaiting his action.

HARTFORD, May 29.--In answer to a call by a committee representing the temperance organizations of the State a mass meeting of Prohibitionists was held in Unity Hall this morning to confer and discuss methods for conducting the campaign in behalf of the prohibitory amendment.
LONDON, May 29.--Maurice Healy, member of Parliament for Cork, was a witness before the Parnell Commission to-day.

Owing to the negligence of workmen in the employ of the New-York Steam Company to properly safeguard one of their everlasting openings in Broadway another accident occurred yesterday, in which a valuable horse was killed.

A posse consisting of two Sheriffs, a Deputy Marshal, and eight citizens made a raid Tuesday on a gang of counterfeiters who have been operating in the neighborhood of Versailles, Ill. Four men were captured and, besides counterfeiting tools and coins, a large quantity of illicit whisky was found. Capt. Porter of the Secret Service yesterday took the four men to Springfield where they were, bound over in $1,000 bonds each for counterfeiting.
LONDON, May 29.--The Earl of Zitland has accepted the Viceroyship of Ireland.

ISHPEMING, Mich., May 29.--Late last night an organized band of masked men from Marienette raided the notorious pinery resort at Peshtigo, wounding the watchman, driving out the inmates, and burning the premises. The law proving inadequate to close the pinery, citizens took the matter in their own hands.

Thirty-six young men, representing the graduating class of '89 of the Law Department of the University of the City of New-York, received the degree of Bachelor of Laws at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening. The exercises were the most brilliant ever held by a graduating class of this college.
Senator John W. Daniel of Virginia is at the New-York Hotel.

The Society of Friends held the third day's session of their annual assembly yesterday in the Rutherfurd-Place Meeeting House. Reports were received from schools in this city, Brooklyn, Easton, Granville, Albany, Purchase, Chautanqua, Cornwall, Plainfield, Jericho, Jerusalem. Flushing, and elsewhere. These schools reported an average attendance varying from twenty to forty-five and generally satisfactory progress. Fully 500 members were in attendance.
WASHINGTON, May 29.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased $618,500 4 per cent. bonds, at 108 flat. Offers of $1,000,000 4s at prices ranging from 129 to 130 were rejected.

For six innings the Indianapolis men held a lead over the Giants yesterday, but in the lucky seventh the latter forged to the front and held the lead during the remainder of the contest. The New-Yorks played a waiting game.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 29.--The Canadian Fisheries Protection Service on the Atlantic coast will go into operation next week. The catch of mackerel this season promises to be the largest for years past, as they are striking in earlier than usual.
The steamship Egyptian Monarch, which arrived at this port from London yesterday, reports having passed on May 26 the waterlogged wreck of the American bark Palatka.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 29.--A crowd of about a hundred, made up of Sophomores and Freshmen of Cornell, with a slight mixture of upper classmen, assembled at the Ithaca Hotel last night and marched through the principal streets to the boat landing.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 29.--The cold wave has caused much damage to fruit and other crops in this district. Grapes will suffer severely, although not so much as vegetables. It is safe to estimate that a large portion of the crops in this county are badly damaged, entailing a loss of over $15,000.

BRUSSELS, May 29.--In the Chamber of Representatives to-day, Prime Minister Beernaert made a long speech, in the course of which he strenuously denied that the Government was plotting the ruin of citizens through the agency of police spies. He accused the opposition of making political capital out of the recent trials at Mons, a charge that elicited applause from the members of the Right.

NEW-HAVEN, May 29.--One of the greatest literary curiosities in Connecticut is a book now owned by Mrs. John Ogilvie Roorbach of Mystic Bridge. John Ogilvie, assistant minister of Trinity Church in New-York City.

CHICAGO, May 30.--Even rumors of clews in the Cronin case died away to-day. Policemen and detectives wandered around Lake View in the rain searching sewers and vaults for Cronin's clothes. They found nothing.

NEW-HAVEN, May 30.--It is now expected that over three thousand Masons from all parts of Connecticut will take part in the observance of the centennial anniversary of the formation of the Connecticut Grand Lodge of Masons which will be celebrated in this city on July 10. The demonstration will be the greatest of the kind ever witnessed in Connecticut.

The Kings County Cricket Club and the Amateur League played a game on the North Meadow, in Central Park, yesterday afternoon. Kings County scored 96 runs in the first and 26 in the second innings; the Amateur League 39 in the first and 36 runs for six wickets in the second inning, when the game ended.

The annual published by the Senior Class, containing interesting as well as peculiar statistics of each member and the summary of the whole class does not make its apperance until Class Day, June 17. However, some of the facts about the class have been ascertained this year in advance. When the class entered college it numbered 14O Freshmen.

LONDON, May 31.--The White Star Line steamship Celtic, Capt. Smtih, from New-York May 22 for Liverpool, art at Queenstown at 9:15 P.M. yesterday.

NEW-HAVEN, May 30.--The proposed constitutional amendment providing for new State Senatorial districts in Connecticut has been favorably reported upon by the legislative Committee on Constitutional Amendments.

Eductional matters with especial reference to the schools at the State of New-York will be considered at length at the forty-fourth annual meeting of the New-York State Teachers' Association, which will be held in Brooklyn July 2 and 3, in the Academy of Music.
COLUMBIA, S.C., May 30.--Col. John C. Haskell of Columbia has been elected the member of the National Democratic Committee from South Carolina.

KANSAS CITY, May 30.--The storm of Tuesday and Tuesday night was general over Missouri, Kansas, and Nebraska, and delayed nearly all trains coming into Kansas City. Nearly all the telegraph poles along the Southern Kansas Railroad were blown down, and south of Iola, Kan., there were many overflows. The trains on the Wabash were over several hours late.

WHITE PLAINS, May 30.--The third day of the meeting at North End Park furnished good sport to a large crowd of spectators. The favorite, Bessie II., failed to win the 2:29 class, and the 2:33 class was only decided in favor of Kentucky Blanche after a stubborn contest of five heats. The meeting ends to-morrow with the free-for-all an 2:45 classes.

Since the beginning of the suit for $250,000 damages against the individual members of the Board of Electrical Control by the United States Electric Illuminating Company the plaintiff company has been reorganized.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 30.--The savings bank at Savannah, Mo., has made an assignment to Gilbert McDaniel and Henderson Edwards. The bank had a capital of $18,000, real estate worth $25,000, and its deposits amounted to $7,500.

RED BANK, N.J., May 30.--One of the oldest Episcopalian edifices in this section of NewJersey is that in which the Episcopalians of Red Bank worship. It is situated on Central Front-street, opposite the Baptist church.

WATERVILLE, Me., May 30.--The President of Colby College, acting under the instructions of the Trustees, has expelled two Freshmen and suspended till Commencement two Seniors said to have been the leaders in the recent hazing of some girl students.

CHICAGO, May 30.--At 1 o'clock this afternoon the memorial monument erected by citizens in honor of the policeman who were killed by an Anarchist bomb in the Haymarket riot on May 4, 1886, was unveiled.

Gen. Harrison passed a busy day yesterday. He arose before 7, took breakfast, held a long reception, reviewed the Brooklyn parade, partook of a grand lunch, and succeeded in getting to the afternoon Washington express at Jersey City nearly half an hour before it started.

RED BANK, N.J., May 30.--Robert Maitland of New-York, who spends his Summers at Oceanic, has presented the Oceanic Presbyterian Church with an organ costing $600.

At present there are stationed in the waters of the Pacific, doing active cruising, eight British vessels of war of modern type, each fully equipped and ready for immediate service. The command of these cruisers belongs to Rear Admiral Algernon C.F. Heneage, whose flag flies from the Swlitsure, flagship.
BALTIMORE, May 30.--The subscribers to the proposed sugar refinery attended a conference at the rooms of the Board of Trade yesterday afternoon. Mr. W.W. Spence presided.
A notice, which is of much interest to the members of the Methodist Church, was sent out yesterday.

Coney Island made a great effort to let all comers know that it was opened for the season yesterday. A good many people strolled along the garbage-fringed beach from West Brighton up to the Oriental Hotel.

The Ascension Day services at old Trinity yesterday had a dual significance, since they signalized not only the chief feast in the Christian calendar but the anniversary of the dedication of the parish church. At the high celebration at 11 o'clock the rector, the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, was the celebrant, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Mulchahey as deacon and the Rev. Mr. Brown as sub-deacon.

A colored man, who was expensively and elegantly dressed and wore a profusion of diamonds, occupied a proscenium box at the Casino last night, and manifested his approval of the performance by frequent and enthusiastic applause.

Palestine Commandery, No. 18, Knights Templar, held a public Ascension Day service in Masonic Hall last evening. There was a fairsized audience present when the Knights Templar marched in. Prayers were read by the prelate, several hymns sung, and a responsive service taken part in. The Rev. Dr. John M. Worrall made the address, and there were solos by bliss Jennie Layman and Mr. Charles H. Baldwin.

The fishing season at Greenwood Lake is always formally opened on Decoration Day, as the law then allows the taking of black bass. An excursion train was run to the lake yesterday, and it was well patronized.

It was a glorious day yesterday for yacht racing on the Sound, and it could not have been a more favorable one for Mr. C. Oliver Iselin's racing yacht Titania if it had been dealt out at a special order from Mr. Iselin himself and his skipper, Capt. Haff of Volunteer fame.

Navigation was again impeded yesterday by a thick fog, and several sight accidents were the result. Early in the morning and for a large part of the forenoon it was very thick off Sandy Hook. During the night the Red Star steamer Pennland, from Antwerp, grounded in the mud near Romer Beacon. The tugboats Hudson and J.F. Crawford succeeded in pulling the steamer off at 8 o'clock.

Capt. C.H. Smith of the Naugatuck Steamboat Company reported yesterday that he passed a capsized vessel off the Norwalk Islands at 12:15 A.M. on Wednesday. The capsized boat was a small one, not more than fifty feet in length, and was painted block, with green below the water line.

WASHINGTON, May 30.--The announcement by the press dispatches from Berlin on Wednesday that the Samoan Conference would agree upon a settlement of the Samoan affairs that night is assumed at the State Department to be the explanation of the appearance in the World of today of what purports to be an outline of the treaty supposed to have been agreed to by the Commissioners for the three powers.
The handsome new clubhouse of the Yonkers Corinthian Yacht Club was yesterday thrown open to the public for inspection, and in the evening the members and their lady friends had a hop.

CHICAGO, May 30.--Decoration Day in Chicago was marred by an unusual scene, growing out of ill-feeling between rival factions of old soldiers. In Oakwood Cemetery there are hundreds of Union and Confederate soldiers buried.
The annual reception of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum took place yesterday at the asylum, One Hundred and Thirty-eighth-street and Western Boulevard.

It has been assumed by the Cup Committee of the New-York Yacht Club that the Royal Yacht Squadron of England took some action regarding the new deed of gift governing the America's Cup at a meeting held May 11.

ELMIRA, N.Y., May 30.--Charles R. Partridge, the lumber merchant who killed Frank Rafferty in New-York yesterday, arrived at his home in this city this morning. He did not know until he arrived here that Rafferty was dead. As soon as he learned the fact he took the first train for New-York for the purpose of giving himself up.

RED BANK, N.J., May 30.--The apple orchards in this vicinity are being attacked by a brown worm about an inch long which eats the stem of the fruit and causes the apples to fall to the ground. The worm also eats the leaves of the tree. The pest is doing great damage.
PITTSBURG, May 30.--Before the seventh annual meeting of the Pennsylvania Board of Health to-day the Secretary read a complaint from Dr. C.O. Probst, State Secretary of the Ohio Board of Health.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 30.--A bicycle race of sixteen miles was run here to-day with this result: John Van Benschoten, Poughkeepsie, first, in 1 hour 2 minutes and 11 seconds; Elias Van Benschoten, Poughkeepsie, second; Edward Cashin, Wappinger's Falls, third.
AUBURN, N.Y., May 30.--Considerable indignation is expressed among Masons here at the summary manner in which the Driving Park site at Utica was selected for the Masonic Home site.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 30.--A southeast storm in the morning cut off the patronage and hurt the beautiful track at Narragansett Park for the bicycle and athletic tournament of the Rhode Island wheelman in the afternoon.

Yesterday was ladies' day at the Brooklyn Yacht Club. Gravesend Beach and the clubhouse presented a gay appearance, as the ladies jauntily dressed in boating costumes, lined the piazzas and impatiently waited for the wind to become a little less boisterous, for sailing in Gravesend Bay was what they came for.

BOSTON, May 30.--The Rev. Minot J. Savage, in addressing the veterans at E.W. Kinsley Post to-day, touched upon the spoils system in a vein somewhat similar to that pursued by Bishop Potter during the New-York centennial.

Decoration Day and the Fourth of July have always vied with each other for the distinction of being the best baseball day of the year. Up to yesterday the honors were about evenly divided, but now Memorial Day is in the lead.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 30.--The Rev. Paul Van Dyke, brother of Dr. Henry J. Van Dyke, has accepted a call from Princeton College to be instructor in church history, to which position he was elected at the last meeting of the Directors. He will probably enter upon his duties next Fall.

The 30th of May is a day of almost as much importance to fresh-water anglers as the opening of the trout season, for it is then that the law is uplifted and fishermen are free to angle for teh rotund and lively black bass. The fish are gamy, and they are usually in fine ...

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 31.--Charlie Carter, a boy of fifteen, with a companion a little older, is in jail here awaiting the arrival of his father from Knoxville, Tenn., to take him home. The boys ran away and had roughed it as far as New-Brunswick, when they were arrested by a Pennsylvania Railroad detective for stealing a ride on a train, Carter's father is a Knoxville physician.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31.--The Rev. William L. Gage, D.D., of Hartford, Conn., jumped from the fourth-story window of the Orthopedic Hospital at Seventeenth and Summer streets this morning, and died two hours later.

Wall-street enjoyed an old-fashioned sensation yesterday. The Governors of the Stock Exchange gave its brokers a surprise, gave rival exchanges a shock, and created a panic among the pirate bucket shops.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 31.--The graduating exercises of the Yale Art School were held today. President Dwight and Profs. Hoppin, Weir, and Neimeyer addressed the graduating class informally, after which diplomas were distributed.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1.--A special to THE TIMES from Bolivar at 3 o'clock this morning says a courier has just reached there from Johnstown who says that at least 1,500 lives were lost by the disaster.

The account in THE TIMES of the absence of representative Republicans of Brooklyn from the reception to President Harrison at Joseph F. Knapp's house created a great deal of gossip yesterday. The local papers took the matter up and pointed out the significance of the snub.

Mr. E.J. Donnell read a paper before the Reform Club last evening on "The Causes and Dangers of Our Present Industrial and Political Condition." The rooms of the clubhouse were well filled with members and their friends, and Mr. Donnell's arguments were followed with close attention.

Dry Dock village has not witnessed such a scene of pleasureable excitement for a long time as that last evening attending the nuptials of Alderman William Tait and Mrs. Mary Potter, at the residence of the bride's father, Nicholas Drummond, at 808 Sixth-street.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., May 31.--Further particulars have been received concerning the barge Bavaria, one of the Calvin's tow, that was reported stranded on Galloup Island.

CHICAGO, May 31.--In accordance with previous announcement, official quotations of the Board of Trade will be cut off to-morrow from about five hundred correspondents who are non-members of the board.

City Controller Dickinson of Jersey City has thrown a new obstruction in the way of the new charter's friends. The new Fire Board recently passed a claim of Daniel Shea, who had been a member of the old Fire Board, for his salary for the last three months of the year he served.

CHICAGO, May 31.--The police authorities were apparently very busy to-day on the Cronin case, but they professed to have nothing new except a fine assortment of clues. These they predicted would develop something, but as to what the something would be they preserved a portentous silence.
LONDON, June 1.--The Inman Line steamship City of Chicago, Capt. Redford, from New-York May 22 for Liverpool, passed Brow Head at 12:40 A.M. today.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 31.--Michael Gillen was arrested last night by Policemen McGarn and Reuter, and was terribly clubbed by them before he was taken to the station house. The policemen say that Gillen was drunk and quarrelsome, and when taken into custody suddenly turned upon Reuter, knocked him down and kicked him in the body. There will be an investigation by the Chief of Police.

The Concord Railroad has taken possession of the Boston, Concord and Montreal, and Frank E. Brown has been appointed General Passenger Agent of the system. It is stated that the following appointments have also been made: E.F. Mann, Division Superintendent; W.A. Stowell, Superintendent of Construction, and G.R. Storer, Boston agent.

The plans of the new World Building, at Park-row and Frankfort-street, were filed in the Building Bureau yesterday. The building is to have thirteen stories and is to be 188 feet high, exclusive of the dome. It will be constructed of brick, stone, and terra cotta, and is to cost $1,000,000. The owner is Joseph Pulitzor.

Dr. Mary A. Dixon Jones and her son, Dr. Charles N. Dixon Jones, who managed the Woman's Hospital at Greene and Sumner avenues, Brooklyn, were indicted yesterday by the Kings County Grand Jury for manslaughter.

PITTSBURG, May 31.--An appalling catastro phe is reported from Johnstown, Cambria County, the meagre details of which indicate that that city of 25,000 inhabitants has been practically wiped out of existence and that hundreds if not thousands of lives have been lost.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31.--The tracks west of Johnstown are at some points entirely carried away, and the roadbed is gone. The river for some distance above the bridge is filled with buildings and drift forty feet high, which is on fire and likely to damage the bridge, which is of stone. The fire is beyond control. Johnstown is literally wiped out.

Paige, Carey Co. and D.M. Carey Co., sub-contractors under O'Brien Clark on Sections 7 and 9 of the new Croton Aqueduct, have filed notices of mechanics' liens on the work with Controller Myers and the Board of Aqueduct Commissioners.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 31.--Edwin K. Burnham, the new Superintendent of Public Buildings, arrived to-day, and late this afternoon took the oath of office and filed his ten-thousand-dollar bond with Controller Wemple. He will enter upon his new duties to-morrow.

The distinctive element of the weather yesterday throughout the East was the wind. All along the coast high winds were reported as early as 8 o'clock in the morning. At that time off Cape Hatteras the wind blew twenty-four miles an hour. Cautionary storm signals were up all along the Atlantic coast.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 31.--The Court of Appeals will reconvene in the Town Hall at Saratoga on Monday, June 3. Following is the calendar for that day: Nos. 1356, 257, 294, 728, 296, 297, 280, 251. The calendar for the Second Division for June 3 is: Nos. 431, 472, 484, 482, 370, 468, 462, 471. Tuesday, June 4, and Tuesday, June 18, will be motion days.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 31.--Six members of the St. Paul Directory arrived in the city at noon to-day, on a special train, to attend the annual meeting to-morrow. They were escorted from Chicago by President Miller.

RAHWAY, N.J., May 31.--A monument was unveiled yesterday at the cemetery here in memory of Dr. Abernethy, a popular physician of this city, whose life was devoted to charitable deeds. The monument is of granite and cost $1,000. The Rev. William Rollinson of Rahway delivered the oration at the unveiling, and there were other addresses by prominent citizens.

Cars were run on schedule time for the first time yesterday on the Steinway and Hunter's Point overhead system electric road. The system, as is well known, consists of small cars drawn by a trawley, which runs on wires overhead.

The voyage had been without incident until May 24, when at 3 o'clock in the afternoon Patrick Shea, a steerage passenger, committed suicide by jumping overboard. The ship was stopped and a boat lowered immediately, but after an hour's search failed to find the suicide's body.

J., May 31.--The sloop Edith Thurber, which lay at anchor in Bridge Creek near this city, was boarded by river thieves last night and completely stripped of rigging and sails, together with two anchors and the chains attached to them. The Stewart will case is in course of compromise. Denials by counsel are at last set at naught in this matter. OMAHA Neb., June 6.--The Bank of Omaha which was incorporated last Fall with a capital of $1,000,000, very little of which was paid in closed its doors to-day. The liabilities are be tween $60,000 and $70,000; assets nominal. The failure is due to bad loans and mismanagement.

The result of the examination of candidates for admission to the College of the City of New-York was given out yesterday. The number of candidates who applied for admission was 1,425. Of the entire number 619 qualified.

WICHITA, Kan., June 7.--This section was today visited by the most severe storm for years. A heavy rain was followed by hail, which caused great damage to grain and fruit. The western part of Sedgwick County and the eastern part of Kingman suffered most.

BALTIMORE, June 7.--It is estimated that three-fourths of the 20,000,000 feet of timber which floated away from Williamsport, Penn., are floating above the Chesapeake or lying on its shores. The "Stray Log Committee" from the Lumber Exchange of that city is now here surveying the situation.

A charming wedding was that of George Bickelhaupt and Miss Louise Arnold, the eldest daughter of Mr. Frederick Arnold, last evening, in St. Luke's Evangelical Lutheran Church, in West Forty-second-street.

The Commencement exercises of the college of New-Jersey (Princeton) will be of special interest this year. They will begin on Saturday next and end Wednesday, the 19th. On Saturday there will be the reading of theses by the graduating class of the School of Science.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 10.--The schooner smack William Fisher of Noank, Capt. Ezra Latham, master, with a crew of twelve men, is believed to have been lost with all on board. There is apparently no chance for her safety, as she is now seventy days overdue on a voyage from the Georgia coast to New-York.
HARTFORD, June 10.--The Secret Ballot bill, which was vetoed by Gov. Bulkeley last week, will be one of the first things to be taken up in the House on the reassembling of the Legislature to-morrow.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 10.--At 1 o'clock this afternoon a heavy cyclone struck the little city of Dayton and passed through it from one end to the other. The cloud was funnel shaped. It struck a new block and damaged it so that it will have to be torn down and rebuilt, unroofed the Opera House, and shook the most substantial buildings in the city.
If the gloomy forebodings of State Assessor WOOD are well founded the famers of this State have rather a dismal prospect before them.

Two bills in the hands of the Governor are of much interest to the National Guard. The first is an act, amending the Military Code, in which it is provided that the pay of armorers, janitors, and engineers of armories shall be fixed by the Board of Supervisors of the county in which each armory is located.

Manager Augustus Pitou, who has been personally directing the tour of W.J. Scanian, arrived home Sunday in the Alaska. He speaks in glowing terms of the reception accorded Mr. Scanlan in England, Ireland, and Scotland.
Edward W. Odell, thirty years old, committed suicide yesterday morning, without any apparent cause, by shooting himself in the right temple at his parents' residence, 23 Bankstreet.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 10.--This evening there was a brilliant soiree musicale at Vassar College and there was a large audience present. The programme embraced organ fantasies, piano selections, solo and duet singing.

WASHINGTON, June 10.--Dr. John B. Hamilton, Surgeon General of the Marine Hospital Service, has made a report to the President in regard to the situation of affairs at Johnstown, Penn., which place he visited in compliance with the order of President Harrison.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10.--On Saturday last Gov. Reaver and Mayor Fitler had a conference at the latter's office regarding the placing of Johnstown and vicinity in good sanitary condition.

Information reached Jersey City yesterday that the Supreme Court Judges, before whom the charter arguments took place last week, had decided to sustain the new city charter. Word was quietly sent to Mayor Cleveland and to the lawyers in the case, and by 3 o'clook the new city officials and assembled in the Mayor's office.

No trace of Sadie Palmer, the pretty typewriter, who disappeared from her home in Brooklyn on Friday, has yet been discovered. Her sister said yesterday that Sadie had probably eloped. Miss Palmer explained that her sister had been anxious to get married for some time, and had finally decided that the only way to succeed was to elope.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 10.--The Cornellian, the satirical annual of the University, is out to-day, and is making a sensation. It contains some of the cleverest "grinds" on prominent prefessors and well-known students that have yet been perpetrated.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 10.--The programme for Commencement Week at Yale has been announced. On Friday, June 21, the class oration and poem will be read, and on the following Sunday the baccalaureate sermon will be delivered.
Patrolman John A. Bromiley of the Thirtyfourth Precinct (Tremont) police was a prisoner at the Morrisania Police Court yesterday morning on a charge of grandlarceny.

There was a special meeting of the Park Board yesterday at which J. Hampden Robb resigned the treasurership, to which he was elected a few days ago, and its duties were put into the hands of Charles De F. Burns, the Secretary.

CHICAGO, June 10.--The announcement is made to-night that within forty-eight hours Alexander Sullivan is to be arrested and held without bail to await the action of a special Grand Jury, the venire for which will be issued Wednesday.

Mayor Chapin of Brooklyn sent $20,000 more to the Johnstown sufferers yesterday, making $45,000 contributed forwarded by the city. From various sources the Mayor received about $1,200 yesterday, of which $567 was from the Church of the Pilgrims. From the boxes in the police precincts $2,691 86 was taken. This money was collected during Saturday and Sunday, and makes the total amount taken up by the police $25,488 38.

HURLEY, Wis., June 10.--The Iron King Mine, one of the best shippers on the Gogebic range, closed down to-day, owing to the trouble between stockholders. All of the Bessemer Consolidated Company's mines have also closed down, owing, as the Superintendent states, to a lack of ready money.
Capt. Probst of the German bark George Washington, which arrived yesterday, reports that on May 27 he sighted a small boat steering east, flying the American colors.

The annual reunion of the Covert family will be held at Lodi Landing, N.Y., on Thursday, June 20. The assemblage will be called to order at 11 A.M. by the President, William C. Covert of St. Paul Park, Minn.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 10.--This State is being overrun by statesmen, real and alleged, anxious to secure a following large enough to justify them in announcing the fact that they are candidates for the Gubernatorial nomination on the Republican ticket.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 10.--Peter Markley, who was tried for alleged complicity in some thieving operations on the Erie Railroad, was erroneously reported to have been convicted of burglary and sent to the Eastern Penitentiary for five years. The fact is that Markley was admitted to bail pending the hearing of a motion for a new trial.

BOSTON, June 10.--From various sections of New-England come reports of a heavy thunderstorm this afternoon which did considerable damage. At Marlborough, Mass., Charles Butler's house was struck by lightning, the chimney demolished, clapboards torn off, and the occupants stunned.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 10.--Messrs Ayer Co., the patent medicine firm of Lowell, Mass., have entered a claim for $124,000 against the Canadian Government for illegal seizure of their preparations at St. John, Quebec, Toronto, Hamilton, and Windsor during 1888 by the Canadian customs authorities.

RED BANK, N.J., June 10.--The sermon to the graduating class of the Red Bank graded schools was preached yesterday morning by the Rev. Nelson A. Macnichol, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church.

Yesterday was a holiday in London, and, the London Stock Exchange being closed, NewYork's stock market had to get along as best it could, minus the tonic of European orders and British quotations. New-York did well. There was a boom throughout nearly the entire list.

Ex-Judge Lewis of Brooklyn went to Washington again yesterday to look after the interests of Theodore B. Willis, who wants to be Surveyor of the Port. Mr. Lewis said that Senator Evarts had withdrawn his opposition, and that Willis's appointment was assured.
The first field meeting of the Actors' Amateur Athletic Association will be held this afternoon on the grounds of the Staton Island Athletic Club at Livingston, S.I.

The Nineteenth Century, the Fortnightly Review, and the Contemporary Review, the three leading English monthly periodicals, are issued in this country by the Leonard Scott Publication Company, their business having been changed from Philadelphia to New-York.

The Dental Association of the Second District of the State of New-York, Dr. Wadsworth of Brooklyn presiding, met in Newburg yesterday. About sixty members were present, the majority of them being from New-York and Brooklyn. The delegates represented the counties of Kings, Queens, Suffolk, Richmond, Putnam, Westchester, Dutchess, Orange, and Rockland. Various papers were read and discussed, and the President read his annual address.

The eighteenth annual regatta of the New-Jersey Yacht Club was sailed yesterday. Twenty-three boats were entered, but only seven started. Several were detained at the clubhouse in Hoboken until it was too late to reach the starting point near Liberty Island. A good many members of the club and their friends accompanied the boats in a steamer.

A special meeting of the Arlington League was held last night to take action in reference to the death of the late ex-President of the club, Henry Storm. A memorial was passed expressing the regrets of the members for the sad bereavement of the family. It was also decided that the members proceed in a body from the clubhouse to the church, at 1 o'clock to-day, to attend the funeral services.

PARIS, June 10.--The Temps says that there is proof against Gen. Boulanger which sustains grave charges, and that the Government has sufficient grounds to instruct the Procureur General to take measures to indict him.

CATSKILL, N.Y., June 10.--The General Synod of the Reformed Church in America resumed its sessions to-day in this village. The question of organic union with the Reformed Church in the United States (German) was, by recommendation of a committee, postponed for final action until next year.

Mr. J.W. Morrissey's season of English opera at the Grand Opera House has found favor with that large portion of the public which takes pleasure in the less serious forms of music, and thus far the business has been of a nature to please any manager.

The race between the Atalanta and Columbia College eight-oared crews takes place this afternoon at 5:30 on the Passaic at Newark. The race will start from the foot of Claystreet and finish near the Greenwood Lake Railroad bridge. The Columbia, launch, the Carrie Goodwin, will be the referee's boat. The Columbia crew while at Newark will be the guests of the Passaic Boat Club.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 10.--The Faculty of Rutgers Colelge to-day announced the appointment of Prof. E.H. Cook, until recently Principal of the State Normal School, at Potsdam, N.Y., as the new Head Master of the Rutgers Preparatory School.

For some time a vacancy in the office of Second Lieutenant of Company E, Sixty-ninth Regiment, Capt. Hugh Coleman, has existed, caused by the death of Lieut. James B. Monohan. A week or two since an endeavor was made to fill the vacancy.

CHICAGO, June 10.--Augustin Daly's company began their second week at Hooley's to-night, producing "The Lottery of Love" with most emphatic success. Mr. Daly gave an extra matinee to-day for the Johnstown sufferers.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., June 10.--A special train arrived here to-day with a railroad party, consisting of Passenger Agents Richards of the New-York Central and Hudson River, Burdick of the Delaware and Hudson, and others, under the care of Superintendent French of Chateaugay. They will visit all the principal points in this section of the Adirondacks.
OAKLAND, Me., June 10.--Train No. 13, due here at 4 P.M., was wrecked a mile and a halfwest of this station.

Notwithstanding the heavy storm which passed over the vicinity of New-York yesterday the twenty-fourth annual regatta of the Atlantic Yacht Club was unsuccessful, owing to a lack of wind. The club was unfortunately in hard luck.

In the trial of William E. Howard for complicity in the electric sugar refining fraud the District Attorney announced yesterday that all of the evidence for the people would be in by recess to-day.

The twelve members of the Hudson County Board of Freeholders who were on trial before Judge Lippincott for malfeasance in office, and Freeholder Hennessy, who was charged with forgery, were acquitted yesterday.

The vessels of the United States Navy are hereafter to be painted white. The order was received yesterday at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and every one who heard the news was delighted to think that at last the American Navy was to have a distinct color of its own.

John Thomas, alias John Welsh, a convict, attempted to kill Keeper James Hanlon at Auburn Prison yesterday. Thomas had been locked in a dungeon for bad conduct, and when Hanlon unlocked the cell the convict attacked him with an iron leg of his bedstead, which he had broken off. A fellow-officer went to Hanlon's assistance and saved his life.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Texas, June 13.--Rube Polk, Jr., and George Andry, two young man of this city, fought a duel to the death with bowie knives Tuesday night for a woman. The men attended a party, and left together apparently the best of friends.

The grounds of the Staten Island Cricket and Baseball Club at Livingston will present a brilliant and picturesque scene this evening, when the Ladies' club and its guests will hold a fete champetre for the purpose of replenishing the club's treasury.

An explosion of compressed air in the malthouse of the Jacob Ahles Brewery, 142 East Fifty-fourth-street, led to a fire that caused $100 damage yesterday morning. Later in the day an explosion occured in the grain elevator at Fred Opperman's brewery, 330 East Fifty-fifth-street, caused by spontaneous combustion. The fire did $1,500 damage before it was extinguished.

ALBANY, June 13.--These business corporations have filed certificates here: The Florida Manufacturing Company, capital $150,000. The objects are to manufacture cottonseed oil and other by-products of cotton seed, commercial fertilizers, and cotton yarn and its products.
ST. LOUIS, June 13.--The latest is a trust of $25,000,000, which takes in all the plug tobacco manufacturers of the United States. Their scheme is claimed to be one of self-protection.

The Society of the Army of the Potomac wound up its twentieth annual reunion with an excursion to West Point yesterday on the iron steamboat Sirius.

Now that many of the streets are to be repaved Mayor Grant is of the opinion that all work necessary to be done under them should be done at once. He expressed that opinion at the meeting of the Board of Electrical Control yesterday.

The longshoremen employed on the National Steamship Company's pier, 39 North River, went out on strike yesterday. The grievance of the men springs from an advertisement printed by the company calling for 100 men to do steady duty along shore for $15 a week.

ST. LOUIS, June 13.--It is now alleged that in view of the pronounced purpose of Circuit Attorney Clover to proceed under the anti-trust law against the various trusts now in existence here by bringing them before the Grand Jury for indictment that the Coal Trust has practically disbanded.

ALBANY, June 13.--Albany, New-York, Kings, and Erie Counties are exempt from the provisions of the Mase bill levying a tax on dogs, which the Governor signed late this afternoon. The tax is from $1 to $3 for single dogs owned by one party and $2 and $5 each for every additional dog.

Frank Templeman, convicted last week of felony in attempting to induce Arthur Conway to commit perjury by swearing that District Attorney Fellows and Inspector Byrnes were partners in a private detective agency, emyloyed by the District Attorney in the boodle cases, was placed at the bar before Judge Martine in Part III. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday morning for sentence.

CHICAGO, June 13.--The principal interest in the Cronin case was centred this morning in the Grand Jury, which met in Judge Shepard's court. In accordance with the general summons issued various witnesses arrived early on the scene.

The Societe Francisco de Bienfaisanco gave a reception last evening to the French Consul General, Edmond Bruwaert, at its hospital at 322 West Thirty-fourth-street. There were present to welcome him the President of the society, Joseph Thoron; Charles Renaud, Mr. Fortrengien.

Surrogate Ransom yesterday granted a motion to confirm the report of Referee Ernest Hall, declaring Bertha Uehlinger to be the widow of George Uehlinger, and dismissing the application of Uehlinger's sister, Lisette Spliess, and others to revoke the letters of administration issued to Bertha Uehlinger on the estate of George Uehlinger.

ALBANY, June 13.--August Zolzer, Thomas Zorn, Fred Grube, Frank Young, Henry Thoesen, Henry W. Steffan, Henry A. Dunkak, George Bauman, William Roeder, Louis Reinach, John Briggs, Henry Hoeler, Daniel Schnabel, Henry Sanders, and Joseph Mayer, Jr., compose the Executive Committee of the Turtle Bay Democratic Club of New-York City, incorporated to-day, with headquarters in the Nineteenth Ward.

RICHMOND, Va., June 13.--Letters have been received here from London saying that ex-Senator Henderson of Missouri and Col. H.C. Parsons of Virginia, who are now there, are advertised as agents of the State for the settlement of the Virginia debt with the bondholders there.

DULUTH, Minn., June 13.--Dispatches received from Sandstone Junction, Moose Lake, Hinckley, Barnum, and other places on the line of the Eastern Minnesota and St. Paul and Duluth Roads indicate that a bad fire is burning along the entire section. In this section are hundreds of camps and loggers' outfits.

WASHINGTON, June 13.--To-day's bond offers aggregated $7,000, as follows: Registered fours, $5,000 at 129; registered four and a halfs, $2,000 at 106 7/8; 4 per cents, registered, $37,500 at 139; 4 per cents, registered, $20,000 at 108 7/8, $10,000 at 106 7/8. All the offers were accepted.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 13.--The heavy rainfall in this neighborhood for three days has been very damaging to the corn crop. Corn which should be at least two feet high scarcely measures twelve inches, the rain having kept the earth too cold for growth. Acres of corn planted on low land throughout the county have been destroyed.

Jerome Park's Spring meeting was brought to a close yesterday, and with its close every horse owner, trainer, and racegoer trusts is a close of the reign of Mr. Wheatley and his antediluvian methods. The races at Huntington, L.I., to-day, under the auspices of the Long Island Live Stock Association, resulted as follows: 2:45 CLASS--PURSE, $225.

ALBANY, June 13.--The return in the appeal in the case of Kemmler, the convicted Buffalo murderer, sentenced to be executed by electricity within the week beginning June 24, has not been filed with the Clerk of the Court of Appeals as yet.
Justice Van Wyck of the City Court of Brooklyn yesterday gave a decision in a case of interest to policy holders in mutual life associations, to which they pay small weekly premiums.

Harlem men are always ready to celebrate Harlem's growth. Last evening nearly 800 of them rejoiced over a great development in social growth--the opening of a fine club house, the future home of the Harlem Club.

PARIS, June 13.--The cab drivers of Paris have gone on strike. There are no cabs in the streets to-day.

Katie Dunn, a ten-year-old child living at 187 Bay-street, Jersey City, while on her way from school on Wednesday afternoon, was given a tin box by Emma Ferguson, a playmate, who told her it would be found full of beads if the cover could be taken off.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 12.--In a few days the season for Summer boarders will be in full swing. Already large numbers of cottagers are taking possession of their Summer homes. Nearly every building in the town is being treated to a coat of fresh paint and many improvements are under way.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 13.--The Anti-Jesuit Convention closed its second and last day here last evening. The most important resolution adopted was one insisting that in the Province of Ontario English shall be the only medium of instruction in the public schools, and that every teacher in the said schools shall be able to teach the English language.
The tennis tournament of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association for the championship in gentlemen's singles began yesterday under the auspices of the St. George's Cricket Club at Hoboken.

The stock of the New-York and New-England Railroad Company provided the most conspicuous feature in yesterday's stock market. It rose about three points on activity that had lots of mystery in it. A dozen or more entertaining stories were afloat to account for this smart rise, but not any of the explanations satisfied the Street.

Manager J.M. Hill did his best to save "Ardriell" at the Union-Square Theatre. When he found that the orchestra refused to play on Tuesday night unless their salaries were paid he offered to guarantee their money for the present week rather than have the record of a failure made at his new theatre. The musicians, however, would listen to no proposition which did not cover the full settlement of their claims.

Mrs. Mary Hershfield, the wife of Louis H. Hershfield, President of the Merchants' Bank at Helena, Montana, reported at Police Headquarters yesterday that her son Ezra, a schoolboy of eleven years, had been missing since Wednesday morning.

Capt. Daniel Goodwin, whose fourteenyear-old son Charles took $1,540 from the family residence, 107 William-street, Brooklyn, on Sunday and decamped, found the boy and most of the money yesterday at Catskill, N.Y.
PICTON, Ontario, June 13.--Lord Adelbert Percy Cecil, the evangelist, was drowned yesterday afternoon in the Bay of Quinte, near Adolphustown, about six miles east of this place.

HARRISBURG, Va., June 13.--The great an nual German Baptist meeting closed to-day. Before the regular proceedings the venerable John Metzger of Cerro Gordo, Ill., delivered a powerful and eloquent address, exhorting the brethren to lead pure lives and keep themselves unspotted from the world.

Rear Admiral Bancroft Gherardi, commanding the United States naval squadron on the North Atlantic station, has received telegraphic orders from the Secretary of the Navy to transfer his flag from the Galena to the Kearsarge, and be ready to proceed in the latter vessel to Hayti. Instructions what to do when he arrives there had not been received at a late hour last night.
The steam yacht Augusta, built by the Herreshoff Manufacturing Company of Bristol, R.I., for I.L. Elwood of Chicago, was launched Wednesday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 13.--Private advices from Rome state that the rectors of the Irish, English, and American Colleges in Rome have formed a committee to collect a fund to purchase a marble bust of St. Thomas Aquinas for presentation to the Catholic University. It is the philosophy of this doctor of the church which Pope Leo XIII. has recommended to the authorities of the university.

First Lieut. Frank H. Barnhart, Eighteenth Infantry, has been granted three months' extension of sick leave; First Lieut. Charles A, Johnson, Fourteenth Infantry, two months' additional leave of absence.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 13.--The Amhers College Chapter of the Alpha Delta Phi fraternity is to erect a new house at Amherst at cost of $40,000.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14.--The developments in the Cronin mystery at Chicago and the NewYork arrests have quieted the objections which National Leaguers here had made to the indefinite postponement of the League Convention, which had been called for July 9.

A great many plays have been brought forward in this city not as creditable to their authors as "Pine Meadows," a drama written by Sedley Brown, an actor, and produced at a special matinee at the Madison-Square Theatre yesterday afternoon. Mr. Brown has not written a great play, nor even a very good one, but he has proved that he is the possessor of dramatic temperament, and that he is not without ideas.

BASTROP, Texas, June 14.--At the last election the negroes proved the most numerous at the polls in Cedar Creek Precinct, and elected a Justice of the Peace named Orange Wickes, and a negro constable, Issac Wilson.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 14.--An unknown woman committed suicide at Niagara Falls this afternoon. She was a German, well dressed, and supposed to be from Buffalo.
The auction sale of the household effects of Miss Rose Coghlan took place at her residence, 144 West Ninety-fifth-street, yesterday.

The attempt to induce Secretary WINDOM to reverse the ruling as to the importation of silver-lead ores from Mexico--a ruling that was made in 1880 by Secretary SHERMAN, and has since been sustained by other Secretaries, both Republican and Democratic--has not escaped attention in Mexico.

The National Furniture Manufacturers' Association finished its hard work yesterday and its Western members will to day, under the guidance of their Eastern associates, enjoy the pleasures of a visit to Starin's Glen Island.

At the Madison-Square Garden, New-York, re cently, five women for six days in succession rode over 100 miles each day upon bicycles and at the and of that time were well and strong. This proved conclusively that women have strength and endurance often equal to men.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 14.--The House concurred with the Senate to-day in passing the Phoenix Mutual Life bill, which gives the policy holders the power to gain control of the company by purchasing the capital stock. The cost per share is not to exceed $250. It is provided that a majority of the stock must be purchased in order to effect the transfer to the policy holders.
LONDON, June 14.--Mr. Gladstone addressed an enthusiastic mass meeting in the Drill Hall at Plymouth this evening, dealing at length with the Irish question.

The Commencement exercises of the Columbia Institute were held at Adelphi Hall, at Broadway and Fifty-second-street, last evening, and the graduating cadets had a large audience of parents and interested friends present to listen to and appland their orations.

George and Charles Sherwood, aged, respectively, fourteen and seventeen years, sons of a conductor on the Northwestern Railway, were drowned in the Calumet River Thursday afternoon. The accident occurred near the Pan Handle bridge, Kensington. The boys were bathing, and the younger one got beyond his depth. His brother went to the rescue, but both were drowned. The bodies were recovered.

Yesterday's stock market lagged. The new boom halted and prices generally weakened. But ever since the Saturday half-holiday law went into operation Friday has usually been a dull and drooping day on the Stock Exchange, just as Saturday used to be.

We are both pleased and thankful to be able, in answer to many inquiries, to state, from the most authentic source, that the Rev. Dr. Austin Phelps is rapidly recovering at Bar Harbor from his late severe illness. Should nothing unforeseen occur to prevent, it is hoped that he will be out of doors in a few days, and, regaining his usual degree of health, will pass a comfortable Summer.

The Coffee Exchange had a sensation yesterday in a big drop in prices. Coffee has been ruling high for some time and something of the sort was looked for, but when it came in the shape of a drop of 95 points, or nearly a full cent per pound, as it did yesterday, it was a surprise.

NEW-HAVEN, June 14.--Yesterday the Yale University crew took its last practice pull on New-Haven waters. To-morrow the oarsmon will go to New-London and will be in their shell on the Thames River in the evening. The shells and launch went to New-London to-day. The crew is in fair condition, physically, at present, but is inferior to the crew of last year in one respect.

The Board of Governors of the Manhattan Athletic Club, which has been lacking a member since the resignation of Charles King several weeks ago, was restored to its proper number last night by the election of C. Vanderbilt Cross. The Treasurer's report showed that but $60,000 worth of bonds on the new clubhouse remain untaken, and the members hope to have those subscribed for before the cornerstone of the new house is laid.

A number of the residents of Clifton, N. J., yesterday petitioned the Court of Common Pleas at Paterson to order an election within certain limits prescribed in the petition to allow the voters of that neighborhood to determine whether or not they want a borough Government.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 14.--Miss Agness Hyde of Boston, a popular elocutionist and dramatic reader, gave an entertainment this evening under the auspices of the Westport Board of Trade, the entire proceeds of which will be sent to the sufferers by the floods in the Conemaugh Valley. A large audience was present and a handsome sum raised.

The College of the City of New-York held its annual Kelly prize debate last evening in the college chapel. The success of the civil service was the topic, and the debaters were warmly applauded.

TAYLOR of the Ordnance Department on the concentration of State troops at the centennial celebration in this city more than substantiates the impression derived from the brief indication as to its character published several weeks ago.

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 14.--Mrs. President Harrison and party have been resting quietly at Postmaster General Wanamaker's handsome seaside residence at the Point since her arrival yesterday until this afternoon, when Mrs. Harrison, her father, and Baby McKee and nurse drove over to Cape May. Mrs. Wanamaker returned to Philadelphia this morning, but will be found at the seaside again to-morrow.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 14.--At 6:30 this evening the last spike was driven in the last rail of the Poughkeepsie and Connecticut Railroad, which connects Silvernails Bridge, on the Hartford and Connecticut Western Railroad, on the east, with Campbell Hall, on the west. This connection will insure, via the Poughkeepsie Bridge, in a few days, the passage of coal trains from Pennsylvania direct to Hartford and the New-England States.
Mrs. Annie Hausen left her home at Westavenue and South-street, Wallabout Market, Brooklyn, yesterday, after writing a note to her husband bidding him and her children good-bye.

The nineteenth annual Corinthian race of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club will be sailed to-day. It is open to yachts of the Atlantic, Beverly, Corinthian of Marblehead, Corinthian of New-York, Dorchester, Eastern, Knickerbocker, Larchmont, New-Bedford, NewHaven, New-Rochelle, New-York, and Oyster Bay Yacht Clubs, although only a few of these clubs will be represented by yachts not belonging to the Seawanhaka Corinthian fleet.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 14.--Information received here by the Government states that mackerel have struck into North Bay in large numbers.

The Home Fire Insurance Company has discontinued the experiment of insuring registered mail packages, after a trial of six months. Losses were no factor in the decision to cease this form of insurance, for not a loss occurred. People had too much faith in the security of registered mail to care to insure it, and the business did not amount to enough to keep it up.

John Brower, dealer in hardware and cutlery at 91 Warren-street, made an assignment yesterday to Mortimer M. Meehan, giving preferences for $10,391,23, $10,000 of this sum being to Sarah L. Brower for money loaned, and the balance to Hagerty Brothers for value received.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 14.--The supposed defection of a number of the students of the Reformed Dutch Theological Seminary to the Episcopalians is still the principal topic of conversation in church and college circles.

BOSTON, Mass., June 14.--Frederick A. Eddy, aged forty-two years, of Somerville, was arrested to-day charged with embezzling $2,700 from the crockery firm of William C. Nicholson Co. He had worked for the firm election years, and up to two years ago had their entire confidence. In 1887 he began to drink freely, and his peculations date from that time.

BROCKVILLE, Ontario, June 14.--At 7 o'clock this morning the works of the Canada Powder Company, two miles east of this place, were blown up with terrific force. Fortunately the men had not gone to work, and consequently no one was killed.
The American Railway Master Mechanics' Association will meet in annual convention at the International Hotel, Niagara Falls, on Tuesday next.

Assistant District Attorney John U. Shorter, who permitted the Kings County Grand Jury to acquit John Smith, charged with robbing John H. Broach of over $500, and then had to stand by and see the next Grand Jury find a true bill against Smith, returned to Brooklyn yesterday.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, June 14.--One by one the facts concerning the illegal acquirement of Oklahoma lands by unscrupulous politicians and others who carried on their work while clothed with the garb of Government authority are coming to light. Some of those who violated the law have since been "frozen out," and are not averse to telling what they know. Their stories corroborate the statements telegraphed THE TIMES.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 14.--The work of organizing town or local branches of the Dairymens' Protective Union is proceeding at quite a rapid pace. Within a few days three of these local branches have been formed, at Holmesville, Marathon, and Hobart, respectively.

FORT WORTH, Texas, June 14.--A fatal duel took place at 4 o'clock this afternoon in Renostreet. The contestants were Clyde Muttox of Galnesville and Marshal Howard of Sanger, Texas. Mattox, who was a Marshal in South Oklahoma, was removed from office yesterday on a charge of neglect of duty and Howard was appointed to fill the vacancy.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., June 14.--The rain is pouring down this morning and has effectually stopped work of all kinds in this stricken city, where work should go ahead as rapidly as possible. Even the soldiers have sought the shelter of their tents, and the newspaper correspondents missed this morning with considerable relief the familiar "Have you a pass ?" from the guards at different places.

PARIS, June 14.--The striking cabmen did not resume work this-morning, as was expected. A meeting of the cabmen was held to-day, which was attended by M. Constans, Minister of the Interior, but no agreement concerning a settlement of the cabmen's grievances was reached. The strike will probably become general.

BOSTON, June 14.--The second week of the Eastern Circuit trotting meeting closed at Beacon Park this afternoon. The unfinished 2:31 class was attended with considerable interest, as Black Shan had been heavily backed at odds over the field, and he was still a favorite at 2 to 1 before the seventh heat to-day.
John J. Moroney and Charles McDonald were yesterday brought into court on the writs of habeas corpus which had been secured by their counsel.

A fire broke out at 6:20 o'clock last night in a tenement house at 83 Norfolk-street, and had it not been for the fact that most of the hundred tenants were airing themselves on the sidewalk the destruction of life would have been enormous. As it was, two persons perished in the flames--an old woman and an infant.

CHICAGO, June 14.--A dispatch from Springfield, Ill., says: "Judge William J. Allen of the United States District Court for Southern Illinois, who was brought home ill Wednesday from Chicago, where he had been holding court for Judge Gresham, is reported not so well. He is suffering from an obstruction of the bowels and his physicians consider his condition as extremely critical."

PROVIDENCE, June 14.--At 4:30 this afternoon Albert H. Olney, member of the firm of Olney Brothers, oil dealers of 7 South Water-street, this city, and 140 Congress-street, Boston, shot Martin Mullen just below the heart in the South Water-street store. Mullen died at the Rhode Island Hospital in the early evening. Mullen was about forty years old, and ten years ago was well known to the police here as a desperate character.

BERLIN, June 14.--The agreement negotiated by the Commissioners to the Samoan conference for the settlement of affairs in Samoa was signed by all the members of the conference this afternoon. The text will not be published until the agreement is signed by the American Government.

CHICAGO, June 14.--Alexander Sullivan was to-day restored to liberty by Judge Tuley. The release was the immediate result of Sullivan's application for a writ of habeas corpus. Bail was fixed at $20,000, and was promptly furnished by four well-known citizens, each of whom represented many times the total amount asked. Mr. Sullivan walked out of court after having been less than three days in custody.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 14.--Not less than six residences on different streets were entered by masked men between the hours of 11 and 1 o'clock last night, and the inmates of the places visited were badly frightened.

The Cramps of Philadelphia have announced to the Navy Department that the new cruiser Baltimore will be ready for trial in a few days. This announcement is to afford the department ample time to prepare the detail of officers to observe the test. The Cramps have long said that they would be ready for the speed test by July, and it now appears that they have not been at all over-sanguine.

The Board of Health yesterday gave a hearing to the residents near Sixteenth-street and Fifth-avenue, who complained that the Judge Building at the corner of those streets, where the Judge and Frank Leslie publications are printed, is a nuisance.

Detective Burleigh of the Ninth Police Precinct is investigating a series of burglaries in that district. OAK BLUFFS, Mass., June 15.--The favorable anticipations for the coming season recorded in THE TIMES continue to grow into realization. Never before in the history of this Summer resort have so many cottages been opened in June. A walk through the old camp ground around Oak Bluffs and across the breezy highlands reminds one more of midsummer than these delicious early June days.

CHICAGO, June 15.--James M. Gamble, a young man who owned nearly $1,000,000 worth of real estate and street railway property, was found dead in his bed, in his room at the Palmer House, this afternoon. His face and chest were horribly burned by carbolic acid, which he had taken.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 15.--S. H. Webb of New-Westminster, B. C., is in town. He says he has information to the effect that England and the United States have come to an understanding, in accordance with which no seizures of British vessels will be made in Behring Sea this season.

A dazzling flash of lightning with a simultaneous roar of thunder at 4:45 yesterday afternoon, during the rain, threw two men to their knees in front of the Church of the Immaculate Conception, on Fourteenth-street, just east of Avenue A. When they had recovered sufficiently to look up they perceived that one of the rear supports of the little belfry like tower on the church had been knocked out by the lightning.

CHICAGO, June 15.--Father Dorney, the Stock Yards priest whom Sullivan and "Pat" Egan intrusted with their disclosures of the Pigott forgeries, is an intimate friend of Sullivan, and within a day or two has come to his defense in interviews.
PARIS, June 15.--The Senate has forwarded to the Public Prosecutor a report on the case of Gen. Boulanger. The Senate advises that proceedings be at once begun against Boulanger.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 15.--The nineteenth annual Caledonian class championship meeting for the Peace Cup was held on the athletic field this afternoon at 3 o'clock. About one thousand spectators gathered on the field to see the great running match between W.A. Dohm, '90, Princeton's champion, and T.P. Conneff of the Manhattan Athletic Club and amateur champion of America.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 15.--Lacrosse matches in both the National and Canadian Senior championship series were played to-day. In the former at Montreal and Montreal Club defeated the Sharocks by four games to three, and at Toronto the Ottawas defeated the Torontos by five games to one. In the latter, at Paris, the Athletics of St. Catharine's defeated the Brants of Paris by four games to two.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 15.--The Stamford Rod and Gun Club is the title of a new organization formed quite recently, chiefly by NewYork gentlemen having summer residences in Stamford and Noroton.

LENOX, June 15.--The numerous cottagers who have arrived are enjoying these bright June days. There was considerable rain during the early part of the week, but it has now cleared away, and the lawns and meadows never looked fresher and brighter than they do now. The cottagers seem to be vying with each other in taking care of their grounds.

Wakefield G. Frye of Maine, appointed Consul General of Halifax, held that position during the Arthur Administration and was succeeded by Mr. Phelan, the present Consul General. He was born in Maine, was a member of the Legislature, and is a man of prominence in his State. He is not related to Senator Frye.

PARIS, June 15.--In the Chamber of Deputies this evening M. Basly attempted to discuss the strike of the Paris cabmen. M. Constans, Minister of the Interior, objected to the present consideration of the matter and moved that the discussion be postponed until Monday. The motion was rejected by a vote of 282 to 242.

Fairie Knowe, the handsome country seat of Mrs. John M. Robinson, in Baltimore County, was the scene of much festivity during the middle of the week. On Wednesday was given a fete champetre, followed on the next evening by a dinner.

Steamers will begin running on the regular schedule to Glen Island next Wednesday. The steamship Saale of the North German Lloyd Line arrived in port late Friday night, after a trip which, but for one trying experience last Tuesday night, was uneventful. Tuesday evening closed in with the Saale surrounded by fog banks which succeeded each other in quick succession.

WASHINGTON, June 15.--Among the approaching marriages is that of Miss Ada M. Morgan, youngest daughter of Dr. James E. Morgan, to Dr. Richard I. Hill, which will take place June 19 at St. Aloysius's Church. Owing to the recent death of Dr. Morgan the wedding will be a quiet one.

At a meeting of the creditors of Cupples Hurd, publishers, of Boston, yesterday a committee reported, recommending that the firm go into insolvency with a view to determining the contingent liabilities. NEWBURG, N.Y., June 15.--The hardest storm for its duration that has happened in years occurred this afternoon. Rail fell in torrents and all the streets were flooded. Wind, thunder, and lightning accompanied the rain. Hailstones fell as large as walnuts over a section of the city, while in other parts there were none.

CHICAGO, June 15.--Miss Nadge Doree's suit against Mrs. Langtry was dismissed by the attorneys in Judge Clifford's court this morning, the statement being made that the suit was settled. Each of the contestants agreed to pay her share of the costs of the suit. Mrs. Langtry agreed to pay Miss Doree $200.

HARTFORD, June 15.--The seventh national convention of chiefs and Commissioners of Labor Statistics, which is to be held at the State Capital in this city, beginning Tuesday, June 25, will be attended by representatives of the labor bureaus in eighteen States.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 15.--The Board of Directors of the Mortgage Bank have finally approved the by-laws for the International and Mortgage Bank, and these have to-day been sent to the Government for its approval. Should the Government promptly ratify the bylaws the bank will open for business in August, but if there is delay the opening will be postponed until October.

PITTSBURG, June 15.--The one session of the Amalgamated Association to-day was a long one, and was confined entirely to the rail turners' scale. Last week this scale was brought up and was referred to a committee of delegates and rollers.

CHICAGO, June 15.--Bishop Keane of the Roman Catholic Church, rector of the new Catholic University at Washington, arrived in Chicago Thursday night from the East. He this morning left for Milwaukee, and will return to Washington in the early part of next week. On Nov. 13 the Washington University will be opened.

CHICAGO, June 15.--"Old Hutch" made a prediction at noon to-day that July wheat would reach 80 cents before the close at 1:15. It closed at 79 cents, and at one time reached 79 3/8 cents.

ALBANY, June 15.--The handsome granite and bronze monument erected at the grave of the late President Chester A. Arthur in Rural Cemetery here by some of his personal admirers was officially unveiled to-day, without ceremony, by the donors, who inspected it.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 15.--The outlook for the Newport season of 1889 is very promising. The cottagers are arriving much earlier than usual, every day witnessing the opening of new Summer residences and large quantities of baggage and many horses and carriages arriving on every boat from New-York. As far as nature is concerned Newport never looked lovelier than at the present time.
Mr. Aaron Vanderbilt, Superintendent of the Ward Line of steamers, was greatly pleased yesterday at the signing by Gov. Hill of the Naval Militia bill, of which Mr. Vanderbilt is the father.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 15.--Antonio Pierre, the champion catch-as-catch-can wrestler of the world, and Duncan C. Rose, the broadsword fighter, are in this city and will meet in a mixed wrestling match for a purse of $400 next Saturday evening.

A fashionable noon wedding took place in the First Methodist Church Thursday, the contracting parties standing beneath a bell composed of marguerites. Little girls in Games boroughs strewed flowers along the aisle as the bride proceeded to the pulpit.

It is the first break that has occurred in the famous Presidents' agreement, and it will probably disrupt the Inter-State Railway Association.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 15.--A statement was published here that a large number of sailors of the man-of-war Vandalia, wrecked at Samoa, was in the city without money, and living on the charity of their friends.
LONDON, June 15.--The throb of the war drum is again awakening an echo in Europe--that is, the newspapers say it is, which seems pretty much the same thing.
Chief Judge Sedgwick of the Superior Court yesterday decided that John T. Lockman, one of the lawyers who was arrested on a charge of libeling Register Slevin, must be discharged from custody.
ST. LOUIS, June 15.--In Justice Spaulding's court to-day it was decided that a gambler is entitled to the possession of his chips, layout, and other paraphernalia captured in the raid of a faro game.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 15.--The Legislature has appropriated $220,000 for the support of the National Guard system of the State during the current two years. The appropriation in 1887 was $218,000 in round numbers. The average expenditure for the past ten years will considerably exceed $100,000 annually.

The Liederkranz Society held its annual Summernight's festival last evening at Washington Park. The grounds were brilliantly illuminated wlth thousands of Chinese lanterns, colored lamps, and calcium lights, that threw all the colors of the rainbow upon the fountains.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15.--A brutal murder was committed in this city this afternoon. George McCann, aged about thirty years, a rough character, killed his wife, Maggie, five years younger, by chopping her head in a horrible manner with a hatchet.

A "submarine bridge" his proposed between Elsinore and Helsingborg, to be incased in a double tube, having the outer skin iron and the inner one steel, the space between the shells being filled with concrete. It is proposed submerging this bridge sufficiently to allow ships to pass over it.

BELMAR, N.J., June 15.--The approaching season promises to be an unusually profitable one for this place. Many of the cottages are now occupied and the boarding houses are rapidly filling up. The Hotel Columbia will soon open its doors for the Summer.

PARIS, June 15.--The cab drivers and the cab proprietors have fallen out over a division of the exhibition spoils, and a cab famine, so to speak, of alarming proportions is threatened. Paris without cabs is like a locomotive without coal: it can't move. To say nothing of the ordinary public demand, nobody is likely to go to the exhibition, the seeing of which is alone sufficient to tire out a bicyclist.

The Jersey City Baseball Club will be transferred to some other city, or the best of the team will be sold and a cheap nine will be engaged. The lack of patronage and the refusal of the authorities to allow the team to play on Sunday are the assigned causes.

CHICAGO, June 16.--The last week has been one of the most prosperous the managers of the Chicago playhouses have enjoyed this season. One new production has been seen, and the old ones have had an exceptional run of good business.
BOSTON, June 16.--Mr. E.H. Moore of Melrose, the well-known dog fancier, has within a few days lost three of his famous prize mastiffs. The first to die was the noted champion, Minting.

LONDON, June 17.--The Inman Line steamship City of Chester, Capt. Bond, from New-York, June 8, was signaled off Brow Head at 2:40 A.M. to-day. The Steamship Columbia (Br.,) Capt. Garrick, from New-York, June 1, for Avonmouth passed Brow Head June 15.

Bishop Littlejohn of Long Island yesterday at Garden City ordained William Wiley and Arthur Stanley Brown to the priesthood. Both, as Deacons, have been serving parishes. Mr. Mr. Wiley will continue at St. Paul's, Patchegue, and Mr. Brown at Zion Church, at Little Neck.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., June 16.--A terrific rain and hail storm occured in the Mohawk Valley this afternoon. Small wash outs are reported at various points along the West Shore Railroad. Tanks in residences were overflowed, gardens ruined, and hop yards damaged.

Case, the veteran Secretary of the Brooklyn Young Republican Club, the only man, in fact, who has ever held that office, resigned a few days ago, and the local politicians ascribe his actions to dissatisfaction.
