Next week will be Commencement Week at Bowdoin College, Brunswick, Me. The baccalaureate sermon will be delivered by President William De Witt Hyde on Sunday afternoon. Class Day exercises occur on Tuesday.

CHICAGO, June 16.--The Times prints this morning another statement made by Frank Woodruff concerning the murder of Dr. Cronin, which Woodruff says is the only true and full story he has told. Many details which would make interesting reading are missing, but it is understood that they are purposely withheld for the time being.

ZANZIBAR, June 16.--Letters received here from Ujiji, dated March 10, say that Stanley net Tippoo Tib and sent a number of sick followers back with him by way of the Congo. Atanley intended coming to the east coast with Emin Pasha, Tippoo Tib would arrive at Zanzibar in July.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 16.--Jerome Fallette, a young man who has been in jail at Kingston, N.Y., for a week on a charge of forery, had been brought to New-Jersey on extradition papers, and was in jail here last night. His brother, H.A. Fallette, was put in jail Saturday.
BOSTON, June 16.--A builder has been issued to the effect that all hope has been abandoned in the case of John Gilbert, and that the veteran actor is dying.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 16.--John s. Gerber, the proprietor of the Mackey Grove Creamery, near Boone, was arrested yesterday for forgery. He had procured a number of blank bills of lading from the Chicago and North western freight office.

The chief topic of interest among horsemen and the many hundreds who visited the race tracks at Coney Island yesterday was the arrival of Terra Cotta, the crack handicap horse of the Chicago Stable, who came here in charge of the stable's chief jockey, Jimmy McLaughlin, and with as many attendants as a traveling Prince would have.

Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon dedicated the new Roman Catholic Church of St. James, at Seatauket, L.I. Spincia, at his country seat, Crane's Neck.

LONDON, June 17.--The Berlin correspondent of the News telegraphs: "The German Foreign Office has been informed that the Czar will come to Berlin, but the date of his arrival has not yet been fixed."

LONDON, June 3.--Passengers who had the good fortune to come over on recent steamers have cause to congratulate themselves on the delightful weather prevailing the entire passage and the corresponding fast time made by even the slow ships--at least those so called in these days of ocean greyhounds.

James McLaughlin, the famous jockey, succeeded in reducing to 117 pounds at St. Louis. He makes fiesh very rapidly, however, and yesterday weighed 120 pounds. He says he is in perfect health, a little too good to enable him to reduce successfully.

"Men will desire military fame," said Gibbon, "so long as the world pays higher honor to its destroyers than to its benefactors." The hero of the work before us figured in both capacities, and in both he achieved high distinction. The words of the title, "soldier and civil engineer," sum up his entire history.

Two Italians--Virgillio Guardino of 161 Mott-street and Antonio Blario of 39 Mulberrystreet--lnflamed by indulgence in stale beer, engaged in a fight in the yard of the big tenement house at 39 Mulberry-street yesterday.

Mlle. Cl menceau, now Mme. Jacquemaire, who was married yesterday at the Mairie in the Pantheon district in Paris, is the pretty daughter of a well-known Republican Deputy and journalist--the Minister maker of France.

PITTSBURG, June 16.--A skiff containing two young couples capsized in the Ohio River from the swells of a passing steamer this afternoon. Lizzle Cortes, aged seventeen years, was drowned, but the others were rescued. Nannie Long, the other young lady, was unconscious when taken from the water, but was revived and will recover.
I see it stated that there is a "movement" in Paris to adopt colored evening coats and knee breeches.

Charles Michel, fourteen years old, a son of Frederick Michel, the Treasurer of the North Hudson County Railway Company, mysteriously disappeared from Hoboken last Tuesday, and has not been heard of since.

TRENTON, N.J., June 16.--Peter Yager and Samuel E. Hankison, two liquor men, announce their intention to bring suits against Joseph B. Richardson of the trenton Law and Order League for damages in the sums of $5,000 and $10,000, respectively, growing out of their arrest and imprisonment last Summer by Mr. Richardson under proceedings which have just been declared illegal by the Supreme Court.

NASHVILLE, Brown County, Ind., June 16.--A rickety cart of antique pattern, hitched to two steers and driven by a sleepy-looking, barefoot man moved out of Columbus, Bartholomew County, a few afternoons ago, directed toward the south. By following this outfit one might reach the wild territory known as Brown County, at once the most interesting and distinctive...

The United States steam corvette Kearsarge left the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday morning shortly after 10 o'clock for her voyage to Hayti. The blue swallow-tail pennant of Rear Admiral Gherardi floated from the mizzenmast head, and at the rate of some eight knots an hour the famous corvette slowly made her way down the harbor, through the Narrows, and out to sea.
UTICA, N.Y., June 16.--The annual meeting of the New-York State League of Co-operative savings and Building Loan Associations will be held at the Butterfield House on Wednesday and Thursday next.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 16.--Capt. Hamilton Murrell, the heroic saver of the passengers of the Danmark, spent the day in this city as the guest of Mr. Charler Evans of the Seaside House.

At the Territorial convention of women held in Cheyenne, Wyoming, Saturday, a resolution was adopted requesting the coming Constitutional Con vention to incorporate a woman's suffrage plank in the Constitution.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 16.--At 7 o'clock this morning an Erie Railroad milk train, westward bound, when at Seeley's road crossing just east of Greycourt station, struck a milk wagon containing Dennis Kane, a single man, aged forty years, and Lucas S. Stead, a boy twelve years old, and killed them instantly.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 16.--There promises to be a decidedly warm time when the Democratic Central Committee meets at Dayton on the 20th inst, in adjourned session. The committee will, without doubt, change the date of holding the State Convention from Aug. 26 to July, but this will cause little, if any, trouble.

The investigations into the ice cream poisoning at Glastonbury, at St. Luke's church festival, on the evening of the 16th of May, show that it was neither load poisoning nor the vanilla flavoring that caused the trouble.

As a result of the racing at Jerome Park, owners of thoroughbreds are richer by $126,010 than they were before the meeting began. That sum was divided among fifty-four owners, which, singularly enough, is just the same number as the winning owners at the Brooklyn' meeting. The nature of the steamer freight business between Boston and New-York is peculiar, differing almost entirely from that between any other two cities. This business in all its parts belongs entirely to Boston. Boston buys from NewYork, New-York seldom from Boston.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 16.--The procession yesterday in honor of Grand Duke Paul alexandrovitch and his fianc e, Princess Alexandra of Greece, was as elaborate as at the coronation of the Czar in Moscow. The whole city was in high holiday and was splendidly decorated, and in the evening was illuminated.

PARIS, June 16.--The Temps says that Germany is treating with Belgium in regard to the buying of a cable from Ostend to Portland, Me., in order to render these countries independent of the English cable companies.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 16.--The death has occurred at Monticello. Sullivan County, of William H. Burnham, eldest son of Dr. Beekman T. Burnham of New-York City.

The Ladies' Yacht Club of Lake Champlain will unite with the Lake Champlain Yacht Club in giving a grand ball in July. The annual meeting of the Ladies' Club was held recently, and the following officers were elected: President--Mrs. Holt; Vice President--Mrs. Samuel Drew; Secretary-- Mrs. Joseph Auld; Treasurer--Miss L.E. Anderson.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 16.--Barnes Hall, the splendid home of the Cornell Christian Association, and the gift of the late A.S. Barnes, the New-York publisher, was dedicated this evening in the presence of 1,200 Cornellians and friends.
George A. Boyd, a medical student, addressed the Manhattan Single-Tax Club last evening at its rooms, 36 Clinton-place, on "the prevention of consumption and its relation to the single tax."
HARTFORD, June 16.--Lawyer E.D. Robbins of this city is the custodian of one of the rarest of colonial relics.

Both have just left prison, the one by compromiss, the other by flight; and as they are of extremely aristocratic appearance and endowned...

TRENTON, N.J., June 16.--Col. Morris R. Hamilton, the New-Jersey State Librarian, a member of the class of '39 of Princeton College, reports that he has received fourteen acceptances of the invitation to members of that class to join in a semi-centennial reunion during Commencement at Princeton this week.

Officer Charles Francis, who has kept order in the Saturday, Sunday, and race-day strings of vehicles at Macomb's Dam and Barry's Hill for unnumbered seasons, and who has a bowing acquaintance with every owner of good horses in the city, had a lively time yesterday afternoon arresting Herman Fuelner for reckless driving. Fuelner is a German market gardener whose farm is in Morrisania.

--A new series of small volumes, announced by the Putnams and to be called "Literary Gems," will have for its earlier issues; Poe's "Gold Bug," John Brown's "Rab and His Friends," Goldsmith's "Goodnatured Man," Drake's "Culprit Fay," G. W. Curtis's "Our Best Society," and Matthew Arnold's "Sweetness and Light."

Outdoor pleasures were so attractive yesterday that all the breathing places of the metropolis were crowded with people seaking to enjoy the clear atmosphere and the balmyouth breeze that blew all day long.
LONDON, June 10.--During the past week discount was quoted at 1 to and the tendency was downward. Gold continues to flow into the Bank of England.

The Bank Clerks' Athletic Association, comprised of the officials connected with prominent moneyed institutions of Philadelphia, numbers 200 members. The initiation fee is $5 and the monthly dues are 25 cents. The President is Mr. Kenton Warne of the First National Bank; Vice President--Mr. Kling of the Guarantee Trust; Secretary--Mr. J. Foster Graham of the Mechanics' National Bank.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., June 16.--Sunday quiet reigned here to-day, and instead of the booming of dynamite the sound of sacred hymns was heard.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 16.--A few weeks ago a farmer named Heins, living on a farm in what is known as the Peru Bottoms, in Dubuque County, was assailed while walking in the woods and beaten nearly to death. The description given of his assailant was unlike that of any person ever before seen in that vicinity.

One beauty of the new TIMES Building which every journalist and printer will appreciate is that it is as convenient interioly as it is handsome outside. Usually a newspaper building crowds the newspaper workers into holes and corners so that space may be let for business offices. THE TIMES takes good care of its own people first.

BASTROP, Texas, June 16.--Sheriff White of Austin and deputies returned from the scene of the Cedar Creek massacre yesterday. The loss of life was greater than at first stated. Six men are already dead and four more are dying. Three others of the wounded have some chance of recovery. This will make four white men and six negroes killed.

When Gen. Andrew Jackson visited Concord, N.H., after his Presidential term had expired he was entertained at Cass's Hotel, at that time the leading hotel of the State.

LONDON, June 16.--Cardinal Manning to-day received into the Roman Catholic Church the Rev. Mr. Townsend, recently principal of the Oxford Mission at Calcutta, also six former clergy men of the Angilcan Church.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 16.--Gov. Robert Taylor and staff and the legislative committee from Tennessee, with about forty prominent citizens of that State, arrived here to-day and were received with military honors.

The question of the identification of John J. Moroney, who, with Charles J. McDonald, is now in the Tombs under suspicion of having had a share in the Cronin murder, will probably be settled this morning. M. Carnot gave away 1,200 to charities during his tour through the north. He has brought back with him a wagon load of bouquets to show to his wife, and had them stowed in moist straw in the luggage van.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 16.--Dr. Patton, President of the college, delivered his first baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class today. His text was II. Corinthians, iv., 18: " For the things that are seen are temporal, but the things that are unseen are eternal."
Steamship Guyandotte, Kelly, Newport News and Norfolk, with mase, and passengers to Old Dominion Steamship Company.
The Rev. R. Heber Newton preached his last sermon this season in All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday, and not withstanding the excessive heat a large congregation listened to him.

After the splendor of his lodging at St. Petersburg, the Shah will doubtless turn up his Persian nose at the modest house that is being prepared for his reception by the French Government in the Rue Copernici.

Considerable sensation has been caused all over Spain by the reported death of the famous brigand known as Blzco del Borge. In the minds of the Andalusian peasants Bizco del Borge was another Fra Diavclo, and there are countless folk songs celebrating his prowess and his amours.

The brief telegram sent back from Mora by Capt. GEORGE W.H. STOUCH, Third Infantry, who had been hurried by Gen. RUGGER from Fort Shelling with three companies of that regiment, shows that the first report of the Mille Lacs uprising was greatly exaggerated.

PARIS, June 1.--Never was a score more talked of than the"Esclarmonde" of M. Massenet. Although quite forty, the composer is always spoken of as a young master, and each new effort is expected to be almost a revelation. The first idea of the subject belonged, I am told, to M. Grammont, and it was put in verse and shape by M. Blau.

PARIS, June 16.--The strike of the cabmen continues. Some of the men resutled work today, but the great body of strikers persist in their demands. A committee of cabmen waited upon M. Constans, the Minister of the Interior, to-day, but the interview was without result. The Minister informed the committee that all matters relating to the strike were being attended to by the municipal authorities.

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., June 16.--John Gilman, a civil engineer of Worcester, has a surveying party at work on a plan for a "short cut" railraod from Worcester to Hartford that is calculated to lesson the time between Boston and the Poughkeepsie Bridge. They started at Sturbridge, Mass., and are...
Hartford is honored by the fact that its theological seminary is the first institution of the kind to admit women to its privileges.

Some of the occupants of the tenement house at 1,893 Second-avenue informed the police of the East Eighty-eighth-street station yesterday that there were two children in the apartments of Charles Gallagher, a laborer, who were sick and neglected.

On the 18th of last month, the positions, peculiarities, and dissimilarities of Mercury and Uranus, two primary planets, were described in these columns, and on account of their aspects, as seen through the telescopes at Mount Hamilton on the occasion of the meeting of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific, May 25, may be of further interest.
A malefactor named Silvy has just been condemned to death at Aix for a double crime. He had violated and then murdered his sisterin-law during the absence of her husband in Marseilles.

WASHINGTON, June 16.--That large concourse of worthy Republicans that has been waiting patiently about the Ebbitt House since the inauguration of Harrison in the hope that they would be rewarded for labor performed in North Carolina are about ready to give up their task as a useless one or to seek outside of the State for "influence" to support their pretensions.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16.--The prohibition campaign in this section, which began about three months ago and was for a time quite spirited, but flattend out very much toward the end, practically closed last night all over the State. The work to be done to-morrow will be simply the distribution of tickets and little matters of detail to be attended to at the last minute.

Mr. Jacob Ruis, who has recently been giving lectures concerning the homes and manner of life of the poorest of the city inhabitants, has been taking a hunt with the camera among the tenements and stale beer resorts of the city with flashlight apparatus. It is sometimes dangerous work, as the lodgers in the dingy rooms seldom care to be photographed, and are apt to...

George H. Coggswell, a driver in the employ of the Brooklyn Sugar Refinery, and Henry Mahler, receiving teller, in the employ of Austin, Nichols Co., the wholesale grocers at 55 Hudson-street, were arrested on Saturday, charged with having for three years past stolen several hundred barrels of sugar from the latter firm.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 16.--The woman who committed suicide at Niagara Falls Friday, and whose body was recovered at Drummondville the following day, was Mrs. Fred Stonfield of Buffalo. The body was identified by her son-inlaw Saturday and brought to this city last evening. She was suffering from mental disorder, which her friends did not consider serious.

While car 70 of the Grand-street Crosstown Line was passing 246 Grand-street yesterday morning, the driver, George Miller, noticed one of the wires of the Brush Electric Light Company strung across the street hanging...

ST. LOUIS, June 17.--Additional advices about the disaster in Kansas from wind and rain storms are that Uniontown, about fifteen miles west of Fort Scott, on the Wichita and Western Railway, was almost swept away, and that two women and four children were drowned.

John Fitzpatrick, alias "Liverpool Jack," was arraigned before Judge Cowing in General Sessions yesterday to plead to two indictments for kidnapping David Kennedy and Harry Toole. His counsel, William F. Howe, said that his client had been required to give bail to the amount of $9,000--$4,000 in the case of James Moran and $5,000 in the matter of the two recent indictments.

The ladies of the Flower Mission of All Saints' Church of Harlem gave a Japanese tea last evening at the handsome residence of their President, Mrs. Charles Loughran, at 2 West One Hundred and Twenty-ninth-street, for the purpose of helping along the building fund of the church.
Ex-Assemblyman Edward A. Darragh of Far Rockaway was arrested yesterday on a charge of grand larceny in having removed some lumber from the site of the Wave Crest Hotel, ...

LONG BRANCH, N.Y., June 17.--The Rev. Dr. Inglehart of Newark delivered the baccalaureate sermon before the graduating class of the high school yesterday morning at St. Luke's Methodist Episcopal Church.

Though Mr. WILLIAM WALTER PHELPS is very properly reticent concerning the result of his mission to Berlin, enough has transpired to indicate that Germany has yielded the chief points in dispute, and that the position taken by the State Department under Mr. BAYARD has been successfull maintained by the State Department under Mr. BLAINE.

Before Surrogate Ransom yesterday was held the first hearing in the contest over the will of Miss M. Louisa Comstock, who up to 1885 kept a fashionable school for young ladies. In her will Miss Comstock paid very little attention to her relatives.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 17.--The Evening Post of to-day states that $1,000,000 has been subscribed for the proposed cable between Honolulu and San Francisco, and that the work of laying the cable will be commenced within eighteen months.
CHICAGO, June 17.--The action of the Chicago and Alton in giving notices of withdrawal from the Inter-State Commercial Railway Association is the all-absorbing theme in railroad circles.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., June 17.--An increased force was at work in the ruins to-day and new men are coming in. Gen. Hastings says about 5,500 men are at work. The dynamite is making a noticeable impression on the debris above the stone bridge. The four Philadelphia fire engines arrived last night and to-day are pumping out ponds and foundations.

MADRID, June 17.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day Senor Becerra, Minister of the Colonies, read the Cuban budget. The revenues and expenditures balanced at $25,000,000. The Minister asked authority to issue a Spanish guaranteed loan of $175,000,000 and to convert the Cuban debts.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 17.--The sad expressions which lingered on the faces of Wells College students to-day when the rain poured in torrents upon them were speedily dissipated by the bright sun which shone outlate in the afternoon. The cornerstone of the new college building was to be dedicated. The burning of the college buildings last Fall left the Wells ...

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 17.--Last Thursday two children of Edward Bachus, a farmer of Rosier, Mo., a small village fifty miles south of Kansas City on the Kansas line, went to a creek about a mile from home to fish.
NEWARK, N.J., June 17.--The pastoral relation existing between the Rev. Joseph W. Porter and the Woodside Presbyterian Church was dissolved by the Newark Presbytery to-day.

NYACK, June 17.--A liquor case of much interest is on trial to-day at Suffern. The defendant is William F. Sinell, who was indicted by the last Rockland County Grand Jury for selling without a license.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 17.--The Commencement exercises at Rutgers College were continued to-day. It was Class Day and therefore Ladies' Day. Girls were everywhere. At the Class Day exercises in Kirkpatrick Chapel in the afternoon they applauded and smiled their appreciation to the students, for whom they were wearing bits of vari-colored ribbon.

BERLIN, June 17.--The Post says that persons familiar with the political situation do not share in the pessimistic views generally entertained regarding a probable tension between Russia and Germany in the event of the Czar's returning Emperor William's visit anywhere in Germany except Berlin.

A quorum of the Executive Committee of the Conemaugh Valley Relief Fund was not present in the Governor's Room yesterday afternoon. Treasurer J. Edward Simmons informally reported that the relief fund in his hands had reached $464,379.85, and he had already honored a draft by Gov. Beaver for $50,000.

Before starting for Cleveland last night Short Stop Ward, President of the Ball Players' Brotherhood, said that a conference in the West will be held shortly between committees representing the Brotherhood and the League.
There was a whirl in wheat yesterday, and for an hour or two great excitement prevailed in the Produce Exchange.

The East River Yacht Club, an organization made up of boat owners in Williamsburg, Greenpoint, and Astoria, held its tenth annual regatta on Long Island Sound yesterday on a twenty-mile course from Hunt's Dock to Sands Point Buoy and return.

BOSTON, June 17.--Two games were scheduled for Bunker Hill Day, and the Bostons won one and lost one. The morning game was won by superior batting on the part of Washington. The game was played during a shower. The attendance was the smallest of the season. Boston could do nothing with Keefe, who struck out Brouthers on three pitched balls.
A movement has been set on foot by a number of conspicuous Hudson County Democrats to nominate Edward F.C. Young, the President of the First National Bank of Jersey City, for Governor of New-Jersey.

The shipments of flour, grain, and provisions from Chicago to the seaboard last week aggregated 16,097 tons, against 17,463 for the preceding week, a decrease of 1,366 tons, and against 12,390 for the corresponding week last year, an increase of 3,707 tons. The Vanderbilt lines carried 50.6 per cent. of the business, the Pennsylvania lines 16.7 per cent., the Chicago and Grand Trunk 18.2 per cent., and the Baltimore and Ohio 14.5 per cent.

LONDON, June 17.--In the House of Commons to-day Mr. William Henry Smith, the Government leader, announced that the Government had decided to pospone further proceedings in relation to the bill to put into effect the Sugar Bounties Convention.

It was a jolly day yesterday for some two thousand or more of the girls and women of the First and abutting Wards, for the free bath at the Battery was opened and they were awarded its privileges. Five o'clock in the morning was the opening hour.

Yesterday's stock market was very weak throughout all the morning dealings. The withdrawal of the Chicago and Alton from the new Inter-State Railway Association induced a free selling movement, and there were on all sides fears that the recently-born bull market was done for.

It was Tennessee day at Mr. Easton's sale paddocks at Hunt's Point, yesterday, where eighty-seven yearlings bred at the Belle Meade Farm of Gen. Jackson, the Cliff Lawn Farm of W.B. Cheatham, and the Fairview Farm of Charles Reed ware disposed of at auction by William Easton, manager of the sale paddocks. The sale attracted some two hundred horsemen to the big ampitheatre where the animals were shown and sold.

There was an almost constant downpour of rain at Brighton Beach yesterday, where six races were run over a track deep in mud and very sloppy. A good crowd saw the racing and the bookmakers kept all the money played on the favorites except in the last race, which King Crab won as he pleased, all the thirteen horses entered being scratched except he and Carnegie and Battersby.

A meeting of the excutive officers of the American, Coney Island, Brooklyn, and NewYork Jockey Clubs, and the Monmouth Park Association was held last evening at the offices of the latter organization.

Chickering Hall contained a large audience last evening on the occasion of exercises in prize speaking by members from the Sophomore, Junior, and Senior Classes of the College of the City of New-York.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 17.--A heavy rainstorm has prevailed here for the past thirty six hours, accompanied a portion of the time by a gale of wind. Reports from the interior of the State indicate that the storm has done more or less damage in several localities.
Another plainly directed letter has been returned to its writer after being in the hands of the Post Office people for twelve days.
TOLEDO, Ohio, June 17.--Judges Gresham and Jackson were on the bench of the United States Circuit Court here to-day in the Wabash Railway case.
The fireworks exhibition, "The Last Days of Pompeii," will be produced in Pain's Amphitheatre at Manhattan Beach for the first time to-night.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 17.--Gen. J. Madison Drake of this city, heretofore a strong Republican, has deserted that party and intends to come out now as a pronounced tariff-reform Democrat. He will begin the publication of a Democratic daily newspaper to Elizabeth, and expects to issue the first number of it by Aug. 1.
LONDON, June 18.--The Times says that the letters received at Zanzibar from Ujiji stated that Stanley intended, in company with Emin Pasha, to force his way through Masailand to Mombasa.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 17.--The Commencement exercises of Cornell University begin to-morrow. The Glee Club's concert Saturday evening, the baccalaureate sermon yesterday by Dr. Green of New-York, and the dedication last evening of the sixty-thousand-dollar building given by the late A.S. Barnes of New-York ...

The end of the case so far as John J. Moroney and Charles McDonald, arrested on suspicion of being implicated in the murder of Dr. Cronin, are concerned, came yesterday morning, when the three men sent here by the Chicago authorities to identify the suspects failed absolutely to do so.

PITTSBURG, June 17.--Pennsylvania votes on the prohibition amendment to-morrow, and it is safe to say that the "wets" will win by a handsome majority. The newspapers of the State are practically unanimous in the opinion that the amendment will be defeated by from 25,000 to 60,000. As indicative of the feeling of the sporting fraternity, John Quinn, a well-known Pittsburg gambler, to-day offered to ...

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 17.--Holton's Mill, near Newaygo, was burned Saturday morning. Adjoining it was a large boarding house, where the employes lodged. Alonzo Delacey and Ole McLenny perished in the flames, and another man, in jumping from a window, received probably fatal injuries.
CHICAGO, June 17.--Another fatal accident occurred this evening in one of the power houses of the Yerkes cable-car system.

Reform in politics had a hearty indorsement at the Federal Club, in Madison-avenue, last evening, on the occasion of a reception to Assemblyman Ernest H. Crosby. The evident object of the organization was not only to compliment the young Assemblyman, but to denounce men of the David B. Hill stamp.

Judge Andrews, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday denied the motion of Col. Edward Gebhard, on behalf of Francis E.S. Wolf, to set aside the judgment entered in the Supreme Court in 1885 in favor of James Hepenstall, Jr., against James R. Keene.
In Long Island City diphtheria is increasing, and no effort has been made by the local authorities to check the spread of the disease.

Gen. Russell A. Alger and Thomas C. Platt start on their Alaskan trip this week. The rumor that Mr. Platt is contemplating an extension of the United States Express to Sitka has not been verified, although it is manifest that Gen. Alger expects to make a political connection of some sort by the trip.

PARIS, June 17.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day Vice Admiral de Dompierre d'Hornoy declared that the men of war now possessed by France were of an antiquated type and ought to be replaced by new vessels which would equal in number and strength the united fleets of Germany and Italy.
Locusts are increasing in numbers and spreading over Long Island. So far no damage has been done to the crops. The locusts confine their depredations to the scrub oaks.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17.--Capt. Hamilton Murrell of the steamship Missouri, which last April brought ashore the foundered Danmark's passengers, was presented this morning by George W. Childs with a gold medal in commemoration of his services. The medal is considerably larger than a silver dollar.

Once more the Suburban is to be run over a muddy and holding track. Once more the great race will probably go to some horse other than the favorites of a week past, Badge and Raceland, and once more the backers of short horses will probably be made happy, while those who pin their faith to the favorites will be made disconsolate.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 17.--Visiting Alumni of Rochester University began to arrive to-day, and the brilliancy of the gathering, as well as the interesting programme, bid fair to make this a memorable Commencement.

LONDON, June 17.--The Queenstown regatta was held to-day. The yachts Valkyrie, Irex, Deerhound, and Yarana were among the contestants.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 17.--The races of the third annual regatta of the New-England Amateur Rowing Association were rowed in the rain at Lake Quinsigamond this afternoon. The rain kept people away, and only about one thousand persons witnessed the contests. Referee Thomas J. The United States steam corvette Quinnebaug arrived in this port yesterday at 9 A.M., after an absence from the United States of nearly eight years. The last point of land left on the homeward run was the Madeiras, the corvette steaming out of Funchal on the evening of May 18.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 17.--"I do not expect any considerable advance in the price of iron for six months," said Mr. Thomas Seddon, President of the Sloss Iron and Steel Company.
CHICAGO, June 17.--Martin Burke was arrested at Winnipeg last night for complicity in the Cronin murder.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 17.--Reginald Foster of New-York, Yale '9l, was arrested tonight, charged with defrauding a boarding house keeper. Foster ran up a bill of $134 and is unable to settle.
It was generally rumored about town yesterday that Rose Coghlan, the popular actress, had separated from her husband, Mr. Clinton J. Edgerly, to whom she was married some years ago.
OMAHA, Neb., June 17.--The Bee prints reports on the condition of the crops, from special cor respondents throughout the State.

David May, who embezzled about $4,000 from his employers, Amos Dotterer Son, brickmakers of Point Breeze, Penn., was taken before Judge Desnoyers at Montreal yesterday.

A larger than ordinary attendance of the members of the Republican Club at its regular monthly meeting last night was occasioned by the announcement that Jay Gould's former partner, Washington E. Connor, was to be elected a member.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y, June 17.--At Norwich yesterday afternoon, during the prevalence of a heavy electric storm, accompanied by rain and hall, a cyclone struck and devastated the large and handsome cemetery just south of the village, which contains most of the dead of the town.

Inspector Hovell of Surveyor Beattle's staff while overhauling a lot of unclaimed steerage baggage from the Hamburg-American steamship Gellert yesterday came across a large chest with a false bottom.

KINGSTON, Ontario, June 17.--The following letter was found in a bottle near Gananoque: "Captain of the Bavaria; help, the ship is sinking; all have been washed overboard but me. I expect my turn will come next. About 100 yards off Galoup Island, Lake Ontario."
WASHINGTON, June 17.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased $142,000 four and a half per cent. bonds at 106 7/8 and $200 fours at 127.

MOLINE, Ill., June 17.--The ordination of twenty-three young men at the session of the Augustana Synod here brought together an immense audience in the church.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17.--The most interesting day of Commencement Week at Princeton is Class Day, and that of 1889 has not proved an exception to the rule. The exercises of the day were begun in the First Presbyterian Church this morning at 10:30 o'clock. The master of ceremonies was W. James George of Ohio, who has played centre rush on the Princeton football team for three years.

BOSTON, June 17.--John Gilbert died at 1 o'clock this afternoon at the home of his sister, Mrs. Pierce, at 45 Rutland-street. His wife, sisters, and other relatives were with him at his bedside as he quietly passed away.
BOSTON, June 17.--"Bunker Hill" day was celebrated in the Charlestown district to-day by a carnival parade in the forenoon and a military and civic parade in the afternoon.

PORTLAND, Oregon, June 17.--The annual elections of the Oregon and Transcontinental, and Oregon Railway and Navigation Companies were held to-day. Mr. Villard carried the former, and a compromise was effected whereby the latter system will be managed as part of the Union Pacific system, the Northern Pacific ...

In the opinion of Mayor Grant the claim of Wilkinson, the detective, for services rendered under the employment of District Attorney Fellows, in the case of Thomas B. Kerr, is not against the county, but against the State, and should have been made to the State in the first instance. He has therefore returned to Controller Myers, without his signature, the warrant for the money--about $5,000.
Pilot Boat 18, the James Stafford, arrived at Stapleton, S.I., early yesterday morning, having completed the quickest cruise on record.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 17.--In the Court of General Sessions to-day, Judge Kershaw presiding, the Grand Jury returned a true bill against Dr. T.B. McDow for the murder of Capt. F.W. Dawson in March last. McDow was arraigned and pleaded not guilty.
UTICA, N.Y., June 17.--The Commencement at Madison University, Hamilton, N.Y., began yesterday, with the baccalaureate sermon by President E. Dodge.

The Newark Bay Yacht Club's second annual sweepstakes regatta was sailed yesterday afternoon in Newark Bay, opposite Bayonne. Owing to the storm which broke about 3:30 o'clock several of the boats were disabled, while others withdrew from the race. An almost dead calm followed, and the winners drifted home with the tide. Under the provisions of the Laws of 1882, Chapter 410, the Board of Fire Commissioners yesterday promulgated a general order governing the handling, transportation, storage, sale, and use of all manner of explosives, in this city, the regulations to go into effect July 1. Violations of the regulations are punishable as felonies, by fine or imprisonment.

It has been an unpleasant revelation to a good many Republicans that on the return of their party to power the office-hunger was stronger than they had ever imagined and even stronger than they had found it in their opponents.

The licenses of most of the liquor dealers in Jersey City expire on July 1, and some excitement has been created by the announcement that the Liquor Dealers' Association had insisted that renewals be given only to the members of the association, and that the Excise Committee had agreed to comply with the demands.

Whitney et al., respondents.--Argument resumed and concluded by William F. Cogswell for appellants, Martin W. Cooke for respondents.

Emigration Commissioners Stephenson, Starr, and Hurlbut have signed a call for a meeting to be held at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon at Castle Garden to consider the cases of detained immigrants.

WASHINGTON, June 17.--The President, Secretary of State Blaine, and Secretary of the Treasury Windom returned this morning from the third Presidential Sunday excursion down the Potomac River. Their report of the trip is extremely brief.
LONDON, June 17.--The Hamburg-American Line steamship Hammonia, Capt. Vogelgesang, sld. from Southampton for New-York to-day.

MONTICELLO, June 17.--It is only a question of time for any one who enjoys personal or intimate relations with Gov. Hill to become disgusted with his selfishness and political avarice. He is losing many friends here for no other reason than that he is regarded as a cold-blooded scheming politician, who is willing to sacrifice his best friends for the sake of gaining a little political profit or notoriety.

Judge Ingraham yesterday sustained the demurrer of the defendant in the suit of the Veteran Association of the Eleventh Regiment against Albert P. Stewart, who was Colonel of the regiment at the time of its disbandment. Col. ELIZABETH, N.J., June 17.--Judge McCormick had his attention called to-day to a curious case, wherein it is charged a woman is being boycotted by her neighbors because her testimony sent to State prison a man who she swore had attacked her.

The steamship Caroline Miller sailed from this port yesterday for Gonaives and other North Haytian ports. On board of her as passengers were Frank C. Elliot, the well-known South-street shipping agent, and James McCaldin, one of her owners.

ALBANY, June 17.--Smith Weed's was the only Normal School bill, and the additional appropriation for the Saratoga armory was the only one of the armory bills that met the Governor's approval to-day. The Governor's veto of the Capitol Appropriation bill met with much adverse criticism about the Capitol.

Morris Cahn, a waiter and a member of the Long Island Labor Union, was the plaintiff in a suit brought before Judge Clement, in the City Court of Brooklyn, yesterday, to recover $2,500 from Simon Weber, a restaurant keeper of Broadway, for false imprisonment.
The German bark Blucher, Capt. Hamer, arrived at this port yesterday, after a voyage of forty-nine days from Hamburg.

The schooner Edwin Janet of Nassau, Capt. Joseph Tedder, from Governors Harbor, which arrived at this port yesterday, reports that on May 31, in latitude 27 , longitude 76 , she encountered a heavy squall from south-southeast.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 17.--During a heavy thunderstorm this afternoon the spire of the Seaside Chapel, the Summer residents' church, in Chelsea-avenue, was struck by lightning and badly damaged.

BOSTON, June 17.--The New-York broker, Untermyer, acting as the authorized agent of the English syndicate, was in Boston recently and made a proposition to all the great Roxbury brewers, which, if accepted, will give the Englishmen possession.

A small band of mourners attended at Holy Trinity Church, in Forty-second-street, yesterday afternoon the funeral of Dr. Edward Mortimer Deey, who died at Limpley Stake, near Bath, England, on Jan. 3.

The trial of Arthur P. Carlin, Harry Dubois, and his wife Sarah, for conspiring with Charles Carlstrand to get money out of the Brooklyn Cross-town Railroad by means of an "accident" to Mrs. Dubois, was begun in the Sessions Court, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Albert Fink, Commissioner of the Trunk Line Association, has resigned his position, which gave him a salary of $25,000. PRINCETON, N.J., June 18.--To-day's exercises at Princeton began early. At 9:20 o'clock came the reading of theses in the Scientific School. Theses had been prepared by Isaac Nakagawa of Tokio, Japan, on "Comparison of the Structure of the Cortex of the Cerebrum and Optic Lobes in the Vertebrate Classes";...

An intelligent young man called at THE TIMES office last night and made a statement in which he declares that Charles McDonald, one of the men liberated on habeas corpus by Judge Andrews on Monday, was one of a trio who tried to induce him to take a letter to Dr. Cronin from the West Shore Railroad station in Chicago on the evening of April 13, just three weeks before Cronin was murdered.

"The Eutopia and Trout Lake Fish and Game Association" is the name under which a company of anglers have organized in this city for the purpose of indulging in their favorite sport under the most favorable conditions.
The Norwegian bark Royal Visitor, Capt. Christiansand, from Pensacola, Fla., for Greennock, Scotland, with lumber, when forty miles off Key West, on June 3, went ashore on a sand bank.

CONCORD, N.H., June 18.--The Senate this forenoon took a ballot for a United States Senator, which resulted as follows: Harry Bingham, 6; Willam E. Chandler, 18. Mr. Chandler was declared the choice of the Senate.
In Wall-street two or three pool rooms did a lively business in the way of taking bets on the Suburban.
JOHNSTOWN, Penn., June 18.--Fair weather and the increased army of workmen seemed to unite to-day in clearing up the debris. Everybody is busy.
The six-story brick building on the southeast corner of Irving-place and Eighteenth-street, occupied as a portion of Huyler's candy factory, was badly wrecked by fire early yesterday morning.

A well-devised attempt to escape from Sing Sing Prison was discovered and frustrated about 2 o'clock yesterday morning by Keeper Dennis Kerr. James Montgomery occupied Cell 389 and Charles H. Cummings Coll 390 on Gallery 8, which is the third tier on the west side of the prison.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18.--The special election to-day to adopt or reject two proposed amendmants to the Constitution of the State passed off very quietly. Sixty-five gentlemen, most of them members of the New-York Cotton Exchange, were interested spectators of an exhibition Monday afternoon at the German-American Stores, Brooklyn, of the working of the New-York Cotton Compress Company's new forty-thousand-dollar hydraulic press.
QUEENSTOWN, June 18.--In the yacht race today the Valkyrie led for twenty miles, when she was overhauled by the Yarana.

RALEIGH, N.C., June 18.--A test was made today on the Raleigh and Gaston Railroad in the presence of a number of prominent railroad men of a process recently invented by Raylus Cade of this county for telegraphing to and from moving trains.

A pretty wedding took place at noon yesterday at Trinity Chapel, in West Twenty-fifthstreet, in the marriage of Miss Josephine Olivia Green, daughter of Mrs. Olivia S. Green of Tremont, to Harry Herbert Gilbert, son of Dr. Walter B. Gilbert, the organist of Trinity Chapel.
PATERSON, N.J., June 18.--The syndicate which is seeking to get control of the breweries of the country has been negotiating with the beermakers of Paterson with a view to buying them out.
TOLEDO, June 18.--The Wabash case in the United States Circuit Court closed this afternoon.
ITAHCA, June 18.--The Class Day excercises at Cornell University were held this afternoon in Gymnasium Hall and on the campus.

The Suburban race interfered with yesterday's stock market. Many of the most active operators of the Street went out of town for this racing event, and their absence was felt. The market dragged all day, and despite a labored spurt in one or two quarters, closing prices were generally weak.
The Commencement excercises of the preparatory department of St. Francis Xavier's College, held last night in the college hall, were of a very entertaining character.

The New-York Institution for the Instruction of the Deaf and Dumb, on Washington Heights, overlooking the Hudson at One Hundred and Sixty-second-street, celebrated its Commencement yesterday in a manner that was very interesting.

ALBANY, June 18.--The Governor's action in vetoing the Capitol Appropriation bill is still sharply criticised by the workingmen.

HARTFORD, June 18.--The interest in the Secret-Ballot bill attracted a large attendance at the bearing this afternoon before the Judiciary Committee. The principal supporters of the measure who were heard were the Hon. Henry C. Robinson and William A. Country man of this city, Speaker John H. Perry, the Rev. Dr. Chapin of Meriden, and Representative Wolff of New-Haven. Albert H. Walker of this city appeared in behalf of an envelope system.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 18.--The chief event of to-day's doings at Rutgers College was the laying of the cornerstone of Winants's Hall, the new dormitory at the college. This occurred early in the afternoon in the presence of a gayly-attired throng of ladies and students.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 18.--At Rochester University to-day the first event of interest was the meeting of the Trustees.
CHESTER, Penn., June 18.--The seventeenth annual Commencement of Swarthmore College took place to-day at Swarthmore. The graduating class numbered eighteen.
LONDON, June 18.--At the Ascot meeting today the Prince of Wales's Stakes was won by Donovan, with Royal Star second and Enthusiast third.

The sum of $125,000 was appropriated by the Legislature for the payment for services, transportation, subsistence, and other necessary expenses of the troops of the National Guard in connection with the Washington centennial celebration.

Hill failed to approve the act of the Legislature appropriating $5,000 for the purpose of equipping the State Camp of Instruction at Peekskill with the electric light, it is altogether probable that the military post will be lighted by that means. ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 18.--The high tide at noon to-day did considerable damage to the beach. From two to three yards of the bluff was washed away in a few hours, and the new walk was badly undermined.
The prospects are that at least a score of yachts will spread their sails this morning in the lower bay to take part in the annual race of the Corinthian Yacht Club.

Treasurer J. Edward Simmons of the Conemaugh Valley relief fund reported yesterday that he had received $14,977.40 during the day, and had sent $50,000 to Gov. Beaver, who has thus far drawn $100,000 of the $150,000 the Finance Committee has authorized him to draw. The sum of the contributions to the fund is $479,357.25, and the amount in the possession of Treasurer Simmons now is $379,357.25.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 18.--The Indianapolis Post Office was submitted to a thorough examination to-day, and the friends of civil service reform everywhere will approve the wholesome investigation conducted by Commissioners Lyman, Roosevelt, and Thompson.
Emma Buhl, the nineteen-year-old daughter of A.M. Buhl, a crockery dealer of Port Richmond, S.I., has been missing from home since June 3.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 18.--In the old St. Louis Cathedral this morning, at high mass, lasting from 9 to 12 o'clock, the Rev. Father Thomas Heslin was consecrated and elevated to the exalted position of Bishop in the Roman Catholic Church.

The Staten Island Athletic Club's lacrosse team was easily defeated yesterday in the first match of the season for the Eastern championship and the possession of the Qelrich Cup by the present holders of the cup, the Brooklyn Lacrosse Club. The score was 7 to 1.

CANTON, N.Y., June 18.--The thirtieth annual Commencement of the St. Lawrence University will begin on Sunday next, when President Hervey and President Atwood will deliver baccalaureate sermons, one in the morning and the other in the evening.

The Lyceum Theatre company arrived in San Francisco on Saturday evening and on Monday evening opened its month's season at the Baldwin with a revival of "The Wife," which is to be played all this week.
The Commencement exercises at Mount Pleasant Military Academy, one of the oldest in the State, will take place to-morrow afternoon.

CHICAGO, June 18.--The Committee of General Freight Agents, representing the lines doing business, between Chicago and St. Paul, appointed last week to consider the practicability of abolishing all pro-rates with Eastern roads, has not been successful in securing the unanimous consent of the lines in interest.
The masterly inefficiency that has lately distinguished the management of the Post Office in this city received another characterstic illustration yesterday.
Judge Andrews, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday appointed John H. Judge referee in the suit of Mrs. Florence C. Ives for a divorce from Albert C. Ives.

The Commencement execises of the Brooklyn Collegiate and Polytechnic Institute were held last evening at the Academy of Music. Isaac H. Frothingham presided and presented the diplomas to the the thirty-six graduates.

BALTIMORE, June 18.--The Rev. John F. Goucher, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, has offered to give $85,000 to the Woman's College as an endowment fund, provided the college secures an additional sum of $40,000 for the same purpose.
The Rev. Father Brady of St. Augustine's Catholic parish in Union Hill, N.J., made a recent marriage among his flock the subject of pulpit reference on Sunday.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 18.--The New-York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad Company's enormous new storehouses for coal at Two Bridges station are nearly completed.

DRESDEN, June 18.--To-day's programme for the octocentenary celebration included an imposing military review. Emperor William in person led the troops before the King. Afterward the Emperor witnessed the unvelling of a statue of the late King John, and also attended a grand army festival. The Emperor returned to Berlin this evening.

The Class Day exercises of the Cathedral School of St. Mary at Garden City, L.I., were held yesterday afternoon. The exercises were held upon the lawn in front of the school, chairs being placed on the turf for the use of visitors.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 18.--Class Day exercises were held to-day at Smith Female College. The address of welcome was given by Alice Buswell of Newton, the poem by Mary Tilton of Laconia, N.H., and the oration by Anna Gale of Minneapolis.

Dr. N.C. King, who left his home in Richmond-street, Brooklyn, about two months ago, leaving a bride of a day and a worthless check for $25 behind him, has not yet been heard from, but Justice Kenna received a letter yesterday that may throw some light on the peculiar conduct of the missing man.

ALBANY, June 18.--James H. Manning, chief stockholder in the Albany Argus Company, denies the rumor that Col. Daniel Lamont, while here last week, transferred his stock in the Argus to Gov. Hill, who was hereafter to control its editorial columns.

The recent published accounts in THE TIMES of contemplated changes in the anchorage grounds of New-York Harbor have excited much interest among the shipping interests, and almost every day inquiries are made as to when the proposed changes are to go into effect.

The first of a series of three match races between the seventy-foot sloops Titania, designed by Mr. Edward Burgess, and Katrina, designed by Mr. A. Cary Smith, was sailed yesterday on the ocean in a high eastern wind and a rough sea. The wind blew fully thirty knots an hour, and its force stirred the surface of the sea until white-capped waves were rolling twenty feet high, if not more.

The first Spanish-American newspaper ever printed in New-York on its own presses and by its own men is El Avisador Hispano-Americano. It is a newspaper about three years old, having been originally started here under the name of El Evisador Cubano, but it was bought by its present owners last January, the name was changed, and its first number from its own presses was issued yesterday.

A large number of politician gathered at the Astor House yesterday to dispose of a sevenand-a-half-pound black bass which was caught in Greenwood Lake last Saturday.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., June 18.--A fare of twenty-five barrels of mackerel, the first of two season, was landed to-day and sold at $15 a barrel. Incoming vessels report mackerel very scarce, and many have returned without fares.

George Allen, aged twenty, a sailor on the bark Kestrel of Windsor, Nova Scotia, stabbed himself yesterday while the vessel lay at anchor off Tompkinsville, S.I. His weapon was a sheath knife.

MANOTICK, Ontario, June 18.--The residence of Richard Wilson caught fire last night and Mrs. Wilson and two young children were burned to death. Mr. Wilson, after a hard struggle, managed to save his other three children, but not before he himself was badly burned.
The last spike has been driven on the Georgia Pacific Railroad extension, making one continnous rail line of 1,110 miles from Washington, D.C., to Greenville, Miss.

All roads led to Sheepshead Bay yesterday. Most of them stopped at the entrance gates to the Coney Island Jockey Club's track. If the roads that led to the beautiful grounds didn't stop there, every one who traveled over them did.
AURORA, N.Y., June 18.--The students at Wells College to-day were as happy as larks and busy as bees. The graduating exercises were to take place at 11 o'clock, and then would come a long vacation.

The conditions governing the contracts for the two new cruisers of 3,100 tons displacement the bids for which are to be opened at the Navy Department August next are exciting considerable comment among navy engineers.
In dealing with the affairs of railroads the last Legislature was very obliging to the corporations and very indifferent to the demands of the public.
Congressman Ashbel P. Fitch tells a good story regarding the rush of Republicans for the offices.

A preliminary report in relation to the mortality in this city for 1888 was presented to the Board of Health yesterday by Dr. Roger S. Tracy, the Assistant Sanitary Superintendent, and the deductions he presents as the result of his investigations are rather remarkable.

LIVERPOOL, June 18.--The shipowners of Liverpool have unanimously refused to grant the advance in wages demanded by the striking seamen, and the strikers stubbornly insist that they will not return to work until the increase is conceded.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 18.--The boycotters who are trying to drive Mrs. John Hoy out of this city because she helped to send one of their friends to State prison are still keeping up the crusade against her, despite the fact that Judge McCormick is on their track.
Surrogate Rausom yesterday, after the hearing in the contest of the will of Miss M. Louise Comstock, put down the next hearing for July 17.
Six-year-old Harry Baker of Twelfth-street, Hoboken, was sent to sit on the stoop with his one-year-old sister on Monday evening.
What appears to be the silliest rumor started in yachting circles for some time was telegraphed to this city from Boston a day or two ago, and was printed in a morning paper here.
NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 18.--Interest in the college boat races to begin on the Thames on Friday is increasing daily. The arrangements for the races are about completed.
The Cathedral of tha Incarnation, Garden City, L.I., will to-day continue its celebration of Founder's Day and the closing exercises of the cathedral schools.
CINCINNATI, June 18.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad Company convened at the company's office in this city this morning.

An amalgamation of the cattle and fresh meat interests of T.C. Joseph Eastman of this city and John Ball Sons, Limited, of London, Glasgow, Liverpool, and other towns in Great Britain, has been practically effected and the stock of the new concern, known as "Eastman's Limited," has been subscribed for in the London market.

"I have no time to talk politics," said Gov. Foraker of Ohio to a TIMES representative yesterday. "I am about to start for home and have barely time to catch my train."

While the boats of the Harlem Yacht Club were bowling along toward the finish at College Point, in the Sound, Monday afternoon, there was enacting a tragedy at Fort Schuyler which, it is believed, cost two lives.
FLUSHING, L.I., June 18.--Benjamin J. Byrd, aged about forty-five years, committed suicide this morning by shooting himself in the left side.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 18.--Burke, the young Irishman arrested here on suspicion of being one of Dr. Cronin's murderers, is reported to have made a clean breast of the whole affair to the Winnipeg Chief of Police. Burke has been extremely nervous since his capture, and has now broken down entirely.
WASHINGTON June 18.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased $17,400 4 per cent. bonds at 106 7/8.

A fire in Jersey City late last night that flamed very high and cast its bright reflection far over the waters of harbor gave many persons the impression that the Red Star docks were burning. It was not these, but some buildings on the west and south that were destroyed.
One of the postponed games between St. Louis and Brooklyn was played off at Washington Park yesterday, and the Browns were the victors.

While digging for sandworms on the upper end of Randall's Island yesterday morning Stephen Thompson of 426 Pleasant-avenue notice the body of a boy, lying on the beach with hands clasped and face down in the sand.

For the Washington memorial arch fund Treasurer William H. Stewart acknowledged the receipt yesterday from Eufrasia Leland of $50, Emma L. Wesson $50, H.M. Smith Son, for Grand Hotel, $25. Previously acknowledged, $43,845.76; grand total, $43,970.76.

Incoming ships report an unprecedented drift of field and berg ice. By the log of the British tramp steamer Orsino, which arrived here yesterday from Mediterranean ports, it seems that the North German Lloyd steamship Saale is not the only vessel that has had a tussle with the ice during the past few days.

After deliberating for just fifteen minutes yesterday afternoon the jury in the case of William E. Howard, the electric sugar swindler, determined upon a verdict of guilty of grand larceny in the first degree.

BONHAM, Texas, June 18.--Many citizens of Bonham are jubilant to-night. In sinking an artesian well for water works in the northern part of the city at a depth of 860 feet a strong volume of oil was struck.

The large switchboard in the station of the Brush Electric Illuminating Company at 210 Elizabeth-street took fire at 11:30 o'clock last night, and was burned out, extinguishing all the lamps served from that station.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 18.--The troops sent to the scene of the reported Indian outbreak at Mille Lacs broke camp at Mora and returned to Fort Snelling last night.

NYACK, June 18.--William F. Sinell, a wellknown liquor dealer of Suffern, was convicted of a violation of the excise law at midnight last night and sentenced to six months' imprisonment in the county jail. It was the most exciting case ever tried in Rockland County.

ALBANY, June 18.--The trotting meeting opened this afternoon at Island Park, the famous old racing course situated midway between this city and Troy. The weather was perfect, comfortably warm, with a light cool breeze, and the track in splendid condition. There was a large crowd of men present, but few ladies.

The twenty-second annual regatta of the Columbia Yacht Club was sailed yesterday in a strong northeast wind, and accidents were plentiful. Unfortunately, one of these resulted in the death of a man. He was Henry Renouf, a druggist of Nostrand and Putnam avenues, Brooklyn.

HARTFORD, June 18.--The Trinity Commencement speakers were announced this afternoon. Willard Scudder of New-York City will deliver the valedictory and Joseph W. Fell of Bristol, Conn., will be the salutatorian.
Dr. William Maass, a druggist, whose place is in Atlantic-avenue, near Vermont-street, Brooklyn, is one of the well-known men of the new section of the city formerly known as New-Lots.
NEW-HAVEN, June 18.--The eighth annual regatta of the New-Haven Yacht Club was sailed to-day over a twenty-mile course, from NewHaven Harbor to the turning buoy off Stamford.
A most brutal wife murder was perpetrated yesterday morning at a few minutes after 10 o'clock on the top floor of the tenement house 49 Bayard-street by Antonio Ricomo, an Italian laborer.

BOSTON, June 18.--The Massachusetts Military Rifle Team, under command of Major James P. Frost, which has been selected to compete with the English Volunteer Riflemen on their own ground, left this afternoon for Liverpool via New-York.
RED BANK, N.J., June 18.--Farmers coming into town report great destruction to crops by the severe storms yesterday afternoon.

There was a pretty wedding last evening at the Westminster Presbyterian Church, Yonkers, the contracting parties being Edwin Rufus Holden, business manager of the Yonkers Garette, and Miss Annie Stone, eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Demmon Stone of Yonkers. The Rev. John Dixon, a former pastor of the church, now of Trenton.

WASHINGTON, June 19.--No bond offerings were received at the Treasury Department to-day up to 12 o'clock. A bond offer of $32,000 registered fours, at 129 flat, was received and accepted this afternoon.

At the meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in the Mayor's office at noon today there is likely to be a discussion of the effect of the bills giving street railroad companies the right to change their motive power and extend their lines without restriction from the local authorities.
NEW-BRUSWICK, N.Y., June 19.--Charles and Garrett Conover have filed a caveat against the will of their father, the late ex-Mayor Garrett Couover.

BOSTON, June 19.--The second annual convention of the National British-American Association of the United States opened here today and will continue for three days.

The Executive Committee of the Woolen Goods Association met in regular session yestarday afternoon for a ganeral discussion of the agreement regarding terms and discounts that has been submitted to the trade for signature.

Treasurer Simmons raported at a meeting of the Finance Committee of the Conemaugh Valley Relief Fund yesterday that the contributions to the fund had reached $492,732 83, of which $392,732 83 was yet in his custody. Mayor Grant presented to the committee Mr. Robert Hutchings of Johnstown, who had come to him with a letter of introduction from Adjt. Gen. Hastings.

ALBANY, June 19.--The tretting at Island Park continued today under the most favorable auspices. With perfect weather, bright and hot, a splendid track, and the Clay Stakes on the card, the people came from the capital, from Troy, and all parts of the State. ELIZABETH, N.J., June 19.--The Pingry Academy of this city, founded over half a century ago by the Rev. Dr. Pingry, who still conducts it, held its anaual Commencement to-night at the Temple Opera House, which was filled with the best people of the city.

CHICAGO, June 19.--The Grand Jury investigating the Cronin murder to-day returned an indictment, against Martin Burke, now in custody in Winnipeg. There are six counts in the indictment, she main features of which are worth mentioning, as they indicate to a certain extent, the course that the Grand Jury will pursue in finding bills.

Archbishop Gross of Oregon, who is on route to Rome, was yesterday teudered a reception at the De La Salle Institute by Brother James, the Director, and his assistants. The address of welcome was delivered with effect by little Martin J. Crimmius.
The Guatemalian Consul General at NewYork has received a copy of the decree issued by his Government regarding the expulsion of Mr. J.H. Hollander, who lately issued a newspaper in Guatemala.

The house of the Hariem democratic Club in One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street, near Fifth-avenue, was thronged last night in response to invitations from the newly-elected officers and members of the Executive Committee of the club.

Among the curiosities of commerce is the unloading of a lot of copper ore from the bark Iceberg at the stores of George A. Lawrence, 755 Water-street, yesterday.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 19.--At a business meeting of the Iowa Holincess Association, held at its camp grounds here this morning, all the names of members known to be professors and practitioners of the so-called "Christian Sscience" were dropped from the list, with others who have forfeited their membership in various ways.

BOSTON, June 19.--S.C. Armstrong, Principal of the Hampton School, has written a letter in reference to the Washington dispatch in Tuesday's papers reflecting on the treatment of Indians at the Hampton School, and on the ability of Gen. E. Whittlesey and Mr, A.K. Smiley...

The Sheriff's sale of the effects of Morris Flesch, manufacturer of knit goods at 387 Canal-street, under the style of the Columbia Knitting Mills, which was advertised to take place yesterday, has been postponed until next Monday. He has confessed judgments for about $2,000. He has been in business about eight years, and claimed to have about $3,000 invested.

Superintendent Jasper wrote to the Board of Education yesterday recommending that specimens of the work done in the schools into which mannual training has been introduced be sent to Brooklyn next week for the inspection of the State Teachers' Association, then to be in session there.
The steamer Elm City landed 325 members of Admiral Foote Post of New-Haven, Conn., at Peck-slip yesterday morning, where they were met by a delegation from Grant Post, and escorted to Brooklyn.

The State Line steamer State of Pennsylvania, Capt A.J.A. Mann, from Glasgow, arrived yesterday. Capt. Mann reports that on June l4, in north latitude 48 37', west longitude 47 24', he passed a large iceberg, and on the same day in north latitude 48 16', west longitude 47 52, another one was passed.

The usual reaction after a hard day's racing was felt at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday, where six races were run for purses of $1,000 each. Only the most hardened and inveterate of racegoers were on hand to enjoy the sport, so closely following the Suburban excitement, but the three or four thousand people who were there didn't regret their visit, as there was very good racing all through the day.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 19.--Four thousand people pushed their way into the Ocean Theatre here last night to attend the Commencement exercises of the Long Branch High School. The hall was prettily decorated with flags and flowers.

DRESDEN, June 19.--The Wettin historical procession took place to-day. The weather was splendid and the city was beautifully decorated. Windows and temporary platforms along the route of the procession were crowded with spectators.

GETTYSBURG, June 19.--New-York State will have seventy monuments out of ninety, its full quota, on the battlefield by July 4, and before the end of the year all the organization monuments of that State will be erected. The onehundred-thousand-dollar State monument will be dedicated next year, and is expected to be, next to the national monument, the most massive and beautiful on the field.
A court-martial to try Paymaster Henry R. Smith of the United States steamship Essex on charges of having been absent from duty without leave commenced in the navy yard yesterday morning.

ROCHESTER, June 19.--At Rochester University the annual meeting of the Alumni took place this morning. The following officers were elected: President--George E. Flsher; Vice PresidentJoseph T. Alling; Secretery--A.G. Warrep: Treasuere--H.K. Phinney; Orator--M.E. Gates; Alternate--J.B.Perkins; Poet--W.C.Wilkinson; Alterante--W.T. Sutherland.

Attorney General Tabor having given an opinion that the act of 1888 made a now Quarantine Board, composed of the old Commissioners and of the Special Commissioners appointed under the act, such a board was organized in the Mayor's office yesterday.

The troops of the Department of the Platte will concentrate at Fort Robinson, of the Department of Texas at San Antonio, of the Department of Missouri between Hunnewell and Arkansas City, Indian Territory; of the Department of Dakota on the Upper Little Missouri. PRINCETON. N.J., June 19.--The one hundred and forty-second annual Commencement exercises or the College of New-Jersey were held in the First Presbyterian Church to-day at 10:30 A.M. The procession formed in front of old Nassau Hall and proceeded to the church.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 19.--A convention of wood acid manufacturers met at Binghamton on April 9 last and organized what is known as "The United states Acid Manufacturers' Association." The industry was then at a low and an unprofitable ebb, and the avowed purpose had in view in forming the combination was the putting up of prices to a remunerative point.

CHICAGO, June 19.--The demoralizaion of freight rates has extended as far west as Marshalltown, Iowa, and south to the northern boundary of Missouri. Public Works Commissioner Gilroy's polite requests to many of his County Democracy subordinates for their resignations, to take effect on July 1, began to meet with responses yesterday.

NORWALK, Conn., June 19.--By far the most fashionable event that has occurred in this city for many years wa the marriage this evening of Miss Mary Louise, the only daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Charles H. Everest, to Mr. Charles Lee Rockwell, a wealthy young banker of Meriden.
JOHNSTOWN, Penn., June 19.--Seven bodies had been recovered to-day up to 1 o'clock, all of them women. None of them was recognizable, however, and there were no means of identification.

NEW-HAVEN, June 19.--In Newton, near Sandy Hook station, Southington, capitalists are at work cleaning out a shaft that was dug fifty feet deep twenty-live years ago with the expectation of rinding gold and silver in paying quantities.

The Brotherhood of Boilermakers and Iron Shipbuilders are holding their annual international convention at Military Hall, 193 Bowery. Delegates were present yesterday from the branches in this city, Paterson, Philadelphia, Reading, Penn.; Milwaukee, Wis,; Chicago...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 19.--The New-Yorks fell easy victims to the Clevelands to-day. The game was too one-sided to afford great interest to tho 3,500 people who witneseed it. The Giants were unable to bat O'Brien's pitching effectively, and fielded badly at critical times. The most noteworthy incident of the game was McAleer's fielding in centre.

ASBURY PARK. N.J., June 19.--The one hundred and twenty-third meeting of the Medical Society of New-Jersey, the oldest institution of the kind in the United States, began yesterday in the ballroom of the Coleman House.
CHICAGO, June 19.--The annual convention of the Wiscousin Anti-Prohibition Association or Liquor Dealers' Society began at Oshkosh yesterday.

The bears had something of an inning on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Four or five ancient tales were paraded and hurrahed over to the hopes of the raiders, and some of these exploded romances were so deftly reconstructed and so nimbly sent the rounds that they really had a temporary influence, quotations going down before them.

MARION, Ind., June 19.--Great consternation has been created among the farmers of this county by the appearance during the last day or two of a small, green bug or parasite that threathens to demolish the wheat, oats, and rye crop. The pests appear upon every head by hundreds, and planting themselves at the base of the grain, sap the fire out of it.

From a very small incident the members of the Gentlemen's Driving Club of New-York derived a lot, of fun yesterday. It was a match race for $100 a side between Charles B. Jordan's blk. g. Government and J. H. Lockwood's b.g. Bounic Bird, best three heats in five.

DULUTH, Minn., June 19.--The fine steamship City of Cleveland and the schooner John Martin are ashore at Two Harbors badly damaged. A tug and steamship wreckage outfit has just left here for Castle Danger, eight miles below Two Harbors.

The annual race of the Corinthian Yocht Club of New-York was sailed yesterday over courses in the lowor bay in light breezes, interspersed with calms. There was so little wind that the course for yachts over thirty feet on the loadwater line was shortened from Scotland Lightship to Buoy 5, off Sandy Hook.

PITTSBURG, June 19.--The Amalgamated Association convention to-day granted the application of the boltmakers for admission to the organization. This will necessitate a boltmakers' scale. The general strike assessment measure suggested by the American Federation of Trades Unions, whereby all members of the federation are assessed in ease of a strike in auy of the trades' unions was adopted.

Bishop Pottor was unable to attend the union sarvices of, the Brotherhood oP St. Andrew in St. Paul's Chapel at Broadway and Veseystreet last evening, but sent a letter expressing regret at his absence and deep sympathy with the organization's purposes.

TORONTO, Ontario, june 19.--A small body of Presbyterians residing at Galt, who are believers iu the doctrine of sinless perfection, were recently brought before the Hamilton Presbytery and found guilty of holding toners opposed to the Scripture and subversive of the unity of the church and of teaching said doctrines.

HASTINGS, N.Y., June 19.--The second annual tournament of the Hudson River Lawn Tennis Association was commonced on the grounds of the Far and Near Club at Hastings-on-Hudson this afternoon.

The Jeffersonian Club of Newark, one of the most influential Democratic organizations in New-Jersey, held a house warming in its--new home, 15 Park-street, last night, and welcomed all its friends.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 19.--The Cornell regatta took place this forenoon. The water was rough and the wind fresh, but good time was made. The first, race was between two four-oared university crews, as follows: First crewHagerman, stroke; Healy, No.3; Benedict, No. 2; Barker, bow.

The Jefferson Democratic Association of Baltimore held an onthusiastic meeting the other evening with the object of properly organizing the party in Maryland for the 1892 campaign. Three hundred children of poor but respectable parents were given an outing yesterday at Brighton Beach. The children were the guests of the Seid Society and were in charge of 150 of the lady members, each of whom had the care of two children.

When Robson and Crane first produced "The Comedy of Errors" at the Star Theatre in 1879 they induced Charles Webb, one of the old Dromios of England, to come here and "coach" them in the characters of the Two Dromius. Mr. Webb was a veteran English actor at that time and had practically outlived his usefulness on the stage.

An important railroad lawsuit was begun in Philadelphia yesterday. COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 19.--The greatest interest is manifested here and elsewhere in the Republican State Convention. which will be held in Columbus next week. All interest centres in the Gubernatorial nomination, there being three candidates in the field, with Congressman-elect Kennedy in the lead.
The boats on the Sandy Hook route now leave New-York, Pier 8 N.R., at 4:30, 10:15 A.M., 3:45, 5 P.M.; Sundays at 9:30 A.M.

PITTSBURG, June 19.--The second section of Mail Train No. 7, west bound on the Pan Hancle Railroad, was wrecked this afternoon while passing New-Cumberland Junction, two miles east or Steubenville. Two persons were killed outright and night injured, four of them seriousiy.

LEXINGTON, Va., June 19.--The Commencement Day of the Washington and Lee University was celebrated by the announcement of class distinctions, the delivery of certificates, diplomas, honorary appointments, and univer sity prizes, and the conferring of degrees by...

CHICAGO, June 19.--The will of the late Nathan Corwith, Sr., has been admitted to probate. His son, Nathan Corwith, Jr., and his brothers, Henry and John E. Corwith, are executors of the estate, which as insolvent.

ALBANY, June 19.--It was discovered to-day that the vetoed bill providing for the appointment of six female Factory Inspectors was, like the Capitol Appropriation bill, upprovad and signed by the Governor on June 15.

PARIS, June 19.--The Soleil says that Germany has made a demand upon France for compensation for the arrest of an alleged spy named Lechmer near Belfort, in the frontier department of Haut-Rhim, on Whitsunday. The French officials declare that documents found on Lechmer justified his arrest.
The funeral of Edward J. Knight, for many years librarian of the Supreme Court in this city, took place at his residence, 295 Broomestreet, yesterday afternoon.
