DUBLIN, June 19.--Nine families were evicted at Youghal to-day. Among the tennats dispossessed was an aged woman named Sweeney, to whom the last sarament was being administered when the evictors arrived. Mrs. Sweeney was subsequently reinstated.

The coal miners of Clay County, Ind., struck on May 1 because their employers had reduced their wages. The reduction-- from 90 to 70 cents par ton--was characterized by our high-tariff neighbor, the Tribune, as "the largest ever demanded in the history of the coal traffic in the West."

The steamship City of Chicago of the Inman Line, which sailed for Liverpool yesterday, showed the Stars and Stripes, the State colors of Massachusetts, and the corps pennant of the rifle team of the militia of that State, in honour of the sixteen riflemen who go abroad on her to show their prowess with Springfield rifles. Their first match will be with the Berkshire Volunteers on July 2.

LONDON, June 20.--Lord Dunraven and his brother-in-law, Mr. Kerr, in an interview to-day declared that the Valkyrie fully answered their expectations. She had proved eminently superior to Crack yachts on all points-in running...

The peace of mind of the taxpayers on Canalstreet, between Greens and Mercer streets, has been greatly disturbed during the last three weeks by the presence of a representative force from the Department of Public Works. The numerical strength of the detail has ranged from four to ten able-bodied Tammany workers.

CONCORD, N.H., June 19.--At noon to-day the Legislature met in joint convention. The journals of yesterday were read, showing that William E. Chandler had received a majority vote for United States Senator in each branch, and Mr. Chandler was formally declared elected by Speaker Upton. A committee was appointed to inform him of hle election, and the convention arose.

Two memorials in bronze just from the foundryman's hands were shown yesterday at the works of the Henri Bonnard Company on West Sixteenth-street. One ie a large group for the asylum for the deal and dumb at Washington, D,C., the other an unusually large relief for a monument to the Sixth Cavalry at Gottysburg.

GUTHRIE, Indian Territory, June 19.--Not withstanding the efforts of the Administration to hush up the scandal growing out of the opening of Oklahoma there are strong indications that a cat and dog fight between the Government and civil official will resultin an official expose of the miserable and corrupt practices which President Harrison has so far sanctioned.

The annual Commencement exercises of Seton Hall College occurred yesterday. A huge canvas had been spread over the beautiful campus for the guests, and all the seats were filled. In the absence of Bishop Wigger, Bishop Farrel of Trenton presided.
LONDON, June 19.--A revolutionary manifesto from Servia has been circulated in Bosnia and Herzegovina announcing that Austria intends to annex those territories. The populace is greatly excited.

The Glen Island season opened yesterday, and on the eight trips wade by the Starin boats, bright with fresh gilt, new paint, and a complete refurnishing, gay crowds of pleasure seekers visited the over-popular resort to find a delightful change from the dust of the city. Pain's pyrotechnic speetacle, "The Last Days of Pompell," was revived at Manhattan Beach on Tuesday evening and was repeated last night.

NEW-HAVEN, June 19.--At the recent graduation ceremonies at the University of Edinburgh the honorary degree of LL., D. was conferred on David Dudley Field of New-York, the President of the American Bar Association, and Prof. Whitney of Yale. Prof. Whitney was appointed to the chair of Sanskrit and Comparative Philology in Yale in 1854.

Dr. Young of the Brooklyn Health Department was notified late on Tuesday night that a case of genuine yellow fever existed at the home of William H. Thompson, 173 Hancockstreet. The patient was Dr. R.W.H. Duncan, surgeon of the steamer Colon, lately arrived from Aspinwall.

Peter Rosa of 26 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth-street reported to the police yesterday that on Tuesday, while he was fishing is a small boat off the foot of East Nintiethstreet, with Critonio Pianza of 405 East One Hundred and Twelfth-street, Rosari Curgo of 407 East One Hundred and Twelfth-street, and Linardo Scavaglioni of 405 East One Hundred and Thirteen-street, the boat was run into by the steamer Long Branch.

Two steam yachts met with accidents on Tuesday. They were Mr. Gould's Atalanta and Mr. Scott's Stranger. The Atalanta was bound up the North River at about 3 P. M., and when opposite Pler 54 a signal to reverse her engine was supposed to have been given by the Captain in the pilot house.

BOSTON, June 19.--The exercises of the Thirty-second annual Commencement of Tuft's College, Medford, were carried out to-day. MILWAUKEE, June 19.--A mortgage covering every dollar's worth of property owned by the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway Company, except lands, has been filed with Secretary of State Timme. The mortgage is in faver of the United States Trust Company of NewYork, and is for the sum of $150,000,000.

NORFOLK, Va., June 19.--The United States practice ship Constellation, which left Annapolis, Md., for her Summer cruise and stranded in Chesapeake Bay, near Cape Henry, yesterday afternoon, arrived at the Norfolk Navy Yard this evening at 7 o'clock.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 19,--The first meeting of the commission created by the last Legislature to establish a Meteorological Bureau and weather service in the State of New-York was held to-day at the office of the Hon. Simeon Smith, in this city.

About sixty of the leading Republicans of Brooklyn accepted the invitation to go to Franklin Woodruff's house last night and confer. The approaching Mayoralty campaign and the proposed introduction of a temperance movement into it were the subjects upon which then were to confer.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., June 19.--The fourth annual Commencement of the Bordentown Military Institute was held to-day. The prize for scholarship, a fold medal given by Dr. J.M. Buckley...
HARTFORD, June 19.--The stock held by President Goodman of the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company has been contracted for by a Hartford syndicate, being sold for $250,000.

LONDON, June 20.--The schooner Mary Jane Gregory was sunk at Liverpool to-day by a collision with the bows of the British steamer Persian Prince, from Chatham, N,B., which was anchored in the harbor. The schooner's crew were rescued. The steamer sustained no damage.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 20.--The Occidental and Oriental Company's steamship Oceanica arrived late last night from Hong-Kong and Yokohama.
PATERSON, N.J, June 20.--For some weeks work has been in progress in grading a track for a spur of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad into the southern part of Paterson.

CINCINNATI, June 20.--The Trustees of Miami University at Oxford, Ohio, to-day conferred the degree of LL. D. upon President Harrison, Secretary of the Interior J.W. Noble, and John W. Herron, all Alumni of the college.

ALBANY, June 20.--Superintendent of State Prisons Lathrop has asked Attorney General Tabor for an opinion relative to his powers under the prison law, and that fixing the pay of laborers on public works at $2 a day.

LANSING, Mich., June 20.--The Senate has indefinitely postponed the bill to create by appointment of the Governor and Excise Commission excise officers in every township to look after the licensing of saloons and violations of the liquor laws.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 20.--Article VIII. of the amendments to the Constitution annulling Article V., the prohibitory amendment, was adopted to-day by a vote of 28,449 to 9,853, being 5,468 over the required three-fifths majority.

RONDOUT, N.Y., June 20.--Astronomers at points along the Hudson River say that a large black spot was visible on the sun this afternoon. It could be plainly seen with the aid of a piece of smoked glass.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., June 20.--The twentythird annual Commencement of Lehigh Uni versity took place this morning. Sixty young men were graduated with degrees and eight post graduates had degrees conferred upon them. The Class of '89 is said by the Faculty to be one of the best ever graduated from the university.

JOHNSTOWN, June 20.--Sixteen bodies were found to-day, and many of them, on account of the advanced stage of decomposition, were promptly buried after being completely covered with oil. The stench is becoming daily more unbearable.

Col. Emmons Clark of the Seventh Regiment forwarded his resignation as Colonel to Adjt. Gen. Porter at Albany yesterday, that being the twenty-fifth anniversary of his assumption of the command of the regiment.

ALBANY, June 20.--John J. Wilson, Edward Bayard Holsted, and Harvey L. Kennedy are Trustees of the Standard Electrical Subway Company, incorporated with $250,000 to construct subways, The principal office is in New-York City.

ALBANY, June 20.--Superintendent of Insurance Maxwell to-day reported to the Attorney General for action the Mutual Benefit Society of New-York and submitted the report of Chief Examiner Horan.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 20.--The City Council of this place, together with the city authorities, are in a quandary over the question of appointing Assessors to fill existing vacancies in the Board of Assessment and Revision of Taxes.

Hiram F. Devol, the new Collector of Internal Revenue for the Sixth District of Missouri, is a native of Ohio, but has resided at Kansas City for the past eight years. He entered the war as Captain of an Ohio regiment and rose to the rank of Brevet Brigadier General. He was indorsed for the office by ex-President Hayes, exSecretary McCrary, and many others.

At Ascot yesterday the Rous Memorial Stakes was won by Love-in-Idleness, with El Dorado sec ond, and Seabreeze third. The Gold Cup was won by Troyles, with Rada second, and Cotillion third. The St. James's Palace Stakes was won by Pioneer, with Ben Strome second, and Swift third.

A committee from the Brooklyn Women's Christian Temperance League, headed by Mrs. A.H. Brundage and Mrs. Harriet S. Pritchard, called on Mayor Chapin yesterday to urge the appointment of temperance men on the Board of Education.

BOSTON, June 20.--The funeral of John Gilbert, the veteran actor, took place this afternoon from the Church of the Unity in this city. The Rev. Minot J. Savage conducted the services, which were simple and brief.
SHANGHAI, June 20.--One half of the important city of Lachan, in the province of Szechuen, was recently destroyed by fire. The conflagration raged four days.

With great pomp and ceremony the cornerstone of the new Corpus Christi Monastery was laid at Hunt's Point yesterday. The edifice, when completed, is to be occupied by the Dominican nuns. NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 20.--The Summer weather is rapidly filling up the many shore reports along the north coast of Long Island Sound, and the sandy shores of Watch Hill and the gravelly banks of rugged old Block Island are already well peopled.

Something like seventy-five lovers of the game of pool braved the heat last evening and went to Daly's billiard rooms on Washingtonstreet, Brooklyn, to see Alfred DeOro and Charles H. Manning begin a tournament for the championship of the world and a stake of $300. Since little Albort Frey died no one has held this title.

EXETER, N.H., June 20.--Considerable comment is made here regarding the expulsion from Phillips Academy, Exeter, of Stuart M. Brice, son of Calvin M. Brice, Chairman of the National Democratic Committee.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 20.--The rain last night and this morning covered about one-half of the Northwest territory. Reports from along the different lines of railroads show that it was local in its character. A better feeling now prevails among the wheat raisers and grain men and the outlook points to a good crop.

Entrance examinations for the Freshman Class of Princeton College were held yesterday at Association Hall, on Twenty-third-street, in pursuance of President Patton's plan to extend the system of local examinations begun in 1875 by Dr. McCosh.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 20.--A break in the new lock in the Erie Canal at Macedon, on Section 11, has necessitated the draining of a threemile level in order to repair it. Traffic will be suspended for three days.

HARTFORD, June 20.--The House concurred with the Senate this afternoon in the adoption of a Secret-Ballot bill, which had been arranged to the satisfaction of both political parties. Gov. Bulkeley will sign the measure.
DULUTH, Minn., June 20.--The latest reports from the steamer City of Cleveland ashore on the north shore of Lake Superior show that she is in much worse shape than was thought.

HARTFORD, June 20.--Gov. Bulkely to-day appointed Senator John M. Hall of Windham and John M. Thayer of Norwich to be Judges of the Superior Court for eight years from July, 1889. The Senate referred the nominations to the Judiciary Committee.

The Clyde Line steamer Saginaw, which arrived yesterday from Cape Haytien and Port de Palx, brought little news of importance from the seat of war.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 20.--The Class Day officers have been announced as follows: Oration--Walter Warren Magee, Groveland, N.Y.; Poetry--Carleton Hunneman, Roxbury, Mass.; Ivy Oration--Oliver Prescott, Jr., New-Bedford, Mass.; Ode--Robert Elkin Niel Dodge, Brookline, Mass. The hymn used in the baccalaureate service last Sunday was written by Mr. Dodge.

VERMILLION, Dakota, June 20.--A heavy windstorm struck this place at 12:45 o'clock this morning, doing considerable damage, Col. Jonathan Kimball's new residence, the Catholic church, and a building on the Fair Grounds are total wrecks. Several houses were moved from their foundations, and steeples, chimneys, and outhouses were blown down. The loss is estimated at $50,000.

St. John's Guild is in urgent need of more money for the free fresh-air excursions for sick children and mothers and for the Seaside Hospital. Subscriptions can be sent to Charles Schwacofer, Treasurer, at 21 University-place.

The Niagara River and Erie Railroad Company, with a capital of $100,000, has been incorporated at Albany. The road is to be constructed from a point in the Twelfth Ward of Buffalo, on the line of the Erie and Black Rock Railroad, to the village of Tonawanda, a distance of eight miles.
The Bruno Publishing and Printing Company, at 27 Beekman-street, was sold out by Deputy Sheriff' Carraner yesterday under two executions for $1,620. The prices realized were very small.

ALBANY, June 20.--Trotting was continued at Island Park this afternoon with the best of weather, a good crowd, and two exciting races. Of the six starters in the 2:34 class Stephanie was a slight favorite over Walkill Boy.

LAKE GEORGE, June 20.--With the opening of the Lake House the season at Lake George has fairly begun, and there is every promise of a successful Summer. Daniel Webster and Henry Clay were frequent guests here.

CHICAGO, June 20.--The first victim of sunstroke in this city since the warm season early in May was Frank Soehrnek, a Bohemian laborer, who was prostrated by the heat late yesterday afternoon while at work in a lumber yard. He was taken to his home, where he died last night.

More had news came from the west yesterday, the troubles in the new Inter-State Railway Association being paraded and exaggerated anew, for which reason the stock market continued weak throughout the day. The drooping tendency was helped, too, by the engagement of over $4,000,000 more of gold for export.

HARTFORD, June 20.--The State Board of Health has made its report on the Glastonbury ice cream poisoning by which a large number of people were thrown into convulsions.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 20.--A month ago the river land settlers succeeded in obtaining an order from the courts suspending their eviction.

LONDON, June 20.--At the meeting of the Parneil Commission to-day Mr. Thomas P. O'Connor, member of Parliament, was examined. He stated that the turning point in the agrarian struggle in Ireland was the rejection of the Compensation for Improvement bill.

Mayor Grant, Gen. W.T. Sherman, Treasurer J. Edward Simmons, and Cornelius N. Bliss were the only members of the Conemaugh Valley Relief Fund Committee at its meeting yesterday. Mr. Simmons reported that the contributions sent to him had increased to $495,344 71.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 20.--The great Northwestern Saengerfest, a musical event which promises to be the most successful festival in the history of the Northwest was opened here this evening in the Music Hall of the Exposition Building.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 20.--The manufacture of lactine, or sugar of milk, is a new industry in this country, which promises to attain importance in the milk-producing districts. Heretofore the manufacture has been confined to Switzerland and Bavaria.
NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 20.--This morning Alvin Park, the cock of the Noank fishing smack Marie Louise, killed a fourteen-year-old girl named Littlefield.

Soup and salad were the distinctive features of the Hoboken Turtle Club dinner, the first of the season, served yesterday afternoon at the club grounds in Jerome-avenue, this city. The first breakfast of the season had been served in the morning, and some two hundred members and their friends enjoyed turtle steak.

Richard Mansfield sailed from Queenstown for New-York on the White Star steamer Adriatic yesterday, and is expected to arrive here about next Friday. The route for his American tour has been admirably arranged by his manager, E.D. Price, and he will have nothing to bother him on his arrival.

A heavy windstorm struck Lafayette, Ind., Wednesday afternoon, doing considerable damage at the car works and wrecking a number of dwellings. The windstorm was followed by a severe shower of rain. CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 21.--Mrs. Hayes, the wife of ex-President Hayes, was stricken with apoplexy this afternoon at her home in Fremont, and at 9 o'clock this evening she was unconscious.
LONDON, June 21.--The Guion Line steamship Nevada, Capt. Cushins, from New-York June 11 for Liverpool, arr. at Queenstown at 10 o'clock to night.

NEW-HAVEN, June 21.--The sale at low figures of the $700,000 of the 3 per cent. town bonds issued by New-Haven to take up the same amount of Air Line Railroad bonds occasions considerable discussion in local financial circles. Financiers are unable to explain why they brought no better figures.
ALBANY, N. Y., June 21.--Col. William G. Rice, Gov. Hill's private secretary, has tendered his resignation, to take effect at the pleasure of the Governor.

CINCINNATI, June 21.--The Hon. Benjamin Butterworth, Congressman from the eastern Cincinnati district, has been at the Burnet House several days holding a sort of continued reception. His rooms have been thronged from morning until evening, and later. He is known to be hostile to Foraker, and yesterday allowed a peppery criticism on Joseph Benson to go into print.
Reports from the Paris Exposition say that one of the finest exhibits, and by far the most complete in ordnance, is that of the Hotchkiss Arms Company.

Thomas M. Baker, aged twenty, until recently was employed by the cotton firm of Garnett, Stubbs Co., in Savannah, Ga.

This will be another gala day at the Sheepshead Bay track, and the ladies will find the music they missed on the opening day there to-day to oheer them between the races. Besides the three over-night purse races there are the Swift Stakes for three-year-olds; the Bay Ridge Handicap for all ages, which Terra Cotta won last year and which he will try to win...
Plans were opened by the Sinking Fund Commissioners yesterday in the Mayor's office for the new Criminal Court building on Centrestreet, a block north of the Tombs.
The body of an unknown man, apparently about third-five years of age, was found in the woods in the neighborhood of Two Hundred and First-street and Eleventh-avenue at 11 o'clock yesterday morning.

The police of the Twenty-ninth Precinect, whose station house is in East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth-street, are much exercised over a statement in some of the afternoon papers yesterday that one of their number was a thief, and that there had been money, clubs, and revolvers stolen from the station house Capt. Westervelt said last night that there had been no clubs nor revolvers stolen.

CHICAGO, June 21.--Senator T.C. Platt of New-York and Gen. R.A. Alger of Michigan, with a party of friends, are on their way to Alaska. They arrived her to-day, and continued their journey this afternoon, via Omaha, leaving the latter city Sunday morning.

CHICAGO, June 21.--In the collision between the steam barge D.W. Powers of Muskegon and the schooner America, about four miles off the Marine Hospital, late last night, Simon O'Day, the Captain of the Powers, received injuries likely to prove fatal.

BOSTON, Mass., June 21.--In the action of tort of Myra Beale, formerly the wife of James H. Beale, to recover damages from Augustus Thompson for alienating the affections of plaintiff's husband by writing him a letter containing a false and libelous statement regarding...
ELIZABETH, N.J., June 21.--Dr. Victor Mraviag, a member of the City Council, offered an ordinance at the last Council meeting prohibiting the playing of music in the streets at a late hour of night.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., June 21.--S. Van Sciver, a young son of Edward Van Sciver of Burling ton, was drowned in the Delaware River, near his father's residence, this morning. He had some pike nets set, and arose at 4 o'clock to take them up. The boy, who was subject to fits, was found with his head over the side of his boat in three inches of water.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 21.--The convention of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers, which has been in session here for the past three weeks, adjourned to-night. The election of officers resulted as follows:

HELENA, Montana, June 21.--The driver of a stage line running from Fort Benton to Livingston says that on Saturday last the body of a middle-aged woman, who had been shot in the back, was found by a cowboy in a wild and unfrequented spot on Judith River.

ELIZABETH, June 21.--It is learne that Miss Nellie Reeves, who has been missing from her home, 3 Washington-avenue, in this city, since Tuesday, left with J.S. Hoffman, an advance agent for the Arthur Rehan Comedy Company.

LANCASTER, Penn., June 21.--Gen. Simon Cameron, who was stricken with paralysis at 12:30 o'clock yesterday, is lying in a critical condition at his home at Donegal, and his death is expected hourly. His condition is rendered more dangerous by reason of his advanced age and his recent illness, the hemorrhage which attacked him last May, and which many of his friends thought at the time presaged very serious consequences.
The boats on the Sandy Hook route now leave New-York, Pier 8 N.R., at 4:30, 10:15 A.M., 3:45, 5 P.M.; Sundays at 9:30 A.M.

In spite of the heat the pariors of the Reform Club were more than comfortably filled last evening with an audience of enthusiastic reformers, who had assembled to listen to an address by ex-Secretary of the Treasury Charles S. Fairchild upon "Tariff Reform." Everett P. Wheeler, the President of the club, introduced Mr. Fairchild in a brief speech, in which he criticised President Harrison's Administration in no measured terms.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 21.--The schooner Baltic of Provincetown, Capt, joseph Fisher, arrived here to-day from an Atlantic whaling voyage. Capt. Fisher had a thrilling experience last May while at Samana Bay, San Domingo, where he put in for water. He had previously visited the bay, (on Feb. 6,) and was boarded by the Officer of the Port, a General...

BOSTON, June 21.--To-day was Class Day at Harvard. The exercises of the day were initiated by the gathering of the Seniors in evening dress at Holworthy Hall, whence they marehad to Appleton Chapel, where religious exercises were held, the prayer being offered...

A dispatch from Ottawa saying that because a clerk had omitted the word "only" from a clause in the Weldon Extradition bill the bill was made retroactive and affects all of the boodlers in Canada was shown to District Attorney Fellows yesterday and he said:
NANTUCKET, Mass., June 21.--Papers and wreck stuff in considerable quantity have been picked up on the ocean side of Smith's Point, this island.

CHICAGO, June 21.--Interest in the Cronin case has been transferred to Winnipeg, where Martin Burke is in custody charged with the murder. Burke was to-day placed in line with fifty-two other men and identified by Martinson, the expressman who took the furniture to the Carlson cottage, as the man who hired him to do that work.

William H. Mudgett, aged forty-seven years, who boarded at 42 South street, was killed yesterday in the forenoon by a large log of mahogany falling upon him. Mudgett had been doing odd jobs along shore, and yesterday was employed in unloading logs from a lighter at the foot of Sixth-street.
SCRANTON, Penn., June 21.--The annual convention of the Father Mathew Society of the Scranton Diocesan Union was the scene of a startling incident this afternoon.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 21.--The bill providing for the retirement of the stock of the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company of this city and placing the control of the company in the hands of the policy holders was vetoed by Gov. Bulkeley this afternoon. The Governor holds that the provisions of the act...

President Hutchings presented to the Board of Street Opening and Improvement at its meeting at the City Hall yesterday afternoon a set of maps, and explained to the board that they represented the proposed plan for extending the streets in certain sections of the Twentythird Ward and Morrisania.

Dullness ruled yesterday's stock market. Prices did not go down, but neither would they go up. Wall-street is awaiting news, good or bad, of some pronounced character before making any move of consequence. The apprehension of a bad bank statement to-day tended to keep the bulls in a slow pace.

SCRANTON, Penn., June 21.--Considerable excitement has prevailed for some time past in the Masonic circles of Pennsylvania over the condemnation by Grand Master McCalla of a lodge belonging to what is known as the Corneau Rite of Scottish Masonry, established in Scranton about a year ago with sixty members.

PARIS, June 21.--The Senate committee which has been inquiring into the charge against Gen. Boulanger has entirely finished its work and forwarded all the documents laid before it to the Public Prosecutor.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 21.--The session of the Legislature which was concluded this afternoon has been the longest in the history of the State. It began Jan. 10, and has cotinued through the five months, with the single interruption of one week during the Washington centennial at New-York.

PRESCOTT, Arizona, June 21.--Ex-Chief Justice Wright yesterday sentenced Dan Harwick, William Stein, and James Halford, who robbed an express train on the Atlantic and Pacific Railway in April last, to twenty-five years each in the penitentiary.

PARIS, June 21.--The rivers have overflowed their banks and partially submerged the town of Bar-le-Due, in the Department of Meuse, and the surrounding country. Many houses have been undermined and destroyed and crops and vineyards have been ruined.

A field meeting of the Adelphi Athletic Club will take place this afternoon on the grounds of the Manhattan Athletic Club, Eighty-sixth-street and Eight-avenue. All the prominent Mahattan Club's athletes will compete.

At the examination for admission to the Normal College of the City of New-York, which took place on June 4, 5, and 6, candidates presented themselves from all the grammar schools,a number of private schools, and the Training Department of the Normal College to the number of 1,026.

A motion was made yesterday before Judge Andrews, in Supreme Court, Chambers, by Mr. Louis O. Vandorn, counsel for the Garfield National Bank, to punish Frank Colwell and bis counsel, William E. Ellison, for contempt of...
VIENNA, June 21.--The striking miners at Kladne, Bohemia, engaged in a riot last night The gendarmes fired on the rioters and killed two of them and wounded twelve.

SHANGHAI, June 21.--Li Hung Change has accepted the control of railways in the north of China, and it is proposed that Chang Chi Tung shall have control in the south. It is stated that tenders will soon be invited for the coustruction of a railway from Pekin to Han-Kow. The Government appears to mean business.

The Hungarian residents of this city held a mass meeting last evening to protest against the charges that had been made against their countrymen in the Conemaugh Valley of having plundered and mutilated the dead victims of the flood. Dr. Gerstner, who had been appointed by the Committee of Arrangements to...

Frank Miller, eleven years of age, son of George J. Miller, a cigarmker, living at 94 Beebe-avenue. Dutch Kills, L.I., died yesterday morning of hydrophobia. The boy was bitten nine weeks ago by a rabid dog owned by Michael O'Conner.

A big crowd enjoyed a rarely-good day's racing at Brighton yesterday, though a heavy sea fog, which prevailed during the last three races, interfered materially with the day's sport. The fields were altogether too large to be handled well on the narrow track, although starter J.F. Caldwell,...
I have heard an anecdote of John Gilbert which illustreates alike his own powers of memory and the characteristics of an old-time Washington-street dealer in dry goods on a very limited scale.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., June 21.--There was no trouble among the workmen here in any way to-day, and there seems to be a general belief that the authorities have won the contest and are masters of the situation. All the saloons in the place are closed by order of Gen. Hastings, and there was little or no disorder.

BERNE, June 21.--The Bundersrath, in reply to inquiries made by the Nationairath, denies that there are any grounds for the complaints made by foreign powers that Socialists are allowed too much freedom in Switzerland.
When asked yesterday concerning the letter addressed to him by the Reform Club about the failure to try Assemblyman Smith and others, indicted for bribery, District Attorney Fellows said:

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 21.--Great preparations are being made at the State Camp Grounds at Sea Girt for the annual encampment, which commences July S. Carpenters are erecting a large commissary building in place of the one destroyed by the storms of last Winter.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, June 21.--Gov. Francis E. Warren of this Territory is displeased by the statements made in in THE TIMES that he was removed from office by President Cleveland in 1885 for illegally fencing in Government lands. His fences limited the area that would be available to pre-emption and final ownership by letters of small means, whose industry makes...

BALTIMORE, June 21.--Cardinal Gibbons today ordained a number of students of St. Mary's and St. Joseph's Seminaries. Of these 6 were ordained priests, 9 deacons, and 18 sub-deacons, while 26 received the lower orders and 17 took the luitiatory steps toward confirmation, receiving the tonsure.
Matthew Hale of Albany is at the Murray Hill Hotel. Naval Constructor Philip Hichborn, United States Navy, is at the Astor House.

Last year the city of Peterson purchased a very eligible piece of property for a public park in response to an intelligent demand on the part of the citizens and subsequently secured the passage of an act of legislation authorizing the organization of a Park Commission.

CHICAGO, June 21.--The Chicago roads to-day formally surrendered to the Lake Superior lines all the through traffic from the seaboard to St. Paul and will hereafter use--local business with the Northwest to recoup the loss.

BALTIMORE, June 21.--It is said that the Directors of the Citizen's Passenger Railway Company are engaged in getting options from the stockholders for a syndicate, who have agreed to purchase the stock within thirty days from June 19, 1889.

The stockholders of the Nicaragua Canal Company held their annual meeting Denver, Col., yesterday. The report of the engineering corps sent out a year ago to make a preliminary survey for the canal was accepted.

George William Curtis made a pleasant addrees yesterday afternoon to the graduates of the Staten Island Academy and Latin School on the occasion of that institution's Commencement. He opened with a few humorous allusions to Staten Island's advantages as a residence quarter, insisting, among other things,...

Police Justice McMahon of Sheepshead Bay, acting as Coroner, held the inquest last evening at Coney Island in the case of Mrs. David Rowe, who was instantly killed on Saturday last on the Manhattan Beach Railroad in the rear of the Oriental Hotel.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 21.--Miss Maggie Harrison of Chicago, niece of President Harrison' narrowly escaped drowning at Lake Minnetonka yesterday afternoon through the capsizing of a boat in a gale.

An interesting letter from Toronto in yesterday's TIMES gave a clearer view than most American readers have been able to get heretofore of the present aspect of Canadian politics. Before and since the confederation the disturbing and threatening element in these politics has been supplied by the difference in race, language, and...

The portrait of Miss Terry as Lady Macbeth, shown by the artist Sargent at the New Gallery, London, excites the indignation of the Athenoeum, whose critic dislikes to see the powder and paint on the actress's face literally reproducted:
MANCHESTER, June 21.--To-day's contests in the jawn tennis tournament resulted as follws; Semifinals: Northern Cup-Messrs. Finch and Wolff Northern Place--Miss Pope and Miss M. Steedman;...

William E. Howard, the electric sugar swindler who was convicted of grand larceny a few days ago, was arraigned yesterday morning before Recorder Smyth in the Court of General Sessions for sentence. His counsel asked for a new trial, which was promptly denied by the Recorder, who then talked to the prisoner in terms which were strong.

LONDON, June 21.--There was a long debate in the House of Commons to-night on a motion by Mr, Ellis in favor of arbitration as a means of avoiding evictions in Ireland, Mr. Sexton and Mr. Balfour took part in the discussion. The motion was rejected by a vote of 248 to 178.
The Associate Alumni of the College of the City of New-York held their annual meeting at the college building last evening. Every clase from '53 to '89 was represented among the 500 men present.

Ex-Judge William H. Arnoux is very much pleased with the Committee of Seven which he, as President of the New-York State Bar Association, and in obedience to a resolution of that body, recently appointed to devise some method of relief for the crowded condition of the calendars of the circuit of the Supreme Court in the First Department, and the delays incident...

BOSTON, June 21.--A disastrous fire, accompanied by serious loss of life, occurred early this evening in the fireworks establishment of Heyer Brothers, corner of Summer and Hawley streets. There dead bodies have been taken from the ruins, and three others received injuries which will probably result fatally. It is feared that there may be more victims among the debris.

The Prohibitionists are still attributing the overwhelming defeat of the constitutional amendment in Pennsylvania to the hostile attitude of the "political machines." So far as we can make out, their resentment is due mainly to the failure of the Republican "machine" to exert its...
Tne differences existing among the Emigration Commissioners bid fair to entail a great deal of distress among the employes of the board, both at Castle Garden and on Ward's Island.

Still another voice complaining against the employment office of "Liverpool Jack" was heard yesterday at Castle Garden. It was that of Wilhelmina Block, who said that her brother, Andrew Block, was one of the unfortunate men who were led by "Liverpool Jack" to become laborers on the "railway in Costa Rica."

Bradstreet's reports 234 failures in the United States during the week, against 195 in the preceding week, and 177, 141, 161, and 184 in the corresponding weeks of 1888, 1887, 1886, and 1885, respectively. The Middle States bad 64. New-England 19, Southern 39, Western 97, Pacific and Territories 15. Canada had 28, an increse of 8 over the previous week.

BOSTON, Mass., June 21.--The National British-American Association held its final session to-day, with President Gooch in the chair. A Ritual and Password Committee was appointed, to report at the next annual convention.
WASHINGTON, June 21.--The President has made the following appointments:

A recent report of Dr. TRACY, Assistant Sanitary Superintendent of the Board of Health, on mortality in tenement houses will attract much attention both among sanitarians and the general public. The entire population included in this report is...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 21.--To-day was Presentation Day at Yale. The exercises of the graduating class were held in Battell Chapel this morning, and were begun by prayer by President Dwight. The class poem was deliveered by Thomas W. Buchanan of Albany, N.Y., and the oration by Hubert W. Wells of Louisville, Ky. The orator's theme was "Moral Activity as the Consequence of Higher Education."

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 21.--Angus McMillan of Little Rapids, River du Livre, has sold his phosphate mine to a New-York syndicate for $20,000. The operation of the mine on an extensive scale will be commenced immediately.

The pool tournament between De Oro and Manning, which began in Daly's rooms in Brooklyn on Thursday night, was continued last night. When the contestants stopped up to the table, Manning had 200 points to his credit and De Oro 137.

The managers of the New-York Club have been looking for new grounds ever since the old diamond at the Polo Grounds was taken away, and the chances are that by the time the club reaches home from the present Western trip a new inclosure will be in course of erection.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 21.--The Maxim automatic guns invented by Hiram Maxim were tested at the naval proving grounds to-day before a board of officers, composed of Lieutenant Commanders Maynard and Dayton and Lieut. Kimball.

LONDON, June 21.--The members of the Royal Yacht Squadron will meet early next week to decide in regard to the deed of gift of the America's Cup. Lord Dunraven does not think that the Valkyrie will compete for the cup.

Surrogate Coffin of Westchester County has admitted the will of Francis W. Lasak to probate. The testator died last February at Dobbs Ferry aged ninety-two years, leaving an estate variously estimated at between $1,000,000 and $3,000,000, mostly in real estate in this city.

NEW-LONDONG, Conn., June 21.--The eightcared, four-mile straightaway race between the Yale and Pennsylvania University crews was rowed this evening over the Thames River course from Gale's Ferry to Winthrop's Point and was won by Yale by one and one-half lengths. The official time of Yale was 23:50 and of Pennsylvania 23:56. A stiff breeze was blowing up the river against the crews, and over the first three miles the water was quite rough.

James W: Dally, who lives at Mount Kisco and is a contractor, owns several trotting horses which he thinks cannot be beaten in their class in the county. On Wednesday Gilbert M. Brundage, who was seated on his sulky behind his handsome stallion, told Daily he could beat anything in the stables.
ALBANY, N.Y., June 21.--The United Glass Company, capital $1,000,000, with the main office at Syracuse, Onondaga County, was incorporated in this city to-day.

There was a fire in the oil tank in the subcellar of C.T. Raynolds Co.'s establishment at 106 and 108 Fulton-street some days ago. Daniel Doberty, an employe, was badly burned. He was looking in the tank by the aid of a light, and the oil in some way ignited.

HANOVER, N.H., June 21.--President Bartlett reached here this evening after ten months' rest in California. The college students met him at the station and escorted him to Dr. Parker's residence. As President Bartlett stopped from the train he was greeted with cheers.
CHICAGO, June 21.--The swift racers and big grain carriers of the lakes have a new competitor between Chicago and Buffalo.

The closing of the Sacred Heart Academy, at Classon-on-the-Sound, was celebrated yesterday by the pupils, who, by the aid of their preceptors, the Christian Brothers, who have charge of the academy, were enabled to present a very pleasant musical and literary entertainment.
The Board of Electrical Control had a spasm of activity yesterday and sent a couple of inspectors to different parts of the city to lay low as many as half a dozen telegraph poles.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 21.--Judge Righter of the Civil District Court to-day decided the celebrated case of the State of Louisiana against the Amarican Cotton Oil Trust, giving judgment in favor of the State, maintaining the injunctions issued against the trust.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 21.--Princeton's scientific expedition to the "bad lands" of Oregon, under the leadership of Prof. Scott, left for their destination this morning. They will be gone till the middle of September.

Tha Rockaway Steeplechase Association has secured open dutes for its race meeting. Which is to be held on the pretty Cedarhurst course on Friday, June 28; Monday, July 1, and Wednesday, July 3.

The second attempt to sail the twenty-fourth annual regatta of the Atlantic Yacht Club was success. Unfortunately, interest in the event was lessened by the withdrawal of many notable yachts which started last week. Thus the fleet-winged Grayling, having no competition, was reduced to the necessity of sailing against...
The failure of the Versailles Woolen Company, inanufacturers of woolens at Versailles, Conn., whose New-York office is at 88 Leonardstreet, was reported yesterday.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 21.--Gov. Gordon has just appointed the following Municipal Government for the town of St. Mary's: Mayor--The Hon. Robert Tompkins; Aldermen--D.L. Lonh, A.C. Wright, J.R. Bachiott, F. Rudolph, and J. J. Vocelle.

ELIZABETH, June 21.--A new gas company, composed of New-York, Philadelphia, and Elizabeth capitalists, has been formed in this city with a capital of $100,000, and will prove a formidable rival to the gaslight company which has heretofore had a monopoly of the city lighting.
ALBANY, June 21.--The trotting ended at Island Park this afternoon with two races. A strong south wind blew up the home stretch, preventing fast time.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 21.--The marriage of Miss Anna H. Green, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bartine Green of Ocean Grove, and Edward Johnson of Asbury Park took place yesterday at noon. The ceremony was performed in the tent occupied by the bride's family by the Rev. Dr. Chandler, pastor of the Presbyterian Church.

An unsually large number of ocean passenger steamships of the large class arrived yesterday. The City Rome came in early during the afternoon; after her came the City of New York, and finally at nightfall, and just too late to receive inspection at Quarantine before sunset,...

Tne scenery on the stage of the lecture room of St. Francis Xavier's College looked very pretty last evening. The hall was brilliantly illminated and a happy throng of ladies and gentlemen, the relatives of the students, occupied the seats.

The Larchmont Yacht Club has issued its circular for the club's tenth annual regatta, to be sailed on July 4. The regatta will be open to members of the New-York, Eastern, Seawanhaka Corinthian, Atlantic, New-York Gorinthian,...

To encourage popular subscriptions THE TIMES will, in common with other newspapers, furnish lists on application. The fund for the construction of the proposed Washington memorial arch in marble is making very satisfactory progress, nearly one-half the amount required having been subscribed.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 21.--The State Board of Health endeavored to have a law passed last Winter that would enable it to step in where no local Health Board exists, in case of disease becoming epidemic, and organize a local board.
A cathoat, with sails set, was found on the beach at Fort Hamilton early yesterday morning, and in the cockplt lay a man, apparently dying.

The will of Susan Pine of Jamaica, L.I., who died over a year ago, was admitted to probate yesterday by Surrogate Weller of Queens County.

SAYBROOK, Conn., June 21.--Fenwick Hall was gayly covered with flags to-day in honor of the banquet which the Arms and Navy Club of Connecticut held this evening. The hotel had not been formally opened for the season, but Mr. Stokes, the proprietor, had prepared accommodations for the 150 veterans and their friends, and the grand banquet hall was fitted...
CAPE MAY, N.J., June 21.--President Harrison, accompanied by Postmaster General Wanamaker and ex-Senator William J. Sewell, arrived at Cape May Point to-night at 9:45 o'clock.

DECATUR, Ill., June 21.--A frightful storm prevailed in the central part of Illinois last night, and in this section particularly. For two hours the rain poured down in torrents and the streets were rivers of water. The thunder and lightning were unusually severe.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21.--Official returns have been received from every county in the State. The majority against the prohibitory amendment is 189,020. The majority against the suffrage amendment, providing for the repeal of the poli-tax qualification, is 235,540.
Alexander McKenna, a boy of eleven years, who lived with his parents at 411 Hamiltonavenue, Brooklyn, died last night in the City Hospital of alcoholism.

ITHACA, June 21.--The closing of Cornell University leaves Ithaca quiet. The students have gone to their homes the professors in various directions in search of recreation. President Adams's plans are undetermined, as his wife is still in a critical condition after a long sickness.
FRANKLIN, Ky., June 21.--William J. Hilton, a wealthy and miserly old merchant, who was thought to be on his deathbed in the back part of his store, groped his way into the store this morning.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 21.--The tennis tournament for the championship of New-England closed here this afternoon with a very exciting match between H.W. Slocum, Jr., of Brooklyn and R.P. Huntington, '91, Yale. Slocum won, the sets being 8--6, 9--7, 6--2. By winning, Slocum secures for his personal property the New-Haven Law Club Cup which he won in in 1887 and 1888.

Members of the New-York Athletic Club were jubilant yesterday over the good record made by Walter C. Dohm on Thursday evening at the club's track at Travers Island, when he broke the half-mile American record of 1:55 2-5, made by Myers in 1885, with a record of 1:55 1-5.

A suit is pending before Surrogate Abbott, in Brooklyn, to recover $21,757 from the estate of William A. Hoar, which if decided in the plaintiff's favor will leave Mr. Hoar's window and children penniless.

A number of visitors inspected the new funeral car Woodlawn yesterday, which the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company has just completed for the transportation of funeral parties to and from Woodlawn and other cemeteries.
CHICAGO, June 21.--There was good prospect of the bulls making a good record in wheat on the Board of Trade to-day, but it was suddenly spoiled.
Gustave Broch, the French cook who undertook to supply Mrs. Langtry's table for $15 a day, was the victor yesterday in the suit brought by him against his employer.
The condition of Dr. Duncan, who was supposed to be suffering from yellow fever and who was removed to Swinburne Island, was reported yesterday as having improved greatly.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., June 21.--At the graduating exercises of Rose Polytechnic Institute yesterday announcement was made that the postgraduate scholarships would not be awarded this year, all the members of the class having received positions in their professions which would take them into usefulness at once.
A careful and instructive account of Iowa is contributed to Harper for July by Mr. Justice Miller, and Mr. Curtis, in his Eassy Chair, gives a sketch of Mr. Miller's career.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 22.--One of the queerest characters in this region is Judson Ellis, aged sixty years, the literary hermit of the Delaware Mountains. The old man's abode is a single-room hut, built by his own hands in a wild and secluded nook of the Delaware Mountains, about ten miles back from Rock Rift station, ...

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 22.--The fact that Gov. Hill has approved of Assemblyman J.W. Morgan of Rhode Island, who falsely accused a brother officer of cowardice and who was appointed Commissioner of Indian Affairs by President Harrison, has accepted the appointment, to take effect July 1. His case will be one of "good enough Morgan" until after the Senate has met and considered it.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 23.--The nine college crews which are quartered at present on the banks of the Thames have taken life easily to-day, none of them having been in the shells. FAYETTEVILLE, Tenn., June 23.--Mr. A.C. Green, agent for the Jenny Electric Light Company of Indianapolis, Ind., who has made Fayetteville his headquarters for the past year left here about ten days ago with $3,000 in money on his person to go to Indianapolis. MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 24.--The Class Day exercises at Wesleyan College of the Class of '89 were held on the campus this afternoon and passed off very successfully. The officers were W.E. Smyser, President; E.H. Travis, Marshal; C.P. Truber, Secretary.

RED BANK, N.J., June 24.--The sea serpent has made his appearance for the season in the North Shrewsbury River. Four Red Bank young men recently took a sail down the river to Highland Beach.
John Richardson, who had been Superintendent of the Bureau of Incumbrances for four years, was removed from office by Commissioner Gilroy yesterday.

Richard J. Forresthal, a Western Union lineman, pleaded guilty yesterday in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions, before Judge Cowing, to a misdemeanor in stringing wires along Beaver-street without a permit.

Mr. Russell Harrison, the son of the President, arrived in the city from Helena, Montana, yesterday, and is stopping at the Gilsey House. He has engaged passage on the steamer City of New-York, which sails to-morrow, and his principal destination is the Paris Exposition. He will combine business with pleasure and further the interests of the illustrated weakly paper with which he is connected.
The works of the Manhattan Brass Company, at First-avenue and Twenty-seventh-steet, were completely destroyed by fire early yesterday morning.

PARIS, June 24.--The trial at Angouleme of MM. Deroulede, Laguerre, and Laisant, on the charge of rioting at that place recently, was completed to-day. M. Deroulede was acquitted of the charge of resisting the police, but convicted of the charge of rioting.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 24.--Shortly before 3 o'clock this morning the Vanderbilt Hotel in this city was discovered to be on fire, and flames were soon seen leaping through the roof.

ELIZABETHPORT, N.J., June 24.--A large number of young men went yesterday on a picnic to Vreeland's Mills, at Crawford. On their way home the big stage in which they were riding was upset. All the party was pitched headlong into the road, and few escaped without cuts or bruises. Fortunately, none was seriously hurt. The stage was badly smashed.
Secretary Tracy visited the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday afternoon and had a long talk with Commodore Ramsay. His visit was not an official one and he was not received with even a salute.

PANAMA, June 15.--The President of Peru has submitted to Congress the ad referendum arrangement made with Mr. Michael P. Grace for the completion of the repairs on the Oroya Railway of the damages occasioned by the recent inundations, the prolongation of the road to the Oroya, and the general reconstruction of the line.

PLAINGFIELD, N.J., June 24.--Word reached here last night that Herbert W. Peck had dropped dead of apoplexy at his grandfather's home in Connecticut, whither he had gone to regain his health.

BERLIN, June 24.--The marriage of Prince Frederick Leopold and Princess Louise of Schleswig was solemnized here to-day. The Emperor and Empress and many royalties were present at both the civil and religious ceremonies. A grand banquet followed, at which the Emperor toasted the newly-wedded couple. After the banquet the Emperor and Empress and the King of Saxony departed for Stuttgart.
The savor of old times was in the Wall-street atmosphere yesterday. And speculators who have mourned the absence of booms got booms enough. One quotation went up eight points; another rose ten.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 24.--The entries to the June trotting meeting at the Hudson River Driving Park are closed, and the meeting opens July 2, continuing four days.

NYACK, N.Y., June 24.--A war of races, imminent at almost any time in the upper part of Rockland County, broke out with fury yesterday, and it is feared that the end is not yet, although a large number of Deputy Sheriffs are this afternoon guarding the place.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 24.--The Government proposes to raise a new loan, the money to be used in the building of strategic railways and fortresses. The semi-official press here daily attacks Italy, while the Czar snubs Baron de Marochetti, the Italian Ambassador.

George H. Purser's funeral took place from the family residence, 37 West Eleventh-street, yesterday afternoon. The services were conducted by the Rev. Henry Wilson, assistant director of St. Goerge's Church, and by the Rev. Francis Clayton of Rutherford, N.J.

NORWALK, Conn., June 24.--A "Gentlemen's Driving Association" is a projected enterprise in this town. The Stamford syndicate which recently purchased the fair grounds is pushing the matter, and a canvass is being made of the towns in this vicinity.

LICK OBSERVATORY, SAN JOSE, Cal., June 24.-- Mr. Barnard discovered a faint comet this morning at 2 o'clock in right ascension 1 hour 21 minutes, declination north 38 degrees 51 minutes. The comet is moving rapidly to the north and east. This is the fourth comet found by Mr. Barnard at Lick Observatory.
The Identity of the young man who is said to have been thrown overboard from the barge Summer into the East River Saturday night was partially established yesterday as Benjamin Hatton, aged twenty.

An exciting runaway occured yesterday afternoon in Yonkers. Mr. A.B. Holliday and some friends were riding in his carriage, when the horses became frightened and dashed wildly down North Broadway, upsetting the carriage and throwing Mr. Holliday and this party to the pavement.

PEEKSKILL, June 24.--Every indication points to the fact that the Seventh has come to the camp of instruction for business and not for play. The current tour of the regiment has been singularly devoid of incident and prosaic to a degree up to the present time.

CHICAGO, June 24.--But little doubt remains that there was an inner circle in Camp No. 20 of the Clan-na-Gael organization, and the authorities are in possession of facts which go far to prove that the murder of Dr. Cronin was determined upon and planned by the members of this inner circle.
The will of S.B. Chittenden was admitted to probate yesterday in Surrogate Abbott's court, Brooklyn.
JOHNSTOWN, Penn., June 24.--A sweeping fire broke out in the First Ward at 12:30 o' clock this afternoon. The flames spread rapidly, and at 1 o'clock twenty houses were burning.

As is customary on the day following the arrival of a man-of-war in a foreign port, the Austrian steam frigate Saida early yesterday morning fired a national salute of twenty-one guns in honor of the country in whose waters she is a guest.
As was announced in THE TIMES a few days ago, workmen started yesterday to get in condition the new grounds of the Giants at Eighthavenue and One Hundred and Fifty-fifth-street.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 24.--News has reached this city that the Burlow dynamite works at Lodd's Station, on the East and West Railroad of Alabama, exploded to-day.

NEW-HAVEN, JUNE 24.--John I. Hutchinson of Essex, Sheriff of Middlesex County, expects this week to receive his commission as Collector of Internal Revenue for the District of Connecticut and Rhode Island.

Secretary of the Interior Noble was at the Windsor Hotel yesterday. He did not want to talk about politics. In his opinion it was wrong for the newspapers to say that there was any ill feeling between President Harrison and Secretary Blaine.

HELENA, Montana, June 24.--Disastrous timber fires are raging west of here on the Northern Pacific Railroad. Clark's Fork Bridge of the Northern Pacific Railroad, 600 feet long, was burned this morning. Much delay and damage are caused by the fires.
The steamship critic, which arrived yesterday from Leith, reported passing the largest number of icebergs sighted this season. All of them were very large ones.

Five Laborers and a boss worked all day yesterday on the subway manhole at the southeast corner of Centre and Walker streets. They labored on it several days last week, but made such slow progress that taxpayers in the vicinity began to protest.

Patrick Sweeney, a resident of Scranton, Penn., had his sister, Mrs. Mary Combey of Marion, Jersey City, arraigned before Police Justice Wansor yesterday on a charge of having abducted his two sons. The boy's mother died in May, and late in the month they disappeared.

WASHINGTON, June 24.--Assistant Secretary Batcheller to-day received a letter from the Produce Exchange of New-York City requesting the privilege of being heard on the subject of the location of a new Custom House in NewYork City. In reply he said they would be given the desired privilege on Thursday of this week.

Max Eichner, dealer in furniture at 76 Avenue B, made an assignment yesterday to Morris Hirtenstein. He began business Jan. 1, 1887, with a capital of $600. In January last a judgment was entered against him for $600 by the people as surety on a bail bond.

The Board of Police Justices met last night in the Jefferson Market Police Court, but did nothing. Six Tammany Justices and two Republicans were present.

The communication from the Hon. Mr. RUSSELL of the Tenth District, Massachusetts, which we published yesterday morning regarding the effect of the tariff upon wool, is likely to attract a good deal of attention if it is spread as it should be among the farmers of the Central Western and Western States.

Members of Holy Trinity Church in Harlem are embarrassed by a philantrophical proposition which will enable them to increase their work of practical charity, but which, owing to prudent reasons, they hesitate to accept.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 24.--This evening Thomas Gavan, a dissolute young man, whose widowed mother resides on Suydanstreet, entered the house as his mother was preparing supper and demanded money.

A strike has been in progress in Rockwell's bakery, at Seventy-fifth-street and First-avenue, the strikers saying that Mr. Rockwell wanted them to sign a pledge that they would leave the union, which they refused to do.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 24.--There is trouble in the Yale Freshmen camp, and up to a late hour to-night it was not definitely known whether the race with the University of Pennsylvania Freshmen would take place to-morrow as has been announced.

HIGHLANDS, N.J., June 24.--Mr. Neil Burgess, the actor, was seriously burned to-day at his residence here by an explosion or gasoline. Although his injury is severe, it will not prove fatal. The life of Mr. Burgess was saved by the heroic efforts of his wife.

Dr. J.B. Bogert, who was arrested for violating a health ordinance in neglecting to report the Dr. Duncan was suffering from what was supposed to be yellow fever, was arraigned in, the Adams-street court, Brooklyn, yesterday, and admitted to bail in $500 bonds. He is going to Montreal to be married and will return on July 10 to fight his case.
The new Board of Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge held its first meeting yesterday afternoon at the office on Sands-street, Brooklyn.
FREMONT, Ohio, June 24.--At 11 o'clock tonight Mrs. Hayes's condition is practically unchanged. She is still sinking slowly.
CARLISLE, Penn., June 24.--There was a large audience at Bosler Memorial Hall, Dickinson College, to-night to hear members of the Junior Class in their oratorical contest for the Pierson prizes.
People who went to the Windsor Theatre last evening to laugh soon got tired of it. The Chinese play began early in the evening. At 8 o'clock the house was crowded.

Mrs. Alicia Ann Stuart died at her residence, 227 West Twenty-fifth-street, Monday night, after an illnees of several weeks' duration caused by general debility resulting from old age. Mrs. Stuart was the mother of Stuart Robson, the well-known actor, and she was born in Annapolis, Md., in 1806.

Williams Jachson, an instructor in Columbia College, and Miss Dora Elizabeth Ritter, daughter of John P. Ritter, were married. The Rev. A.B. Carver, rector of the church, officiated. The bride were a gown of white silk, with heavy gold embroidery.

WASHINGTON, June 25.--The marriage of Miss Daisy Wood to Mr. Henry D. Nicholson, son of Commodore Somerville Nicholson, United States Navy, took place at St. John's Church, Georgetown, this morning.

The disposition to consider only the attractive features of unfamiliar social problems and to cultivate a philosophic indifference to their dark and painful characteristics is nowhere more strikingly shown than in the popular estimate of the Japanese Empire and people.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., June 25.--The 145 members of the One Hundred and Twentieth NewYork Regiment to-day dedicated the monument which marks their position on this battlefield. Gen. George H. Sharpe made the address.

The Directors of the Madison-Square Garden Company are considering propositions which may lead either to a sale outright of the property or to building operations on a splendid scale. A drawback to the latter, which was the original intention, is lack of funds.

VIENNA, June 25.--In the Delegations to-day Count Kulnoky made a long speech on the political situation. He expressed the belief that the peace of Europe was not at present endangered, although he admitted that the situation was unsettled and might easily change. He denied that Roumania was hostile.

ROME, June 25.--The Pope is preparing an important encyclical letter, which will be issued on Sts. Peter and Paul Day. As the Pope's time is largely occupied with this work all audiences at the Vatican have been for the present postponed.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 25.--Michael Rizzelo, alias "Red-Nosed Mike," was hanged in the jail yard here this morning.

By direction of the Secretary of War the appointpointments in the army, with the rank of Second Lieutenant, to date from June 12, 1889, of the following named cadets, graduates of the Military Academy, have been announced:

CHICAGO, June 25.--The Board of Trade enjoyed one of its big old-fashioned days to-day. The fun began mildly at the very first in wheat, and ended with a true bull climax at the tap of the closing bell. All day long there was a roar in the pit.
LONDON, June 26.--The Chronicle's Rome correspondent says: "Emperor William will pass through Rome and Naples en route to Athens. He will not visit the Pope.
The Sixth Auditor of the Treasury is one Gen. COULTER Of Ohio. It is hardly necessary to say that he is a Republican.

FREMONT, Ohio, June 25.--Mrs. Hayes died this morning at 6:30 O'clock, after passing the night quietly. At 8 o'clock last night she became much worse and gradually sank until the hour of her death.

HARTFORD, June 25.--The seventh national convention of the Bureau of Statistics of Labor opened in this city this afternoon. Carroll D. Wright of Washington was re-elected President, Samuel M. Hotchkiss of this city Vice President, and E.R. Hutchine of Dos Moines, Iowa, Secretary.
HELENA, Montana, June 25.--Sheriff Heyfron, with a posse of ninety men, left Missoula at noon for the Flathead Reservation to make a second attempt to arrest the Indian murdereres.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 25.--Henry Ray, a colored man, four months ago was sentenced to three months and ten days' imprisonment in the county jail for stealing from his employer, Druggist Louis Rothenberg.

Towne, General Manager of the Southern Pacific Company, has supplemlented his testimony given recently before the United States Senate Committee on Relations with Canada by an open letter of the committee as to the effect of competition of the Canadian Pacific Railway on American lines.

Francis S. Saltus died on Monday at midnight in the Riverside Sanitarium at Tarrytown, after an illness of several weeks. His trouble was a gastric one, and for several days prior to his death he had been unable to take solid food of any description.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 25.--The State Board of Agriculture estimates that there will be 127,000,000 bushels of oats harvested in Illinois this year and 4,072,000 bushels of rye.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25.--Mrs. Sarah Jane Wniteling was hanged this morning in the corridor of the county prison. The drop fell at 10:07 o'clock, and the body was lowered and removed at 10:41.

The Stock Exchange still gave more attention yesterday to trading in trust "securities" than to transactions in any of the ordinary, old-fashtioned, commonplace railway stocks. The "crowds" in Lead Trust and Sugar Trust monopolized most of the active brokers present in the Exchange Board Room, white all over Wall-street the retained contingent of fairy-tale dispensers kept public interest awake.

The hearing in the suit brought by Frank W. Sanger against T. Henry French to recover his alleged share in the profits accruing from the "road" performance of "Little Lord Fauntleroy" was resumed yesterday before Referee Daniel G. Rollins at 32 Nassau-street.

The twenty-fifth annual Commencement exercises of the Manhattan Commercial Academy took place at the Standard Theatre yesterday afternoon. Seven young men received their diplomas: Francis J. Conway, George J. Dougherty, ...

There were only eleven members of the Board of Education present at yesterday's special meeting, at which the awards of various commissions of appraisement of the value of school sites that the board were seeking to acquire under the law of eminent domain came up for consideration. Commissioner Gallaway, who is Chairman of the Committee on School Sites, was voted into the chair.

The Lyceum Theatre company of this city scored another brilliant success in San FranCisco on Monday evening with the production, for its second week's engagement, of Mr. Pinero's comedy, "Sweet Lavender."
Superintendent Billings of the Pullman Palace Car Company yesterday denied a rumor that on July 15 the colored porters on all of the company's routes would be replaced by white men, ...

BERNE, June 25.--As a result of the complaints made by foreign powers of the actions of Socialists and others in Switzerland, the Government has appointed a permanent Public Prosecutor in order to strengthen the control of the police over the movements of refugees.

Though there are no stake events on the racing card at the Sheepshead Bay track to-day, the six races have a good class of horses in them and should furnish some excellent sport. The programme for the day is as follows:
NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 25.--The unexpected came within a boat's length of happening here this evening in the race between the Freshman crews of Yale and the University of Pennsylvania.
The trust stocks were active again in Wallstreet yesterday, but their boomers were not in anything like so jubilant a mood as when they sent quotations spinning upward on Monday.

Gen. Thomas H. Hubbard of New-York City has caused to be placed in Memorial Hall, Bowdoin College, Maine, a series of brass tablets bearing in raised letters the names of the graduates and students of the college who served in the Union Army during the war of the rebellion.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 25.--Three thousand people attended the opening at the Syracuse Driving Park Association's races to-day. The day was fine and the track in good condition. Both races were hotly contested. The summaries:
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 25.--The first session of the Trustees of the Wesleyan University was held this morning. Judge George G.Reynolds was re-elected President and the Rev. Dr. Burr Secretary.
Some gossip has been occasioned in Orange by the postponement of the wedding that was to have taken place yesterday of H. Charles O'Reilly, a reporter, and Miss Jennie Grimes.

CORNWELL, Penn., June 25.--The Alumni of Trinity College, Hartford, Conn., are arranging for a unique reunion and encampment, which is to be held as Mount Gretna, Lebanon County, Penn., from June 28 to July 6, inclusive.

PARIS, June 25.--In the Chamber of Deputie this evening M. Laguerre asked leave to interpellate the Government in regard to the violation of Parliamentary immunity which the authorities of Angouleme had committed in causing the arrest and detention of M. Laisant and himself.

BOSTON, June 25.--The meetings preliminary to Commencement at Harvard began to-day, when meetings of the Law and Divinity Schools took place, and this evening every hotel and clubhouse in Boston is entertaining graduates at the class dinners.

Two complaints of forgery were made at the Jefferson Market Police Court against Henry A. Maas, who was arrested for swindling a number of tradesmen by means of forged checks purporting to have been signed by his father.
The Dwyer Brothers have purchased from J.F. Caldwell, who on Monday became his sole owner, the colt Starter Caldwell, two years old, by Ten Broeck-Miss Nailer.

WASHINGTON, June 26.--The following officers of bonds were accepted to-day: Registered 4 s, $50,000 and $25,000, at 106 7/8.

Andrew Whiteman, a private detective who was convicted of blackmail in the Sears divorce case and sent to Sing Sing, has begun an action in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn to recover $20,000 from Warden Brush and Keeper Connaughton for cruelty.
ELIZABETH, N.J., June 25.--Local politicians are discussing a row which took place last night between President Smith of the City Council and ex-Alderman Joseph Metzner.

WILKESBARRE, Peen., June 25.--Mrs. Charles H. Hall of Dallas, who for a day or two past has shown evidence of mental unsoundness, stepped into her husband's drug store yesterday and quietly swallowed a quantity of carbolic acid and corrosive sublimate.

COLUMBUS, June 25.--The Republican State Convention, the preliminary session of which was held this afternoon, is in a chaotic state. It is one of the largest ever held by the Republicans of Ohio, and promises to develop one of the hardest fights in the history of the party in this State.
SCHECECTADY, N.Y., June 25.--This was Alumni Day at Union College. The attendance was larger than for years before.

PEEKSKILL, June 25.--Capt. Don Alonzo Pollard reported for duty in camp to-day. The coming of the veteran senior company commandant, who had been detained in the city by imperative businees engagements, rounds out the list of officers of the Seventh Regiment.

The congregations of the First and Bergen Presbyterian Churches of Jersey City met last night and decided to consolidate under the name of the First Presbyterian Church.

Fifteen-year-old William P. Havemeyer of the Marlborough flat, who was charged by Mrs. Nellie Denton of 104 West, Fifty-third-street with insulting her, was discharged yesterday by Justice McMahon, in the Yorkville Police Court.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., 25.--A Corner's jury called to investigate the latest of many deaths on the railroad in this city closed its labors to-day.

The spring circuit trotting meeting began at Charter Oak Park this afternoon on a good track and with quite a crowd of spectators. Billy Stewart was favorite in the 2:20 pacing class and won his race in straight heats.
AUBURN, N.Y., June 25.--Bourke Cockran made his argument to set aside the sentence of Kemmler to death by electricity before Judge Day this morning.
CHICAGO, June 26.--Provisions broke away today from their old leanings. Though Armour, Cudahy, and other leaders failed to come to the front, the trade showed a bullish tendency from the start.
STUTTGART, June 25.--The Emperor and Empress and the King of Saxony arrived here today. The Emperor and Empress were received with great enthusiasm by the people.

Surrogate Ransom will not be at the Surrogate's Court to-day, although it is the day set for the argument in the Stewart will contest. That the negotiations for the settlement of the case will be successful is generally believed.

The answer of the Baltimore and Ohio Employes' Relief Association to the bill of complaint of Isaac S. Conley, who recently applied for the appointment of a receiver of the association has been filed.
WASHINGTON, June 25.--A large assemblage gathered in the Gaston Memorial Hall of Georgetown College this morning to witness the seventy-second annual graduation exercises of that institution.
NEW-HAVEN, June 25.--A report coming from reliable authority is that a controlling interest in the Shepaug Railroad has been bought by the Westport syndicate.

NEW-HAVEN, June 25.--The work of remodeling the old Sheffield homestead on Hillhouseavenue for the use of the Sheffield Scientific School has begun. The building will be devoted to the departments of botany, physiological chemistry, and biology.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., June 26.--Acting surgeon Foster of the Fourteenth Regiment and laboring camps reported this morning that within the last twenty-four hours forty-nine laborers were taken seriously sick with symptoms of typhoid fever. Many of them were sent home, and the others are being cared for in the hospital.

Grammar School No. 41, the pride of the old Ninth Ward, held its graduation reception yesterday morning, and Principal Elizabeth Cavaunah had a hard task to accommodate the hundreds of fond parents who called to inspect the school and its methods.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26.--The statement of the business of the Baltimore and Potomac Railroad Company for the month of May shows gross earnings of $138,839, being an increase of $7,453 as compared with the same month last year.

HANOVER, N.H., June 26.--Dartmouth's PhiBeta Kappa men met this morning at 9 o'clock. At 10:30 Prof. L.T. Townsend, D.D., of Boston University delivered the Alumni oration. His theme was "The Christian college the Safeguard of the Republic." In discussing it be said that there are three methods of government, ...

PARIS, June 26.--The Figaro says that at the request of the senate committee which made an investigation into the charges against Gen. Boulanger the payment of Gen. Boulanger's pension has been stopped.

CHICAGO, June 26.--With the exception of the first inning this afternoon New-York played a faultless game. Welch was in the box for the Giants and pitched a good game, keeping what hits were made well scattered. For Chicago Krock was pounded unmercifully, New-York making sixteen hits off his delivery for a total of thrity-one bases.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., June 26.--At the last session of the annual convention of the American Society of Civil Engineers Capt. R.E. Peary of St. Louis read a paper upon ship canals. The annual election will be hold in New-York next January. The place for holding the next convention has not yet been decided on.

READING, Penn., June 26.--United States Marshals from Philadelphia went to Fleetwood, in this county, to-day, and arrested Dr. A.N. Fretz and David M. Kline on the charge of frauds on the Pension Department. It is alleged that they accepted too excessive fees in collecting pensions.

The American manufacturers of silk, mohair, and wool braids, finding cause for complaint in the alleged undervaluation of goods by their foreign competitors, and feeling in their business the pressure of the inconsistencies of the American tariff laws as at present arranged, are endeavoring to form an association for the purpose of correcting the existing evils.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 26.--At the death of Gen. W.T. Withers, the well-known trottinghorse breeder, it was the general opinion that his famous trotting establishment, Fairlawn, would be sold and his horses disposed of under the auctioneer's hammer.
The price of coal was pushed up again yesterday at a meeting of the sales agents held at the office of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 26.--The most sucsessful commencement season that Union college has known in many years closed to-day, when twenty men were given the degree of A.B. and eleven of A.M. Besides these the university graduated during the year twentythree in law, forty-two in medicine, and twentysix in pharmacy--122 in all.

Dr. Duncan, the surgeon of the Pacific Mail steamship Colon, who was removed to the Quarantine Hospital some days ago suffering from what was alleged to be yellow fever, was discharged from the hospital on Swinburne Island yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 26.--John F. Beggs, Senior Guardian of Camp 20 of the Clan-na-Gael, is looked up in a cell at the Central Station on the charge of complicity in the murder of Dr. Cronin. Beggs spent last night in a cell at the Warren-avenue station, ...
