The way that auction sales of real estate have of knocking out tradition and conservatism was illustrated at the partition sale of the estate of Edward Burke at the Real Estate Exchange yesterday. Mr. Burke was a wholesale butcher in Washington Market.

The Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange begins to-day a new system of trading in the certificates of crude petroleum. It is proposed hereafter to do business so that the seller in any month shall have the optin of a delivery during the ensuing month.

LATROBE, Penn., June 26.--A triple collision of freight trains occurred on the Pennsylvania Railroad near here about 2:30. o'clock this morning. At the hour named freight train No. 308, west-bound, left Latrobe, and had just reached the bridge about fifty yards west of that place when it collided with extra freight ...

ELIZABETH, June 26.--A fashionable wedding took place last night at St. John's Church. Miss Lita Roberts, daughter of Mr. J.P. Roberts of Elizabeth, was married to Henry O. Prentiss, son of the Rev. George R. Prentiss of NewYork.

ELIZABETH, June 26.--The second annual Commencement of the High School took place to-night at the Temple Opera House. Frederick J. Faulks delivered the salutatory. The valedictory was delivered by Miss May Bloomfield.

Mexico appears to be turning to American capital for a development of her resources. The State of Tabasco, in Southern Mexico, on the Gulf coast, has just placed in the hands of William P. Burr, an attorney in this city, the authority to contract for improvements in its capital city, San Juan, on the Grijaiva River.

Though there were no stake events in yesterday's racing programme at sheepshead Bay, there was a fine day's sport and as good a class of horses in two or three of the events as the stake races bring together on the days on which they are run.

The Dutch steamer Prins Willem I., which left Port an Prince June 20, arrived yesterday morning. On board of her were Stephen C. Preston, a son of the Haytian Minister at Washington; Gen. La Forest, Military Governor and Procureur de Roi of Port an Prince; Leon Hutinot, ...
DENVER, June 26.--Articles for the consolidation of the proposed Denver and State Line Railroad with the Rio Grande and Western have just been filed with the Territorial Sec retary.

SARATOGA, June 26.--In the Court of Appeals today, present the Hon. William C. Ruger, Chief Justice, and associates, the following business was transacted: No. 723--Mary F. Williams and another, respondents, vs. Joseph Walker et al., appellants.

LANCASTER, Penn., June 26.--Gen. Simon Cameron died at 8 o'clock this evening. The General's condition during the day was rather encouraging, and death came suddenly from a weak spell. Up to the last attack he was conscious and had no trouble to swallow the food given and which he appeared to assimilate.

Comedian George W. Larsen, who was last season with the "Fate" company, distinguished himself at the Actors' Fund rooms at Fifthavenue and Twenty-first-street, yesterday afternoon by temporarily "knocking out" Mr. J.J. Spies, the agent of the organization.

CHARLESTON, S. C., June 26.--Dr. McDow told the story of the killing of Capt. Dawson twice to-day, once on the direct and again on cross-examination. He was on the stand for two hours. He presented a haggard appearance, and was as white as a sheet when he began to testify, but before his story had half been told ...

Annie Sanchez, alias Dubois, who so brutally beat and burned Della Boyce, the seven-yearold daughter of the man with whom she was living, was yesterday sentenced by Judge Martine to pay a fine of $500 and spend one year in the penitentiary.

CARLISLE, Penn., June 26.--The Hon. Stewart L. Woodford of New-York addressed the literary societies of Dickinson college this morning. His subject was "The Relations of Capital and Labor," and, after comparing the condition of labor at this age with that at the time of the birth of Christ, he showed that the scientific progress of the world had lifted labor up.

The fiftieth performance of "The Brigands" was given at the Casino last evening. The house was crowded, and the faint odor of perfumery from the gorgeous sachots presented to the ladies as souvenirs of the occasion permeated every part of it and escaped into the open air of the roof garden.

Drizzle won in England as well as at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, the English Drizzle being Lord Durtham's five-year-old inare, who won the Northumberland Plate, for which King James ran second and St. Mantias third. The Athens Plate, for twoyear-olds, at the windsor meeting, was won by Nermandy, by Robert the Devil, with touch-McNot second, and white Abbey third.

The Italian bark Columbus, Capt. Manganaro, from Smyrna, arrived yesterday after a voyage of eighty-four days. Capt. Manganaro reported the Herbert Shourts, sixteen years of age, a Philadelphian, ran away, died from general debility while on the voyage and was buried at sea.

LONDON, June 26.--Mr. Sexton, member of Parliament and Lord Mayor of Dublin, appeared before the Parnell Commission to-day. Mr. Sexton would not say that he opposed the principles of the Fenian Society. He claimed that boycotting was a necessary evil.

There will be some excellent racing at the Sheepshead Bay track to-day, for all the six events on the card will have good fields, which the exception of the June Stakes for two-yearolds, out of which Blackburn seems to have frightened nearly all the eligible lot.

In removing Zachariah J. Halpin from the place of Postal Note Agent at New-York, President Harrison and Postmaster General Wanamaker have once more shown their disregard for the spirit of the civil service law. Mr. Halpin was appointed by President Cleveland in 1885, and no charges of any kind have ever been made against him.

PEEKSKILL, June 26.--A rainstorm broke over the camp at midnight last night, and to-day the work of the Seventh's tour has suffered from an overplus of moisture. To a certain extent, it may be said, the storm was favorable to the regiment's record, since it came at an opportune moment, ...

ST. PAUL, June 26.--One of the greatest failures in the history of the Northwest occurred to-day, the Eureka Improvement Company of this city making an assignment with liabilities between $700,000 and $1,000,000.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 26.--A telegram from Marshalltown states that "Charles Johnson of this city, the well-known agent of the State Knights of Pythias Insurance Association, died suddenly at Spirit Lake, Monday evening.

LONDON, June 26.--England has declined to guarantee the evacuation of Egypt, which was demanded by France as a condition of her acceptance of the Egyptian coversion scheme. The scheme has therefore been abandoned. France also demanded the annulment of the Anglo-Turkish convention of 1887.

CLINTON, N.Y., June 26.--Hamilton College has an addition to its Faculty in the person of Prof. William R. Terrell, who has been elected to fill the Chair of History, Political Economy, and Law. He is an Alumnus of Williams College, and is a thoroughly capable, scholarly man and a successful teacher.
PITTSBURG, June 26.--A handsome gold medal was sent to Washington to-day for a novel purpose.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 26.--Walter Hamp, a butcher from Lancaster, Penn., murdered his wife here to-day and then committed suicide by shooting himself. About six months ago Hamp's wife, after possessing herself of as much of her husband's money as she could get hold of, abandoned her home and fied with one Henry Doerr.

KINGSTON, Ontario, June 26.--During the past three weeks Bishop Cleary has received several telegrams from Ireland asking if be would accept the Bishoprie of Waterford, but he had on every occasion replied that he objected to his name being brought forward and voted on.

Messrs. Dan Talmage's sons, this city, have the following from their southern correspondents respecting the movement of the domestic rice crop and stock ahead. Carolina--Receipts, cleaned, 63,975 barrels.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 26.--The HarvardColumbia Freshmen race, which was to have been rowed to-night, has been postponed until 5 P.M. to-morrow. At 5 o'clock the Columbia launch, with the referee on board, steamed over the course, and on returning announced that the water was too rough, and postponed the race for one hour. At that time, 6:30, the referee declared the race postponed until to morrow.

DES MONIES, Iowa, June 26.--Complaints have been filed with the Board of Railroad Commissioners by certain shippers of Davenport and of Burlington against the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific and the Burlington, ...

The success of the scheme of the American Fine Art Society to erect a building by the side of the new homes of the Century Club and the Academy of Medicine in West Forty-third-street, for the occupation of the Soceity of American Artists, ...

George B. Ormsby, who was lately dismissed from the navy, has entered suit in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia against Secretary Tracy for $100,000 damages for trespass incident to his recent imprisonment at Mare Island, California, his trial, and dismissal.

Daisy Sadler and Mamie Parrarria, the two Brooklyn girls who disappeared last Saturday and were found at Mayville Junction, N.Y., were taken to their homes yesterday by a Brooklyn detective. Both admitted that their story of having been enticed away by a strange woman was a fabrication.

COLUMBUS, June 26.--The Republican State Convention to-day did precisely what THE TIMES predicted it would do three weeks ago, nominated Joseph Benson Foraker the fourth successive time as its candidate for a third term.

WHITMAN, Mass., June 26.--Joseph Macomber, aged eighty-three years, committed suicide last night by cutting his throat. He had been an inmate of the poorhouse here for the past eleven years. At one period of his life he was wealthy and had quite a reputation as a lecturer on astronomical subjects. He is not known to have left any relatives.

FALL RIVER, Mass., June 26.--At the United States Fish Commission at Wood's Holl this season arrangements are being perfected for a series of exhaustive researches in the deep sea. The laboratory has been placed in charge of Dr. H.V. Wilson.

A lively session of the Board of Electrical Control was held in the Mayor's office yesterday afternoon. The discussion covered every phase of the conduit question, even reviving the controversy whether iron pipes or cement ...
LONDON, June 26.--The Portuguese Government to-day canceled the concession it had granted for the building of a railroad at Delagoa Bay.

Edward M. Morgan, recently in charge of the branch office known as Station D of the Post Office, was appointed Superintendent of the city delivery by Postmaster Van Cott yesterday, in place of John Richards, who resigned.
HARTFORD, June 26.--There were two exciting contests at Charter Oak Park this afternoon. In each instance favorites came to grief, and both races were close and interesting.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., June 26.--Among the recent arrivals at this place are Vice President Levi P. Morton and family. They will spend a portion of the summer here. The distinguished guests are being entertained by W.A. Street, Mrs. Morton's brother-in-law, who owns a commodious Summer villa on the bluff. It is thought that President Harrison will spend a week here in August.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26.--The iron trade was somewhat surprised this afternoon by the announcement of the failure of S. Robbins Son, manufacturers of bar iron, plates, and pig iron, who made an assignment, to Edward H. Wilson, one of their creditors.

The council of the Academy of Medicine, one of the foremost societies of physicians in this country, met in its house, 12 West Thirty-firststreet, last night and considered Charles George Wilson, the Tammany President of the Board of Health.

No news except the cablegram published yesterday has been received to throw light upon the position taken by the Royal Yacht Squadron of London in relation to the Earl of Dunraven's yacht Valkyrie entering a race for the America's Cup.

DELAWARE BREAKWATER, Del., June 26.--The steamer William R. McCabe ran into and sunk the schooner Jessie w. Knight off Sharp's Island, Chesapeake Bay, at 1 o'clock A.M. yesterday. The Captain, his wife, and one of the crew of the schooner were drowned. The steamer was not injured.
FLUSHING, L.I., June 26.--Commencement exercises were held at St. Joseph's Academy this afternoon before a large gathering of visitors from New-York and Brooklyn.

BOSTON, June 26.--a clouded sky tempered the heat for the Harvard commencement today, and made it one of the most enjoyable occasions of the kind for many years. The attendance of Alumni was large, and from the meeting of the Overseers at 9 o'clock until the close of the commencement dinner late in the day there was no cessation of literary activity and scholastic interest.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., June 26.--The season was opened at the Spring House here on Saturday. Richfield is as lovely as ever. Its hills and vales and lakes are full of beauty, the air is soft and balmy, and the flowers are fair and fragrant.

CHICAGO, June 26.--The application of the Chicago and Alton for permission to reduce the passenger rate between Chicago and Denver to $26 has been denied by the Western States Passenger Association. Nevertheless the reduced rate will be put into effect July 1.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 20.--Colored people are demanding the right to ride on a merry-go-round on Lake-avenue. william Nelson was ejected from the building last night by John Krause. a fight followed, and both were arrested and fined. The colored people say they will insist upon their rights.
EDGEWOOD, N.Y., June 26.--A man named Robert Brown, who resides near Fox Hollow, is credited with having killed a bear about five miles from this Catskill Mountain hamlet on Monday afternoon.

HOTEL KAATERSKILL, N.Y., June 26.--The thirty-third annual convention of the NewYork State Press association is being held at the Hotel Kaaterskill. About one hundred representatives of daily and weekly newspapers of the State, with members of their families, are in attendance.

Yesterday was commencement Day at the Brooklyn central Grammar school, on Nestrandavenue, and 130 young ladies were graduated from there last night. Principal Calvin Patterson presided and Nelson J. Gates attended to represent the Board of Education. Mr. Gates presented the diplomas and Superintendent of Instruction Maxwell made a brief address.

Mayor Chapin yesterday appointed Gen. John B. Woodward, the Rev. Dr. Richard S. Storrs, and Theodore F. Jackson Park Commissioners. Gen. Woodward and Dr. Storrs were appointed for the short term, ending Jan. 31, 1890, and Mr. Jackson for the long term, expiring Jan. 1, 1891.

The malaria of Hunter's Point is material as well as moral. It fact it was the physical effluvia of that suburb that called the attention to it, ten years and more ago, of thousands of New-Yorkers who would otherwise have been blissfully unaware of its existence from one year's end to another.

The Engineering and Building Record has received from Thomas Hawksley, F.R.S., of London, the designer of the famous Vyrnwy Dam for Liverpool's water supply, a check for 50 as his contribution to the Johnstown relief fund.

ISHPEMING, Mich., June 26.--The Duluth and Boston limited train, known as the transcontinental flier, will be put on July 1, passing over the Duluth, South Shore and Atlantic from Sault Ste. Marie to Duluth, a distance of 400 miles.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 26.--When the Burke extradition case was resumed this morning before Judge Bain, Mr. Howell, Q. C., asked for a further remand, which was strongly opposed by Mr. Perdue, who, with Mr. Campbell, appears for the prisoner. He argued that there was not a tittle of evidence against Burke.

FREMONT, Ohio, June 26.--The funeral of Mrs. Hayes will take place at spiegel Grove, the Hayes residence, at 3 o'clock on friday afternoon, and will be public. The services will be brief and will be conducted by the Rev. Dr. McCabe of the Ohio Wesleyan University.

Sylvester of 206 East Thirty-second-street, reported at the East Thirty-fifthstreet police station on Tuesday night, that he had been called to attend Mrs. Kate Emmons of 204 East Thirty-second-street, who, he had been told, had attempted to commit suicide by shooting hereself in the head with a pistol.

A large audience greeted the Rev. Charles Spurgeon, son of the great English preacher, in Calvary Baptist Church, Fifty-seventh-street near Sixth-avenue, last evening. The subject of his lecture was "Nails," and he illustrated it with specimens of the genuine article and some hammers.

Fourteen-year-old Miranda Terrell, a servant, attempted yesterday to poison her mistress, Mrs. Letitia Mott, at her home in Patchogue, L.I. While eating her dinner yesterday Mrs. Mott drank a cup of coffee.

Judge Andrews, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday reserved his decision on a motion for an injunction to prevent Venable Heyman, importers of Johannis Spring Water, from selling it in bottles labeled similarly to the bottles in which Apollinaris water is sold.

Fire broke out in the Federal Telephone Company's Building at Montreal yesterday morning and spread to the Stock Exchange Building adjoining. The two upper floors of the Exchange Building were completely gutted, entailing a loss of $5,000. The Federal Company's loss is about $23,000, and insured as follows: National, $7,500; Atlas Fire Insurance Company, $5,000; Commercial Union, $3,000.

PATERSON, N.J., June 27.--Tunis Labee, a Hollander, about thirty years old, was hanged at Paterson this morning for the murder of his wife, whom he stabbed last February because she refused to live with and support him in idleness.

PITTSBURG, June 27.--The new rules providing for trading in petroleum futures went into effect to-day and completely upset things at the Petroleum Exchange. The brokers did not seem to understand the new system and but little business was transacted. The range of values up to noon was only a cent.
LATROBE, Penn., June 27.--The work of clearing away the wreck here is progressing as rapidly as possible.

The water tank was swept away, leaving the troughs between the tracks without the usual supply of water. The damage was repaired by noon to-day.

CHICAGO, June 27.--It is now pretty generally conceded that the low commodity tariff, which goes into effect on business to St. Paul July 5, will also be extended to the Missouri River.

HARTFORD, June 27.--The Spring trotting meeting was continued at Charter Oak Park this afternoon with three good races and the best attendance of the week.

CHICAGO, June 27.--When New-York came out to practice before the game this afernoon, "Buck" Ewing said the Giants has not changed their suits since yesterday's game, having slept in them last night. As the last man for NewYork went out in the ninth, Gumbert told "Buck" the fourteen hits by New-York substantiated his statement.

WASHINGTON, June 27.--Mr. Edward O. Graves, Chief of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing and formerly Chief of the National Bank Redemption Bureau of the Treasury Department, sent his resignation to Secretary Windom to-day.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 27.--George and Freddie Sanisky, aged respectively twelve and twenty years, were drowned in the Des Moines River at this point yesterday. George was bathing and got in water below his depth. Freddie went to his brother's rescue, losing his life in the attempt.

CHICAGO, June 27.--The Chicago and Alton Railroad is growing more and more aggressive. It has always been held that the roads having lines west of the Missouri River should break the bulk of their east-bound freight at that point instead of carrying it through solid to Chicago, and thus give the roads terminating at the river a chance to secure a share of it.

Mr. ROOSEVELT, in giving an account of the recent tour of inspection made by the Civil Service Commissioners, says: "We feel fully convinced that the greatest service we can render the cause of civil service ...

CLINTON, N. Y., June 27.--Hamilton College, always prominent for the oratory of its students, held Commencement exercises to-day which did especial credit to the institution. Every speaker spoke with that finish, grace, ...
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 27.--The Democratic State Committee met here to-day and did what they could to insure Republican success in Iowa this Fall.

Ruger, Chief Justice, and associates present, the following business was transacted: No. 751--Kingsland vs. Tucker.--Argument resumed by Sidney S. Harris for appellant and concluded. No. 743--William H. Owens, respondent, vs. Henry T. Cromwell, appellant.--Argued ...

Further engagements of gold for export gave a back-set to yesterday's stock market, which, after being fairly firm all day, weakened at the close and put final quotations at the lowest point of the day.

Antonio Cortez, alias Emanuel Perez, alias Charles Drayton, who was arrested on Wednesday for having swindled a number of tradesmen by worthless checks, was arraigned before Justice Ford, at the Jefferson Marked Police Court, yesterday morning.
The funeral services over the body of Roland Greene Mitchell, who died of heart failure on Monday last, were held yesterday morning at his late residence, 8 West Nineteenth-street.

The trunk line Presidents accepted the resignation of Albert Fink, Commissioner of the Trunk Line Association, yesterday. They did it because there was no other course left them. Mr. Fink insisted on resigning. No long vacation would suit him.

The ambition of A.B. Atkins, a Brooklyn newspaper man, to be one of Collector Erhardt's Deputy Collectors has stirred up some more trouble for Mr. Erhardt. A committee of Brooklyn Republicans called at the Custom House yesterday to protest that Atkins should not be appointed.
The following are the weights for the Knickerbocker Handicap, at a mile and three-eighths, to be run at the Sheepshead Bay track to-mor row afternoon:
The Judges of the City Court held a meeting in the Special Term room yesterday to take action in regard to the death of James B. Sheridan, who was for several years a Judge of the old Marine Court.
ST. LOUIS, June 27.--Pierre Lorillard has been in St. Louis for four days trying to effect a plug tobacco combine, and he has failed.

HANOVER, N.H., June 27.--The first event of the one hundred and twentieth annual Commencement Day at Dartmouth College was the prayer meeting in Rollins Chapel at 8:30 A.M. At 9 o'clock an adjourned meeting of the Alumni Association was held, but no business of importance was transacted.

An Augusta bank cashier recently told me about a queer experience. There came into his bank a seedy man with a wild look in his eyes, who said: "I guess I'll take that money." "What money?" "There's five hundred thousand to my credit here, ain't there?"

LONDON, June 29.--The Standard's Rome correspondent reaffirms the correctness of his communication announcing the Pope's condemnation of the Clan-na-Gael. The correspondent also says that the Pope will decline to interfere in the matter of the complaint of some Irish Bishops against the harsh treatment of Land Leaguers in prison on the ground that it is their own fault, they having disobeyed the decree against boycotting.

The marked peculiarity of yesterday's weather was the absolute lack of a cooling zephyr to encourage perspiring man in his struggle for comfort against a rising thermometer. Even at 3 A.M. the air was so still that the flame of a burning match hardly flickered.

Calvary Presbyterian Church has flourished since it was organized about six years ago with 26 members. Its first home was on One Hundred and Eleventh-street, near Third-avenue, and from there it moved to One Hundred and Thirteenth-street and Madison-avenue.

More Brooklyn politicians visited the Custom House yesterday to see wheat could be done toward heading off A.B. Atkins of that city from getting a Deputy Collectorship. His friends were there also, and a letter was received from Franklin Woodruff setting forth that Mr. Atkins was a stanch Republican.

A dispatch from Ashland, Wis., announces that Judge Parish in the Circuit Court directed a verdict for the plaintiff in the case of Fred C. Prentice of this city against Mayor Beasor and others. Martin Beasor, father of Mayor Beasor, over thirty years ago sold to A.B. Butterfield ...

HARRISBURG, Penn., June 28.--All that was mortal of Gen. Cameron will be laid at rest tomorrow afternoon in the beautiful cemetery that lies beyond the city. Neighbors and friends will carry his body to the tomb, and the Rev. Dr. Chambers of Harrisburg will conduct the services. No change has been made in the arrangements for the funeral previously announced.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 28.--Asher D. Cohen and Judge Magrath addressed the jury to-day in the McDow murder case in behalf of the prisoner. Mr. Cohen asked that his client be acquitted on the plea of self-defense.

OTTAWA, June 28.--American lumber merchants who are in the city to-day were asked if the reduction in the export duty to $2 per 1,000 feet on pine logs would satisfy the demand for retaliation. "In my opinion it won't," said one of them.

BOSTON, Mass., June 28.--Gov. Ames was seen to-day with regard to the report published this morning that he intended to go into the field as a candidate for Congress in the Second District, now represented by the Hon. E.H. Morse.

VALPARAISO, Ind., June 28.--James B. Harvey, agent of Swift Co. of Chicago, was arrested at Hammond last week and fined $50 by a local magistrate for selling in that city dressed beef slaughtered in Chicago. He was committed to jail for failure to pay the fine. On Monday he was taken before the Hon. William Johnson, ...
WINDSOR, Vt., June 28.--A big jam of logs formed at the railroad bridge yesterday, and although the ten or twelve logmen worked gallantly they were unable to make a break through the tangled mass.

The Directors of the Michigan Central Railroad met at the Grand Central Station yesterday and declared a dividend of 2 per cent, payable Aug. 18. The following statement for the six months ending June 30 was presented, (June being partly estimated;) Gross earnings, $6,233,000; operating expenses and ...

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 28.--Judge Edwards has rendered a decision in the matter of the application of the Attorney General to bring an action to annul the corporation of the AtlanticAvenue Railroad Company of Brooklyn in favor of such petition, giving leave to bring an action. The following is the memorandum Judge Edwards has written in the case:

The Eleventh Assembly District Republican Association met last evening in Tom Gould's old hostelry in West Thirty-first-street, near Broadway. About forty patriots were present, all afflicted with the itch for office. A letter from Robert Ray Hamilton, resigning the Presidency of the association, was read.

OMAHA, Neb., June 28.--Yesterday morning S.C. Morgan, cashier of the State Bank of Sidney, was found lying in bed with the top of his head blown off and a revolver in his hand. The bank, it is said, was not making money.

The long-talked-of extension of the Brooklyn water-works system came up before a committee of the Aldermen last night, and, after an hour of discussion, it was decided to adopt the plans submitted by Chief Engineer Van Buren.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment appropriated $65,000 in December last to enable the Fire Commissioners to build a fireboat. Commissioner Robbins yesterday informed the board that a proper boat could not be built for ...
PATERSON, N.J., June 28.--John Gottfried, a German silk weaver, about eighty years old, employed in Adams's silk mill, was last seen alive on Wednesday night.

An autopsy was held yesterday on the body of Benjamin Hatton, who, it is charged, was thrown overboard while on the excursion of the American Bank Note Company, and it was discovered that his neck was broken.

Many of the best known citizens of New-York were among the mourning friends who yesterday attended the funeral of Col. William Henry Woods. The Rev. Dr. Henry M. Field, one of Col. Woods's closest friends, come down from his country home in New-England to officiate.

A gang of men in the employ of the Western Union Telegraph Company were busy yesterday afternoon laying a cable containing ninety-one electrical conductors in the subways in Parkrow from Broadway to New Chambers-street.

NEW-HAVEN, June 28.--It is believed that Yale will remain in New-London to row against Cornell. "Bob" Cook has refused to row a three-mile race, and has received a challenge for four miles. Every man in New-Haven to-night is a Yale man and all are celebrating the common victory.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 28.--The will of President Horatio N. Case of the Pynchon National Bank at Springfield, Mass., is to be contested by the Connecticut relatives of the deceased. President Case left an estate worth half a million dollars at least. By the will, which was executed in 1850, one week prior to his marriage, ...

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 28.--The negotiations between the Government and Mr. Anderson of London for the establishment and maintenance of a fast line of steamships between Quebec and Plymouth have been brought to a successful termination. The details have been arranged between the contracting parties, and today the Minister of Justice finally approved of the form of contract between them.

CHICAGO, June 28.--Nothing was done at today's meeting of the Western Freight Association to change the Northwestern situation. The fear was generally expressed that unless the application of the low commodity tariff was restored the break in rates would extend to local ...

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., June 28.--The situation in Johnstown is growing brighter every day. Eighty thousand dollars in cash arrived to-day to pay the men in the various departments. It was distributed among the contractors and the heads of the departments to pay the men under them.

The veterans of the Thirtieth Regiment, NewYork Volunteers, left Troy, N.Y., yesterday on a special train for Hoosick Falls, where the twentyeighth anniversary of the regiment's master into service was celebrated. Representatives from companies in Troy, Albany, Lansingburg, Poughkeepsie, and Valatie joined the veterans. A delegation from Post Tibbetts of Troy and Post Bolton of Lansingburg also attended.

CHICAGO, June 28.--For the first time since the Grand Jury began its investigation into the Cronin murder those in a position to know believe that an indictment will be returned against Alexander Sullivan for complicity in the crime.

Gilmore's Band has returned to Manhattan Beach, and the popular leader offers two exceptionally good programmes for to-morrow, with solos by Signor Def Puente, Signor Stengler, Signor Raffaylo, Signor Italo Campanini, Signorina De Vere, and Miss Helen Dudley Campbell, Pain's pyrotechnic spectacle, "The Last Days of Pompeii," will be given this evening.

HALIFAX, N.S., June 28.--The crew of the brigantine New Era, from Pictou for St. John, landed at Locke Port this morning, their vessel having foundered last evening. At noon yesterday the Captain judged himself well to the westward of Cape Sable Light.

The Trustmakers and their spokesmen are now telling the people that among the advantages gained by the suppression of competition in a great industry is a marked reduction of price, and that this reduction can be made because the cost of production is largely reduced by combination. LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 28.--Sprout Post, G.A. R., of this city held a meeting to-day to psotest against the remarks made by Mayor Oliver at Albany regarding the veterans of the war in his row with Gen. Sickles, Chairman of the Civil Service Commission.

Col. Marshall McDonald, United States Commissioner of Fisheries, having visited the Mechanicsville dam in the Hudson one day last week, says that he found salmon there jumping at the dam in their ineffectual efforts to get above it.

The Dock Commissioners yesterday informed Mayor Grant that the Board of Aldermen acted under a misapprehension in adopting on Wednesday last a resolution denouncing the scheme to permit a change of the North River front from Tenth to Twenty-third-street.

ALBANY, June 28.--A certificate of incorporation was filed in the Secretary of State's office to-day of the Natural Gas Company, organized by Francis Forbes and George S. Bixby, residents of New-York City, and Emanuel Stein of...

The Kings County Wheelmen opened their eighth annual race meet at the Washington Park Ball Grounds, Brooklyn, yesterday. The attendance was fair, but not what might have been expected considering the victories the Kings County men have won this season.

The difficulty between the management of the Southampton docks and the North German Lloyd Steamship Company having been satisfactorily settled, the steamers of the latter company will, in calling at the port of Southampton, proceed up Southampton water to within a mile or two of the city instead of anchoring in Cowes Roads.

Neighbors of Michael Birmingham of NewKirk-street, Jersey City Heights, are talking of the manner in which he treats his twelve-yearold son Tommy. The boy wears a flatiron, chained to his wrist, and is confined to the house and back yard.
A large number of prominent Catholics, cleric and laic, were attracted to the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon by the Commencement of Manhattan College.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 28.--Prof. Newton issued a statement to-day that the increase in the number of examinations for the Freshman Class this year is almost 10 per cent., both for the college and for the scientific school.
WASHINGTON, June 28.--The President made the following appointments to-day: Minister Resident and Consul General at Hayti. --FREDERICK DOUGLASS of the District of Columbia.

ALBANY, June 28.--The purchase of the large tract of land in the Adirondacks known as the Durant tract by a syndicate of five capitalists residing, two in New-York, two in Albany, and one in Cincinnati, is now an assured fact. The Albany men are Henry Patton and Thomas McGraw, and one of the New-Yorkers is Conrad N. Jordan, ...

CAMBRIA, Iowa, June 28.--W. McGinnis, living about six miles north of here, has been showing symptoms of mania for some time. To-day Sheriff Ramsey, of Lucas County, Deputy Rollins, and a man named Blouse went to McGinnis' house to take charge of him.

A slight fire which originated in A.D. Wilson's pork packing establishment, at South First and Driggs streets, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon caused a panic among a number of girls employed on the top floor.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 28.--The New-York State Hop Growers' Association, in session at Oneida, voted to hold the annual convention and picnic of the society at Sylvan Beach, Oneida Lake, July 27.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 28.--Fair weather and a good track brought out a large attendance at the last day of the June meeting of the Syracuse Driving Park Association. The races were trotted with these results:

Lieut. (junior grade) George M. Stoney has been ordered to examination for promotion; Assistant Surgeon George T. Smith to duty at the Army and Navy Hospital, Hot Springs, Ark.: Mate P.C. Van Buskirk to the receiving ship Independence; Gunner Thomas R. Wilson to appear before the Retiring Board.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 28.--In an extra edition to-night the Times-Star says: "It was learned this morning that William Means has gone to Germany and is on the borders of Switzerland.
WASHINGTON, June 28.--To-day's bond offerings aggregated $35,000, as follows: Coupon 4 s, $5,000; $8,000 at 106 7/8. Registered 4 s, $12,000; $10,000 at 106 7/8. All were accepted.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 28.--A commandery of Knights Templar, the first in the city, was instituted here last night by Mr. Albert D. Winfield of Paterson, Grand Commander, assisted by the Grand officers of the State. St. John's Commandery of Elizabeth and a delegation from Damascus Commandery of Newark were present at the ceremony, which was followed by a banquet.

NEWARK, N.J., June 28.--Adam L. Brown, the delinquent Bloomfield Postmaster, who was to have been examined to-day before United States Commissioner Jones, did not appear, but the latter said to-night that he understood that the deficiency was not as great as reported, and that Brown had made good the amount to his bondsmen.

While the members of the Fourteenth Regiment were practicing at Creedmoor on Thursday Private George Lambert of Company D, who lives at 351 Wyckoff-street, Brooklyn, was seized with convulsions. A train took him to the Flatbush-avenue station and Surgeon Frank Tetamore of the regiment sent for an ambulance.

At the meeting of the Board of Oversees of Bowdoin College, Maine, on Thursday the honorary degree of LL.D. was conferred upon the Hon. Hugh McCulloch, the Hon. William Peirce Frye of the Class of '50, and the Hon, William W. Virgin of the Class of '44. Tae honorary degree of D.D. was conferred upon the Rev. Americus Fuller of the Class of '59 and the Rev. William Scott Southgate of the Class of '51.

CONCORD, N.H., June 28.--In an editorial in his paper Senator William E. Chandler charges Dr. Jacob H. Gallinger, the opposing candidate for United States Senator, with organizing the attacks which were made upon him (Chandler) in the recent Senatorial contest.

RUSHFORD, Minn., June 28.--A combined cyclone, waterspout, and hailstorm passed from one to five miles east of here last night, destroying everything in its path. It probably gathered over the town of Wiscoy, Winona County; ...

The third race at the Coney Island Jockey Club races on Tuesday next will be a selling race at a mile and a quarter, with $3,000 the highest selling price and $1,000 the lowest. On the same day the last race on the turf will be at a mile and threeeighth, with $1,250 added, the conditions being: "Three-year-olds to carry 115 pounds; four years, ...

LONDON, June 28.--Murray's Magazine announces that Prince Albert Victor, eldest son of the Prince of Wales, has been affianced to Princess Victoria of Prussia, a sister of the Emperor of Germany. With the announcement the information is given that the Queen will give the Prince a marriage settlement and that Parliament will not be asked to make provision for him.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 28.--The annual Commencement exercises of the Newburg Free Academy took place this evening at the Academy of Music. Harvey B. Fleming was the salutatorian and Miss Carrie G. Felter the valedictorian.

New-Yorkers who live in the pretty village of Clifton, N.J., and are commonly called "commuters" by the natives, are having a hard time of it. They say that the real aboriginal Jerseyman, such as inhabit Acquackanonk Township, ...

More people went to the pretty grounds of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association at Cedarhurst yesterday than have ever been there before to enjoy the luxury of amateur racing. The means of getting to the track were even worse than they have been in past years, ...

LEBANON, Penn., June 28.--The special train from New-York over the Pennsylvania Railroad bringing the Faculty, Trustees, undergraduates, and Alumni of Trinity College, who are to be the guests of Mr. Robert H. Coleman at Mount Gretna Park until July 6, arrived at Mount Gretna this evening. The visitors number over two hundred. They are encamped at Mount Gretna Park, which is the camping ground of the National Guard.

Public Works Commissioner Gilroy gave several Tammany men a boost into the heaven of well-paid office holding yesterday, and put a corresponding number of County Democrats into the deepest gloom. Water Register John H. Chambers having resigned at his request he appointed Joseph Riley to the vacated place.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 28.--G. Pimple of Gretna Manitoba, a short time ago bought two thrashing machines of the Minnesota Machine Company of Stillwater, Minn. The Canadian Government seized the machines because they were prison-made. Pimple now sues the Canadian Government for $1,000 damages. The authoriites are in doubt whether to destroy the machines or send them back to the United States.

RONDOUT, N.Y., June 28.--A nurse girl employed by L. Hurry of Saugerties was out walking with the children one day recently. Seeing some handsome daises in the grounds of the late Joseph Sheffield, the children entered and were busily engaged plucking the flowers when they espied a snake in the grass.

HARTFORD, June 28.--The Spring meeting at Charter Oak Park ended this afternoon with two races. It was uncomfortably hot for the spectators, but a good day for fast time, as proved by the performance of Gean Smith, ...

The Brooklyn Board of Estimate got to work again yesterday, and found that some of the policemen whoso salaries were raised on Thursday were dissatisfied. The discontented ones were the nineteen Captains, who were raised from $2,000 to $2,200.

PARIS, June 28.--The medals of honor of the Paris Exhibition in the Art Department have been awarded to John S. Sargent, who sent six portraits, and W. Gari Melchers, who exhibited four large canvases.
Chauneey M. Depew made an application to the Treasury Department some time ago for the free entry of an oil painting of Cornelius Vanderbilt by Leon Bonnat.

LONDON, June 28.--At the Largs (Scotland) regatta to-day the Valkyrie made the first round in 1:51:03, the Irex in 1:54:18, the Yarana in 1:54:42, and the Marjorie in 1:56:50. The Valkyrie won. Time--5:26:17. The others came in as follows: Irex, 5:30:04; Marjorie, 5:34:41; Yarana, 5:41:35. The Yarana was second by time allowance.

ERIE, Penn., June 28.--The town of Edinborough, these at of the Edinborough State Normal School, is excited by the second attempt of firebugs to destroy the town. A few weeks ago they burned two large mills and set fire to a valuable State building, but it was saved.

The officers of the Brush Electric Illuminating Company made an inquiry yesterday into the circumstances attending the death of Edward Quinn, the chief foreman of the dynamo room, who was killed by an accidental shock of electricity on Thursday night.

LONDON, June 29.--The steamship Persian Monarch, (Br.,) Capt. Bristow, from New-York June 15, arr. at London yesterday.

LONDON, June 28.--A special Cabinet council will be held to-morrow to consider the Delagoa Bay Railroad question. It is expected that a portion of the Cape of Good Hope squadron will participate in a naval demonstration at Lisbon.

NEWARK, N.J., June 28.--Charles S. Hearst of 1,238 Arch-street, Philadelphia, who says he is a diamond broker, jumped from a Pennsylvania Railroad train at the Walnut-street crossing in this city to-night, and broke one of his legs. He was taken to the City Hospital.

A new political party that wants to befriend and champion the workingman has started in business. Its full title is the Progressive Reform Party of the United States of America, and John McMackin, who was the chief of the defunct United Labor Party, is to be its prophet.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 28.--At the meeting of the American Medical Association to-day the report of the librarian, Dr. Kieninschmidt of Washington, was read. Dr. W.H. Welch of Johns Hopkins University made an address.

There have been no large catches of weakfish during the past week in the lower bay, though few parties have been entirely unsuccessful in their efforts to procure specimens of this brilliant-tinted species of the finny tribe.

The General Term of the Supreme Court, in an opinion written by Judge Dugro, confirmed the judgment of the trial court in dismissing the complaint in the suit of the Oregon Improvement Company against the executors of John Roach. The suit was for $100,000 damages for an alleged breach of warranty in the construction of a steamship for the Oregon Railway and ...

FREEHOLD, N.J., June 28.--The one hundred and eleventh anniversary of the battle of Monmouth will be observed with appropriate ceremonies to-day. The exercises will include a visit to the monument and a dinner at the Union Hotel in the afternoon.

The new Brooklyn Park Commissioners appointed by Mayor Chapin have not yet qualified, and probably will not do so until September. One is in Europe, another is about to go abroad, and the third is summering at Shelter Island.

FREMONT, Ohio, June 28.--The funeral services of Mrs. Hayes were simple and unostentatious. They were opened with the reading of the Twenty-third Psalm by Mrs. Hayes's pastor the Rev. J. M. Mills of the Methodist Episcopal Church.
The Citizens' Excise Reform League of Brooklyn has adopted resolutions explaining its position on the excise question and closing with the following clause:

PITTSBURG, June 28.--To-morrow the 1888-9 scale of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers expires, and unless the manufacturers reconsider their determination there will be smokeless stacks and silent machinery at all the iron works in this section Monday.

GAINESVILLE, Texas, June 28.--Gus Dobbs, who was acquitted last term of the District Court of the charge of bringing stolen property into this State, was arrested yesterday by Deputy Marshal Car on a charge of theft. He was being taken to Purcell handcuffed and chained to a seat on the north-bound Santa Fe passenger train.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 28.--Blue are the rippling waters of the Thames, blue the NewEngland skies, and blue are the colors of Yale, but bluer than any of those, or of all of them combined, are the hearts of the Harvard men.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 28.--Squire Pitchor of this place, after a year's diligent search, has captured the notorious fugitive, Jacob Riley, known throughout the State as "Slippery Jack."

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 28.--Up to the seventh inning the home team had the game well in hand. In that inning, however, a wild throw by Denny sent the ball in among the crowd and 2 runs were let in. This was followed by other errors, which allowed New-York to score 4 runs in that inning.

There are some beautiful illustrations of family feeding at the public trough among the Tammany politicians. It is believed that Excise Commissioner Edward Fitzpatrick's family's good fortune seldom has been equaled in this country, and the other Tammany chieftains gaze upon him with unmitigated envy.

The graduating exercises of the girls' department of Grammar School No. 69. Fifty-fourthstreet, near Sixth avenue, Annie M. Hoffmann Principal, occurred yesterday afternoon and were well attended. Excellent entertainment was provided by the pupils in the shape of recitations and vocal anti instrumental music.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 28.--Commencement exercises were held to-day in the public schools of this city. The averages of the graduates in the grammar departments were unusually high this year. A feature of the exercises was the music and singing of the pupils in the different schools.

A stupid and ill-planned scheme to burn the Knickerbocker Conservatory at 44 West Fourteenth-street, or a plan to make it appear that such an attempt had been made, was brought to the notice of a policeman of the Fifteenth Precinct between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday morning ...

Miss Grace Wade, who says she is an actress, has begun a suit in the Supreme Court, Brook lyn, to recover $10,000 damages from a firm of cigarette manufacturers for libel, in having circulated miniature pictures of herself clad in tights. An application for a bill of particulars was denied by Justice Cullen.

The lubricating effect of a post-campaign, thoroughly-good dinner, served with all the charms of a perfect evening by the seashore, upon the jarring wheels of the political machine, bas not been demonstrated so perfectly in many seasons as it was on Thursday night at the Manhanset House, on Shelter Island.

Judge Andrews, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, issued an attachment against Gaetano Amoroso of Palermo, Italy, in the suit brought against him by the fruit importing firm of J.D. Nordlinger of this city.

HURON, South Dakota, June 28.--The Republican State Central Committee yesterday afternoon issued a call for a Republican Convention to nominate officers for the new State of South Dakota, to be voted for in October. The first convention will be held here on Aug. 28, and will be composed of 448 delegates.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 28.--The steamer Bay Queen of the Continental Line and the steamer Eolus of the Wickford Line came into collision at 10:45 o'clock this morning just above Gould Island, five miles up Narragansett Bay. The Bay Queen was on her downward trip and the Eolus was going up. A thick fog prevailed. Neither had much headway on, yet the collision was a serious one.

NEW-HAVEN, June 29.--The New-Haven City Directory for the year 1889 has just been issued. It contains 37,574 names, indicating, as the compilers say, that the city has a population of between 80,000 and 90,000.

The indications to-day are that the strike among the mountain miners in Pennsylvania will be farreaching in its effects. Those employed at Gallitzin, Lilly's, Sonman, and Ben's Creek are now reported out, with the single exception of the miners in the employ of W.H. Piper Co. at Sonman. About 1,000 men are affected, and it is probable that those employed by the Crosson and Coalport Coal and Coke Company will also go out.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 29.--The season here is opening slowly. This week has been quiet almost to dullness, the religious exercises not having begun in earnest and the number of guests being hardly sutficient to start into activity the amusements of the later Summer. Tents are going up rapidly on every hand and not a few of the occupants have already arrived.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 29.--The season of 1889 starts out with flying colors, and everybody here is feeling in excellent spirits over the present condition of affairs and prospects. The season has taken a spurt this week, and at least 275 cottagers are now established here for the Summer. NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 29.--This afternoon New-Brunswick had a reproduction of the story of the bull in the china shop. James Mensen was driving on Hiram-street, when his horse ran away and dashed at full speed into the crockery store of R.M. Addis.
CHARLESTON, S.C., June 29.--Dr. McDow was acquitted to-day of the murder of Capt. Dawson. This verdict was rendered on the ground of self-defense.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., June 29.--The season at Lake George has been a little backward, partly owing to the rainy weather and partly on account of the decision reached by the proprietors of the larger hotels to open at a later date than heretofore. OAK BLUFFS, Mass., June 29.--Already many yachts have appeared in the harbors of Martha's Vineyard. The steam yacht Oneida, Capt. E.C. Benedict, was here this week and the guests on board enjoyed the hospitalities of the Oak Bluffs Club. The Cavalier of the Atlantic Yacht Club anchored off the clubhouse on Sunday last and sailed westward on Monday.

HELENA, Montana, June 29.--Two weeks ago a man named Perry killed another in a dispute over a horse race at Silver Lake. Perry escaped to the hills, and ever since a large posse has been in pursuit.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 29.--Two colored Emigration Commissioners from Texas have arrived here to consult with Government officials in regard to procuring land for a large colony of colored cotton raisers from Texas.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 29.--The Rev. Peter Claude Creveling was to-day instituted as rector of St. John's Church, Cornwall, by the Rev. Dr. W.R. Thomas, Archdeacon of Orange. The Rev. E.M. Reilly of Burlington College delivered the institution sermon.

MONTE CARLO, June 2.--Until quite recently the principality of Monaco did not possess a prison. The one which exists here at present was built a short time ago for the detention of a murder r who had been sentenced to hard labor for life. For the first six months of its tenancy all went well.

A lonely hamlet in the depths of a Moravian pine forest. It consists of but five low cottages, built of rough stones and thatched with straw. For light the peasants burn pine logs upon the hearth. The flickering gleam of their red flames shines through the small windows and is lost in the gloom of the forest.

There will be an unusually large number of conventions of learned bodies in Europe during this Summer--about twenty are announced to take place at Paris alone--but none will be more interesting than the Eighth International Congress of Orientalists, which is to convene at Stockholm and Christiania from Sept. 2 to Sept. 13.

LANSING, Mich., June 29.--The final act of the Legislature last night was to pass a new general election law. It is a modification of the Australian system.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 29.--The ejection of several colored men by the proprietor of one of the beach resorts last Wednesday night and the disgraceful row between white and colored loungers which ensued have again directed public attention to the color line controversy. This question is of annual recurrence, and is one of the most difficult matters the town authorities and the bonifaces have to deal with.

WASHINGTON, June 29.--Secretary Tracy has received the report of the Board of Visitors to the Naval Academy at Annapolis. It convened June 1, and organized by the election of Commodore George Brown as President, Senator Butler as Vice President, and Lieut. Wainwright as Secretary.

SARATOGA, June 29.--The Court of Appeals dissolved yesterday after a four weeks' session. The Judges go home, not, however, for a vacation from their labors, but for hard work on the cases already heard, and when the court convenes in the Fall a large batch of decisions will be handed down.

LONDON, June 29.--For the moment our stern alarms are changed to merrymaking. This week every polite person in these latitudes has been to the great cattle show at Windsor, where royalty disported itself day after day, and the most magnificent display of live stock to be seen in the world was on view, and next week nothing will be talked of but the arrival of the Shah, unless it be the Henley regatta.

A renewal of activity in the Brooklyn Navy Yard will accompany the advent of the new fiscal year beginning July 1. In some instances it was found necessary recently to suspend navy yard work in consequence of the exhaustion of appropriations. LENOX, Mass., June 29.--The cool weather of the past week has made long drives a feature of life in Lenox. There is very little gayety at present, and about the only amusements of the cottagers are driving, riding, and tennis.

PITTSBURG, June 29.--It may be safely said that there will be no strike in the iron mills over the wage question this year. The officials of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Stee1 Workers were notified to-day that sixteen firms had signed the scale.

PORT HURON, Mich., June 29.--This morning about 8 o'clock as the west-bound express train on the Chicago and Grand Trunk Railway was passing Emmett at the rate of about forty miles an hour it struck a misplaced switch and went into a ditch. KALIFAX, N.S., June 29.--Yesterday afternoon, during a thick fog, the steamer Yarmouth, from Yarmouth for Boston, ran into the brigantine Fannie B. Tucker of Portland, Me., about thirty miles off Cape Ann. The brigantine went down at once. All of the crew but one scrambled on board the steamer.

LONDON, June 29.--Mail advices from West Africa confirm previous reports of the shocking privations to which Mr. Stanley has been subjected. It is stated that his hair has turned snow white, that his clothes are in rags, and that he is without shoes, being obliged to use skins to cover his feet.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 29.--Stock in the Hossier Baseball Club is way below par. This week joy reigned in the heart of every follower of the club when the Bostons were beaten in three games, and they had reason to believe that their favorites would repeat the dose to NewYork's representatives. This belief was nurtured in the bosom of every crank in town, and to-night they are as blue as only baseball cranks can be.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30.--The authorities at the navy yard in their anxiety that none of the appropriation should go to waste put to work a while ago a number of men. The money being now exhausted, with the end of the fiscal year of the Treasury Department, eighty-seven men were discharged last night.
