PHILADELPHIA, June 30.--The famous Pennsylvania high-license law, which has done so much to decrease the number of saloons in this city and in Pittsburg, and has given substantial prohibition to many counties, has had the bottom pretty well knocked out of it by a decision announced by the Supreme Court last Friday.
LISBON, June 30.--It is rumored that the Port-- uguese Government will agree to submit the Delagoa Bay Railroad question to arbitration.

Amateur photographers are greatly delighted with the news that in a few days a perfectly transparent gelatine emulsion film, sufficiently flexible to use in a roll holder, will soon be placed upon the market by the Eastman Dry Plate and Film Company, the pioneers in the film discoveries.
It seldom happens that naval officers are heard clamoring for sea service, and yet this is exactly what the officers of such ships as the Boston, Chicago, Atlanta, and Yorktown are doing.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 30.--Senator Higgins is in hot water over his recent appointments to office, and the disgust that was so freely expressed by Democrats at the time the appointments were made is now openly re-echoed by Republicans in all parts of the State.
The appointment of the Earl of Zetland to the office of Viceroy of Ireland has been fairly well received, for if a good many Unionists would like to see the post abolished at once, they have...

The Mets defeated the Cuban Glanta yeaterday at Weehawken by a a score of 16 to 1. At Recreation Park yesterday afternoon the Gramereys of Yorkville defeated the Manhattan News nine in a game of baseball by 13 to 5.

LONDON, June 30.--Discount during the past week was quoted at 1 to 2. The usual six months demands caused a temporary advance, which is certain to be followed by a fresh decline. On the Stock Exchange during the week business was very quiet.
The Rev. Charles Spurgeon of London preached in the Baptist Church of the Epiphany yesterday morning to a congregation which filled the auditorium.

A sleeping-car conductor on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, who is fond of a joke, had considerable fun out of one on a recent trip West at the expense of a passenger who probably will not know about the part he played in it until he reads this.

CHARLESTON, West Va., June 30.--Some of the Federal appointments which have been made in West Virginia since the new Administration came in are so bad as to be a very decided set-back to those citizens who have been hoping for an improvement in practical polities, while the respectable element of all parties...

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 30.--The Tradesman of July 1 will publish a statement showing the industrial situation in the South as exhibited by the number of new industries established during the last three months.

The fiscal year ended yesterday. The period for which all appropriations are made, and as to which all estimates of revenue and expenditure are arranged closed. We gave yesterday morning the chief facts in the statement of the Secretary covering the year.
ST. PAUL, June 30.--The presence here of Villard and a number of other Northern Pacific magnates has caused a good deal of speculation as to the object of their recent trip through the Northwest.

There appears to be an uncontrollable disposition on the part of mankind to give those who have never enjoyed the luxury what we call "middle names," or at least middle initials, and of all letters in the alphabet H seems to be the favorite.
BOSTON, June 30.--An English firm of rubber manufacturers, the largest house in Great Britain, has bought the foreign patents and complete plant of C.J. Bailey Co., the Boston...

Michael Dowdell, alias Berdy, who is under indictment for stealing a purse from a woman, was arraigned at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday for theft. Michael Corcoran, an electrician, was engaged on Saturday in...
LONDON, July 1.--The steamship Rotterdam, (Dutch.) Capt. Vanderzee, from New-York June 20 for Rotterdam, passed the Lizard yesterday.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., June 30.--This was the quietest Sunday since the disaster. The number of visitors was not as large, and most of them went to the broken dam. Religious servers were held on the street corners by the people whose churches had been washed away. Gov. Foraker of Ohio was expected to-day, but he did not come. The division of local funds will take place to-morrow.

PROVIDENCE, June 30.--The new Cathedral of Sts. Peter and Paul, the seat of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Providence, was consecrated to-day. It is a large red sandstone structure, occupying a commanding position at the junction of High and Westminster streets, on the west side of the city, and fronts on the square...

WASHINGTON, June 30.--When the Senate takes up next Winter the nomination of William T. Sorsly of Mississippi to be United States Consul at Guayaquil, to which office he was appointed by President Harrison yesterday, there will probably be a very lively political discussion.

Christian Webber and his wife of 126 Chrystiestreet were yesterday, in the Essex Market police Court, by Justice Power ordered to give bonds in $400 to keep the peace for one month. Almost seventy years have rolled by since Webber and his wife were born.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 30.--It is understood that the application of the Canadian Pacific Railway to the United States Treasury Department in regard to bonding privileges over its short line through the State of Maine to the Candian seaboard has been withdrawn.
The fleet of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club will assemble to-day at Oyster Bay, in the Sound, and begin the annual cruise of the club.

--A biography of John Ruskin, by W.G. Collingwood, is nearly ready for publication in London, and a complete bibliography of Ruskin's writings is in preparation at the hands of Thomas J. Wise, an officer of the Shelley Society.
OCEAN GROVE. N.J., June 30.--The regular Summer services were inaugurated here to-day and all the meetings were largely attended. Mrs. Palmer's holiness meeting and Evangelist...
About two hundred passengers were on the Staten Island ferryboat Westfield yesterday evening when she left for Staten Island on her 6 o'clock trip.
A stabbing affray, which narrowly escaped being fatal, occurred early yesterday morning in the saloon known as the Bowery in West Brighton, Coney Island.
MOUNT GRETNA, Penn., June 30.--This was a quiet day at Camp Trinity College. This morning the Trinitarians attended church at Lebanon and heard a sermon by Bishop Rullison.

TOPEKA, Kan., June. 30.--The evidence adduced in the recent hearing of the charges brought by the Chicago Board of Trade against the various railroads of discrimination against Chicago comes in the nature of a godsend to those who have long declared the existence of a beef and pork combine.

Twenty-nine boys and girls graduated from Grammar School No. 54, Tenth-avenue and One Hundred and Fourth-street, on Friday. Trustee Leopold Wormer presided, and addresses were made by Dr. G.F. Jackson, Assemblyman Connelly, and ex-Trustee David H. Knapp.

Miss Gracie Wade, the Brooklyn actress, who is suing a cigarette firm for $10,000 damages for issuing a cigarette picture of herself clad in tights, proves to be a member of Dan Sully's traveling company. She is average to tights.

LONDON, July 1.--No credence is attached here to the New-York rumor that the imperial Government will veto the Weldon extradition law. An official in the Canadian office assured me to-day that there was no likelihood whatever of such action, ...

Widow Ann Garrison, who sold papers at the entrance to the Roosevelt-Street Ferry for about a dozen years, was knocked down and run over while attending to her business yesterday afternoon by a truck driven by Louis Boldt of 502 Sixth-street.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 1.--Ten innings were required to decide the game to-day between the Hoosiers and the Giants, and the former won by a single run. Luck played an important part in the game. The Giants batted in good form, doing 50 per cent. better work than their opponents, but their hits were nearly all made when the bases were empty.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 1.--The best people in Charleston were stunned by the verdict in the McDow case on Saturday. The lower classes and the negroes are rejoicing at the miscarriage of justice. For twenty years Capt. Dawson was the head and life of the Democratic Party in this city.

ALBANY, July 1.--As one of the results of Gov. Hill's veto of the Capitol Appropriation bill, which provided for repairs to the roofs, among other things, the water found its way into State Entomologist Lintner's quarters and destroyed specimens that it took the entomologist years to collect and prepare. Some were very rare and valuable specimens.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 1.--Gov. David B. Hill of New-York spent Saturday and Sunday at the Normandie as the guest of Ferdinand P. Earle, who is a member of his staff. On Sturday Gov. Hill took a drive along the river, through Oceanic and Red Bank, and then down the turnpike to Long Branch and Elberen. Gov. Robert S. Green spent Sunday with Chief Justice Beasley.

The second annual sale of the Rancho del Paso yearlings, bred by J.B. Haggin, took place at the Hunt's Point sale paddocks yesterday afternoon, ninety-six head being disposed of for a total of $113,800, this giving an average of $1,185 42, a considerable falling off from the average of a year ago, when sixty-four head sold for $112,775, an average of $1,762 10.

The assessment rolls were laid before the Board of Aldermen by the Tax Commissioners yesterday. They show the assessed valuation of the real estate in the several wards, in comparison with those of last year, as follows:

Francis Larkin, Jr., James S. Willard, and Peter U. Fowler, the experts appointed by the Supreme Court March 5, 1889, to make an investigation into the financial affairs of the town of East Chester and the official accounts of all the officers of that town, have completed and ...

The Washington Heights Taxpayers' Association held a meeting last evening at the Mount St. Vincent Hotel, One Hundred and Fortyseventh-street and Tenth-avenue. The attendance was especially heavy, owing to the fact that several important matters were to come up.
PHILADELPHIA, July 1.--The creditors of S. Robbins Sons, Philadelphia Rolling Mill and Blast Furnace, which failed last week, met here to-day.

One of Wall-street's fads is an apprehension that stocks bought on the eve of a Fourth of July holiday are dangerous burdens, and the result is that the speculative traders keep their boxes as bare as possible at this time of the year. Yesterday's market had a dullness therefore that was natural enough. Few stocks fluctuated except over a margin of small fractions.

The Coney Island Jockey Club will bring to a close this afternoon the most successful racing meeting in its history. The programme for the day is one of exceptional excellence, the star feature being the race for the Realization Stakes at a mile and five-eighths, for which nine horses are named as probable starters.

SAVANNAH, Ga., July 1.--Fire broke out in A. J. Miller Co.'s furniture house on Broughtonstreet, in the heart of the business portion of the city, at 7 o'clock to-night and in one hour destroyed the entire establishment.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 1.--As was rumored yesterday the Soo line has decided to restore all-rail west-bound freight rates to 85 cents for first-class.

FALL RIVER, July 1.--The steamer Aries of the Windsor Line, from Philadelphia, arrived this morning. Capt. Briggs reports having passed on the 30th ult. a three-masted schooner in a wrecked condition off Fire Island, bearing north by west thirty miles.
Mr. J. F. Caldwell didn't go down to Cedarhurst yesterday to start the horses, and David Clark, his assistant, had to try and get the horses in the several races away on their journey.

Maltby G. Lane, a well-known man and millionaire operator in real estate and street railway securities, died suddenly about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the Bennett Building, at Nassau and Fulton streets.
WASHINGTON, July 1.--The President made the following appointments to-day:

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1.--The Supreme Court has rendered an opinion sustaining the decree of distribution entered by Judge Coffey of the Probate Court, by which the will of the late Gershom P. Jessup was annulled and his estate given to his illegitimate son.

The availability of large appropriations for repaying streets has revived interest in the question of providing means by which heavy trucking may be carried on with less injury than at present, not only to the streets but to horses and vehicles as well.

The Sixth New-York Cavalry yesterday dedicated its monument at Gettysburg, Penn., standing near the Mummasbug road, on Seminary Ridge. The monument is twenty-six feet high, built of granite. The blocks are small, the style being that of the later Romanesque.
The Excise Board yesterday appointed three inspectors. They are Peter E. Tarpey, John Delaney, and Myer Elsas. Tarpey has been a public school teacher, with a fondness for politics and contention.

LONDON, July 1.--The Massachusetts Rifle Team contested with the Honourable Artillery Company at rifle shooting to-day. The American team won by a score of 1,015 points out of a possible 1,260 points to 961.

The Post Office was full of disappointment and anger yesterday. The day opened the fiscal year, and the bill passed by the last Congress near the close of its session regulating the salaries of the employes went into effect.
HARRISBURG, Penn., July 1.--The official vote of the recent election as received and computed at the State Department this afternoon is as follows:

Policemen Daniel M. Janvrin of the Thirtyfourth, or West Farms, Precinct shot himself in the left side early yesterday morning intending to kill himself, and he was taken to the Harlem Hospital, where his wound was pronounced dangerous.

NEW-HAVEN, July 1.--Some one in this city wrote to the Post Office Department in Washington recently that Postmaster B.R. English of New-Haven had put a political assessment on the clerks in his office.
CHICAGO, July 1.--John Kunze, the man who drove Dan Coughlin to the Carlson cottage the night Dr. Cronin was murdered, is locked up in a cell at the Armory Station.
The Sing Sing Yacht Club will have its second annual open regatta on the fourth, open to all yachts belonging to the New-York Yacht Racing Association.

Police Justice Hogan began yesterday morning in the Tombs Court the examination in the case of William Sally, who is charged with having caused the death of Benjamin Hatton on June 22, on the excursion of the employes of the American Bank-Note Company.

Ex-Fire Chief Shay, who never in his thirtysix years of active fire duty met with a conflagration or danger that could upset his coolness, "shook like a baby," as he himself expressed it, yesterday afternoon, when he was escorted to the gymnasium at Fire Department Headquarters in East Sixty-seventh-street.
Complaints are made daily by householders below Thirty-fourth-street that the Croton water does not rise higher than the first floors of their houses, and in some cases not so high.

Ex-Senator Stephen W. Dorsey appeared by his counsel, Root Clark, as defendant in two suits in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday morning. The first appearance was in the suit brought against him by the Nevada Bank of San Francisco to recover about $5,000 alleged to be owed by him to the bank.

WHEELING, West Va., July 1.--The negotiations which have been in progress for several weeks past among the manufacturing potters, looking to a formation of a combination, or trust, for the future control of that industry, ...
Rear Admiral John H. Russell, United States Navy, is at the Windsor Hotel.
DUBLIN, July 1.--Mr. William O'Brien, member of Parliament, who was arrested at Cork yesterday for addressing a meeting which the Government had prohibited, was released today on bail.
Among the passengers who arrived yesterday from Liverpool on the Umbria were Capt. H. B. Corvick, Dr. Henry Conkling, T.F. Cushing, Miss Cushing, Mrs. Brookholst Cutting, ...

The ninth annual tournament of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association, for the championship in doubles, began yesterday on the grounds of the Staten Island Cricket and Baseball Club at Livingston.

"The Burglar" is obviously a play made for "the road." It would never be attempted at an important theatre in New-York in the sea son. All there is in it of artistic value was in the little one-act sketch called "Editha's Burglar," taken from a story by Frances Hodgson Burnett.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1.--News from Susan ville, in the Sierra Nevadas, says that slight earthquake shocks continue and that the people have become so accustomed to the constant trembling of the earth that they pay no attention to it.

The Rev Dr. A.S. Freeman, who has been pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church of Haverstraw, N.Y., since his ordination, preached his forty-third anniversary sermon there on Sunday last. He was presented during the services with ten volumes of the Expositor's Bible by the members of the choir. The presentation speech was made br Elder Alonzo Wheeler.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 1.--The rain which has fallen fitfully since reveille, with but an occasional glimpse of blue sky through the clouds, has not interfered in the least with the more or less successful attempts to teach the infant soldier idea how to shoot. The regiment, under the command of Lieut. Col. Dennison, ...

The American College of Musicians, which is the outgrowth of the Music Teachers' National Association, and services as a sort of Board of Regents to persons desiring to be licensed instructors of music, met in the council room of ...
JACKSON, Miss., July 1.--Gov Lowery has issued a proclamation forbidding the SullivanKilrain fight, and has offered $500 for the arrest of principals or participants.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 1.--The steamer Rio de Janeiro arrived late last night from Hong-Kong and Yokohama.

An interesting table has been prepared by Bradstreet's, showing the record of commercial failures for the first six months of this year, by States and geographical divisions of the country, in comparison with previous years.

ROME, July 1.--The Pope, at the secret consistory yesterday, referring to the speech made in the Senate in which Premier Crispi dwelt upon the hopelessness of the attempts made to reconcile the Vatican, and declared that the ...

Capt. Arthur MacArthur, Jr., Thirteenth Infantry, has been appointed Assistant Adjutant General, with the rank of Major to succeed to the vacancy caused by the appointment of Gen. Kelton to be Adjutant General. The new Major is a son of Judge MacArthur of Washington, and was born in Massachusetts June 2, 1845.
WASHINGTON, July 1.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased $95,400 4 per cent. bonds at 106 7/8. An offer of $1,00,000 4s at 129 was rejected.
A young man who registered at the UnionSquare Hotel about midnight on Sunday as Edward Lang, Chicago, committed suicide there yesterday morning by taking morphine.

CHAUTAUQUA, July 1.--The Assembly of 1889 opens to-day. It includes a "college of liberal arts," with a university curriculum strong in the languages and weak in mathematics. The Faculty of this Summer's college is composed as follows:
RED BANK, N.J., July 1.--Thomas S. Hubbard, the paying teller of the First National Bank, met with a serious accident yesterday.
NEW-HAVEN, July 1.--Alexander Troup, Collector of Internal Revenue for the District of Connecticut and Rhode Island, received notice to-day of his removal by President Harrison.
Speaking of the complaints that roads over which he has jurisdiction in the upper part of the city were in bad condition, Public Works Commissioner Gilroy said yesterday that he was not responsible.

CAPE TOWN, July 1.--The British gunboats Bramble and Peacock have been ordered to proceed from here to Delagoa Bay. The Bramble is a composite gunboat of 715 tons and 1,000 horse power. The Peacock is a composite gunboat of 755 tons and 1,200 horse power.

Bourke Cockran prides himself as having the biggest head in New-York. He wears a No. 8 hat and sometimes claims that that is tight. An old member of the Manhattan Club, once a Democratic oracle, but who is now a "lookeron in Vienna," says that Cockran is the only one of the persons now in control of Tammany ...
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 1.--The Rev. Dr. W.H. Campbell, ex-President of Rutgers College, has resigned the pastorate of the Fourth Reformed Church in this city, on account of failing health.
The seizure of the Clyde steamer Ozama is the most striking illustration we have had of the absurdity of proceeding with re gard to Hayti as if it were a civilized or a friendly power.

Mayor Grant said yesterday that he should not wait any longer to hear from Gen. Duane, but should proceed without delay to appoint an Aqueduct Commissioner to fill the vacancy caused by Gen. Duane's ineligibility.

A detachment of soldiers of the regular army started for camp at Fisher's Island, at the eastern end of Long Island, yesterday for rifle practice. They will stay there until Aug. 1 and be relieved by the remainder of the men stationed near New-York.
LONDON, July 1.--One hundred cases of petroleum, ex-ship Hamilton Fish, at Hamburg from NewYork, were lost from a lighter, but most of them were subsequently recovered.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 1.--James McNierny, an insane man, ran a race with a locomotive at Carteret yesterday. The train hands were astonished to see the man bounding over the ties ahead of the engine, yelling like a demon.

For the benefit of members of the New-York State Teachers' Association, now in session in Brooklyn, and of others interested in the subject, Superintendent Jasper has issues a circular, naming the schools in which manual training may be seen in practical operaiton to-day and to-morrow from 9 until 3 o'clock. The schools are as follows:

AUSTIN, Texas, July 1.--This morning Mrs. Johnston, wife of Dr. T.B. Johnston, a wellknown physician of Austin, went to make up the bed on which she slept. She jerked one of the sheets, and a pistol which she always kept under her pillow fell on the floor. It was discharged, the ball striking her in the abdomen. She died in great agony three hours afterward.
At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday Alderman Walker called attention to the dangerous condition of the ceiling of the Aldermanic Chamber.

We have no doubt that the explanation given in our letter from Rome on Sunday last of the motives for appointing in Europe the professors to be employed in the new Roman Catholic University at Washington was substantially correct.

The criminal libel case of Patrick Sarsfield Cassidy against Jeremiah O'Donovan Rossa, editor of the United Irishman, and Wilbur H. Hendrickson, its publisher, came up before Justice Hogan, in the Tombs Police Court, yesterday.
Steamship Bohemia, (Ger.,) Kopff. Hamburg 12 ds., with mdse, and passengers to R.J. Cortis.
Mrs. Lutie Lawton Frenzel yesterday secured an injunction in the Supreme Court from Judge Andrews, restraining Mrs. Harriet Hubbard Ayer from selling 470 shares of the Recamier Manufacturing Company.

ALBANY, July 1.--Superintendent Lathrop and the Wardens of the State prisons met to-night to formulate a plan whereby the 2,700 prisoners in the State prisons may be placed at work on the piece-price plan under the recent law.
The cross-examination of Frank W. Sanger in the "Little Lord Fauntleroy" suit was continued yesterday before Referee Rollins with but little result.

CHICAGO, July 1.--The reported disappearance of Dr. John McInerny of New-York has brought to light the fact that Dr. O'Cleary of the town of Lake, a suburb of Chicago, has not been seen for nine months, and some of his friends believe that he, too, has been "removed."
NORFOLK, Va., July 1.--Active operations commence at the navy yard to-day, the beginning of the new fiscal year, and several hundred mechanics and laborers will be put to work.
DANVILLE, Va., July 1.--The sales of leaf tobacco here for the month of June amounted to 4,149,579 pounds, a million and a half more than for June last year.

WASHINGTON, July 1.--The Presidential party will leave Washington to-morrow in President Roberts's private car, which will be attached to the 3:45 train on the Pennsylvania Road, reaching New-York at 9:20.

RED BANK, N.J., July 1.--The opening of Grace Methodist Church in this place will take place on Thursday, July 11, when the Rev. Dr. C.C. McCabe will preach at 2:30 P.M. A public meeting will be held in the evening, at which addresses will be given by Gen. Clinton B. Fisk, Dr. McCabe, and others. A selected choir will furnish the music.

A few weeks ago Collector Erharat rejected a certification of three names, from which he intended making an appointment, because the friends of two of the men so certified by the Civil Service Examining Board had learned that they were on the eligible list and had urged their appointment.

ALBANY, July l.--The twenty-seventh convocation of the University of the State of NewYork will be held in the Senate Chamber of the Capitol during Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday, July 9, 10, and 11. The following papers will be read, each being limited to thirty minutes:

Clark Brothers' Pottery Company went into voluntary liquidation at Trenton, N.J., yesterday. A meeting of creditors has been called for to-morrow. The company recently executed a mortgage to Clark Brothers Campany, another corporation, for $15,000 to secure money to put into the failing company.
The Grand Jury for July was sworn in yesterday in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions by Judge Cowing, who appointed Thomas C. Oakley, the flour merchant, foreman.

Gen. Lloyd Bryce arrived from Europe yesterday on the Umbria. By the will of the late Allen Thorndike Rice, proprietor of the North American Review, Gen. Bryce has come into possession of the controlling interest of that magazine. Concerning this matter Gen. Bryce said yesterday afternoon:

At lunch time on Friday, according to a report made at Sanitary Headquarters yesterday, Mrs. C.H. Finch, wife of a stockyard clerk, her two daughters, and two grandchildren ate a light meal of tea, bread, milk, and cerealine in their flat at 122 East One Hundred and Seventeenth-street, and in less than an hour all were very sick.

Capt. Rockwell of the Clyde steamer Ozama, which arrived Sunday night from Gonaives and came up from Quarantine yesterday, had to repeat the story of his struggles with the Haytian Navy a great many times.

When Mrs. Mary Ellison was knocked down and killed by a runaway horse June 8 at the New-York end of the Brooklyn Bridge there was considerable discussion as to the best means of protecting human life and minimizing the danger from similar accidents.

LONDON, July 1.--The Chancery Court has restrained one of Henry M. Stanley's transport officers from publishing a book called "With Stanley's Rear Column." The court holds that the publication of the book would be a breach of the agreement between those engaged in the expedition not to publish any accounts of it until the official reports have been issued.
Park Keeper Thomas Devine of Hoboken is lying unconscious at St. Mary's Hospital in that city suffering from a mysteriously-inflicted wound.

Every good Republican knows that the mismanagement of the Post Office Department during the Administration of Presi-- dent CLEVELAND was simply sickening. Since the excellent Mr. WANAMAKER and CLARKSON, that athletic axeman, feared of fourth-class Postmasters, have taken the ...
Four thousand Principals and school teachers are expected to attend the convention of the New-York State Teachers' Association, which meets in the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, today.

Louis Steckler, brother of Civil Justice Alfred Steckler, took possession yesterday of the Corporation Attorney's office, to which he was recently appointed by Corporation Counsel Clark, and thus secured to Tammany Hall one more berth in the ship of State.

The tenth annual convention of the French Canadians of New-York, Vermont, and NewJersey was begun yesterday morning at Beethoven Hall, in Fifty-sixth-street, near Thirdavenue. There were representatives from this city, Brooklyn, Jersey City, Haverstraw, Stony Point, Grassy Point, Plattsburg, Cohoes, Troy, Albany, Champlain, Malone, and Rochester.
BOSTON, July 1.--The ship carpenters of East Boston employed on what is termed "new york" struck to-day for nine hours' work per day and ten hours' pay.

BALTIMORE, July 1.--Cardinal Gibbons has received a beautiful present from Pope Leo XIII. It is a large golden and richly jeweled ostensorium and was sent to the Cardinal as a souvenir of the Pope's jubilee. Its place will be upon the main altar of the cathedral.
READING, Penn., July 1.--The immense plant of the Reading Iron Works, which failed four months ago for over $1,000,000, was put up for sale here this afternoon.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 1.--The surprising statement given to THE TIMES the other day by its San Francisco correspondent to the effect that David D. Houston of Middletown, N.Y., as assignee of John K. Moore, had begun an action in the United States District Court of California against the city and county of San Francisco ...
POUGHKEEPSIE, July 1.--The hotels are filling up with strangers, who come to attend the July meeting at the Driving Park, which begins tomorrow and lasts four days. There are 106 entries.
The Park Commissioners determined, about a month ago, that the bridge across Mott Haven Canal at One Hundred and Thirty-eighth-street was unsafe.

The Seidl concerts continue successfully in the Music Hall at Brighton Beach, Coney Island. The programmes for to-morrow afternoon and Friday evening will be given up entirely to Richard Wagner. At the matinee the selections will include many works of Wagner's earlier period, including "The Flying Dutchman" overture, ...
PARIS, July 1.--The sale of the wonderful collection of oil paintings, water colors, and drawings belonging to M.E. Secretan was begun here to-day by Boussod, Valadon Co. and Charles Sedelmeyer.

LONDON, July 1.--The Anchor Line steamer Victoria, Capt. Jamieson, which left New-York June 19 for Avonmouth, passed Brow Head this morning. Some fears as to the safety of the Victoria have been felt, as some bills of lading belonging to her were lately found on the shore off Nantucket Island.

The funeral services over the body of Abram Waskeman, ex-Postmaster of New-York City and one of the organizers of the Republican Party, who died of rheumatic gout at his home, 46 East Twentieth-street, on Saturday last, were held in Trinity Chapel yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 1.--The schooner Buffo, Capt. Wilbur, of St. John, N.B., from Fall River for St. John, went ashore this afternoon in a fog on Beaver Tail, south end of Canonicut Island. She is high on the rocks and in a bad place. She is bilged and has several holes in her.

The naval fiscal year beginning yesterday brought with it many changes at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Several discharges were given to employes, noticeably to men of Democratic leaning. Among the officers of the yard, Capt. William A. Kirkland gives place to Capt. L.A. ...

A new system of art decoration in wood which produces very elegant effects has recently been introduced into this country from Germany. It is the invention of Messrs. Ludwig and Radeke, and is known as Dalura decoration, and consists in impressing upon wood any kind of art designs, which stand out in relief.

The report that David Belasco is to give lessons in acting to the woman who lately figured as a principal in a Chicago divorce court, and who now proposes to attempt to coin money on the stage out of her notoriety, is denied at the Lyceum Theatre. Mr. Belasco's contract with Mr. Frohman as stage manager of the Lyceum prevents him from accepting any outside contracts of the kind mentioned.

The Board of Estimate of Brooklyn completed its task of preparing the city budget yesterday, and sent it in to the Aldermen, who immediately referred it to a committee of seven to report at the next meeting.

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 1.--The special yacht race open to forty-footers, given by the Oyster Bay Yacht Club to-day, was a grand contest between six of the most conspicuous of the yachts in that class.

DURANGO, Col., July 1.--At 3 o'clock this afternoon a fire broke out in the south part of the city, and in a short time the flames, assisted by a strong wind, spread in every direction, leaping from building to building until at 4 P. M. half of the town was in ashes.
Another case which seems to come under the prohibitory contract labor law in regard to immigrants occurred yesterday at Castle Garden.
A fire broke out at 7:30 o'clock last night on the steamship Flamborough, belonging to the West Indies Steamship Company, as she lay in her dock, Pier 14 East River.

WASHINGTON, July 1.--The Attorney General has given an opinion to the Secretary of the Treasury expressing grave doudts as to the authority of the latter, under Section 3,469, Revised Statutes, to compromise cases arising under the alien labor contract law.

Mr. BROWNE of Indiana has been interviewing the President on the subject of an extra session of Congress, and, though the latter did not commit himself wholly, he left the impression that Congress would be called together earlier than the usual time.

The designs for the Puritan as modeled are coming in from Washington with fair celerity. As fast as they are received Naval Constructor Hoover assigns the work, and now that the new appropriations are available he is able to put on additional workmen.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 2.--New-York won today's game in fine style. The Giants kept within hailing distance until the seventh inning, when they made one of-those spurts for which they are famous, took the lead, and held it until the finish.

CHICAGO, July 2.--The Louisville, Evansville and St. Louis, the Tell City, Huntingburg and Cannelton, the Belleville, Centralia and Eastern, the Illinois and St. Louis Railroad and Coal Company, and the Venice and Carondelet Railway Company have been legally consolidated,...
George Carpenter, seventy-five years of age, and a well-known citizen of Woodside, L.I., dropped dead on the corner of Cherry-street and James slip at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon...
HARTFORD, July 2.--Gov. Bulkeley has positively refused to act as President of the day at Henry C. Bowen's Woodstock celebration on the Fourth.
PROVIDENCE, July 2.--For six months the various railroads entering Providence have been preparing plans for a new union station.

WASHINGTON, July 2.--Secretary Window-has rejected the offer to compromise the judgmant against the Hory Trinity Church of New-York City for violation of the allen labor contract law and the case will go to the Supreme Court . The Secretary's action is based on the advice of the Attorney General.
CHICAGO, July 2.--Joseph C. Mackin, known to fame as "a fine worker" in elections, was today pardoned out of Joilet Pententiary by Gov. Fifer. Application was made to Gov.

Mr. J.B. Haggin supplements his successful sale of yearlings on Monday by having his colt Salvator place to his credit, at the Sheepsnead Bay track yesterday, the Realization Stakes, the richest prize for three-year-olds of the year.
Col. John Thomas North, with a large party of ladies and gentlemen, is at the Victoria.
Gen. George B. Williams of Indiana is at the Grisey House.

LONDON, July 2.--The Speaker read messages from the Queen this evening commending to the House the granting of a provision to Prince Albert Victor of Wales and Princess Victoria of Prussia on the occasion of their marriage,

CHICAGO, July 2.--Chicago played, an up-hill game to-day, but by bunching their hits in the the seventh and eighth, and with Quinn's error and Duffy's hit in the ninth, succeeded in winning-their third game of the series from Boston.

There has been considerable blasting near the northern end of the now reservoir in Central Park recently, the workingmen firing one charge on Monday night which fairly shook the foundation of Reservoir Keeper Hankinson's house, between the storage lakes.

The Board of Health yesterday appointed the following named physicians as a Summer corps to visit the tenement houses and give free medical attendance to the sick found in them who are not already under medical treatment. The list includes one female physician:

Incorporators of the Kings Country Trust Company hava decided to tender the Presidency of the company to Joseph C. Hendrix, Postmaster of Brooklyn. The company will be organized with $500,000 capital and a cash surplus of half that amount. Among the incorporators are J.S.T. Stranahan S.V. White. A.O. Barnes. William Berri, and Fellx Campbell.

There was an explosion followed by a fire yesterday afternoon in the fur-cleaning establishment of A. Bowsky Sone, at 220 East Fifty-first-street. This is a four-story brick building fronting on Fifty-first-street, with a two-story brick extension in the rear.
HELENA, Montana, July 2.--The Constitutional Conventon convenes here July 4, but it is not probable that anything will be done that day except to form an organization.

Sergt. Rathgen of the Hoboken police yesterday visited Park Keeper Thomas Devine, who was mysteriously assaulted on Sunday evening, and, finding him conscious, learned from him his story of the attack.

The young man, who committed suicide early Monday morning at the Union-square Hotel by taking an overdose of morphine has been identified as J.E. Hoedemaker, a clerk employed by Druggist Muller at Eleventh-street and University-place. Hoedemaker was only twentyone years old.

LONDON, July 2.--The daughter of Sir John Puleston, member of Parliament for Devonport, was married to-day to Mr. Ashurst Morris. By special permission of the Queen the ceremony was held in the Chapel Royal, ...
CLEVELAND, July 2.--In the ninth inning this afternoon the Washingtons read Bakely's signs and pounded out three runs. With one man out and Wilmot on third, the future seemed full of glory for them.
ON BOARD THE FLAG SHIP SEA FOX, OFF OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 2, 1889. The fleet of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club has been lying quietly at anchor all day in the picturesque harbor at Oyster Bay.

No reader of the Century who takes a vacation will overlook the papers in the July number on inland navigation in this country, the same being an account of lake, river, and Sound steamboats by Charles Barnard and Mrs. Van Rensselaer.
BERNE, July 2.-The Bundesrath will not adjourn for the usual Summer recess, owing to the political situation resulting from the complaints of foreign powers regarding Socialists in Switzerland.
LONDON, July 2.--The World's Sunday School, Convention opened its sessions in London to-- day. There are 900 foreign delegates present, including over 300 from the United States.

Johanna Alfreda Akerbom, a Swedish domestic, twenty-three years old, who is known to her associates as Mary Johnson, was struck on the forehead by a brick thrown by some unknown person while she was standing in front of her home, 225 East Twenty-eighth-street,

Shrieks and cries of "Rats! Rats!" awakened and alarmed the Maher family, who live at 116 Boerum-place, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning. The cries came from the room of Mary Maher, twenty years old. She had been awakened by a sharp pain in her leg and had seen a big rat jump down from the bed. The young woman was made hysterical. A doctor was called in and the wound was dressed,

A tough citizen named Farrell from the Ninth Ward was in Jefferson Market Court some time ago charged with larceny. He got off for lack of evidence, assaulted a man on the same day, and got a term on Blackwell's Island.

By a general order issued from Army Headquarters the American Morse code will hereafter be used by the army for all purposes of signaling, whether visual or acoustic, and the use of the English Morse, or Continental code will be discontinued. This action was taken upon the recommendation of the Chief Signal Officer with a view...

Marvin D. Wheeler, a Delaware County Republican, yesterday took his plane in the Post Office Inspector's Department as successor to Chief Inspector Thomas Ryan. The other Democratic inspectors are daily expecting their successors' arrival.

At the meeting of the Finance Committee of the Conemaugh Valley relief fund in the Mayor's office yesterday a discussion took place on the appeal sent to the committee last week from Johnstown for the transmission of money thither for distribution in such a way as to enable the impoverished people to make purchases from the impoverished merchants,
BOSTON, July 2.--A decision was given this morning by Judge Colt in the United States Circuit Court in the case of the United States against the American Bell Telephone Company and others.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 2.--The County Convention of Prohibitionists was held in the Opera House here yesterday for the election of delegates to the State Convention, to be held at Asbury Park on July 18.

If our neighbor, the Tribune, shall stick to its assertion that "the Sugar Trust exists and extorts money without the slightest aid from the tariff," it will be left by its party associates to the undisturbed contemplation of its own ignorance.

Judge Andrews of the Supreme Court yesterday decided that a writ of peremptory mandamus must issue requiring Commissioner of Public Works Thomas F. Gilroy to reinstate John Sullivan as a laborer in the employ of the department. Sullivan was employed as a street paver.
Interest in yesterday's meeting of the Board of Education centred in the report of the Committee of Eight.
There is a chance that the long-drawn-out controversy over the Castle Garden Clearing-House question and the attitude of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company will be settled to-day.

The Gas Commission yesterday opened bids for the lighting of streets with electric lamps, and found that the bids for the supply of lamps in the subway district were much lower than those which were registered last month, because Mayor Grant and his colleagues did not believe the declaration of the companies that the subway rents were so high as to necessitate very high prices for electric lamps.

John Fretts, employed by the Western Union Telegraph Company, had some lines to overhaul in Eighth-avenue, between Twenty-first and Twenty-second streets, yesterday, and the wires were put on the sidewalk with an electric light wire which was supposed to be "dead,"

CHICAGO, July 2.--September wheat, which closed yesterday at, 79 cents, opened cent lower to-day and immediately fell to 78 1/8 cents. It was still raining at 11 o'clock at Fargo, Grand Forks, and a dozen or more points in Dakota, as well as in Minnesota,

BELGRADE, July 2.--The young King Alexander was anointed at Saitchar to-day by the Metropolitan, Michel, assisted by the chief ecclesiasties of Servia. The King afterward reviewed the troops. M. Persiani, the Russian Minister, was present at the ceremonies.
When Robert Lenox Kennedy went to Europe in 1887 Dr. William S. Forbes of Philadelphia accompanied him.

PARIS, July 2.--The sale of Mr. Secretan's grand collection of paintings was resumed today, with a large crowd in attendance. The excitement caused by the spirited bidding for Millet's "The Angelus" yesterday had not died away, and the price paid by M. Proust to retain the painting in France was a theme of general discussion.
ST. PAUL, July 2.--There were heavy rains last night at Grand Forks, Dakota, reaching well out all around there and extending to Park River and Devil's Lake, a trifle only falling at Bismarck.
Twenty-four of the American survivors of the terrible disaster at Apia Harbor, Samoa, arrived here yesterday on the steamer Newport and were taken to the navy yard at once.

An event-of ever-increasing importance-to all the people of the State is the annual convention of the New-York State Teachers' Association, How much it has accomplished in the expansion or thought on the all-important subject of popular education and in preventing the natural tendency of educational systems toward contraction may never be found out;
The Sinking Fund Commissioners yesterday examined the thirteen architectural designs for the criminal court building to be erected on the block north of the Tombs.

While the increase in the number and extent of the commercial failures for the first half of the present year in this country over those of the corresponding period of any other recent year is not to be attributed directly to political causes,
It was reported and believed down town yesterday that the Atlantic White Lead and Linseed Oil Company had been absorbed into the white Lead Trust.

LONDON, July 2.--Late to-night I learn that Wilkie Collins has had a stroke of paralysis, which, I believe, is his second, and he lies in an unconscious state at the house where he was to have dined Sunday with Sebastian B. Schlesinger, one of the most prominent members of the American colony here and an intimate friend of the novelist.
DANVILLE, Va., July 2.--Ten days ago the Danville and East Tennessee Railroad Company was organized at Danville, Va., by the election of a Board of Directors.

Judge O'Brien, in Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday confirmed the report of William Smith, who was appointed referee in a suit brought by David H. Gould against George I. Seney and Samuel Shethar.
NEW-HAVEN, July 2.--The German singers are arriving in this city for the state Saengerfest to be held in the Hyperion Theatre to-morrow and Thursday.

The Plan and Scope Committee met yesterday for the purpose of ascertaining the cost of the centennial celebration and adjourned subject to the call of the Chairman. The committee will not meet again until September, when it is expected that all its accounts will have been adjusted and finally closed.

Thomas H. Thorn and Oscar Thorn, composing the firm of T.H. Thorn Co., dealers in coal and wood at 524 Second-avenue and 1,094 First-avenue, made an assignment yesterday to Robert A.B. Dayton, giving a preference for $2,158. The fixtures and plant of the two yards cost, it is said, $7,000. The business has been established upward of twenty years.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 2.--This has been the dreariest of dreary days in camp. The rain has fallen in a steady downpour, so steadily indeed that it has been impossible to do work. Even tht sentries have kept to their boxes most of the time.

Walter F. Linnell, a young dry goods clerk, living at 131 West Thirteenth-street, had an exciting experience last evening with an electric light wire, and as a result he is now at St. Vincent's hospital with both his hands badly burned.

Already some five hundred horses are at Monmouth Park, ready for the racing, which begins to-morrow with a programme of eight races. The track is in fine condition, having been in use for training purposes daily from daybreak to 10 o'clock, after which time it has been worked daily with the harrows.
The experiments to determine the position of metacentre of the gunboat Yorktown were completed at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday.

The post Office clerks this year will join the letter carriers in their Fourth of July parade, and all arrangemants for the event have been completed. The clerks will assemble at the old armory of the Seventy-first Regiment at 2 o'clock in the afternoon, and the Rev. Dr. MacArthur will present to them a handsome stand of colors.

The history of Jean-Francois Millet's painting, "L'Angelus," which was sold at the Secretan sale in Paris Monday for $111,000, as told to a TIMES reporter last night by Mr. Samuel P. Avery, Sr" is a most interesting one.

LONDON, July 2.--The Massachusetts rifle team contested with the Royal Berkshire Volunteers' team to-day on Lord Wantage's famous Churn range, although it was thought probable at one time that they would shoot on the new Wimbledon range. Lord Wantage, Viscount Bury, and other notables were present.
Mayor Grant has not yet nerved himself up to the task of appointing a Tammany man to attempt to oust Gen. Duane from the Aqueduct Commissionership.

The feature of the day's racing at Cedarhurst this afternoon will be the race for the Cedarhurst Grand National, a steeplechase over the four-mile course, in which some six or eight of the best jumbers in training will be contestants. The entries for the-several races are as follows:

Atchison was weak enough yesterday to spread an insecure feeling throughout the whole stock market. Atchison fell four points; no other stock made quite so bad a record, but in various quarters there was unhappiness and a disposition to sell.

About two hundred and fifty excursionists, members of the Brooklyn Tabernacle Society, started yesterday on a five days' jaunt to Saratoga and Lake George. The start was made at 9:25 A.M. from Jewell's Wharf in Brooklyn...

AMHERST, Mass,. July 2.--The first feature of the Class Day programme was the public gymnasium exercises by' 90, winners of the Gilbert prize, who went through the evolutions of marching and the dumb-bell exercise before 800 people.
Many hundreds of reports have been published on the Pilot Chart and elsewhere relative to the great benefits derived from the use of oil to prevent heavy seas from breaking on board vessels.

LONDON, July 2.--Mr. Lamont, a Glasgow critic and intimate friend of Mr. John Ruskin, has received a letter from Brantwood, Mr. Ruskin's residence, saying that Mr. Ruskin is so ill, that there is no immediate prospect of his recovery.

CINCINNATI, July 2.--John L. Sullivan and party arrived in this city over the Bee Line at 2 o'clock this afternoon. They came several hours earlier than they were expected, so as to avoid a crowd. Johnson and Wakely, the fighter's backers, are with him.
WASHINGTON, July 2.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased $766,500 4 per cent, bonds at 106 7/8. An offer of $170,000 4s at 128 5/8 was rejected.
The Catholic News of this city has received the following cablegram from its roman correspondent:
WASHINGTON, July 2.--The President made the following appointments to-day:

LONDON, July 2.--The Shah, after receiving Lord Salisbury and the other members of the Cabinet and the members of the diplomatic corps to-day, departed for Windsor Castle. Upon his arrival there he was received by the Queen at the state entrance.

LONDON, July 2.--Michael Davitt was examined before the Parnell Commission to-dayHe declared that there was no truth in the account given by Le Caron before the commission concerning proposals of John Devoy being submitted to Mr. Parnell. Mr. Parnell had nothing to do with the witness's visit to America in 1878.
LONDON, July 2.--In the House of Commons this evening Sir James Fergusson, Parliamentary Secretary to the Foreign Office, stated that the treaty agreed upon by the Samoan...
DUBLIN, July 2.The Amateur Cricket Club of Philadelphia and the Dublin Cricket Club played here to-day. The home team went to the bat first and offered a stubborn resistance to the American bowlers.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 2.--P.T. Barnum, speaking of his coming season in London, says: "The entire show known as Barnum, Bailey Co.'s Circus and Menagerie, greatly amplified, will sail for England about Oct. 12 next, and will open in the Olympia, London, about Nov. 1, for a Winter season.

Letters of administration were issued to Julia M. Watson, widow of Millionaire George Watson, and, William Dickinson, by Judge knickerbocker, in the Chicago Probate Court yesterday. The personal property is placed at $320,000 and the real estate at $730,000.

ALBANY, July 2.--It has been learned here that the relations between Gov. Hill and Tammany Hall have been seriously strained, and that the only thing that is in the way of an open rupture is the fact that the Governor's term lasts two years longer, and that if Tammany broke with him now the question of...

The United States Treasury Department has decided to make a number of changes in the anchorage grounds at the port of New-York. These will be formally promulgated in a few days over the signature of Secretary William Windom.
PITTSBURG, July 2.--Fifteen hundred persons witnessed to-day's game at Recreation Park. The Phillies started out as though they were determined to win at least one game here.

LYNCHBURG, Va, July 2.--A fearful accident by which many lives were lost and a large number of people injured occurred on the Norfolk and Western Railroad at 2:30 o'clock this morning, one mile above Flaxton's switch and thirty-one miles above the city.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., July 2.--The tenth annual meet of the League of American Wheelmen began here to-day. President Luscomb arrived Monday night and was met by Mayer Louis Delamater and a committee of citizens, who escorted him to the Hotel Hamilton, which will be the league headquarters.

On Monday evening a large urn of palms and roses was sent to Mme. Cottrelly's dressingroom during the performance of 'Clover" at Palmer's. Attached to the urn was a letter and nestling among the flowers was an elegant jewel case, inclosing a pair of ivory castanets.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 2.--The weather was so unfavorable this afternoon that it was decided to carry the opening day's tretting art the Hudson River Driving Park over till to-morrow. This will bring the meeting into Saturday, but the third day's programme will not be changed, as it is the best one for the holiday, and Wednesday's card will be taken up on Friday. For tomorrow the events are the 2:22 and 2:37 trotting classes.,

CHICAGO. July 2.--The Western and Northwestern roads to-day agreed to put into effect on July 5 the special commodity rates between Chicago and St. Paul, about which there has been so much contention for a week or more.

President Harrison, Secretary Tracy, and Secretary and Mrs. Noble and Lieut, Mason, Secretart Tracy's private secretary, left Washington yesterday afternoon in a parlor car under the charge of Clarence W., the son of Henry C. Bowen, and arrived at the station of the Pennsylvania Railroad in Jersey City at 9:30 last evening.

An examination of the "proclamation" setting forth the nature and objects of the "National Convention of French Canadians" now meeting at Macnnerchor Hall, Fifty-sixth-street near Third-avenue, shows that it is a somewhat more exclusive and less national body than its name indicates. In urging a better attendance at the convention this year the proclamation says:

PRINCETON, N.J., July 2.--The new electrical engineering buliding at the College of NewJersey will be constructed entirely of brick. No iron will be used. The latest and most valuable instruments of all kinds will be obtained for this new department in the college.

Does President HARRISON intend to do anything in regard to the facts in the record of Col. JAMES T. MORGAN, the new Commissioner of Indian Affairs, that have lately been brought to the attention of the public?

Dealers in milk and butter feel somewhat demoralized, for both milk and butter are at present almost drugs in the market. The wet weather has caused a very luxuriant growth of grass, and cows are producing very large quantities of milk, which, however, is not rich in quality.

The three-story frame tenement building at 58 Webster-avenue, Jersey City Heights, was the scene of a double tragedy yesterday afternoon. Charles Meisel keeps a butcher's shop on the lower floor and occupies the second floor with his family.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., July 3.--The bad weather of to-day cast a damper on the league meet. The hundreds of wheelmen were delighted with the beautiful weather which greeted them in the morning, and many runs were projected but the storm changed all this.

One after another the endeavors to keep the price of copper abnormally high fall through. It is only a few weeks since the various companies producing lake copper entered into an agreement to sell their accumulations at 12 cents per pound and to limit their sales proportionately to the amount of product.

ELIZABETH, July 3.--The fight made by the wife of Anton Debaud, a wealthy, but eccentric Frenchman of Fan wood, against admitting to probate his last will and testament, was ended to-day in the Union County Orphans' Court.

CHICAGO, July 3.--At the June meeting of the Board of Managers of the Inter-State Commerce Railway Association the question arose regarding the establishment from St. Paul to St. Joseph of the same rates on alcohol as are made from Peoria to St. Joseph, application so to do having been made by the Chicago, St. Paul and Kansas City Road.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 3.--Sensational news of probable war between Costa Rica and Nicaragua over the Canal came by steamer yesterday from Panama.
OTTAWA, July 3.--The Hon. George E. Foster, Minister of Finance and youngest member of the Dominion Cabinet, was married to Mrs. Addie C. Chisholm at the First Baptist Church, Chicago, Monday last.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 3.--The unusually wet weather of the past two months has served to increase the rheumatism that has so seriously affected Judge Thurman since last Fall.
An assault, which was made Sunday night upon Charles W. Brooks, Jr., son of the wellknown lawyer, who has a country residence near Great Neck, L.I., was made public yesterday.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 3.--The occasional, though very minute, patches of blue sky which have now and again parted the rain-sodden clouds, have encouraged the belief that this disagreeable weather is slowly dragging itself out, exhausted by its own intensity.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 3.--Civil Engineer R. E. Paulin has returned from Brazil, where he went in the interest of a syndicate of Canadian and American capitalists to report on a vast railway project to open up the southeastern section of Brazil. It is also proposed to place a fleet of steamers on one of the rivers, as well as to establish steam communication between Para, New-York, and Montreal.

ALBANY, Ga., July 3.--Primus Jones brought in the first cotton bale of the season, 390 pounds, to-day, being two days earlier than the same event last year. The bale was sold at 12 cents per pound and was shipped to New-York.

The Cedarhurst race meeting was concluded yesterday, the principal event being the Cedarhurst Grand National Steeplechase. It was over a course of about four miles, seven horses starting for the twenty-five-hundred-dollar purse.

Morris Stolz, sixty-five years old, of 65 Mainstreet, Brooklyn, was standing in front of his house last night, when a number of small boys playing in the street set off a package of firecrackers. The noise frightened the old man so that he fell to the ground. An ambulance was summoned, but he died before its arrival. Death was apparently due to fright.

ON BOARD THE CUTTER CLARA, OFF LARCHMONT, July 3, 1889. This smart fifty-three-foot cutter, owned by Dr. J.C. Barron of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, left the Seawanhaka fleet at Oyster Bay soon after noon to-day, and after a run of about an hour and a half in a spanking breeze ...

We have already commented upon the view taken of the civil service law by that eminent spoilsman, lobbyist, political jobber, and financial schemer, the Hon. "TOM" PLATT, ex-Senator and actual Boss of the State of New-York.

AMHERST, Mass., July 3.--To-day was Commencement Day at Amherst College. There was a large attendance.

WESTBOROUGH, Mass., July 3.--The funeral of Miss Mary A. Brigham, the new Principal of Mount Holyoke College, who was killed in the railroad accident near New-Haven, Conn., on Saturday last, took place this afternoon from the Congregational church and was largely attended.

An unknown man, supposed to be an Italian laborer, threw himself into the opening of the Fourth-avenue tunnel at Ninety-eighth-street before an incoming train of the Harlem Railroad about 8 o'clock yesterday morning. He was instantly killed.

SALT LAKE, Utah, July 3.--Further details of yesterday's fire at Hailey, Idaho, are to the effect that all the business portion of the town was destroyed except one fire-proof house. There is left but one hotel, two livery stables, one lumber yard, one grocery store, one saloon, and one dry goods store.

Yesterday was a great day for manual training and kindred branches of study in the convention of the New-York State Teachers' Association at the Academy of Music in Brooklyn.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 3.--A special from Randolph, N.Y., says that Deputy Sheriff Woodworth, while looking for the perpetrators of a local burglary, captured Fritz Schultz, who had about $3,300 on his person. Schultz confessed to having robbed his employer. Police Justice Charles Welde of 77 East One Hundred and Twenty-eighty-street, New-York.

BALTIMORE, July 3.--The Baltimore and Ohio has at last taken the bull by the horns. It gave official notice to-day that, taking effect July 6, it would reduced rates on wheat and corn from Chicago to Baltimore from 22 to 17 cents, and from Chicago to Philadelphia from 23 to 18 cents. The New-York rate of 25 cents is reduced to 20 cents.

PUTNAM, July 3.--President Harrison and the rest of Mr. Bowen's distinguished guests are sleeping under his roof to-night, tired out with their day's journey, which, to use Mr. Bowen's own eloquent language, has been "one triumphant ovation from beginning to end."
FORTRESS MONROE, Va., July 3.--Gen. Armstrong makes the following reply to the recent letter of the Rev. Dr. Childs concerning the ill treatment of Indian boys at Hampton School:

CHICAGO, July 3.--Wheat was bullish this morning Notwithstanding the copious rains all over the Northwestern wheat sections.

Utica, N.Y., July 3.--Under the amendment to the Inter-State Commerce act of March 2, 1889, the Judges of the United States Circuit and District Courts were authorized to issue the writ of mandamus to compel common carriers to transport the traffic of any applicants upon the same terms they accept from other shippers for like service.

ALBANY, July 3.--The Wardens of the State prisons met here yesterday with Superintendent of State Prisons Lathrop. The subject under discussion was the employment of the prisoners under the Fassett bill.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 3.--The Fredonian, one of the six leading Republican papers of the State, has given an interpretation of the sentiment of the Republicans on the civil service question which is interesting.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 3.--In the United States Circuit, in this city, to-day, Associate Justice Bradley of the Supreme Court of the United States and Resident Judge Wales presiding, question was rendered in the case of the administrators of C. Brown Snyder, late of New-York City, ...
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 3.--The Tennessee Coal, Iron, and Railroad Company to-day advanced the price of iron 50 cents per ton all around, ...

ALBANY, July 3.--A Brooklyn paper has questioned the truth of the statement in a dispatch from this city, printed in THE TIMES last week, which contained the announcement that the State Forest Commission was about to erect large signs on the islands of Lake George bearing the words "State Land," and that it had ...
TROY, July 3.--The growing of Kentucky hemp has been introduced in this locality. This season about thirty farmers in Rensselaer and Washington Counties have tried the experiment with marked success.
CUMBERLAND, Md., July 3.--The Baltimore and Ohio train due here at 7 P.M. was delayed by a storm. Kilrain and party were aboard of the train.

LONDON, July 3.--The Mudhook Club held its annual regatta to-day. Light breezes prevailed in the morning, but the wind freshened in the afternoon. The race was fifty miles over the Clyde course. The Yarana won in 5:55:05 on time allowance. The Valkyrie's time was 5:54:20 and the Deerhound's 6:23:23. The Irex lost her bowsprit and topmast.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 3.--After a delay of twenty-four hours from rain the trotting meeting began at the Hudson River Driving Park this afternoon.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 3.--The Northwestern Miller says: "The mills ran a little stronger last week. The aggregate output was 115,000 barrels--average, 19,167 barrels--against 109,800 barrels the previous week and 152,500 barrels for the corresponing week in 1888.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 3.--The old turnpike between this place and the resorts lying on the coast south of here has for many years been in very bad condition. It is owned by the old Deal and Sauan Bridge Turnpike Company, though it has long been virtually abandoned by its owners.

WASHINGTON, July 3.--To-day's bond offerings aggregated $668,950 as follows: Coupon fours, $500 at 128; registered fours, $55,000 at 130, $200 at 128; coupon four and a halfs, $4,000 at 106 7/8, $4,000 at 106 7/8; registered four and a halfs, $600,000 at 106 7/8, $4,250 at 107 7/8; $5,000 at 106 7/8.

NEW-HAVEN, July 3.--Coroner Eli Mix, who has been investigating the recent accident on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad finds that the accident was caused by the criminal carelessness of Thomas Shields, a section boss.
PHILADELPHIA, July 3.--The thirteenth annual meeting of the Music Teachers' National Association was called to order this morning by Thomas A'Becket of this city.

MADRID, July 3.--The Imparcial asserts that the Government having received a telegram from the Vatican authorities, inquiring whether the Pope would be allowed a place of refuge in Spain in the event of his being obliged to leave Rome, Premier Sagasta, after consultation with the Queen and Ministry, replied in the affirmative, granting the Pope an asylum in Valencia.

WASHINGTON, July 3.--The report that came yesterday from the White House that the extra session of the Fifty-first Congress would probably not be called before November fits in very well with the talk about the activity that the Republicans are to manifest in Montana in ...

LONDON, July 3.--Mr. Davitt, in his testimony before the Parnell Commission to-day, stated that he would not object to join any movement to secure the independence of Ireland, if such a movement was backed by a force strong enough to justify the hope of its success.
Promptly at 2 o'clook this afternoon a good hold of horses will start for a race of threequarters of a mile at the Monmouth Park Association's race track.
The body of an unknown woman of about fifty-five years of age was found in the trout pond at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, by a policeman yesterday afternoon.
CHICAGO, July 3.--The Chicago, St. Paul and Kansas City has apparently thought better of its proposition to put the community rates into effect to St. Joseph, Mo., on July 8.

FORT WORTH, Texas, July 3.--The Trinity River is higher than since 1866, and is between three and four miles wide to places. The damage in the city is slight, but the loss to the railroads and suburban property will be a million and a half dollars.

NEW-HAVEN, July 3.--Major John A. Tibbits of New-London, who was appointed consul to Bradford, England, last Saturday, will accept the appointment as the best within his reach, but he is by no means satisfied.
The chances of George W. Lyon and Edward Mitchell to procure the Surveyorship of the Port and the United States District Attorneyship respectively were better last week, seemingly, than they are now.

Special orders from First Brigade headquarters designate Wednesday evening, July 10, as the date of holding an election for Colonel of the Seventh Regiment to fill the vacancy caused by the retirement of Col. and Brevet Brig. Gen. Emmons Clark.
Fireworks enough got into yesterday's stock market to provide more liveliness than Wallstreet has had in a good while. The trust "securities" were most conspicuous, every one dealt in scoring a loss.
LYNCHBURG, Va., July 3.--The scene of the terrible disaster near Thaxton's, on the Norfolk and Western Railroad, is beyond description.
ELIZABETH, N.J., July 3.--This city was again visited by burglars last night and three houses were entered. At George Thompson's, 137 Racestreet, the robbers secured $15 and a lot of clothing.

NORWALK, Conn., July 3.--The second of a series of regattas by the Cedar Point Yacht Club will be sailed to-morrow off Seaside Park, Bridgeport. It is expected that this will be one of the most exciting contests ever held by the club, as the entries are much more numerous then formerly, and far greater interest is being manifested.
The testimony of MICHAEL DAVITT before the Parnell Commission is in some respects the most interesting and important that has been taken by that body.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 3.--The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Road has made all arrangements for a San Francisco terminus.
RONDOUT, N.Y., July 3.--Hotel proprietors and boarding house keepers all through the Catskill Mountain range are happy to-night.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., July 3.--A terrific thunderstorm passed over this city last evening. It was followed by two cloudbursts that caused a furious overflow of Church Run, which traverses and winds through the city.
LIMA, July 3, via Galveston.--The extraordinary session of Congress called for July 4 will sit until the opening of the regular session of Congress July 28.
George A. Hurd, dealer in fancy dry goods at 317 and 319 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, yesterday confessed judgments for $42,600, and the Sheriff took possession of the store.

LONDON, July 3.--The Cabinet has decided to appoint a committee on the allowances which Parliament will be asked to grant to Prince Albert Victor and the Princess Louise.

Judge O'Brien of the Supreme Court has granted an attachment against Alfred Carr Co., bankers and brokers at 36 Pine-street, for $3,570 in favor of J.A. Yates on a balance claimed to be due on stock transactions up to June 28. The firm is composed of Alfred Carr and his mother, Mrs. Purdy.
The Yorktown was towed out of dry dock yesterday afternoon at the navy yard, and her place was taken by one of navy yard tugs.
Sewer Inspectors James Valentine and James Sheridan were removed by Public Works Commissioner Gilroy yesterday.

William A. Hall, the owner of the Battery Swimming Baths, has lodged a complaint with the Board of Pilot Commissioners against the New-Jersey Central Railroad's Sandy Hook steamboats, the Sandy Hook and the Monmouth.
It is proposed to hold a meeting of the Governors of the thirteen original States in Independence Hall, Philadelphia, to-day for the purpose of having a jollification.

John Studiagor, thirty-nine years old, of 344 Hudson-street, was cleaning an old gun last night in his preparation for to-day's festivities, when it suddenly exploded and blew off his right hand. He was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital.
The charge of P.S. Cassidy against O'Donovan Rossa of criminal libel had a further hearing yesterday before Justice Hogan at the Tombs. Having decided to become his own lawyer, ...

SCRANTON, Penn., July 3.--Two sleek swindlers, giving the names of Carey and O'Malley, but traveling also under the aliases of "Wilson" and "Haywood," have come to grief here after swindling a number of clergymen to whom they sold large quantities of common cloth, which they represented as "Spanish serge."

BOSTON, July 3.--The Committee on Pardons of the Executive Council to-day gave a hearing on a petition for the pardon of James Dunlap, who was concerned in the famous Northampton Bank robbery in 1876.

There was a long examination at the Jefferson Market Police Court before Justice Smith yesterday in the case of John L. McMurray, one of the proprietors of the Knicerbocker Conservatory of Music and Dancing, at 44 West Fourteenth-street, who was accused of having arranged to set fire to the promises occupied by the conservatory last Friday morning.
ALBANY, July 3.--Two trust companies to-day filed in the Banking Department their semiannual reports for the half year ending June 30.
Annetta Bruckhurst, a widow, married Albert Johnson four years ago, and they went to live at 807 East Ninth-street.

LONDON, July 3.--This was the first day of the Stockbridge meeting. The race for the Stock bridge Cup at three-quarters of a mile was won by Lord Hastings's St. Patrick, Napoleon second, and Noble Chieftain third.

BANGOR, Me., July 3.--A telegram to the Bangor Daily News from Brownville states that the Canadian Pacific Railroad was thrown open to-day through Maine for the transportation of bonded goods, and that long and heavy trains which left Montreal yesterday afternoon passed Brownville, half way across the State, at noon, billed for St. John, N.B. The Canadian people have made out a time table for big traffic.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., July 3.--The heavy rains of yesterday and last night flooded out five families in Cambria City. The water came pouring down the mountain last night and filled the first floors of the houses, destroying all the furniture that had been saved from the big flood.

The Castle Garden Clearing House question that has disturbed the Trunk Line Association for so many months was before Commissioner Fink yesterday for arbitration.

Ellen Davison and her husband, Patrick, of 515 Carroll-street, Brooklyn, quarreled last night. Her husband drove her around the room in his anger till she leaped through a window to the yard. Her ankle was fractured and she received internal injuries. She was removed to the Long Island College Hospital.
ELIZABETH, N.J., July 3.--A serious accident was barely averted here this morning at a funeral.
Many tourists sailed on the five large steamships that left this port for European points yesterday. The White Star steamship Adriatic, for Liverpool, carried many prominent people, ...
A very enjoyable performance of "Pinafore" was given at Proctor's Twenty-third-Street Theatre last evening.
MOBILE, Ala., July 3.--At a late hour last night the Mobile Insurance Company made a general assignment to D.R. Burgess and Elliott Texey.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 3.--The schooner Thetis, the first arrival from the Grand Banks cod fleet, to-day brings 250,000 pounds of codfish. Since the appearance of caplin for balt, codfish are more plentiful on the banks and good catches have been made.

The policemen on the station platforms and the guards on bridge trains are again at their old tricks, and it is merely a question of time when a serious and possibly fatal accident will bring the public to a realization to which they are hourly subjected in traveling by the great highway between New-York and Brooklyn.

The American Yacht Club will hold a special regatta for sailing yachts on Monday, July 8. The course will be on the Sound off the clubhouse at Milton Point. It will be open to yachts of the New-York, Atlantic, Seawanhaka Corinthian, ...
It was discovered yesterday by accident that Miss Leoni Steuvenal, aged 30, of Bayonne, Hudson County, N.J., attempted suicide in a peculiar manner on June 26, while insane.
Police Justice Petterson of Brooklyn, who has only been on the bench since May 1, is making a record not very satisfactory to lawyers who appear before him.

Major Gen. Schefield has ordered two troops of cavalry now at Fort Myer, Virginia, and three light batteries--Turnbull's Third Artillery, Cushing's Fourth Artillery, and Brinckle's Fifth Artillery--to concentrate at Mount Gretna, Penn., for Summer encampment in connection with Pennsylvania troops.

The French Canadians, having finished their convention, enjoyed themselves at a picnic yesterday at Sulzer's Harlem River Park.

Among the changes of importance now in progress in the Navy Department, the approaching departure of the Chief Intelligence Officer from the position he has occupied for more than four years deserves other than passing notice.

LONDON, July 4.--A dispatch from Lisbon to the London Times says: "In an interview today, Senhor Gomes, Minister of Foreign Affairs, declared that, except for the assistance of the Portuguese Government, the Delagoa Bay Railway Company would have forfeited its concession long ago.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 3.--R.G. Dun Co.'s Alabama representative has made a full report through correspondents in every important point in the State as to the condition of crops and trade.

Rosa Lisner's Palais Royal dry goods store, at 4 East Fourteenth-street, was an fire yesterday morning, and about sixty employes escaped injury because of the cool-headedness and good sense of John Gras, a bookkeeper.
