ALBANY, July 3.--Clork Parks of the Court of Appeals will notify lawyers that they must have their returns filed by Sept. 20 if they want their cases on the new calendar which the court directed to be made up for the court proper.

Plans have been submitted to the Building Department for a ten-story office building on West. Washington, and Liberty streets, to be 186 by 103 feet in extent, and to cost $700,000. The New-Jersey Central Railroad is the owner.
The annual Summer games of the West Side Athletic Club will be held on the Manhattan Athletic Club grounds on Saturday afternoon, July 20. The games will begin at 3:30 o'clock.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 3.--The following certificates of incorporation have been filed in the Secretary of State's office:

Mayor Grant, Chamberlain Croker, Public Works Commissioner Gilroy, Corporation Counsel Clark, and W. Bourke Cockran will lead the Tammany braves in singing "The Star-Spangled Banner" and "The Red, White, and Blue" this morning.

CHICAGO, July 3.--Samuel B. Leach, an expert machinist, living at 4,912 Wabash-avenue, who is alleged to be one of the conspirators in the celebrated Electric Sugar Company swindle, was locked up at the Harrison-street station to-day.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 3.--Moraga Ranch, which comprises over thirteen thousand acres of the finest land in Contra Costa County, was owned until last week by W.H. Carpenter. The land runs through the centre of the county.
LEXINGTON, Va., July 3.--Alumni Day of the Virginia Military Institute brought additional hundreds of old cadets and visitors.
ALBANY, July 3.--Robert H. Hunter, the new Collector of Internal Revenue for this district, came up from Poughkeepsie to-day and spent several hours here.
DECATUR, Ill., July 3.--The grain firm of L.F. Webb Co. of Dalton City and Macon, this county, have brought suit for damages in the United States District Court at Springfield ...

Francis Tropp, fifty-two years old, of 7 Lewisstreet died suddenly last evening in his store, at 403 Madison-street. He was for many years in the express business. He was a large property owner and leaves a fortune to his family. Mr. Tropp's death was caused by apoplexy.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 3.--The Hawes Company of this city, manufacturers of straw board, this afternoon deeded all its property and mills and transferred its business and good will to the trust organized as the American Straw Board Company, capital stock $6,000,000 O.C. Barber of Akron, Ohio, President. The fifteen largest mills in America are in the deal. Their daily production is 300 tons of straw boards. There are only five little mills left out.
CHICAGO, July 3.--The Farmers' Review publishes in its issue this week careful estimates based on reports from its correspondents relative to the probable yield of wheat in the Winter wheat States.

LONDON, July 3.--The race for the diamond sculls between Charles G. Psotta, the American amateur champion, and Blackmore, the English oarsman, was rowed at Henley to-day. Psotta won, beating his opponent by three lengths.
LONDON, July 3.--A match took place to-day at Rainham between the Massachusetts rifle team and the London Rifle Brigade.
CLINTON, Iowa, July 3.--Last evening a steam bleacher in the mill of the Lyons Paper Company, adjoining Clinton, exploded with terrific force, wrecking half of the large brick building ...
LONDON, July 3.--The Shah, accompanied by several members of the royal family, members of the diplomatic corps, and other prominent persons, was to-day escorted by a procession to the Guild Hall.
Ex-Mayor William R. Grace gave a dinner at Delmonico's last evening in honor of Col. John T. North, the "Nitrate King."

MINNEAPOLIS, July 3.--As a result of the remarkable performance of the three-year-old trotting horse Axtell at Minnehaha yesterday, Robert Bonner of New-York telegraphed the owner of the animal to-day that he would pay $65,000 for him. Mr. Williams refused to accept the price offered.
HARTFORD, July 3.--At a special meeting of the Directors of the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company this afternoon the resignation of President A.C. Goodman was accepted.
CAIRO, July 3.--An engagement has taken place at Arquin between a force of Egyptian troops, under command of Col. Wodehouse, and a body of dervishes. The dervishes were defeated and fled.

Ever since the figures of the men who took the school census of Jersey City were made public a month ago the Newark press has been claiming that the census was fraudulently large.
PARIS, July 3.--An explosion of fire damp at the coal mines of St. Etienne occurred to-day. About 300 miners were entombed, over 200 of whom are killed.
The Hudson County Jockey Club has just been organized and will hereafter have control of the race track at Guttenberg.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 3, via Galveston.--Heavy rains during the past two days have partially inundated this city. The heavy pumps which it was believed would secure to the city at least a partial drainage are proving practically useless.

WATERVILLE, Me., July 3.--Commencement exercises at Colby University were held at the Baptist church to-day. The Trustees met and received a check for $500 from Mrs. Edwin Noyes to found the Timothy Boutelle Library of the Coburn Classical Institute.
VANDALIA, Ill., July 3.--Monday night Marshal Phillips went to the house to arrest Charlie Stolle, when will, an elder brother and a powerful man, seized Phillips by the throat, choking him severely.

CHICAGO, July 3.--A special dispatch from St. Paul says: "On the recommendation of Henry Villard and President Oakes it has been decided that the preferred stockholders of the Northern Pacific will, this Fall, receive their first dividend in cash.

CONCORD, N.H., July 3.--The conference between the Boston and Maine and Concord officials for an amicable adjustment of their differences is being continued to-day with an excellent prospect of an early settlement.
Manager Frank L. Goodwin, who is to produce "The White Elephant" at the Bijou Theatre on July 15, describes the piece as a "musical farcecomedy of the higher order."

There was a large number of vessels arriving in port yesterday afternoon from up the Sound. All of them had evidently managed to take advantage of the same slit in the fog bank, for they arrived off City Island in the shape of a big fleet.
The hearing in the "Little Lord Fauntleroy" suit, brought against T. Henry French by Frank W. Sanger, was continued yesterday before Referee Rollins.
GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 3.--This afternoon the monument of the Fifty-ninth New-York Infantry Regiment was dedicated by the veterans, who arrived last evening.
The braid manufacturers who want to form an association will meet at the Metropolitan Hotel on July 10 at 2 P.M., to discuss an organization and the effects of the tariff on the trade.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3.--The surety companies of this city and New-York who were on the bonds of Supreme Treasurer George W. Wright of the order of Tonti are not going to pay the $40,000 which Wright has misappropriated if they can help it, and they think they have discovered that they cannot be held liable.
DUBLIN, July 3.--The game between the Amateur Cricket Club of Philadelphia and the Dublin Cricket Club was continued to-day.
Mr. George Gould, President of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, received a dispatch yesterday verifying the report of the wreck of the company's steamship Granada at Punta Tejuhan.

BISMARCK, Dakota, July 3.--To-morrow the Constitutional Convention for the new State of North Dakota will assemble in this city, and already a large number of the delegates are on hand ready for duty.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3.--Oarsmen have seldom faced a more riotous river or worse weather to row in than were encountered by the home and visiting crews to-day on the Schuykill in preliminary trial heats of the people's regatta.
CHICAGO, July 3.--Chairman Blanchard has issued a call for a meeting of the Freight Committee of the Central Traffic Association to be held next Tuesday.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 4.--The Minister of Customs has ordered that facilities be given to land new cables in Dover Bay, N.S., for connection with the New-York land lines.

The Kill von Kull Yacht Club sailed its third annual regatta over a five-mile course, starting off Port Richmond, S.I., yesterday. The start was made shortly after 11 o'clock, at which time there was a very stiff breeze.

In the shoot for the Phelps Badge at Woodlawn Park, Long Island, yesterday, H. Blattmacher, 25 yards, Dr. Shields, 30 yards; C.A. Seddons, 25 yards, and L. McKane, 30 yards, tied with 7 birds each.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4.--The high, wooded cliffs of Philadelphia's pet pleasure ground at Fairmount were one extended grand stand today from which crowds viewed the people's regatta on the Schuylkill, which gives one of the finest stretches of water for boating owned by any city.

The Bayswater Yacht Club held its first annual regatta at Bayswater, on Jamaica Bay, yesterday. The racing, however, was sadly interfered with by the heavy rain, and many boats that had been expected to compete for the prizes did not appear.

NEWTON, Ala., July 4.--Mrs. Duncan, the wife of the Rev. Henry Duncan, the resident Methodist minister, died Wednesday, and was buried on the following day.

Herman Probst, the young Jersey City expressman who killed his mother Wednesday and then put two bullets into his own head, was still alive last night at the City Hospital, and the physicians think he may recover. It was learned yesterday that Probst injured his head by a fall when he was a boy. It is thought that he never fally recovered from the effects of the fall.
MILWAUKEE, July 4.--The big brewery of Falk, Jung Borchert in Wauwatesa, just beyond the city limits, was totally destroyed by fire this afternoon.

CHICAGO, July 4.--The Sheridan Stakes, for three-year-olds, was the feature at the Washington Park races to-day, and was remarkable only because Proctor Knott, the champion twoyear-old of 1888, finally succeeded in defeating the Montana colt Spokane, though in very slow time.

The Mississippi River is behaving in a queer way this year. The usual Spring rise did not come, owing to the failure of the Ohio, the Arkansas, the Missouri, and the Red Rivar to get in their vernal booms.

PARIS, July 4.--The sale of the Secretan collection was concluded to-day. Over 240,000f. were realized. Jacobus, a Copenhagen brewer, to-day bought five pieces of Gobelin tapestry for $85,000f. Two candelabra--a bacchante and a faun--realized 25,000f.; a group by Faiconnet, 20,000f.; two statuettes by Gauter, 20,000f.; a Sevres vase, 20,100f., and another vase, 19,000f.

COHASSET, Mass., July 4.--Charles Reardon of Cambridge, G.H. Bellier, Jerry Cummings, and Jacob Fellows of Boston made a trip to Minot's Light from Black Rock Beach in a hired boat to-day.
ALBANY, July 4.--To the average observer the political situation in this State in both parties is serene and peaceful. As a matter of fact, while the "shallows murmur the deeps are dumb."

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 4.--The plan of profit sharing announced by the Bourne Mills corporation last May went into effect on July 1, and a circular to that effect from the Treasurer has been distributed among the overseers and employes.

LONDON, July 4.--The examination of Mr. Michael Davitt was continued before the Parneil Commission to-day. In reply to questions Mr. Davitt said he did not know the whereabouts of the books of the Ladies' League.

Canada has more than one national holiday. As a part of the empire she celebrates the 24th of May with great heartiness, but as a nation her day of rejoicing is the day of her birth, Dominion Day, July 1.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 4.--Miss Susie Ross, who lived with her parents in Collegeavenue, eloped last evening with Isaac Bennett, a young restaurant keeper.
BURLINGTON, N.J., July 4.--The heaviest and probably the most destrictive storm that has visited this vicinity for years prevailed to-day. It has rained almost incessantly for the last five days.

BOSTON, July 4.--The principal event of the day in this city was the rowing regatta on the Charles River. The professional single-scull race, three miles, brought out Toemer, Plaisted, Kennedy, McKay, Ten Eyck, and P.H. Conley.

FORT WORTH, Texas, July 4.--Several inches of rain fell in this part of the State yesterday, and great damage has resulted. Reports from the West show heavy rains for 200 miles. The Brazos and the Trinity Rivers are booming:

ST. PAUL, July 4.--George W. Ewing of Fort Wayne, Ind., has made a claim through an attorney to one-fifteenth interest in property in various parts of St. Paul, estimated to be worth about $2,000,000.

Mr. Gladstone, who disdains an umbrella when speaking in the rain, is not above the use of a sunshade when addressing an open-air audience under a cloudless sky.

PARIS, July 4.--The coal pit at St. Etienne, in which the explosion of firedamp occurred yesterday, is still on fire. Many more bodies have been recovered, but the work is attended with great difficulty and danger.

The Post Office clerks and carriers celebrated the Fourth of July, as usual, with a parade. The exercises opened at 2 P.M. at the old armory of the Seventh-first Regiment in Thirty fifth-street, where the Post Office Clerks' Association...

The steamer City of Paris, which arrived early yesterday morning, made an unusually poor record for her. Though the weather was not very unpropitious, the force of green stokers in the fire room was unable to shovel coal fast enough to all the fleet steamship's furnaces to make good time.
A farm in the Isle of Ely, which cost 10,000 about fifteen years ago, and on which 3,000 has since been expended, was sold last week at Wisbech for 3,850.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 4.--The Burke case, pursuant to adjournment from Wednesday, will be proceeded with to-morrow morning.

WASHINGTON, July 4.--Hodji Hossein Ghooly Khan, the Persian Minister to the United States, will shortly leave this country for Europe. In an interview to-day he told a reporter that he would not come back, and that he had been driven out of the country by the unkind and ungenerous things which had been written about him and his sovereign in the American newspapers.

The Sing Sing Yacht Club had a regatta yesterday, open to all yachts belonging to the NewYork Yacht Racing Association, and twentynine cabin sloops and cat-rigged yachts were ready at 11 o'clock, the time for the start.

The steamer Chester, from Rotterdam, reports that on June 28, in latitude 46 30', longitude 44 20', she passed a large iceberg, and the next day, in latitude 45 55', longitude 46 15', she sighted another iceberg.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 4.--Owing to the rain this forenoon, the holiday programme arranged to take place at the Hudson River Driving Park had to be abandoned for the present. An effort will be made to get some of the races off to-morrow, the 2:28 and 2:34 trotting classes coming first in order.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 4.--Reports received from the southwestern portion of this province announce the discovery of a small green fly which is infesting the heads of the Fall wheat. It is believed by some to be the midge fly. Fears are entertained that the crop, which for luxuriance and quality has not been equaled in many years, will be a light one.

Though the Monmouth Park Association had a very bad day for the opening of its racing meeting, the prospect of rain did not deter a great crowd, probably fully 15,000 people, from assembling at the track to enjoy the beginning of the last Summer meeting at the historic and popular race course.
Officers of the steamer Pennland, from Antwerp, report that on July 2 Johann Ludwig Hofheir, a second cabin passenger, aged sixty years, died of heart disease and was buried at sea.

The Essex County Commissioners are called upon to pass on the question as to whether a dog is a domestic animal. Boxford was recently visited by a mad dog and several valuable dogs were bitten by him.

Herbert Wills, an Englishman, who is an architect living in Yonkers, reported at Police Headquarters last night that he and a companion named Hubert Westell, who is also an Englishman, an architect, and a resident at Yonkers, went out rowing on the Hudson River yesterday afternoon. When about two miles below Piermont a squall came up. The boat filled with water and was capsized. Wills swam ashore, but Westell was drowned.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., July 4.--The Summer whirl is on, and the Pier benches are daily lined with sitters who watch the blue Atlantic The Pier is at its best.

ROCKLAND, Me., July 4.--The town of Cushing celebrated the centenary of its incorporation to-day. An oration was delivered by H. M. Lord of Rockland. A poem, a historical sketch, a procession, and cannon salutes were the other features.

LONDON, July 4.--The Massachusetts rifle team shot against the Sussex theam at Brighton to-day. The light was clear, but a strong wind was blowing.

According to a cable dispatch received yesterday the Augusta Victoria, which left her dock at Hoboken June 27 at 5:30 A.M. and passed Sandy Hook at 7 A.M., was sighted off the Sclilies at 4:30 yesterday morning. She would, therefore, reach Southampton at about 1 P.M., making the trip from Sandy Hook to Southampton in seven days and one hour, corrected time, which would be equal to six days and seven hours to Fastnet.

RED BANK, N.J., July 4.--The new Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, which is to be dedicated next week, is one of the handsomest and most substantial edifices in the county.

Thomas Parker, Lawrence Collins, and John Doyle, all of 10 South-street, went sailing yesterday morning in a small yacht which belonged to Parker. They left Pier 5 East River at 10:30 o'clock for Bay Ridge.

ST. PAUL, July 4.--The wheat crops of Minnesota and the Dakotas will turn out much better than has been anticipated. The effect of the rains of the last two days has been highly beneficial for the grain, especially the last sown.

CATSKILL, July 4.--The Catskill Firemen's tournament will be held July 17. Nearly $600 in prizes, cash and otherwise, will he competed for. For the race between hose companies $100 will go to the winner of the first place and $50 to second place.
CITY OF MEXICO, July 4.--The heavy rain for the past two days has partially inundated the city, proving the uselessness of the heavy pumps to drain the city.
CHARLESTON, West Va., July 4.--The vestibule train east-bound, on the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, was wrecked by a slide in a cut near Ona about 1 o'clock this morning.

Charles Kerns, aged twenty-two years, and William Snyder were employed yesterday as special watchmen at Ackerly Gerard's sawmill in Long Island City. During the afternoon the men quarreled and Snyder struck Kerns on the back of the head with his club. The blow fractured the base of the skull. Kerns was reported to be dying last night and Snyder was locked up.

Another example of Gov. Hill's disregard for people who helped him when he needed help most is shown in the treatment of Editor T.C. Callicot of the Albany Times. Mr. Callicot's paper supported the Governor as against Mr. Cleveland, and its editor is now paying penance.
RALEIGH, July 4.--The small-grain crops throughout this State have been harvested, and oats, wheat, rye, and barley give the best results for several years.
PARIS, July 4.--This afternoon President Carnot went to the Isle de Cygnes to inaugurate the replica of Bartholdi's Statue of Liberty Enlightening the World. An immense crowd witnessed the ceremony.

BOSTON, July 4.--The sailing regatta off City Point to-day was the best ever held under the city's auspices. There were a large number of entries and a spanking breeze made the races interesting throughout.

Twenty-one revolvers of twenty-one different sizes and shapes lay on the desk in the Nineteenth Precinct Station House last night. Nearly twenty-one owners of these revolvers lay in the cells in the lock-up.

NEWARK, N.J., July 4.--Emil Broulon, aged sixty, to-day deliberately walked in front of an approaching train and was instantly killed. Broulon came to America eight months ago. He was a Lieutenant in the French Army. He was arrested Tuesday on a charge of insanity and was discharged this morning. He imme diately went to the railroad and ended his life.
The "old inhabitant" could not remember a quieter Fourth of July than that of yesterday in Brooklyn.

The Emperor of China has presented his bride with an immense tiara of gold, with a very lofty cap of Sibarian sable, embroidered with rows of pearls, and the feathers of the golden pheasant. Twenty skilled workmen were employed for two months in making the head dress.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 4.--Sir Charles Tupper's proposal of a double column tariff between the colonies and England and the colonies and foreign countries, such as France, Germany, Belgium, Italy, the United States, , is attracting general attention.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 4.--John Maginnis of this city, President of the Maginnis Cotton Mills, was killed by lightning to-day at Ocean Springs, Miss. Mr. Maginnis was well known in NewYork, being a son-in law of the late William M. Tweed of that city.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., July 4.--The league meet ends to-night with fireworks and a noise never before heard in Hagerstown. The events of the day were the parade, in which over five hundred wheelmen participated, and the races...
NEW-ORLEANS, July 4.--A large crowd gathered at the Queen and Crescent station this morning to greet John L. Sullivan and party upon their arrival.

The hospitable denizens of Coney Island were sadly disappointed yesterday. From the managers of the big hotels down to the proprietors of the sandwich stands, all had laid in great stocks of provisions wherewith to feed the Fourth of July multitude.

LARCHMONT, July 4.--The annual regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club was sailed here today and resulted s satisfactorily as it could under the circumstances, the weather being anything but favorable to a successful regatta.

The New-Jersey Athletic Club yesterday succeeded in running off their regatta and starting the lacrosse match before the storm swept over Bergen Point. The management postponed the events until Saturday, July 20.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 4, via Galveston.--Senor Mendoza, Minister of the Argentine Republic, arrived at Vera Cruz to-day.

The luckiest yachtsmen about New-York yesterday were the members of the Oyster Bay Yacht Club, who got away on their fifth annual regatta just after the showers of the morning, and went over their seventeen-mile course before such a rattling southwester that they finished and got everything safely housed before the tremendous downpour of the afternoon began.

The Journal of the Military Service Institution for July opens with an article on "An American War College," by Lieut. Arthur L. Wagner. It is a masterly treatise of a subject so long under discussion.

The French Canadians do not form a very conspicuous element in the population of this city or of this State, although it is rather startling to be informed that some twenty-five thousand of them are living and working in Clinton County.
MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., July 4.--The grape and berry crop in this locality will not be as large as the opening of the season promised, but, will probably be more profitable.

BELVIDERE, N.J., July 4.--Mrs. James Gouger of Knowlton was severely gored by an infuriated bull Wadnesday. She was crossing a field when the animal pursued and overtook her. The bull knocked her down and struck her in the side, fracturing her ribs and inflicting other injuries. A farm hand came to her relief and chased the bull away.
SALT LAKE CITY, July 3.--While the products of the soil occasionally disappoint the wind-andweather-toughened Utah Granger, even here in the Salt Lake Valley, there is one crop that never fails.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 4.--The Giants split even with Pittsburg to-day, losing in the morning, 4 to 2, and winning in the afternoon, 6 to 4. Exactly 5,279 people witnessed the first contest, the largest crowd that has ever attended a morning game in Pittsburg.
DUBLIN, July 4.--The Philadelphia and Dublin cricket teams met again to-day. The weather was splendid, and a large number of spectators witnessed the game.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 5.--The funeral service of the late Theodore Dwight Woolsey, ex-President of Yale University, were held this afternoon.

The railroads in the Trunk Line Association, like some sporting people, are wondering whether there is going to be a fight or not. Some of the roads have been training for a big bout over freight rates for some time.
PITTSBURG, Penn., July 5.--The Pittsburgs won the game from New-York to-day fairly and squarely on its merits. They outbatted and in many instances outployed the Gaints.

AUGUSTA, Mo., July 5.--Secretary Blaine arrived last night. This forenoon he called on Gov. Burleigh and took a drive with him, improving the opportunity to call upon a few of his old friends and neighbors. He took a train for Bar Harbor at 1:18. He is in excellent heath, and is enjoying his outing very much.
A consignment of Mormons under the charge of two burly and well-built elders named Smith and Anderson were landed at Gastle Garden yesterday from the steamship Wisconsin.

While two men were talking yesterday afternoon to Charles Burlin, cashier for Edward Jansen, a basket manufacturer at 124 West Nineteenth-street, another man entered the store and stole about $60 from the safe. The first anniversary of the law of emancipation occurs to-day. The year just closed has proved to every candid observer that the dangers and evils predicted of emancipation were in great measure unfounded.

MONTREAL, July 5.--The funeral of P.L. MacDonnell took place to-day from his late residence. The coffin was taken to Notre Dame Cemetery, and, by permission of Cure Sentenne, was placed in a vault awaiting permission from the Archbishop for interment.

According to information received from the Norfolk Navy Yard yesterday the Pensacola is practically ready for sea. She has all her stores and provisions on board, and in two weeks might be ready to start. Much of the work on the Pensacola has been held over until the appropriations for this year become available.
PHILADELPHIA, July 5.--The closing day of the annual convention of the National Music Teacher's Association was marked by the reading of essays on the question of music in the public schools.

As the Staten Island ferryboat Southfield was making here eight-o'clock trip form this city last night, a passenger named Patrick Rice, aged fifty-five years, of this city, jumped overboard from the forward end when off Governor's Island. A boat was lowered and the wouldbe suicide rescued. He was taken to West NewBrighton and locked up. He refused to give any explanation.

SHEARMAN, in delivering an address on "Taxation" at Portland, Oregon, recently, declared that it could be demonstrated by statistics which are undisputed that 100,000 persons are possessed of incomes which enable them to save about three-fifths of all the wealth that is annually saved in this country.
BRICK CHURCH, N.J., July 5.--Daniel C. Webb, whose wife eloped from Orange last Tuesday with James H. Quimby, a man of family, is a journeyman butcher.

The discovery of a large number of York coins at Neville's Cross, in the North of England, is exciting a good deal of interest. They are believed to be associated with the battle between the English and Scotch armies in 1346.
Mayor Grant and Commissioner Waldo Hutchins, the President of the Park Board, had a long discussion at the meeting of the StreetOpening Board yesterday.

Sander Nelson, a destitute survivor of the steamship Danmark, was in the city yesterday seeking information about his brother, Charles Nelson, a contracting engineer, who, he learned, is at present at Los Angeles, Cal. LONDON, July 5.--This was the first day of the Kempton Park Summer meeting. The race for the Victoria Cup, at five furlongs, was won by Carnival, with Master Charlie second, and The Kelpie third. The race for the Kempton Park Grand Twoyear-old Stakes was won by Signorina, by St. Simon, with Alloway second, and Lactantius third.

Inquiry having been made in the House of Commons respecting the treaties recently negotiated by Japan with Mexico and the United States, Sir JAMES FERGUSSON announced on Tuesday last that the former agreement had not yet been ratified, and that the latter would take effect in February, 1890.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 5.--The arrival of Sullivan on the Fourth of July and his taking quarters a block away from Canal-street, in the heart of the city, has made him the conspicuous figure, and all attention concentrates upon him. He arrived under good auspices and in superb condition.
SALEM, Mass., July 5.--While the fireworks were being set off in the Common to-night a shell exploded in the mortar blowing fragments into the crowd.

Judge Holme, in the City Court, yesterday gave judgment for $200 in favor of Annie Herzlich, in her suit against Abraham Fliegel for breach of promise.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 5.--Crop reports received by Secretary Mohler of the Agricultural Department of Kansas are to the effect that the wheat harvest is almost finished. The Secretary estimates the total yield at 34,000,000 bushels, which is just double that of last year. The crop may now be said to be successfully harvested. The largest yield is in Sumner County, where bushels 3,000,000, have been harvested.

PITTSBURG, July 6.--Four thousand disappointed Pittsburgers went to Recreation Park this afternoon and witnessed the defeat of the home team by the New-York Club. The score was 7 to 1. There was some very loose fielding by the Pittsburgers, and the New-Yorkers found no difficulty in solving Morris's slow curves.

The silver was computed at about one hundred and seventy millions.

PROVIDENCE, July 6.--At the July and regular quarterly meeting of the Rhode Island Historical Society yesterday Gen. Horatio Rogers was elected President. An addition of 50 bound volumes was reported during the past three months, in addition to 261 unbound works and 33 miscellaneous articles. Henry Watson, M. D., of New-York was elected a corresponding member.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 7.--One of the fairest of days broke over the State Camp here to-day and found the Ninth Regiment and the Tenth Battalion thoroughly settled in their quarters after passing a night almost as quiet as the stil moonlight which rested over the camp.

On Thursday next a notable event in the history of the venerable St. Paul's Rock Creek parish will be commemorated. Fifty years ago the Rev. Dr. Buck, the rector, was consecrated a priest in the Episcopal Church.

HALIFAX, N.S., July 7.--The general store and dwelling of J.G. Byrd at East Chezzeticook was burned last night. A young daughter was burned to death. Another daugher jumped from a window with an infant in her arms, and was seriously injured, besides being badly burned. Byrd and his wife were also severely burned. Byrd is an American.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 7.--Returns received from over sixty points in the fruit-growing districts along the Hudson Valley show that the unparalleled rainfall during the latter part of May, all through June, and the first four days of July, together with the humidity of the atmosphere, have wrought much havoc to small fruit.

Edward Barker, who belongs on the towboat McAuley, while cruising down the bay yesterday was astonished to see a wild steer in the water. The steear is supposed to have escaped from a White Star Line steamer.

Westell, the young man who was drowned July 4 while rowing with his friend, Herbert Wills of Yonkers, having been caught in the furious storm of wind and rain when of Piermont, on the opposite side of the Hudson, was found yesterday morning by William H. Lewis and J. Voris, in the middle of the river, opposite Hastings.

ELIZABETH, July 7.--Michael Dougherty had a narrow escape yesterday afternoon at the Elizabethport Cordage Works. His arm was caught by the machinery and he was dragged into it. Before he could be extricated the arm was doubly fractured at the elbow, and only the promptness of the engineer in stopping the machinery saved Dougherty's life.
LONDON, July 7.--Discount was easy during the past week at 1 to 1. On the Stock Exchange business was quiet. Speculation was stagnant, but a fair amount of investment business was done.

Lyman R. Williams, for nearly thirty years Superintendent of Schools in Steuben County, Ind., committed suicide yesterday by hanging. He was a graduate of Ann Arbor College. Mr. Williams served two terms as County Treasurer. Grief over the death of a member of his family and poor health are supposed to be the cause of his self-destruction.

To the lover of aquatic sports the Harlem River was a paradise yesterday. From Randall's Island to Cedarhurst, a distance of nearly live miles, the river offered an ever-changing panorama, with the myriads of boats, filled with gaudily-uniformed occupants, flashing here and there, across, and up and down the surface of the stream.

When Father Shupe Columbia got back from his ten-cent excursion to Newburg yesterday be figured that he had made just $22 27 out of the first regular day of his new season. He dropped $30 on the Fourth of July and he is pretty nearly square up to date.

The heads of the Danish police have introduced as way of suppressing intemperance which is both simple and original. If a man is round drunk in the streets or at public places a cab is hired and he is taken home.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 7.--Dr. K.T. Mullen and W.T. Wadkins had a dispute about a bill for medical service. Last night Wadkins went to Mullen's, near Woodlaw, and tried to shoot him with a rifle. Mullen succeeded in wresting the gun from him and beat him to death with it.

The call for help which went up from the survivors of the great disaster of May 31, 1889, in Johnstown and vicinity was responded to by the people of the whole country in such a manner as, for Christian charity and liberality, to stand unparalleled in the history of the world.

The body of Thomas Parker of 164 East Twenty-eighth-street was found yesterday in the East River at Pier 50. Juiletta Bachelette, thirty-one years of age, of 196 Bleecker-street, left her home at 6:30 o'clock yesterday morning, and has not yet been heard of. Her husband inquired for her last night at Police Headquarters and said he thought she was insane. She left a letter addressed to him in which she said that she would kill herself.

NEW-HAVEN, July 8.--On the first of next month the new law governing the use of screens in liquor saloons and drinking places, passed at the last session of the Connecticut Legislature, goes into effect.

MALDEN, Mass., July 8.--While Charles W. Carrath, a well-known druggist of this city, and F.H. Miller, a prominent Boston broker, were shooting on a marsh near Malden River this afternoon, Carrath's rifle was accidentally discharged, the ball entering Miller's neck and killing him instantly.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 8.--Intelligence of a double tragedy thirty miles west of Tishomingo, Chickasaw Nation, was received to-day. Miss Metta Overman, the eighteen-year-old daughter of James Overman, has been the object of affection of a school teacher named Oscar Prouffe ...
SAN FRANCISCO, July 8.--Mayr Ecclestein of New-York, who was found unconscious in his room at the Palace Hotel with the gas turned on, died this morning.
WATERTOWN, South Dakota, July 8.--Kronsberg, a little village of fifty people, two miles east of here, was visited by a windstorm yesterday, and every house in the village was ...

Referee Hamilton Cole has reported in favor of Mr. James R. Jessur, who sought to have the receiver of Grant Ward turn over to him some securities in his possession. He deposited 145 shares of the capital stock of the Ohio ...

There is not the slightest foundation for the report going the rounds of the press that Lieut. Paul was relieved from duty connected with the Maine because his energy and desire to further the construction of the big cruiser was objectionable to the employers.

AKRON, Ohio, July 8.--The Pittsburg and Western west-bound passenger train was wrecked in a cut about two miles east of this city last night. An axle of the locomotive broke, the engine being thrown across the track.
JOHNSTOWN, Penn., July 8.--Secretary Davies of the Baard of Inquiry has made a compilation of the losses, reported and estimated, which the board has confirmed.

Private letters from the Caucasus state that the arrangements are almost complete for the inauguration of the new kerosene pipe line over the Suram Pass. The works in connection with the undertaking have been in hand for several months past, and have involved the laying down of thirty-four miles of four-inch oil piping.

DULUTH, Minn., July 8.--So far to-day the strikers have been quiet. Three hundred men were put to work at noon and more trouble may ensue. To date two men are dead, and two more will die. Thirty were wounded in Saturday's riot, ten of them seriously.
A.H. Wood, manager of the new West End Theatre in Harlem, and who is to direct the coming starring tour of Tommy Russell, has secured what he regards as a suitable play for his young star.

LONDON, July 8.--The Valkyrie, Irex, Marjorie, and Yarana raced again to-day in the Royal Clyde regatta. The Valkyrie got the best of a pretty start. The wind was eastern, and all four yachts made a quick passage to Skelmorlie bell buoy.
The prize to be run for at Monmouth Park today is the rich Lorillard Stakes, at a mile and a half, in which Salvator, Longstreet, the Faverdale colt, Sorrento, and Eric are certain to be starters.

The first sailing race which has ever been contested under the auspices of the American Yacht Club took place yesterday afternoon on the Sound off the handsome clubhouse of the organization, situated at Milton Point.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 8.--Nearly four hundred wheelmen attended the annual meet of the Connecticut division of the League of American Wheelmen here to-day, representing clubs in nearly all the principal towns in the State.

It took the Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge precisely fifty-two minutes yesterday afternoon to complete the business of their annual meeting, twice previously postponed at the request of Mayor Grant.

Clarenceville, a suburb of the village of Jamaica, L.I., comes to the front for rapid church building. During the Winter the congregation of the Methodist Episcopal church held services in the homes of its members.

The Court of General Sessions for Oconee County, S.C., convened on Monday last, Judge Hudson presiding. Judge Hudson is noted the State over for his ability and uprightness, and many consider him the ablest of South Carolina's lawyers.

Mrs. Margaret Groshon died at her residence, Port Richmond, S.I., yesterday morning at the advanced age of one hundred years, having passed the centennial point last November. She was the widow of Frederick Groshon, a Justice of the Peace of Richmond County, who died in 1872. She was before her marriage a Miss Meyers of this city.

Evidence accumulates that Alfred Carr, the insolvent Pine-street broker, carried off much of his creditors' money with him when he started for Europe on the Etruria. About two years ago Jay de Lagerberg went to Carr and obtained a loan of $1,200 on Wabash reorganization bonds, Decatur and Eastern Division.

Funeral services were last evening held at the residence of S.W.H. Ward, 813 Lexingtonavenue, over three victims of the railroad accident at Little Silver, N.J. The remains were in three sealed caskets placed side by side in the back parlor and almost buried by palms and flowers.

The Board of Appraisers met at 10 o'clock yesterday morning at the Appraiser's Stores on Laight-street. Appraiser Marvelle W. Cooper, was called upon to preside over the current quarterly conference by the unanimous vote of Appraiser Thad S. Sharretts of Baltimore, ...

LONDON, July 8.--The Massachusetts riflemen have not as yet come to a decision as to the matches in which they will engage at Wimbledon. The decision of the council excluding Springfield rifles from the general contests was expected.

President Harrison's selection of State Senator and ex-Chairman of the Republican State Committee Thomas V. Cooper for Collector of the Port of Philadelphia causes no surprise beyond the wonder that it was not made before.

NEWARK, N.J., July 8.--Fire broke out in a frame building attached to St. Peter's Orphan Asylum on Livingston-street to-night, and the flames spread rapidly. The 100 children in the institution were gotten out safely without panic. The asylum was saved.

NEWPORT, July 8.--Superintendent Kimball, Assistant Treasurer Tichenor, and Assistant Superintendent John Waters of the Life-saving Service visited Block Island to-day and located a new station at Sandy Point. They leave tomorrow on the cutter Dexter for New-Bedford and vicinity and will then take the cutter Gallatin for Massachusetts and Maine stations.

The Executive Committee of the Trunk Line Association met yesterday afternoon and selected H.J. Hayden, Second Vice President of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, to act as Chairman of the Executive Committee pro tem.

Terrace Garden, under Mr. Amberg's management, is a real Summer theatre, modeled on the Continental plan. Enjoyable performances of operetta are given on the stage, and in the waits between the acts, which are reasonably long, the entire audience flocks into the garden accompanied by the orchestra, and there while the band plays the beer flows.
George Mainten, aged thirteen, lay at the point of death last night in Astoria from an injury which he received in a very peculiar manner.

PALOUSE CITY, Washington, July 8.--On Saturday night R.D. Johnson, a well-to-do, respectable citizen, about fifty years of age, living about four miles northeast of here, killed his wife and son, about fourteen years old, and fatally shot his seven-year-old daughter, and then killed himself.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 8.--The Charleston clergy were greatly stirred by the acquittal of Dr. McDow. At a meeting of the Ministerial Union to-day the Rev. C.C. Pinckney, D.D., Rector of Grace Episcopal Church, offered the following paper, which was adopted by the union:

CHICAGO, July 8.--Under the law as laid down by Judge Horton to-day fully three-fourths of the prisoners confined in the bridewell can obtain their release to-morrow by applying for a writ of habeas corpus. His decision was given in the case of the city of Chcaigo against William ...

NEW-HAVEN, July 8.--The funeral services of George H. Watrous were held this afternoon, and were attended by a large number of prominent persons and the Directors of the NewYork, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company.

The data giving the results of the first of the series of metacentre experiments on the new cruiser Yorktown have just been worked up and it is found that the height of the Yorktown's metacentre above the centre of gravity is only ...

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 8.--A valuable bed of hydrous peroxide of iron and red hematite, or fibrous red iron ore has been discovered on the Oscar Satterlee farm, on the west branch of the Neversink, twelve miles from the Ulster and Delaware Railroad at Big Indian.

BOSTON, July 8.--Another Maine delegation appeared before the United States Senate Committee on Inter-State Commerce to-day. It consisted of E.B. Neally, President of the Bangor and Piscataquis Railroad; Corporation Counsel Charles P. Stetson, and Directors Benjamin B. Thatcher and J.P. Bass. They also represent the Bangor Board of Trade.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 8.--To-day the Ninth Regiment and the Tenth Battalion had their first experience of this year's warm weather on the camp ground. The day opened dry and sultry, with a light haze on the river, and the thermometer rose steadily. At 11:30 o'clock it registered 93 and an hour later marked 98 in the shade.
Lieut. Col. George M. Elliot, Corps of Engineers, now at Newport, R.I., has been ordered to Washington to relieve Lieut. Col. John M. Wilson of his duties in connection with the Washington Aqueduct.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 8.--Prof. Brooks, director of the Smith Observatory, discovered a new comet last night and confirmed his discovery by a second observation this morning. Its position is right ascension 23 hours 45 minutes declination south 9 10'. The comet is moving slowly in a northeasterly direction.

The Trustees of the town of Hempstead, L.I., have decided to appeal from Justice Pratt's decision that the bequest to the town for the benefit of its poor in the will of Abram Hewlett is invalid. They hold that the charters given the town by Govs. Kieft and Dongan in 1685 enable it to receive bequests like an individual. The case will be argued before General Term in September.

BALTIMORE, July 8.--The Christian Brothers of the Province of Baltimore, which embraces New-Jersey, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, and the District of Columbia, have made another important acquisition to their already large property holdings.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 8.--Surveyors are at work laying out a route for a new railroad, known as the Raritan Valley Road, which will furnish a new route to the coast.

President HUTCHINS of the Park Board could hardly have given more conclusive evidence of his unfitness for the place he occupies than by expressing the opinion that there is no objection to having Central Park used as a site for a World's Fair in 1892.

CHICAGO, July 8.--It now looks as if the Western States Passenger Association, which has been regarded as one of the strongest railway organizations in the West, was about to be split by internal dissensions. The crisis was precipitated by a private circular issued to-day ...

I am in a position not only to reaffirm the exactness of my statements respecting the Pope's condemnation of the Clan-na-Gael, but I can also further state that the present action of the Vatican is not the result of sudden impulse nor the direct consequence of any isolated crime.

BETHLEHEM, N.H., July 8.--The sixtieth annual meeting of the American Institute of Instruction was called to order in the Grand Casino at Maplewood this evening, President G.A. Littlefield of Rhode Island in the chair.

Dr. John W. Waters, who committed suicide by shooting himself at 30 College-place on Sunday evening, was at one time a practicing physician in Carson City, Nev., and is said to have had an income of $20,000 a year.

An abundance of stock-jobbing dispatches from Chicago gave yesterday's stock market to the bears. Old-fashioned raids did effective business, and scarcely a stock on the whole list escaped without a slump.

While the steamer Sylvan Shore was returning to her dock in Harlem about 5 o'clock on Sunday afternoon with a party of excursionists from Oak Point an accident happened that for a time promised to be attended with serious results.

One of the drollest of the many bits of comedy that are enacted on the streets during the midnight hours was witnessed by a small knot of night owls in Printing House-square last night. A Third-avenue car had just turned the Franklin Statue and stopped. Its only passenger was a well-dressed man in middle life, who was enjoying the sound sleep of the bibulous.

WASHINGTON, July 8.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased $35,800 four and a half per cent. bonds at 106 7/8.

The Sun is entitled to all the comfort it can get from the fact that the internal revenue receipts were rather more last year, and the customs receipts rather less, than the estimate of Mr. FAIRCHILD made nineteen months ago.

The persistency with which Mormon missionaries are carrying on their work in some parts of West Virginia is beginning to excite a great deal of indignation. There is likely to be trouble very soon. Ritchie County is at present the scene of most active operations.

Daniel Frohman, the proprietor of the Lyceum Theatre, has just bought the house and lot 22 East Twenty-fourth-street, in the rear of his theatre. The lot is 25 feet wide by 150 deep. Mr. Frohman intends to alter the house and add an extension to it, so that he will have ...
CHICAGO, July 8.--Herbert A. Pearson, a millionaire mine owner from Bonanza City, Custer County, Idaho, was drowned while bathing in the lake near the foot of Thirty-firststreet last night.

From the point of view of the public morals the only consoling circumstance about the prize fight that was actually fought to a finish in Mississippi yesterday was that it could not have been fought in any more populous part of the country.

The Metropolitan Cross-town Railway Company yesterday petitioned the Board of Aldermen for permisson to construct a railroad through Grand, Delancey, and Spring streets, South Fifth-avenue, Fourth and Macdougal ...

The funeral services of Charles W. Sanders were held yesterday at his residence, 53 East Fifty-third-street. The face of the dead man had a calm, peaceful look as though he were asleep. On the coffin a large ivy wreath had been laid, and in the middle of the wreath stood a full sheaf of wheat.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 8.--The order issued by Judge Edwards giving permission to the Attorney General of this State to bring an action against the Atlantic-Avenue Railroad Company of Brooklyn for the purpose of having its railroad charter forfeited because it failed to run ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 8.--Monroe R. Green, Superintendent of the State Fish Hatchery at Caledonia, has just made his report of the fish and eggs shipped and fish turned loose during the season, which commenced Jan. 28 and closed June 24.
Great slices of roast ox and huge hunks of bread were devoured with relish by Grand Army men of Kings County and several visiting posts at Washington and Broadway Parks, Brooklyn, last evening.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 8.--The Grand Ma-- sonic Lodge in this State will celebrate the centennial of its institution at New-Haven on Wednesday of this week, the event promising to be one of great interest and consequence in the history of the order.

PITTSBURG, July 8.--The Right Rev. Bishop Cortland Whitehead, D.D., of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Western Pennsylvania, was asked to-day what his views were with reference to the proposal of the civil-service reform leaders that sermons on that question should be preached generally over the country on Thanksgiving Day. He said:

Unusual activity was observed in the Hoboken First National Bank Saturday and yesterday, and it is believed that the books of Teller Hoyt, who was arrested for embezzling $18,000 of the bank moneys, are being examined for further deficiencies. Meanwhile, however, the arrangements for a settlement of Hoyt's deficit are going forward.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 8.--The steamer Haytian Republic from this port, which, it was feared, had been damaged or sunk by collision in the Atlantic, arrived here yesterday.

A horse attached to a wagon belonging to the Wheeler Wilson Manufacturing Company, driven by Edward Shane, while standing at the corner of the Bowery and Houston-street took fright at a passing train on the elevated railroad and dashed up the Bowery at a rapid gait.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 8.--Never, during even a Presidential election, has there been so much excitement as there is here now, even when the brutal exhibition is over and it is known that Sullivan was successful and that seventy-five rounds were necessary to "knock out" Kilrain.

Many very interesting and important facts bearing upon the awful Pennsylvania floods are now being made public in a definite and authoritative way, which permits a more intelligent study of the great calamity than has hitherto been possible.

The following cases of prostration by the heat were reported by the police yesterday: John Howard, thirty-five years old, of 16 Gansevoort-street, was prostrated in front of 125 Christopher-street, and was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital.

ALBANY, July 8.--For the quarter ended June 30 the Dry Dock, East Broadway and Battery Railroad Company reports: Gross earnings, $201,290 30; operating expenses, $155,885 72; other income, $1,221 20; fixed charges, $44,183 38; loss from operation, $542 76; profit and loss surplus, $34,872 47; cash on hand, $24,882 85.

Charles Sachs, a Grand Army man in reduced circumstances, has lately been forced to live in a small room. On Saturday he received news that he was entitled to arrears of pension money amounting to $5,378, and that $24 a month would be forthcoming for the remainder of his life. A happier man than Sachs was hard to find in Brooklyn yesterday, as he had been dependent upon the veterans for support.
HARTFORD, July 8.--The stockholders of the Hartford and Connecticut Western Road will hold a special meeting here to-morrow to decide on the route for the Springfield extension of the line.

The shoe-manufacturing firm of G.W. P. Terwilliger of Newburg, N.Y., has made an assignment to Wilson Terwilliger for the benefit of the firm's creditors. No schedule of assets and liabilities has yet been made out.

BALTIMORE, July 8.--Jacob Turner, colored, aged sixteen years, and Edward Bantum, colored, aged fifteen years, were drowned yesterday near Deal's Shore Spring. In company with a number of other boys they were in a boat which upset. The bodies were recovered.
ALBANY, July 8.--For the week ending July 8, 163,912 tons were carried on the canal, against 182,333 tons carried during the same period last year.

BALLSTON, N.Y., July 8.--Everything is in readiness for the opening of the McQuade trial to-morrow morning. The village is full of subdued excitement, although it will hardly feel sure of its prize until court is actually called. Ballston has had many anxious moments in the ...

Manager Mutrie's classic features were a study for an artist yesterday. He stood at the main entrance of the New Polo Grounds at One Hundred and Fifty-fifth-street and Eighthavenue, and as the thousands of patrons of the national game filed into the inclosure he smiled as only a successful baseball manager can.

NEW-HAVEN, July 8.--The Southern New-` England Telephone Company has completed a metallic circuit or double-wire service throughout its territory in Connecticut. The new service is similar to the long-distance service now in use throughout the country, and differs from the old system of grounded circuit ...

BERLIN, July 8.--Emperor William's Norwegian trip has nearly had a fatal termination. While the Emperor and his party were viewing the Buar Glacier a great mass of ice became displaced, and a fragment struck the Emperor on the shoulder, dashing him violently to the ground. Full particulars of the accident have not been received, but it is known that the Emperor's injuries are not at all serious.

NEW-HAVEN, July 8.--The body of the man found floating in the Sound yesterday and supposed by the ticket in his pocket to have been a passenger on the steamer Northam has been identified as Abraham Thompson, Jr., of New-York. He leaves a widow and two children at New-York. His mother resides in this city.
PHILADELPHIA, July 8.--The appointment of State Senator Thomas V. Cooper as Collector of the Port of Philadelphia by the President today created no surprise and gives general satisfaction.

Mrs. Warren, at a meeting of the Trustees of the Denver University last night, perfected her gift of $100,000 to found and endow a school of theology. Her original promise was to give the magnificent sum when $50,000 toward the ...

The tournament for the championship in doubles, held under the rules of the National Lawn Tennis Association of America, was resumed yesterday on the grounds of the Staten Island Cricket and Baseball Club at Livingston. The courts were in excellent condition.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8.--Lue Ah Sing was killed in a Jackson-street Chinese theatre last night in a highbinder quarrel. The assailants were armed with hatchets, revolvers, and iron bars, and entered the theatre during the performance ...

The American Athletic Club offers prizes well worth striving for in its fourteenth annual Summer games to be held at its new grounds, One Hundred and Thirty-fifth-street and Railroadavenue, on Saturday afternoon, Aug. 24, at 3:30 o'clock.

Real estate men do not believe that the city authorities will ever seriously consider the selection of Central Park for the World's Fair of 1892.

Ex-Commodore James D. Smith, Chairman of the America's Cup Committee, on his return to town yesterday morning from a several days' outing on land and water found awaiting him a letter from the Earl of Dunraven concerning the Valkyrie's challenge.

CHICAGO, July 8.--The railway Presidents who meet here to-morrow to see if the shaky machinery of their famous agreement can be patched up and continued in operation began to assemble in Chicago to-day.

Mr. Arthur B. Claflin has purchased, through Mr. O.L. Hughes's yacht agency, the steam yacht Puzzle from Mr. Jordan L. Mott. The Puzzle is 85 feet on the load water line, 96 feet over all, and draws 4 feet 6 inches of water. She was built in 1886 by Samuel Ayres on Mr. J. Lorillard's designs.

WINNIPEG, July 8.--John Norquay, ex-Premier of Manitoba, was given a state burial this afternoon. The militia, the police, fire brigade, Judges, members of the Legislature, Board of Trade, the City Council, and other civic bodies took part in the funeral parade. The funeral was the largest ever seen in the Canadian Northwest. The remains were laid in state in the Parliament buildings until 4:3O P.M., and were viewed by thousands.

The county papers are making especial note of the fact that two very worthy gentlemen declined Gov. Richardson's tender of the State Treasurership. Refusals of public office, when the office was within reach, have been very rare since the Democrats came back to power in South Carolina.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 8.--When the Burke case was called this morning Mr. Howell applied for further time, stating that Carlson, a witness to identify the prisoner as Frank Williams, who rented the cottage, was on his way from Chicago.

The National Convention of the American Flint Glass Workers' Association met at Bellair, Ohio, yesterday and will remain in session all week. Nearly 200 delegates were present from all parts of the country. No trouble is expected on the wage question this year, except among the shade and chimney men who have not been able to settle their differences with the manufacturers.

DETROIT, July 8.--The council of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations will assemble in this city to-morrow and continue in session for three days. It will bring together the most prominent Hebrews of the country.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 8.--The Australian mail brings advices that the steamer Maital, bound from Melbourne to Auckland, struck on rocks June 1 and sank. Purser Larsen and the cook were drowned.
LONDON, July 8.--Sir Andrew Clarke, the wellknown physician, paid a visit to Lord Tennyson yesterday and was surprised to find him much improved in health and mental activity.

Maestro Charles A. Cappa, leader of the Seventh Regiment Band, is going to Europe. He is suffering from an affection of the throat, which prevents him from speaking above a whisper, and he hopes to restore his voice by taking a sea voyage.

The General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday, in an opinion written by Judge Daniels and concurred in by Presiding Justice Van Brunt and Judge Brady, affirmed the decision made in Chambers denying a motion to vacate an order for the examination of Col. W.W. Dudley as a witness before trial in his suit for libel against the Press Publishing Company. Judge Daniels says:

The woman who was taken to the City Hospital, Brooklyn, from Raymond-Street Jail, suffering from a dose of carbolic acid, is surprising the doctors by her improvement. She now has a chance to recover. She proves to be Mrs. Bouchelet of 192 Bleecker-street, this city.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 9.--There is a rumor current that if the United States Government reverses its ruling regarding Mexican silver and lead ores, foreign and Mexican capitalists will unite in building smelters at interior points, ...
A morning paper contained an advertisement yesterday asking that persons who saw a lady thrown from a Broadway car at Seventeenthstreet Sunday night, June 30, address H.M. Herman, ...

By a curious error of the types in yesterday's issue of THE TIMES the epithet "questionable" was applied to the boarding house at 5 East Forty-first-street in an account of the insanity of Ralph Joyce. "Fashionable" was the word written and which should have been printed, as it describes a characteristic that the establishment in question properly possesses.

The decision of ex-Surrogate Rollins in admitting to probate the will of Louis C. Hamersley was yesterday affirmed by a decision of the General Term of the Supreme Court in the suit of Henry Mason against George G. Williams.

Rumors of a marked coolness between the Rev. E.L. Stoddard, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church, and the Rev. Charles Herr, pastor of the Presbyterian Church in South Bergen, Jersey City, were found yesterday to be well founded.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 9.--Thus far this year the scale of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers has not caused any friction between manufacturers and workmen. There have been more signatures affixed to the scale since July 1 than in an equal length of time for years.

Henrietta Francke, a woman about thirty-five years of age, arrival at Castle Garden yesterday from the steamer La Bretagne. She claimed to be a cousin of the Hammerslough Brothers, Broadway clothiers.

The cornerstone of the Manhattan Athletic Club's new house, at Madison-avenue and Forty-fifth-street, was put in its place yesterday by Mayor Grant, several hundred athletes, who had participated in the previous ceremonies, cheering lustily as he slapped and patted the spongy mortar with a solid silver trowel.
RONDOUT, N.Y., July 9.--The intensely-hot weather of to-day was followed this evening by the heaviest rainfall on record here. Water fell in sheets for three minutes.
The Alumni of St. John's College have decided to erect a bronze statue of the late Archbishop Hughes in the college grounds. The statue has already been ordered and is so far advanced...

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 9.--The particulars of a woman's heroic act, which resulted in her death, come from Lake Mohonk. Among the guests at the Lake Mohonk House last week, of which A.K. Smiley is the proprietor, was a family named Brink of New-York City.

That the world is growing smaller every day is a truism joyous to globe-trotters and contractors for building railroads and laying cables, and correspondingly grievous to professional criminals and fraudulent debtors. We infer from the tone of our exchanges that there is an element of sadness...

There is trouble in the Republican camp in Brooklyn, and the boys don't care who knows it. Patronage is at the bottom of it all, and President Harrison and Senator Frank Hiscock are on top of the patronage holding it down.
WASHINGTON, July 9.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased $125,000 four and a half per cent. bonds at 106 7/8.
The New-York Quarantine officers are taking extra precautions at this time of the year to prevent contagious diseases from coming into port.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, July 9.--Wyoming is moving toward Statehood. The election of delegates to the Constitutional Convention held yesterday resulted in the choice of 36 Republicans, 16 Democrats, and 3 independents. The convention will meet Sept. 2. The desire for State government is general.

Mr. Mendenhall was born near Hanoverton, Ohio, in 1841. He was Professor of Physics and Mechanics in Ohio University from 1873 to 1878, and then went to Japan as Professor of Physics in the Imperial University in Tokio. During his stay he organized the general meteorological system of the Imperial Government.

Interest in the question of the authorship of the series of letters which appeared some time ago in the North American Review and were signed "Arthur Richmond" increases with the discussion of the matter.

Civil Service Commissioners Thompson, Lyman, and Roosevelt had a busy time of it yesterday. Messrs. Thompson and Lyman arrived here in the morning from Washington, and Mr. Roosevelt, who had been applying himself closely to catching up arrears of work at his...

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., July 9.--The red raspberry season along the Hudson between Cornwall and Catskill, a distance of over seventy miles, is now at its height. The prevalent hot weather favors the luscious fruit. The season in all probability will last two weeks yet. During the remainder of this week some of the finest berries ever gathered will be shipped to New-York City.
The report of the survey on the Quinnebaug is not yet fully prepared. The general opinion is that the Quinnebaug's repairs will exceed in cost the 20 per cent. limit.

The report of the Commissioners of Estimate appointed to acquire title to the land taken for the new parks was confirmed by the General Term yesterday, with a few exceptions. Chief Justice Van Brunt wrote the opinion in the case.

SING SING, July 9.--Three explosions of some patent powder very much resembling dynamite and manufactured by the Rand Drill Company at North Tarrytown wrecked a brick building in which it was being packed for shipment this morning about 10:30 o'clock.

LONDON, July 9.--There was a great house gathered at the Lyceum Theatre to-night to welcome Sarah Bernhardt to London and see her portrayal of Lena Despard, the character which Mrs. Bernard Beere had "created" and monopolized in England.

Commodore James D. Smith, Chairman of the America's Cup Committee of the New-York Yacht Club, yesterday gave out for publication the letters he has received from the Earl of Dunraven and Secretary Grant of the Royal Yacht Squadron, explaining, or at least attempting to explain, the reasons for withdrawing the challenge to sail an international race for the America's Cup.
BUFFALO, July 9.--The Buffalo City Directory for 1889 was issued to-day. It contains 82,027 names, an increase of 2,470 over last year. This is indicative of an increase in population...
Agnes Herndon will open her next season as a star on Aug. 12, in the Windsor Theatre, this city, appearing in a new play entitled "La Belle Marie."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9.--The American steamer Haytian Republic, now in port, was on fire May 26. The fire was discovered in the lower coal bunkers, which was only extinguished after eight hours' hard work.

A dispatch from Vineyard Haven, Mass., received by THE TIMES last evening, states that the schooners Sea Fox, Mayflower, and Iroquois and cutter Medusa will sail to-day for Marblehead, instead of yesterday as they had planned.
The National Confectioners' Association opened their sixth annual convention at the Grand Central Hotel yesterday morning at 11 o'clock.
ELIZABETH, N.J., July 9.--Manager A.H. Simonds of the Temple Opera House has come into possession of several relics of J. Wilkes...

ALBANY, N.Y., July 9.--The twenty-seventh convocation of the Regents of the University of the State began its session in the Senate Chamber at 10 o'clock this morning. Among those present were the Rev. Harris R. Greene...

The decision of the Supreme Court, Special Term, enjoining Mrs. Margaret Haberkorn (Margaret Mather) from acting under other management than that of J.M. Hill was yesterday reversed by a decision of the Supreme Court, General Term.

The Hatters' Association held its national convention yesterday at 263 Bowery and there were present delegates from most of the hat manufacturing districts. The condition of the trade was reported good everywhere, and then the convention discussed several amendments to the constitution and by-laws. To-day the delegates will go on a picnic.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 9.--A blazing sun, heated camp streets reflecting a steady glare, and scarcely any wind stirring have made the day one of the hottest that has been felt here this season.

LONDON, July 9.--Several members of the Massachusetts rifle team entered the contest for the Alfred Cup at Wimbledon to-day. Each marksman fired seven shots at the 200-yard range, the highest possible score being 35 points. The winner scored 33 points. Of the American riflemen, Johnston took a minor prize, with a score of 32. Hinman and Huddleston made 31 each, Bull scored 30, Hussey and Farrow 29 each, and Edes 27.

CROW CREEK AGENCY, South Dakota, July 9. --There was another council this afternoon. White Ghost, Drifting Ghost, and Bull Ghost spoke on the part of the Indians. They complained generally of the failure of the Government to treat them justly; that they formerly...

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 9.--Deputy Tax Collector Michael Finneran was arrested to-day by Sheriff Glasby for the costs in a replevin suit brought against him and Controller Carlton some months ago by Councilman Noyes.
The Senate committee which has been pursuing its investigation of the question of Canadian competition with our railroads has learned just one thing during its sittings in Boston.

NEWARK, N.J., July 9.--Dr. Lawrence Vanderpant, a well-known Orange dentist, was found dead in his office this afternoon with the gas turned on. He had been dead nearly twelve hours. He was of eccentric disposition, and it is thought that domestic troubles caused him to kill himself.

DETROIT, Mich., July 9.--The city wears a festive air this evening. The principal thoroughfares, parks, and gardens are brilliantly illuminated, while most of the public buildings and many private ones are tastefully decorated.

RONDOUT, N.Y., July 9.--Physicians at many points along the Hudson Valley say that scores of patients are afflicted with a peculiar disease, which is variously called "muscular rheumatism" and "a new manifestation of malaria."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 9.--A number of horses in this locality and along the Hudson have been attacked with a mild form of epizootic. Several of the horses booked for the races here were withdrawn on that account. There are no fatal cases, but an old driver says the disease makes the animals very weak. He attributes the sickness to the estremely humid state of the atmosphere lately.

A cable dispatch from London announces the engagement of another American heiress to a titled gentleman of the British empire. The fortunate nobleman is Lord Edward Fitzmaurice, the younger brother of the Marquis of Lansdowne, formerly Governor General of Canada and now Viceroy of India.

State Assessors John D. Ellis of Antwerp and James L. Williams of Poughkeepsie will begin their investigation of the values of the pieces of real estate in this city to-morrow, and they say that they will occupy ten days in their researches.
The steamers Furnessia and Wisconsin, which left yesterday for Glasgow and Liverpool, took sections B and D, respectively, of the teachers' excursion, the first section of which left on the Suevia.

LONDON, July 9.--In the House of Commons Mr. W.H. Smith, the Government leader, moved that the Committee on allowances to Prince Albert Victor of Wales and Princess Victoria of Prussia on the occasion of their marriage consist of twenty-three members.

Edward Goldsmith, a member of the Socialistic Labor Party, disappeared several days ago, and his relatives say that they have not heard of him since. He had been heard to say that he could not get any work and that he would do away with himself.

PARIS, July 9.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day Admiral Krantz, Minister of Marine, declared that there was need of several new war ships, the cost of which would be about 58,000,000f.
WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., July 9.--In Nippenose Valley, this county, yesterday, Samuel Bowles, a farmer, was mowing grass, and laid his mower down to go into the house.

The second round in the contest for the double tennis championship of America was finished at Livingston, S.I., yesterday afternoon. The winners of the two matches were Messrs. Taylor and Slocum and Hall and Campbell, respectively.

It was Lorillard day at Monmouth Park yesterday, and the usual great crowd was present to see this, one of the richest of the three-yearold prizes of the year, run for. A good crowd of youngsters were out for it, Mr. Haggin starting both Salvator and Kern, the Dwyer Brothers...

It was a New-York day on the New Polo Grounds yesterday. The Giants took a lead of 7 runs in the first two innings, increased that advantage as the game wore on, and finally came off the winners by the famous score of 9 to 0. From start to finish only one club was in the race, and the Pittsburg never had a fifty-toone chance.

The Electric Light "combine" made an attempt to perfect its monopoly of street-lighting before the Gas Commission yesterday at the Mayor's office. The Brush Company protested against the consideration of bids from companies having no wires in the streets upon which it bid.
Commodore Jefferson Hogan of the Atlantic Yacht Club is busily engaged in making preparations for the annual cruise of the Atlantic Yacht Club.

VIENNA, July 9.--The Delegations to-day adopted the estimate of expenditures for the Foreign Office. In connection with the estimate a report was submitted on behalf of the Foreign Office by Baron Falke de Lilienstein.

ALTOONA, Penn., July 9.--The Pennsylvania State Teachers' Association began its session here to-day and was addressed by Dr. E.E. Higbee, State Superintendent of Public Instruction of Pennsylvania. Dr. Higbee spoke first with regard to the curriculum of the public schools, saying that it should embrace...

KANSAS CITY, July 9.--During the past two days heavy rains have visited the entire State of Kansas. Hot winds during the latter part of last week caused some apprehension regarding the welfare of the corn crop. The rains came in time not only to save the crop, but soaked the ground so thoroughly as to dispel all fear of disastrous effects from possible future hot winds.

Several cases of public interest were considered yesterday by the United States Appraisers, who are holding their quarterly conference at the Public Stores Building in Laight-street. Recorder Sharretts gave the details of the conference.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 9.--An attempt was made before daylight yesterday morning to blow up with powder a building in the central part of the city in which the Salvation Army has established barracks.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 9.--Smith Scudder, a farmer living in Fanwood Township, about three miles east of here, was driving a spirited team to his mowing machine yesterday afternoon, when the horses became frightened. He was thrown from his seat directly in front of the knives. The keen-edged shuttles cut open his side and lacerated him terribly. He died very shortly afterward. He leaves a wife and several children.
EDINBURGH, July 9.--The cricket game between the Philadelphia team and the Gentlemen of Scotland was concluded to-day, and resulted in a victory for the Americans.

CAIRO, July 9.--Advices were received here to-day that Col. Wodehouse's cavalry occupied the camp of the enemy and found it deserted by all except several men, women, and children, who were dying from thirst and exhaustion.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 9.--Gov. Hill was a visitor here last Friday and Saturday. This is the second time that the Governor has been to Seabright this Summer. He was the guest of Ferdinand P. Earle of the Normandie, who is a member of the Governor's staff. The Governor took a sail in a steam launch belonging to John Duncan, a wholesale grocer of New-York. The party went up the river as far as Red Bank.

PITTSBURG, July 9.--The Rev. E.F. Flemon, alias John Yeldell, was arrested last night in this city on a charge of murder.
Postmaster Van Cott was yesterday in a position to give some statistics about the business of the New-York Post Office, returns for the year ending June 30 having been received and compiled.
Patrick Packenham, John Lewis, and James Nolan were yesterday morning sentenced by Recorder Smyth and Judge Cowing to be hanged on Friday, Aug. 23.

There stands at West End, Coney Island, a picturesque group of cottages painted in drab tints and giving the sole restful bit of color for a long stretch of beach. Their utility as the Health Home of the Children's Aid Society may be understood when it is known that it is seldom that there are less than 250 children and mothers within the walls of the cottages or enjoying themselves on the sands.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., July 9.--The Underwriters Association special agents and adjusters of New-York State were in session to-day at the Sagamore, and there was a large attendance.

SIOUX FALLS, Dakota, July 9.--The Constitutional Convention of South Dakota was in session to-day less than an hour. President Edgerton announced the membership of thirty-two standing committees, averaging ten members each.
The eighth annual National Convention of Christian Endeavor Societies will begin its session to-day at Philadelphia, in the First Regiment Armory.

Jersey City's Board of Finance has announced a reduction of $502,000 in the city's debt by redeeming $402,000 of the city of Bergen and Hudson City improvement, water, and public school bonds which mature this month. Provision has also been made to meet another $100,000 of improvement bonds not yet presented. The entire lot bear 7 per cent. interest. None of these bonds will be renewed.
The Brooklyn Board of education was in an exceedingly benign mood yesterday at their annual meeting, and showered blessings freely in the substantial manner of increased salaries.

STREATOR, Ill., July 9.--Action was taken by the miners at Streator yesterday which will probably end the strike. The Coal Run Company, which some time ago proposed the plan of profit sharing to its employes, has, since the rejection of that scheme, signified its willingness to arbitrate.

LONDON, July 9.--At the Newmarket meeting today the race for the July Stakes for two-year-olds at five furlongs and one hundred and forty-two yards was won by the Duke of Hamilton's ch. c. Loup, with Keythorpe second, and Salutation third. At the Carlisle meeting to-day the race for the Cumberland Plate at one mile and three-quarters was won by Propriety, Sorrento second, and Countess Lilian third.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 9.--George E. Sanders, for many years head clerk at the grocery store of R.W. Rice Co. in North Plainfield, has left town with a record of peculation and forgery that extends back for many years.

DETROIT, July 9.--The Triennial National Council of American Hebrew Congregations convened in this city this morning and was opened with prayer by Dr. Silverman of NewYork.
The Grand Lodge of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks is meeting in annual session at Masonic Temple, Sixth-avenue and Twenty-third-street.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 9.--Crop reports received from all parts of Ontario and a few points in Western Quebec show that Fall wheat will be more than an average crop; Spring wheat, barley, and oats an average one; peas slightly below the average; roots average, and fruits almost a failure.

BETHLEHEM, N.H., July 9.--The second day of the American Institute of Instruction's annual session was called to order this morning with a very large attendance. It is estimated that over one thousand teachers are in town.
LONDON, July 10.--The steamship Thingvalla, (Dan.,) Capt. Laub, from New-York June 22, arr. at Copenhagen yesterday.
