In the easiest possible manner the New-Yorks disposed of the Pittsburg players yesterday and sent the latter away without allowing them to win a game of the series on this trip. The victory was due to hard batting.
BELVIDERE, N.J., July 10.--Oxford Furnace is excited over the stealing of valuable papers belonging to the late Col. William Scranton, who died June 19.

LONDON, July 10.--Sarah Bernhardt has written an indignant letter, in which she complains of the unprepared state of the stage settings for her representation of "Lena" last evening. She expresses her thanks to the audience for their courtesy under these deplorable circumstances.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 10.--Cool air, with gray mists clinging to the mountain peaks round about and a sprinkle of fine, light rain, has made the day an agreeable change from the intense heat of yesterday.
The last meeting of the Board of Education before vacation was held yesterday afternoon. The Principals and teachers in the evening schools for the term of 1889-90 were appointed.
DETROIT, July 10.--The monthly crop report for the State for July is just out, and upon this the first estimate for this year's wheat crop is made.

HELENA, Montana, July 10.--The seventh day of the Constitutional Convention was one of marked activity. The members are taking hold with a will and a seeming determination to make every hour count. Many members expressed the belief that the convention can adjourn in twenty-one days.

BERLIN, July 12.--A fire which broke out today among some hemp warehouses on the docks along the River Pregel at Koenigsberg, caused a loss of 500,000 marks. LONDON, July 12.--The Magdeburg Sugar Ring, being unable to meet the settlement, was compelled to ask a week's grace, which the Sugar Export Association declined to grant. The collapse caused a fall of 4 marks in Hamburg yesterday.

BERLIN, July 12.--The Cologne Gazette gives prominence to a statement that the Russian War Minister, who is staying at Vichy, has received a very important dispatch from the Czar. DETROIT, July 12.--The Inter-State Committee resumed its investigations at the Russell House this morning. LIVERPOOL, July 12.--The Gentlemen of Liverpool finished tbeir first inning to-day for 123 runs. They could make no headway against the bowling of Patterson of the Philadelphia team, who took 8 wickets for 30. The Liverpools immediately followed with their second inning, making only 170. Clarke took 5 wickets for 22 and Brown 3 for 16. The Americans won by an inning and 152 runs.

Judge Cullen of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, decided yesterday that Dr. William S. Forbes of Philadelphia had no cause of action in his suit against the executors of the estate of Robert Lenox Kennedy to recover $5,000 for professional attendance. Dr. Forbes claimed he accompanied Mr. Kennedy to Europe as his physician. Mr. Kennedy's relatives set up a defense that the physician accompanied him as a friend. The Judge thought so, too, from the evidence.

CAIRO, July 12.--The dervish prisoners arriving at Assouan are terribly emaciated, having suffered greatly from hunger and thirst. Among them are many women and boys.

Wellington R. Burt and his fellow-members of the Michigan Salt Association went home yesterday morning without forming an international salt trust. The Kansas and Louisiana salt men did not materialize. Franklin Woodruff expressed disappointment at the failure, but said it was only temporary and that the idea would not be dropped, but would be prosecuted to success at a more propitious time.

RICHMOND, Va., July 12.--The furneral of the late Mrs. Julia Gardiner Tyler, the wife of exPresident Tyler, took place from St. Peter's Cathedral this morning at 11 o'clock. The sacred edifice was filled with representatives of every walk in life.

The Chicago and Grand Trunk Railroad indulged in a little rate cutting yesterday on its own account. NEWBURG, N. Y., July 15.--The location of the Post Office in this city will, on Oct. 1, be transferred to the Bigler Building, in which place it was previous to removal to its present site--in a building owned by the State Senator Pete Ward.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 15.--The term of the Circuit Court of this county, which has just closed, disposed of one of the oldest suits pending in Kentucky, and one of more than ordinary interest, having been in the courts since 1811, known as that of Wickliffe's executors against Breckinridge's heirs.

MORRIS COVE, NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 15.-- A very severe storm has been raging over Long Island Sound, and a number of the yachts belonging to the fleet of the Atlantic Yacht Club have been tossing about on the choppy sea all day long, making strenuous efforts to accomplish the second run of the club's annual cruise.

While excavating for a sewer at Peck-slip on South-street yesterday the workmen brought to the surface several sections of wooden pump log water pipe, which at one time constituted part of the distributing pipes of the first water works built in this city.

PATERSON, N.J., July 15.--Excise Commissioner Renny of Passaic is highly indignant because Policeman Lockwood arrested him as a corner lounger, just as he would any ordinary citizen, and had him fined $1.

CHICAGO, July 15.--The Senate Inter-State Commerce Committee resumed its work to-day. It began with the hearing of a special committee of the Board of Trade. Secretary Stone read a report on questions submitted by the committee to the Board of Trade on July 10. Among the questions and answers were these:

WHEELING, West Va., July 15.--At a picnic at Reas Run, on the Ohio River, yesterday Jacob Francis, a wealthy farmer, was assaulted by John and James Rowland and Thomas Cook. Francis's friends took part and a pitched battle ensued, knives, revolvers, and stones being used freely.

The residents of Woodhaven, L.I., are discussing the elopement of one of their most promising young women with a young man to whom her parents had objected. The young lady was Miss Alice Cauling, and she now is Mrs. George Nostrand.

MILWAUKEE, July 15.--E.D. Wheeler of Manistee, Mich., one of the most promiment salt manufacturers in the West, is in Milwaukee today, and gives an outline of the plans of the proposed international salt trust.

The chance of Millet's "Angelus" coming to America grows less and less as the days move on. The native art dealer is a shrewd man, and backs his offer with a certified check for a fabulous amount; but the question has become international.
OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 15.--This was the third day of the annual meeting of the Sunday School Assembly in the Grove, and was celebrated as "Teachers' Day."
There is a dispute in Long Island City which is likely to be continued until the next city election. It is between the Rev. Father McGuire of St. Mary's Church and the city administration.

Along the line of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railway as far east as Bridgeport, Conn., are bonfires big enough to set an east side boy wild with enthusiasm.
James A. Patterson, Jr., of Staunton, Va., made an assignment yesterday to A.C. Braxton, an attorney of Staunton. His assets are over $60,000 and debt less than $10,000.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 15.--The Summer School of Pedagogy began its sessions this morning at Educational Hall. Prominent educators were present from nearly every State in the Union. SAN FRANCISCO, July 15.--The contest over the property of the late Thomas H. Blythe was commenced in Probate Court to-day.

The city's title to the ownership of the land bounded by Eighth-avenue and the Macomb's Dam road and One Hundred and Fifty-fourth and One Hundred and Fifty-fifth streets is disputed by Nathaniel Jarvis, Jr., and the heirs of James Connor.

Negotiations for the release of Denny, the third baseman of the Indianapolis Club, to Washington, which were suspended some weeks ago, have again been reopended, and it is probable that within a few days he will become a Senator.
Notwithstanding the new anchorage laws have gone into effect, the old buoys have not yet been changed.
CHICAGO, July 15.--The ordinance granting the Standard Oil Company the right to construct and operate a pipe line to the centre of the city was vetoed by Mayor Cregier to-night.

The Newburg Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals hae decided to withdraw from the fostering care of the New-York society, and on Saturday next articles of incorporation as a separate society will be presented to Judge Cullen of the Supreme Court for his approval. The incorporators will be George W. Peters, T. Hazzard Roe, Charles E. Williams, Nehemiah Fowler, Hugh s. Banks, Henry Dudley, Alfred Bridgman, Dr. G.J. Appleton, and F.W. Scriff.
PHILADELPHIA, July 15.--John Cadwalader, Collector of the Port of Philadelphia during the Democratic Administration, formally vacated his office to-day to Senator Thomas V. Cooper, the new incumbent.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 15.--About 400 representatives of the local Brotherhood of Engineers of the State held a secret meeting here yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, July 15.--Yesterday afternoon two heavy freight trains on the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway came together with terrible force at the foot of a steep hill two miles south of Boonville, Mo.
GRAFTON, North Dakota, July 15.--The wheat crop of Dakota is 30,000,000 bushels short. The figures are large, but not in the least exaggerated.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., July 15.--The Board of inquiry met to-day and issued orders for relief to those entitled to it. Tne commission at Cresson classified the sufferers into classes 1,2,3,4, and 5, and recommended that immediate payment be made to classes 1,2, and 3, requiring $496,000.
NEW-HAVEN, July 15.--An important legal fight is being waged between the shore town of Clinton and Mr. A.J. Hurd, one of the wealthiest and best-known citizens in the town.
BURLINGTON, Vt., July 15.--The annual Commencement of the medical department of the University of Vermont occurred this evening, the exercises being held in the Howard Opera House.

Another change "for the good of the service" was made yesterday in one of the small offices which became a Tammany perquisite according to the local political notions as a result of the last election.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 15.--The report that Secretary Blaine had resigned is positively denied by Walker Blaine, who is here to consult with the Secretary upon matters pertaining to the State Department. Mr. Blaine's health is said to be good.

A meeting of the Theatrical Managers' Protective Association was held yesterday afternoon in the Bijou Opera House. Frank W. Sanger presided in the absence of President A. M. Palmer, who is in Europe.

James Connolly, an eccentric carpet weaver, was buried at Jamaica yesterday. He was over eighty years of age and had lived in the village over fifty years.

WELLINGTON, Kan., July 15.--Arrivals from the Cherokee strip to-day report that Texas fever is playing havoc with cattle there. Forty head were seen in dead one pasture yesterday, and in others from seven to twenty-five carcasses were lying around. Hundreds of cattle, they say, are dying in Oklahoma, and they predict that not a hoof will be taken from there to the north for some months.
MEMPHIS, July 15.--Yesterday morning Swan Bures, a negro charged with the murder of a young white man named Whitehurst, was lynched at Iuka, Miss.
Samuel W. Walker, a boy aged fifteen, residing at 1,987 Seventh-avenue, this city, was drowned while bathing at South Beach, S.I., on Sunday evening.
LONDON, July 15.--The Parnellites held a meeting in a room in the House of Commons today for the purpose of taking action relative to the proposed Tenants' Defense League.

BISMARCK, North Dakota, July 15.--The discussion in the various committees of the reports of sub-committees occupied the earlier part of the day, and few Constitutional Convention delegates had much, if any, leisure, even for talking politics.

Judge Ingraham, in Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday hanged down a decision refusing to annul the marriage of Fannie F. Crowell to Henry B. Maurer. The marriage took place May 25, 1886, when the girl was just over fourteen years of age.

The Board of Appraisers met yesterday and discussed several questions of classification. Metal buttons again claimed attention on the ground that many imported as such, under a duty of 25 per cent., should be classed as brass buttons, under a duty of 45 per cent.

A cablegram from London last night announced that Capt. La Bosquest of the steamer New-York City of the Bristol City Line had been lost overboard while the vessel was bound from this port to Havre. Nothing could be learned last night concerning the missing Captain. The vessel is represented at this port by James Arkell Co., of 19 Whitehall-street.

The Board of Aldermen decided yesterday to adjourn until Aug. 5. Immediately after it had taken this action Alderman Carlin asked his colleagues to pass, over the Mayor's veto, a resolution to permit the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas Aquinas to build a vault under a sidewalk.

John Bolander, a ship broker of 15 Statestreet, yesterday again denied the story that he had purchased the old revenue cutter McCullough for Gen. Legitime's navy. He said that he had purchased her solely on speculation. He would neither deny nor affirm a report that he had been approached by Legitime's agents with a proposition to buy the boat.
Public Works Commissioner Gilroy yesterday cut down the force employed in maintaining the boulevards and roads on the west side.

Edwin Herzog, about twenty-eight years of age, a member of the Stock Exchange, and a pushing young man, who was well known and well liked down town, was drowned late Sunday night at Larchmont.
Argan Flynn, seventeen years old, of 211 East Seventy-sixth-street, pleaded guilty yesterday, before Judge Cowing, of committing a murderous assault on Betty Harsches of 248 First-avenue.
Constable De Mott of Hempstead, found a man who said he was Frank Meyer of 137 East Thirty-seventh-street, this city, running a shell game of Sunday at Rockaway Beach and arrested him.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 15.--The New-Jersey State Dental Society will open its annual meeting in the ballroom of the West End Hotel on Wednesday morning. About two hundred members will be in attendance. The meeting will continue three days.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 15.--Rhode Island's license law is not likely to go on the statute books without a good deal of trouble. The hitherto harmonious joint committee of the Legislature, which is drafting it and will report to the adjourned session to-morrow, divided for the first time to-day on party lines, and the division was a bitter one.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 15.--At last the rumors about the purchase by English capital of a big interest in Minneapolis flour mills are becoming more definite.

There was nothing like a boom in yesterday's stock market, but there was a healthy reaction from the panicky feeling and action that ruled in the latter part of last week. During the earlier part of the day there were smart advances that carried the general list upward, though at the close of business quotations ran off again, leaving the net changes of the day few and inconsequential.

PITTSBURG, July 15.--This afternoon United States Marshal Storm and Deputy Thomas J. Lyon went to the county jail to see if they could identify the Rev. E. Flemon as John Yeldell, the alleged South Carolina murderer.

The body of seven-year-old George Engelhardt, whose home was at 148 Bayard-street, Brooklyn, was found yesterday morning in the bottom of an unused well at the corner of Meeker-avenue and Ewen-street. LONDON, July 15.--The St. James's Gazette says that the Widow Acton, who committed suicide by drowning in Tegernsee Lake, Bavaria, on Friday, was a relative of an Italian family of the same name. The report that the suicide was Lady Acton, the sister of t he German Minister at Washington, was not true. Lord and Lady Acton are now at their villa at Torquay.

WHEELING, West Va., July 15.--The Dayton and Wheeling baseball teams were arraigned before Justice Phillips to-day, and, on examination being waived, they were held to the Grand Jury. Twenty-five dollars bail was exacted in each case. The examination on the second arrest before Justice Arkle was deferred until tomorrow evening.

Barth Lamassi of 2,404 Third-avenue called at Castle Garden yesterday with a letter received from a Hungarian named Landsman, now in Progreso, Yucatan. The letter is written in Hungarian. Landsman calls on Lamassi to secure his release from Progreso, where he is held in slavery.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 15.--The will of the late John Guy Vassar is to be brought into court, probably one day this week, by the executors. They are unwilling to construe certain important clauses of it and will lean on the court in their dilemma.

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., July 15.--No one need be surprised if by to-morrow night McQuade is a free man, acquitted by the order of the court. As it is, the defense will move for an order of acquittal, and it hard to see how Judge Daniels can refuse it.

Taylor of London County; Lieutenant Governor--W.J. Shelburn, Montgomery County; Attorney General--Judge J.M. Quarles of Staunton. The convention adopted the national prohibition platform.

ROUNDOUT, N.Y., July 17.--Buffalo moths and carpet bugs are making housewives weary along the Hudson River. The havoc wrought by these pests during the past few weeks has been extensive. Up in portions of Rensselaer County and elsewhere that they carpet bugs are said to be so voracious that they actually, in instances, have eaten off the cords by which mirrors and pictures were suspended.

SHELTER ISLAND, N.Y., July 17.--A steady and fresh western breeze, comparatively smooth water, a liberal allowance of bright sunshine, and a favorable tide were the conditions which governed the special race of the Atlantic Yacht Club's cruising fleet to-day.

Assistant Treasurer Roberts has made several promotions at the Sub-Treasury, owing to the vacancy left in the office of chief bookkeeper by the death of Andrew J. Bixby.

Nobody got very rich in yesterday's stock market. A few stocks went down; practically none went up. The Street was filled with entertaining tales, but the chronicles and predictions generally laoked refutable backing, and the result was that they failed to stir up much speculative fervor.

Mr. Robert W. Goggin died yesterday afternoon at his residence, 927 Gates-avenue, Brooklyn, aged sixty-seven years. He had been employed on THE TIMES as a compositor for the past thirteen years. His remains will be taken to Washington, D.C., his former home, for burial. He leaves a widow and three children.

EAST KINGSTON, N.Y., July 17.--Yesterday afternoon Robert Leonard found the dead body of a man in the Hudson River near the icehouse of D.D. Addis. In one of the pockets there was a ticket from Bondout to Glasco on the steam yacht Glenerie. Patrick McGinnis thinks the remains are those of John Donnelly of Brooklyn, who had worked in the brick yard of Robert Mains.

James Coupland, a resident of Amityville, L. I., went to Greenwood Cemetery late yesterday afternoon to visit the grave of his son, Edward, who was accidentally shot and killed three years ago. He sat down near the grave and wrote several notes in a blank book.

CHICAGO, July 18.--This afternoon the only matter of general interest in the great mass of business disposed of by the Executive Board of the Knights of Labor was the leasing of the coal mine owned by the organization near Cannelsburg, Ind. The mine was let to the present lessees for a period of ten years.

LONDON, July 18.--Upon the opening of the session of the Parnell Commission to-day Mr. Matthew Harris, who has been under cross-examination for the past two days, again took the stand for the purpose of stating that Messrs. Egan and Brennan severed their connection with the Fenians on joining the Land League.

Horatio Howard, who was recently appointed to a clerkship in Naval Officer Burt's department at the Custom House, is a young colored man. He stood first on the certification sent to Col. Burt, and he was selected on his merits. His color was not known until he presented himself for work yesterday.

CHEYENNE RIVER AGENCY, Dakota, July 18.-- The Indians assembled yesterday morning and asked that certain portions of the act of Congress which are not clearly understood be read again. These related to taking lands is severalty and the method of expending the permanent fund. Gov. Fostor explained carefully all these provisions.

LONDON, July 18.--Mr. Lincoln, the United States Minister, visited the camp of the Massachusetts riflemen at Wimbledon to-day, and was accorded a hearty reception. The American team afterward visited the Crystal Palace.

When yesterday's stock market opened, Richmond Terminal stock was selling at 22 , and nobody seemed to be paying any attention to it. But is wasn't long before attention was paid to it. Instead of selling at 22 it dropped to 19. This might not have surprised anybody over much, only the rest of the market went slumping along with it.

A number of gentlemen were standing in front of the St. James Hotel about 9 o'clock last night when an attractive young woman in a pretty black dress came along and pointed out one of the young men to Detective Sergeant Hanly of the Central office who was following her.

NASHVILLE, July 18.--the fifth session of the National Educational Association was devoted to a further consideration of denominational schools and the history of education. The Hon. John Jay of New-York submitted a paper.

DENVER, Col., July 18.--The Criminal Court Grand Jury, which has been investigating the charges of corruption made against State officials in connection with the purchase of supplies and furniture for the use of the last General Assembly, adjourned late last night.

Under the spreading branches of the slippery elm and shrinking mimosa trees that constitute Gabe Case's grove on Central-avenue the jolly members of the Hoboken Turtle Club sat down to breakfast and dinner yesterday for the second time in the ninety-sixth year of the club's existence.

The A. C. Nellis Company, seeds, at 64 Cortlandt-street, is in the hands of Deputy Sheriff McGinnis, on two judgments for $1,082, which President A.C. Nellis confessed to his attorneys and wife, the result of a quarrel between the President and some of the stockholders.
Henry Merwies, a German fifty-five years old, hanged himself yesterday in his bedroom, on the top floor of the tenement house 328 West Thirty-eighth-street. He lived there with his wife.

The meeting of the New-York Yacht Club held yesterday afternoon at Delmonico's Broadstreet place laid a rather large wetblanket upon the Earl of Dunraven's eagerness to send the Valkyrie to this country by refusing to put up a special cup to be raced for by the visitor.

BOSTON, July 18.--It has just become known here that President Patton of Princeton, who was a guest of President Elliott of Cambridge at the Harvard Commencement, received from Harvard University the honorary degree of LL.D. By some oversight Dr. Patton's name was omitted from the official list of recipients of degrees which was furnished to the press, and the fact that he received the honor has not been published.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 18.--Tne Kebo Valley Club House opening took place to-day, and was an informal but brilliant affair.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, July 18.--The Territorial Convention called for the purpose of framing a scheme for provisional government met at noon. The convention which was held Monday at Frisco in opposition to the present convention has had the effect of limiting the representation.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 18.--The State Convention of the Prohibition Party of NewJersey met this afternoon in Educational Hall. About two hundred and fifty delegates, representing every county in the State, were present, and others are expected to arrive in time for tomorrow's meeting.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 18.--The hearing of testimony in the Andover controversy before ex-Gov. Robinson as Commissioner was resumed this morning, the Board of Visitors opening their side of the hearing.

PEEKSKILL, July 18.--The Twenty-third have taken to grand guard duty as naturally as a duck to water. Yesterday's experiment was so popular and so successful that a request was made this morning to Gen. Porter for another for this afternoon.

Nothing queerer in the form of a legal proceeding has ever been witnessed than the inquiry now going on as to the propriety of executing the sentence of the law upon a convicted murderer. The condemned man is not rich.

The Democratic State Committee met at Taylor's Hotel, Jersey City, on Wednesday, and appointed a committee to request ex-Gov. Leon Abbett to preside over the State Convention. He is a candidate for the Governorship.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 18.--The Manitoba and Canadian North west wheat crop is a failure beyond doubt. Lately some encouraging dispatches were received, but later authentic reports confirm the statement made a few days ago of the crop's being a failure.
William Elvin, an English passenger on the steamship Westernland, which landed her steerage passengers at Castle Garden yesterday, is in a peck of trouble.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 18.--This is the second day of the annual meeting of the NewJersey State Dental Society at the West End Hotel. Dr. Richard C. Newton of Montclair read an essay on "The Teeth as a Factor in Diagnosis."
LONDON, July 18.--At the Leicester meeeting today the race for the Leicestershire Summer Handicap, for three-year-olds and upward, was won by King Monmouth, with St. Helen second; Stone Cross, third.

The removal of the baseball grounds to One Hundred and Fifty-fifth-street and Eighth-avenue has given opportunity for a display of police authority that is amusing to those who view it philosophically, but decidedly disgusting to others. The new grounds are down in a hollow.

The Northern Pacific Railroad Directors yesterday referred to their Finance Committee a financial plan for the future management of that great property.

BISMARCK, Dakota, July 18.--The joint commission for the division of property between the States of North and South Dakota met again today, but is still a long way from an agreement as to the basis of division. They are now far apart as to facts as well as to the method of dividing.
DAYTON, Ohio, July 18.--Capt. Abbott and seven other secret service men this morning made a descent on the United States Hotel, near here, to capture a gang of counterfeiters.

The United States Trust Company of New-York has filed in the office of the Secretary of State of Illinois a release of a mortgage held against the property of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway and the Chicago, Evanston and Lake Superior Railway. The mortgage was executed in September, 1888, and was for $2,500,000 to secure additional tracks and terminal facilities in Chicago, and to build an extension in Northern Wisconsin.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 18.--The court-martial, Capt. Oscar F. Stanton, President, trying Commander P.F. Harrington on a charge of "negligence in allowing a vessel of the navy to ground" continued to-day.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., July 18.--To-day Judge Cummin and Banker Thompson, having charge of the relief funds, began paying out money to the sufferers. Up to noon $6,000 had been paid out; most of the checks being for $80, the lowest amount paid to a single sufferer.
KINGSTON, N.Y., July 18.--A decision in a motion of interest to owners of streams, water companies, and manufacturers has been handed down by Judge Edwards, at Special Term of the Supreme Court.

Messrs. Ellis, Wood, and Williams, the State Assessors, listened to a piece of Tax-Commissioner Michael Coleman's mind yesterday. They went into the Tax Commissioners' office and handed to Mr. Coleman a list of 1,000 parcels of land to which they had affixed valuations, and asked that the valuations which the Tax Commissioners had placed upon them be voted down.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 18.--The commision appointed to appraise the value of the Prescheur Bettner property, opposite the Union Station, which the Pennsylvania Railroad Company wants for its fourth track, met yesterday and decided to complete its work and make a final report to the court by Aug. 7. The company has offered the owners $25,000 for the property, on which is situated a restaurant. The owners, however, want $40,000.

LONDON, July 18.--The election in the west division of Carmarthenshire to fill the vacancy in the House of Commons caused by the death of Mr. Walter Powell, home ruler, resulted in the return of Mr. Morgan, Gladstonian, who received 4,252 votes, against 2,533 cast for his opponent, Mr. Drummond, Conservative. At the last election Mr. Powell received 4,181 votes and Sir J.C. Lawrence, the Liberal Unionist candidate, 1,916.
WASHINGTON, July 18.--The Washington and Cleveland teams played a most exciting and interesting game here to-day, which Umpire Curry called at the end of the tenth inning on account of darkness.

KEY EAST BEACH, N.J., July 18.--The thirteenth Summer School of the American Institute of Christian Philosophy opened to-day under the direction of the Rev. Dr. Charles F. Deems of New-York, the President Bishop Fallows of Chicago lectured on "Christian Pantheism." To-night the Rev. Dr. H.C. Hovey of Philadelphia told his personal experiences in a pedestrian trip through the mountains and canons of Colorado.

ALBANY, July 18.--Mayor S. De Forest of Schenectady appeared before the State Civil Service Commission to-day and said he would comply with the civil, service laws by adopting civil service regulations for his city. Mayor John Nills of Watertown, who failed to attend the last meeting and had been subpoenaed to attend this one, also expressed his willingness to comply with the law.

On complaint of Dr. Edward W. Martin, the chemist of the Health Department, Justice Gorman, presiding at the Jefferson Market Police Court, issued warrants yesterday for the arrest of Wallace C. Andrews, President of the...
ALBANY, July 18.--Emma Degroat, a young woman, was killed in John Stevens's shirt factory this afternoon.

Mr. Elbridge T. Gerry made the first part of yesterday's session in the electrical execution hearing particularly lively. He measured swords with Mr. Cockran in repartee, and incidentally entertained the largest crowd which has yet gathered to hear the testimony in this interesting case.
LOUISVILLE, July 18.--It is reported here that an English syndicate through Nathan Hofheimer is continuing its efforts to buy up the distilleries of this State.

LONDON, July 18.--At the inquest held on the body of the woman found murdered in the Whitechapel district yesterday morning the fact was developed that in addition to two large gashes there were fourteen other wounds on the body. The greater number of the wounds, however, were only skin deep.
LONDON, July 18.--In the second day's contest of the Kingston regatta the Yarana again defeated the Valkyrie by a few seconds.

PORT AU PRINCE, July 7.--Port au Prince, within the last few days has been in a state bordering on frenzy. Hippolyte has assaulted the extreme outworks. He is being held in check at the present writing. Legitime is impressing into the ranks every man capable of carrying a rifle.

The Board of Street Opening and Improvement will this afternoon listen to arguments by Alderman Walker and other Ninth Ward citizens in favor of the purchase of the old cemetery ground at Hudson and Clarkson streets...

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 18.--The contest over the will of Christopher Meyer was continued to-day, but the whole session was occupied in the examination of Ernest Gerlach, the nurse, and in discussing attempts to put in evidence his memorandum book. He explained certain gifts from parties to the contest which he had recorded in the books. Geriach has been on the stand during nearly the whole of three sessions. The case will be resumed July 24.
A good many citizens seem to have grievances against street musicians, principally against organ grinders, judging from the letters received by Mayor Grant daily.

CHICAGO, July 18.--The races at Washington Park to-day were run with these results: FIRST RACE.--Purse, One mile, Bravo, 102 pounds, (Ray,) won; Winona, 110, (Barnes,) second, and Cassius, 109, (Taral.) third. Time--1:41 , Betting--5 to 1 Bravo, 20 to 1 Winona.

The body of the young woman who was known only as Kitty Doane, and who killed herself by taking carbolic acid in her room, 152 Third-avenue, last Saturday, will be taken from Daly's undertaking shop in East Twenty-sixth-street...

NEW-ORLEANS, July 18.--This has been the hottest day of the year, and, in fact, for some years, the thermometer at the Custom House reaching 95 . There were three fatal cases of sunstroke--John T. Hay, a drummer from Kansas City; K.K. Thomas, a photographer, and a German laborer, whose name was not discovered.
The Board of City Record passed yesterday upon all the requisitions for stationery for the various city departments before it, and then stopped the work of supply until December.

COLUMBUS, Texas, July 18.--The Colorado River at this point is thirty-one feet high and rising. The lowlands are all inundated and crops are entirely destroyed. The damage to the cotton crop alone in this county is estimated at $500,000.

BALLSTON SPA, July 18.--All the testimony in the McQuade case is in, and the arguments will be made to-morrow. Ex-Judge Fursman will address the jury in behalf of McQuade, and Col. Fellows will follow him for the prosecution. Then Judge Daniels will charge the jury. Unless the eloquent counsel are remarkably longwinded, McQuade's fate will be put into the hands of the jury before Court adjourns to-morrow, and there may be a verdict by evening.

Indianapolis's aggregation of brawn and muscle received a set-back yesterday in the shape of a defeat administered in the most approved style by the Giants. After the poor success in Boston on Monday, the Hoosiers set about to redeem themselves yesterday, and with that purpose in view put Boyle, their best...

Benny Falk, who for a long time has enjoyed a reputation of a peculiar kind on the race tracks, opened a pool room at 80 Park-row yesterday, and engaged a booking expert called "Blackie" to work for him and make his books.
CHICAGO, July 18.--Last night Frank Ives made a total of 315 while Jacob Schafer scored 226 in a game of balk-line billiards in this city. Ives's average was 18 6-33 and Schafer's 18 31-33.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 18.--Dr. McDow, the slayer of Capt. Dawson, was expelled from the South Carolina Medical Society to-day. At a special meeting of the society the following preamble and resolution were passed:

CITY OF MEXICO, July 18, via Galveston.--The anniversary of the death of ex-President Juarez was observed by the Liberais, who marched in grand procession to the cemetery wherein Juarez was buried. Some students in the procession shouted "Death to the clergy!" "Death to the Conservatives!"

CHICAGO, July 18.--The boiler in the planing mill of the R.V. Stone Lumber Company, on Hoyne-avenue, exploded at 8:15 o'clock this morning. The mill was blown to atoms, scarcely a board or a sign of the machinery being left.
ST. PAUL, July 18.--At the request of Gov. Merriam Attorney General Clapp has rendered an opinion upon the John Day Smith law to regulate executions, and he pronounces it constitutional.

Brig. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald presided at the election held in the Seventh Regiment Armory last night for a successor to Col. Emmons Clark. He was assisted in that duty by Lieut. Col. Robert W. Leonard, Assistant Adjutant General First Brigade, and Adjt. George Washington Rand.

The runaway marriage of Johanna B. Cuych and Charles M. Florenzi, a Brooklyn bartender, created a storm in the home of the bride's parents. On July 2 the young people went to Jersey City and were married.

The Jersey City and New-Haven Clubs played a close and exciting game at Oakland Park yesterday, which resulted in favor of the latter. Horner for the visitors pitched strongly in the early part of the game, but he was hit hard toward the close, but too late, however, for his opponents to win. Score:
HUDSON, N.Y., July 18.--Many complaints have been heard of late in reference to newspapers being delayed while in transit in the railroad postal cars. Generally the complaints have been well founded.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 18.--Prof. J.B. Smith, the entomologist at Rutgers College, has received letters from all parts of the State reporting the presence of the Texas or horned fly, also known as the buffalo fly, whose sting is fatal to cattle.

Gen. MAHONE is determined to establish his dictatorship over the Republican Party in Virginia in the political canvass of the present year, and, to give peculiar emphasis to his pretension to control its action, he proposes to have himself nominated for...

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 18.--S.R. Seamans, Treasurer of the National Millers' Association, says that, so far as he knows, there are no representatives of English capitalists in the city for the purpose of purchasing some of the flouring mills.

Not many men who lodge in the Bowery are burdened with a package containing $24,500 in bank notes. But there was a Bowery hermit, a morbid man, with the miserly instinct developed to a high degree, who for a decade or more led a wretched existence and all the while kept within reach a parcel done up in brown wrapping paper which contained the sum named in good American currency.
The Atlanta Constitution prints as follows correspondence which has lately passed be tween Gov. Gordon of Georgia and Gov. Taylor of Tennessee on the subject of extradition. Gov. Taylor wrote:

A morning newspaper yesterday published an article reciting the fast, published some days ago in THE TIMES, that Archbishop Corrigan was going to Rome, and then endeavoring to explain the reasons why he intended to take the trip. Among other things it said: "It is a matter of history among the Catholic clergy that Cardinal McCloskey was as much pained...

Senator Gorman created a slight breeze among the Democratic politicians yesterday by going down to Wall-street, calling upon Col. Brice, and having a long talk with him. Both he and Col. Brice denied that their colloquy had any political significance.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 18.--The committee appointed to investigate the accounts of City Clerk Cook, who had been charged by a local paper with being short in his accounts, have reported that the city owes him 21 cents, instead of his being indebted to the city.

For the purpose of demonstrating its facilities for making the fastest time between this city and Coney Island the New-York and Sea Beach Railway Company yesterday sent out a special "flyer," guaranteed to make a quicker passage...

PHILADELPHIA, July 18.--The Phillies ran away with Pittsburg this afternoon. Galvin was the easiest kind of a mark, 13 of the 15 runs being earned off his pitching. Casey was very effective, the visitors making only 4 hits,...

NEWBURG, July 18.--Suit has been commenced in the Supreme Court by Mary L. Mowatt of Fishkill against Theodore C. Mowatt, Augustus W. Mowatt, John M. Mowatt, Adelia and Nicholas Hopper, and Helen B. Saunder of Fishkill Landing; Wines B. Mowatt of Elmsford, near Tarrytown, and Hester C. McFarland of Brooklyn. It is brought to recover possession of property valued at $300,000.

Andrew Carnegie's music hall company has just acquired some additional real estate and will erect thereon a much larger building than was originally contemplated. Now its frontage on Fifty-seventh-street is 150 feet, on Seventhavenue 175 feet, and on Fifty-sixth-street 25 feet.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 18.--O.P. Cheney's stables at Canal Winchester, were struck by lightning and burned this evening. There were twenty-five horses, more or less noted and valuable, in the barn.
Bernard Mohar, an insane hatter, fifty-seven years old, who lived at 480 Grand-street, committed suicide yesterday in the barber's shop at 474 Grand-street by cutting his throat with a razor.

EATONTOWN, N.J., July 18.--About one hundred children were brought to Maxwell in Eatontown, last week by the New-York Life fresh air fund. On Tuesday one hundred more were brought here from the city. The Maxwell cottages are owned by a New-York gentleman, and he leased the property to Life for the season for 1 cent.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 18.--The police of Cranford have discovered that a gang of young robbers, who call themselves "The Moonshiners," exist in that village and have been systematically plundering stores and dwellings for six months.

RONDOUT, N.Y., July 18.--The weather was so cool along the Hudson River and in the Catskill and Shawangunk Mountains this morning that light overcoats for men and wraps for women were desirable. Cooler weather in July has not been experienced in many years. The sky was of a deep blue. For several hours not a speak of color was to be seen.

LONDON, July 18.--The Egyptian Government has notified the French Government that the latter's refusal to accept the conversion scheme will cost Egypt yearly 200,000. The Jockey Club will withdraw the license of R.G. Sherrard, the celebrated Newmarket trainer.

CHICAGO, July 18.--After an eleven days' trial in Judge Waterman's court, the jury returned to-day a verdict in the case of the Troy Lumber Company against A.E. Cartier. The verdict was the result of a fraud which the...

The tugboat W.A. Lavergne was picked up in the bay early yesterday morning in a sinking condition, having collided with the steamboat John H. Starin while coming down the Sound on Wednesday night. The crew were rescued by the police patrol boat Judge Moore of Brooklyn. The Lavergne was towed to the foot of Twenty-third-street, South Brooklyn, by the Judge Moore.

Mrs. Lillie Mager, who lives at 4 Hope-street, Brooklyn, established a reputation for courage on Wednesday night that is making her the subject of local consideration. She saw a man trying to enter her house with a skeleton key.
Hong Lee's laundry, at 1,414 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, is next door to Gigengo Scaryati's fruit store.

The United States Board of Ordnance assembled in the Army Building, Whitehall-street, yesterday, and organized for business in accordance with orders from the War Department. Major Gen. Schofield is President and Capt. Morrison...
PITTSBURG, July 18.--Suits are to be at once commenced by the Westinghouse Electric Company against all companies using the alternating current system.
The Brooklyns returned home from their Western trip yesterday and were greeted by over five thousand persons when they took the field to play the Athletics.
Commissioner Blanchard of the Central Traffic Association said yesterday that the restoration of grain rates had been postponed from July 22 to Aug. 1.

LONDON, July 18.--Disquieting reports from Vienna regarding Servian affairs are coming in to-night, which are likely to give a new impetus to war rumors and preparations. It is still officially a profound secret, but I have reason to believe that when the naval manoeuvres are over here in September it has been arranged to hold another series immediately following them at the...

LANSING, Mich., July 18.--A sharper named Streeter worked the gold-brick dodge to a successful issue here last night upon William McKeilops, a wealthy gentleman of Perry, Shiawassee County, and President of the First National Bank of Corunna.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 18.--Joseph Bolvin, who arrived in this city yesterday, on a raft of square timber from Upper Ottawa, reports that seven men were drowned on the way here. There were three different accidents.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 18.--At last the State officers of Indiana have succeeded in negotiating the sale of the $3,900,000 of bonds issued for the purpose of refunding the school fund loan. A telegram has been received announcing that New-York capitalists have been found who...
The steamship Veendam, which sailed for Rotterdam yesterday morning, carried as passengers Miss Ellen Herndon Arthur and Miss Jessie McElroy, the daughter and niece of exPresident Arthur.

An order was entered in the Supreme Court yesterday, signed by Judge O'Brien, restraining the Union Pacific, Northern Pacific, and Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad Companies from paying to any one the interest on the coupons of about $60,000 in bonds, ...

MONTREAL, July 18.--W.R. Anderson of the firm of Anderson Anderson of London, with whom the Dominion Government has entered into a new mail contract for an Atlantic fast service, left for New-York this afternoon. He expects to be ready to commence operations in two years, but will perform partially the weekly service in eighteen months. The firm will begin at once to build four steamers.

LOW POINT, C.B., July 18.--The Norwegian bark Adelphia, from Buenos Ayres for Sydney, fifty days out, has just passed here. She signaled that she had on board the whole crew of the British bark Harriet Campbell, Capt. Pearson, of Weymouth, which was abandoned on May 31 in latitude 31 south, longitude 45 west, while on a voyage from Mobile for Buenos Ayres. The Adelphia reported all well.
BALTIMORE, July 18.--The second trial of the new United States gunboat Petrol was not as satisfactory as the first. She failed to meet the requirements in the important point of speed.

PURVIS, Miss., July 18.--To-day legal proceedings against those who abetted the late prize fight were begun here, this being the seat of the Second District Court of Marion County, in which the battle was fought. Like Richburg, Purvis is on the railroad, is surrounded by pine forests, and has similar industries of saw...

About five hundred oil and water-color paintings by American artists are to be shipped to Chicago from this city, Boston, Philadelphia, London, and Paris this week, and hung at the seventeenth annual Inter-State Industrial Exhibition, which opens there on Sept. 4.

Contrary to expectation, the Secretary of the Treasury did not communicate any more questions of classification yesterday to the Board of Appraisers, and, after waiting until 3 P.M., it adjourned sine die.
LONDON, July 18.--The Philadelphia cricketers played to-day against the Gentlemen of Surrey. The home team, which consists of noted players, went first to the bat and made 294 runs.
A Mrs. Buckingham, who formerly lived in this city, and who had been committed to the Richmond County House to be examined as to her sanity, appeared before the Board of Superintendents...

FORT SMITH, Ark., July 18.--Col. E.C. Beudinot, the Cherokee lawyer, in a speech at a picnic to-day in the Cherokee Nation, a few miles from here, to a large concourse of people, expressed his views without reserve relative to the CheroKee Commission and the sale of the Cherokee outlet.

The announced sales at the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday, Thursday, July 18, were postponed as follows: Sale by Richard V. Harnett Co., auctioneers, of a plot of land and buildings on Franklin-av., New-Brighton, S.I., was adjourned to Oct. 9, and sale by James C. Lalor, auctioneer, of three flats, with lots, 1,120 to 1,128 9th-av., northeast corner of 69th-st., was adjourned sine die.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, July 18.--A storm of unusual severity passed over this section yesterday. The wind blew almost a gale. Rain descended in torrents for two hours and the thunder and lighting were terrific.

WASHINGTON, July 18.--Secretary of the Treasury Windom is not troubled by the published reports that the reserve in the New-York banks is getting dangerously low and that there are indications of a stringency in the money market, which may call for some action by the Treasury Department.

News was brought to this city yesterday that tends strongly to prove that Inventor Peter Campbell's airship America, which made an ascension and trial trip from Brooklyn on Tuesday last, has been lost, together with its navigator, Prof. Edward D. Hogan of Jackson, Mich.

HARTFORD, July 18.--Insurance Commissioner Fyler has completed the examination of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, which he undertook at the request of President Greene after the Indianapolis defalcation.
RONDOUT, N.Y., July 18.--Several large new spots were noticed on the sun to-day. In one group there are fifteen small spots. The spots are being closely watched by astronomers along the Hudson River.
CHICAGO, July 18.--The "model town" of Pullman may have a rival in the "model village" of Wagner.

PATERSON, N.J., July 18.--About three hundred danters, doublers, and winders, employed in the silk-throwing establishments of Paterson, are on strike owing to notice given by their employers that after the next pay day...

The summer vacation of W.H. Crane is rapidly drawing to an end, and he will soon be hard at work preparing for his coming season as a lone star.
About 2 o'clock yesterday morning Capt. Samuel Corse of the schooner Mary Alice of Far Rockaway, while sailing in the inlet, heard the cries of men, apparently in distress.

A number of our Republican contemporaries have been lashing themselves into a most unseemly state of mind over certain criticisms by THE TIMES of Mr. HARRISON, by grace of DAVID B. HILL President of the United States.
Policeman David Holran, who belonged to the Eleventh Precinct, Brooklyn, was dismissed a few months ago for drunkenness and assaulting a citizen.
HARTFORD, July 18.--Mrs. Elizabeth Wells, the widow of Dr. Horace Wells, the discoverer of anaesthesia, who died here yesterday, was buried this afternoon.

When the English bark Belt of Windsor, N.S., came into port yesterday morning she had aboard of her twelve persons who had been rescued from a sinking vessel. They were Capt. Herbert Hage, his wife, and ten sailors from the Norwegian bark Cupido.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 18.--The programme of Superintendents' Day at the Sunday School Assembly included an address on "The Mountains of Palestine" by Mrs. B.B. Loomis.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 18.--Thomas, Timothy, and Dennis O'Leary, three boys, were prisoners to-day in the police court on complaint of their father, who charged them with having stolen $2.50 from his pockets.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 18.--Capt. William J. Blake of Fairmount, Md., owner and commander of the schooner John H. Ford, was attacked this afternoon by Samuel Fisher, a colored seaman, nineteen years of age, who inflicted three terrible knife wounds in his victim's left side. The wounded man will probably die during the night. Fisher was arrested.

The indictment for perjury against Charles Philipsen, former manager of the North River Fish and Game Company, found in connection with the Washington Market investigation last Spring, was yesterday dismissed by Judge Cowing.

BOSTON, July 18.--State Treasurer Mardin this afternoon opened proposals for $2,500,000 State House construction loan bonds, and accepted three bids of the Bank for Savings of New-York, each for $500,000, at 105.37, 105.77, and 106.17. Those premiums will make the rate of interest equivalent to 2.65, 2.62 , and 2.60 percent, instead of 3 percent. The Treasurer has not yet awarded the remaining $1,000,000.

APPLEDORE, Isles of Shoals, July 18.--The cruising fleet of the Eastern and Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Clubs came to anchor here last evening, and at 9 o'clock this morning got under way for Boothbay, Me. The run from Marblehead was made in six hours.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 19.--The following companies filed reports with the Banking Department to-day for the half year ended June 30:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 19.--The court-martial trying Commander Harrington for "negligently allowing a vessel of the navy to be grounded" continued to-day, with Capt. Oscar F. Stanton president of the court, Lieut. Perry Garst Judge Advocate, and Lieut. Alexander McCracken, United States Navy, counsel for the defense.

LONDON, July 19.--I.I. Mapes, a graduate of Columbia College, New-York, has taken the Edinburgh University medal for proficiency in the study of anatomy. His rating was 95 per cent. of the available marks. Douglas Ewell also a graduate of Columbia College, stood third in the class, his percentage being 93.

BALTIMORE, July 19.--The Sun's Washington special says: In the diplomatic circles the impression is growing that the United States and France are making preparations for a controversy over a small island under the jurisdiction of the Haytian Government.

WINNIPEG, July 19.--The attorneys for Burke, the Chicago suspect, are preparing their appeal from the decision of Judge Bain committing him for extradition. Application for a writ of habeas corpus will bring the matter up within a few days. Burke's friends, there is every reason to believe, have at last come to his rescue.
LONDON, July 19.--The game between the Philadelphia cricketers and the Gentlemen of Surrey was continued to-day. The Americans played sound cricket and finished their first...

GUTHRIE, Indian Territory, July 19.--The Territorial Convention assembled at 11 A.M. The Committee on Credentials submitted its complete report, seating ninety-two delegates. The report was, after some wrangling, adopted. The report of the Committee on Organization recommended F.T. Green of Edmond for Permanent Chairman and M.A. Duff of Cimarron...
In the batch of appointments of Postmasters to Presidential offices, sent out yesterday from Washington, was this one: "Adam Berry at New-Brighton, N.Y., vice Robert Humphrey, removed."

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 19.--The convention of the New-Jersey Prohibitionists at Educational Hall finished its labors this afternoon and adjourned at 2:30 o'clock. George La Monte, President of the First National Bank of Bound Brook, received the nomination for Governor on the first ballot.

Capt. John Allen was one of the famous men of the times when the British held possession of Penobscot Bay in the early part of this century. He was presented with a sword for gallant conduct in capturing a British privateer. Many stories have been told about the dashing Captain.

BOSTON, July 19.--The Terminal City people are jubilant to-day over the receipt of a cablegram from agents of the company in London, England, announcing the sale of a block of 100,000 shares of the company's Treasury stock for the round sum of $200,000, or $2 per share.

George Bechtel, the Staten Island brewer, who died at his home in Stapleton on Tuesday last of heart failure, was buried yesterday afternoon in Silvermount Cemetery with all the honors due so geneous and fair-minded a man. At 2 o'clock, the hour set for the funeral services at his residence on Richmond Hill, more ...

Notwithstanding the crops along the water courses and in the lowlands of the State have been seriously damaged by excessive rains and floods, the indications are that the crops of the State at large, as a whole, will be rather better than usual.

Editha Diss Debar--that is the way the notorious medium gives her name--entered 145 Broadway yesterday and waddled along the hall to the elevator door. When the elevator came down the boy operator opened wide his eyes with wonder and astonishment.
BALLSTON SPA, July 19.--As was predicted in THE TIMES a fortnight ago would be the case, Col. Fellows's bluff of trying McQuade has ended in a farce and the boodle Alderman is acquitted.

RED BANK, N.J., July 19.--A match race for $250 a side between the yachts Enigma and Jessie, owned, respectively, by Fred Oakes and Robert Furey, was sailed this afternoon on the South Shrewsbury River.
LONDON, July 19.--An Englishman was arrested this morning on the charge of having murdered the woman whose body was found Tuesday morning in Castle-alley, Whitechapel.

PITTSBURG, July 19.--The published false report that Carnegie, Phipps Co. (Limited) had made a cut of $6 per ton on steel plates caused quite a flurry among brokers, manufacturers, and mill workmen to-day.

Chief Officer Smith and Chief Engineer Malcolm of the steamship Mars, with twenty-five of her crew, arrived yesterday from La Guayra on the steamship Philadelphia. The Mars was wrecked off the island of Great Avis, in the Caribbean Sea, on July 5.

LONDON, July 19.--The Massachusetts rifle team took part in the shooting for minor prizes in the Steward's contest at Wimbledon to-day. The conditions were seven shots each at 200 yards. Following are the scores of the winners: Farrow, 33; Edes, Sergt. Bull, Doyle, and Hinman, 32 each, and Johnston, Merrill, and Bumstead, 31 each.
JOHNSTOWN, Penn., July 19.--Business in Treasurer Thompson's little bank progressed smoothly to-day and about $10,000 was paid out, making a total of $23,895 for the two days.

Gen. John E. Ward, Winthrop Parker, and James H. Wood, composing the commission for the condemnation of certain school sites, met yesterday at-45 William-street to listen to objections to their awards for the six lots or parcels on the northeast corner of Mulberry and Bayard streets.

NEW-HAVEN, July 19.--The returns of the Connecticut State Board of Health from all but one town show 925 deaths in the month of June out of a population of 756,722. This represents a death rate of 14.6 in 1,000. New-London has the highest death rate, 22.2.
TRENTON, N.J., July 19.--Arthur Ogilby of New-Brunswick, the embezzling cashier of the Dime Savings Bank, was pardoned to-day.

Derrick, the colored minister who made himself "numerous" as one of the National Republican Committee's Spellbinders during the last Presidential campaign.
PEEKSKILL, July 19.--The excitement and fun in camp last night was the experience of the grand guard which left camp about 4 o'clock in the afternoon under command of Capt. De Forest of Company C.

NEWARK, N.J., July 19.--Ex-Judge J. Frank Fort and Alderman Gaddis returned from Washington last night with the information that in a few days Postmaster Fiedler of Newark will be removed to make way for E.L. Conklin. Some weeks ago ex-Speaker Schuyler B. Jackson pasted together a lot of Republican newspaper clippings and sent them on to Washington.

A decidedly curious case is occupying the attention of Surrogate Weller of Queens County. In 1873 a man who was known as John Snowden died at Hicksville. His heirs were his widow and three children. To the former he bequeathed his entire estate, valued at that time at $12,000. The will was probated.

SARATOGA, July 19.--The war on the hackmen, which is the way the hackmen put it, seems to be definitely settled. At a meeting of the village trustees Tuesday night a resolution was passed to enforce the law already existing against obstructing the streets.

Eleven innings were required to decide the New-York-Indianapolis game yesterday and the latter won by a score of 9 to 8. We mentioned with great gratification in our Sunday morning's issue that our distinguished ex-Governor, the Hon. T.J. Jarvis, had been elected to the Presidency of the Agricultural and Mechanical College of Raleigh, selected to govern boys with the fine capacity he had displayed in the government of men.

ASHLAND, Wis., July 19.--A wife murder occurred near Bad River Station, this county, yesterday afternoon. The victim was the eighteen-year-old bride of Joseph Fuschs, and the murderer is the husband, a man of about forty years of age. They had been married about two weeks, and made their home at Glidden.

One Indian boy says he doesn't like Hampton because "everything is too green." The rich, dense folige and grass here are in too great contrast with his sun-baked prairie.
BRADFORD, Penn., July 19.--An explosion occurred this morning in the "grinding department of the Eagle Valley Tannery at Ridgway, Penn. Immediately the tannery was in flames.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 19.--There are no new movements in the suit of Miss Mary Mowatt against her brothers and sisters to compel them to return $100,000 alleged to have been fraudulently obtained and to relinquish their claims on real estate in Mexico and elsewere valued at $200,000 more.

As there is a vacancy in the Military Academy at West Point for the Twelfth Congressional District, represented by Roswell P. Flower, that gentleman has appointed a committee composed of Prof. J. Howard Van Amringe. Gen. Fitz John Porter, Commissioner Allen, Assemblyman Blumenthal, and Paul Dana to select a candidate for competitive examination.
Not a Summer now passes without extensive concentrations of garrison troops in camps of instruction and elaborate programmes of practice manoeuvres.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 19.--The arrival here this afternoon of the steamer Nellie with two menhaden steamers in tow created a good deal of interest, as it has been known that Rhode Island fishermen have for days been openly violating the law by setting seines in Buzzard's Bay.

Work on the new track of the Monmouth Park Association will be begun on Monday next. The association now owns 660 acres, including the old and the new tracks.

Mr. Wallace of the firm of Wallace Finch, blacksmiths, at Madison, N.J., is about to bring proceedings against the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad to recover damages. On Thursday evening he purchased a ticket from Hoboken to Madison.

CANSO, N.S., July 19.--The Captain and crew of the Norwegian bark Foerder of Drammen, Norway, reached here this morning in a boat from Sable Island. They report that their vessel was wrecked there on Sunday last, but as the sea was smooth they landed without difficulty. The Foerder was bound from Newport to Halifax.
PARIS, July 19.--M. Spuller, Minister of Foreign Affairs, as a mark of esteem, has presented Mr. McLane, ex-United States Minister here, with a, handsome Sevres vase.

TROY, N.Y., July 19.--The saengerfest to be held here next week promises to be a noted musical event. Singing societies from many points in this and adjoining States will be present. The committee of Arrangements have been at work ever since last Spring perfecting the details.
The situation in Hayti is evidently very critical for resident foreigners, who are almost if not quite the only civilized people within the limits of the Black Republic.

Surrogate Ransom yesterday announced his decision that the will of old Patrick Trenor, who died in January, 1888, could not be admitted to probate. Hearings have been going on before the Surrogate in the contest of the will for several weeks.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 19.--To-day, the seventh of the ten days' session of the Sunday School Assembly in the Grove, was celebrated as "missionary day." A lecture by Mrs. B.B. Loomis on "The Journeys of the Patriarchs"

To apologize for giving so much space to the prize fight one paper says: "Those who do not approve the fight cannot refrain from taking interest in the physical condition, training, habits of the men." And another dwells upon the fact that "the championship of the world is at stake."

The New-York German Gun Club held its annual Summer tournament at Dexter Park, Jamaica, L.I., yesterday afternoon. The conditions were in favor of good scores, with the exception of the wind, which interfered especially in the shooting at inanimate targets.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., July 19.--The greatest disaster which ever befel Little Kanawha came last night in the shape of a terrible cloudburst which has completely flooded the county, destroying many lives, carrying off thousands of dollars in property, and ruining the crops for many miles.

Benjamin Faik, the pool seller who disappeared from his office at 80 Park-row on Thursday after a run of hard luck with the money which his confiding customers had paid him, could not be found yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 19.--The gang of real estate swindlers which operated with success in St. Paul did not confine their operations to that city, but are known to have been extensively at work in this city.

De Lancey Nicoll, in reply to questions put to him yesterday concerning the cancelling of the bail of Charles Philipsen, who was indicted for perjury in connection with the West Washington Market investigation, said yesterday that a march had been stolen on him in the matter.
By another freak of good fortune two explosions which occurred in the electrical subway at Broadway and Nineteenth and Twentieth streets last evening Failed to either kill or maim anybody.

Louise Martin, the six-year-old child of Thomas Martin of Soho, in Essex County, N.J., was picking blackberries a day or two ago, when two ragpickers seized her and threw her into a wagon they had with them. They covered her with rags and drove on.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 19.--The Unitarians of Plainfield have organized a church society as the result of a series of meetings held during the Spring with that end in view. Henry B. Wells was elected President and the following Board of Trustees was chosen: Chairman--Job...

John L. Sullivan arrived in Jersey City last night over the Pennsylvania Road. There were very few people, except a dozen reporters and the station employee, around when he alighted from the train. He got off on the baggage platform and hastened to a cab waiting outside.
ALBANY, July 19.--Since the publication of the list of the successful candidates for free State scholarships in Cornell, several substitutions have taken place by reason of withdrawals.

EDINBURGH, July 19.--Mr. Parnell arrived here to-day, to receive the freedom of the city. A large crowd had gathered at the railway station to greet him and he was accorded an enthusiastic reception. Shortly after his arrival he addressed an open-air meeting of workingmen.
Col. Shepard's Fifth-avenue stages are becoming quite as dangerous for women unaccompanied at night as the bobtail cross-town cars, concerning which recent complaints have been made.

One night in January last a policeman saw a man walking along Fifty-third-street with his throat cut. The man, who was a painter named William Rinck, said he had been assaulted and robbed, and his case created something of a sensation at the time.
LONDON, July 19.--The steamship critic, (Br.,) Capt. Davies, from New-York July 4, arr, at Leith to-day.

The total number of Confederate pensioners in South Carolina, as shown by the record in the office of the Secretary of State, is 1,932. Of these only 539, or a little more than onefourth, are men who were in service, the rest being soldiers' widows, who have become dependent in their old age.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 19.--The annual meeting of the New-Jersey State Dental Society continued in session all day in the West End ballroom. The election of officers for the ensuing year took place this morning, resulting in the election of Dr. S.G.C. Watkins of Montclair as President.
There will be a good day's racing at Monmouth Park to-day, and, if the weather will continue pleasant enough, an enormous halfholiday crowd will be at the track to enjoy the sport.
ELIZABETH, N.J., July 19.--A bold leap for liberty was made by a young man here this morning whom the police tried to surprise at his mother's house.

Judge O'Brien of the Supreme Court has confirmed the report of Referee W.C. Cox granting Dr. Frederick W. Olcott a separation from his wife, Hilda F. Olcott, Dr. Olcott is the Assistant Surgeon of the United States receiving ship Vermont. He and his wife lived together less than a year.

UTICA, N.Y., July 19.--W.C. Chambers, a prominent citizen of Ogdensburg and a member of the firm of Chambers Douglass, committed suicide last night with a razor. He left his wife asleep and went down stairs to do the deed, returning to die by her side. Despondency was the cause of the suicide.

Chairman Walker of the Inter-State Commerce Association rendered a decision yesterday in regard to the relative adjustment of rates on bullion and ore from Colorado points to the Missouri River. He advises the restoration of the bullion rate to $8 per ton. it having lately been reduced to $7, and decides that with such a basis in effect on bullion the rate on ore should be $5 per ton.

UTICA, N.Y., July 19.--About 4 P.M. to-day the Herkimer Creek at Schuyler's Lake, Otsego County, began to rise, and to-night has flooded the village four feet deep, driving people from low rooms. The course of the creek has changed, and it now runs directly through the village, between the two hotels.

WASHINGTON COURT HOUSE, Ohio, July 19.-- At 5:30 o'clock this evening a portable saw mill engine of twenty-five horse power of H.P. Duvall make was pumping out water from wells for the new water works in process of construction. Suddenly the boiler went to pieces with a terrible report.

Thirty-six hundred sick children and mothers were taken on the free fresh-air excursions given by St. John's Guild Floating Hospital this week, and 250 sick children and mothers are being cared for at the Seaside Hospital, New-Dorp, S.I.

BOSTON, July 19.--The members of the Massachusetts Club to the number of fifty or more enjoyed their Summer outing at Point of Pines this afternoon. Ex-Gov. William Claflin presided during the earlier part of the meeting, then giving place to the Hon. A.W. Beard.

CHICAGO, July 19.--A heavy thunderstorm visited this city last night. It was bad for the theatregoers, as many of them were unable to get either carriages or cabs to take them home, and they had to take shelter under awnings.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 19.--The weather in this vicinity has been capital to-day for sailing. It was not taken advantage of by the yachts cruising eastward under the Atlantic Yacht Club's colors.

The Bay Ridge Ferry, from the foot of Whitehall-street, has been using a small double-ender called the Suffolk County during the last week, to the intense discomfort of the people who are obliged to use the ferry as a means of getting to various suburban resorts.

Word comes from Albany that matters of a political nature are exceedingly quiet. State officers assert that they are either out of politics or else aver that it is too early yet to discuss coming events. "Not until after the meeting of the State Committees will there be any politics," said a well-known poltician a few days ago.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 19.--The Missouri State Board of Railroad Commissioners has decided that all the railroads in the State must reduce their rates on grain 10 per cent.; on live stock 25 per cent., and on coal 25 per cent. The new rate is ordered to go into effect as soon as the railroads can publish their new tariff sheets.

About 6 o'clock yesterday morning a collision took place on the New-Jersey Central Railroad at Bergen Point. Ten feet to the east of the Avenue D bridge a train of seven empty passenger cars lay on the west-bound track.

Six hundred and forty-five mothers and children, iucluding 138 infants, made up the Montefiore excursion of the New-York Juvenile Guardian Society to Ocean Beach, Coney Island, yesterday.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 19.--For several years a feud has existed between the families of Simpson and Howton in the extreme western portion of this county. It began by Tom Simpson killing one of the Howtons, for which he was tried in the Criminal Court here.

There have been not a few disgruntled fishermen during the past week--men who went forth with great expectations and returned with no fish.

Surrogate Weller at Jamaica, L.I., yesterday decided the contest of the will of James Stewart, finding that the bequests--one of $1,000 to the Little Sisters of the Poor of this city and the other of $500 for masses for the repose of his soul--were invalid, neither bequest being definite.

The Rev Dr. Storrs of Brooklyn, who a short time ago was offered the Park Commissionership of that city by Mayor Chapin, has replied in a letter from Shelter Island, declining to qualify for that office.

Over four million dollars in gold was engaged in Wall-street yesterday for shipment abroad. Announcement of this along with talk about a prospective squeeze in money upset the stock market. The bears had one of their old-time jubilees. Nearly every stock on the list went down some; a few went down a good deal.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 19.--The seventh session of the Educational Association was opened at the Theatre Vendome this morning with prayer by the Right Rev. Bishop John Keane, rector of the Catholic University, Washington.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 19.--Major Warner, commander in Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, yesterday issued General Order No. 10, in which he urged all the Grand Army of the Republic posts of the country to send as large delegations as possible to the national encampment at Milwaukee.

It was announced some weeks ago that large importations of poor Irish families might be expected at this port at about this time. The number of paupers had become so great in some parts of Ireland that land owners upon whom the tax for the support of the almshouses is levied had tried to devise some way of getting rid of the paupers.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 19.--An important meeting of the City Council will be held on next wednesday evening, at which developments of a surprising nature are promised. It is hinted that the present examination by experts of the boogs of the financial department is one of the matters that will come up, but whether any discovery has been made of a startling nature the Councilmen decline to say.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 19.--Capt. John S. Bell, Chief of the Government Secret Service, will take Nelson Driggs and wife and baby and Mrs. Mary Brown to jail at Cincinnati for complicity in the counterfeiting deal that was discovered yesterday.

GREAT FALLS, Montana, July 19.--Two miners, named Williams and Newcomb, arrived yesterday with Arthur Ford, a ranchman, and recorded about twenty mineral claims. The claims are in a newly-discovered district near where Otter Creek flows into Belt Creek.

A young man named Terrance Daigle was shot and instantly killed near Church Point fifteen miles southwest of New-Orleans, La., Thursday, by Ulysses Thebadeaux. There was an old feud between the parties, and it is alleged that Daigle went to the residence of Thepadeaux armed with a shotgun for the purpose of killing him, but Thebadeaux fired first and immediately surrendered to the Sheriff, claiming to have acted in self-defense.
The schooner Mosquito, which arrived last night after a remarkably quick trip from Greytown, Nicaragua, had a voyage which was full of incident.

LONDON, July 19.--The syndicate of paper manufacturers has about completed all the arrangements for the proposed combination. The capital of 1,500,000 has already been guaranteed. It is expected that the immediate effect of the combination will be an advance of 5 per cent. in the price of paper.
CHEYENNE AGENCY, Dakota, July 19.--Last night and to-day there have been numerous councils by the Indians. The number of signatures received yesterday was a surprise to the reactionary party.

PLATTSVILLE, Wis., July 19.--The venerable Nelson Dewey, the first Governor of Wisconsin, who is lying at the point of death at his home in Cassville, this county, is reported to be gradually sinking, and the end is thought to be not far distant.

FISHKILL, N.Y., July 19.--The saloon men of Newburg and at points elsewhere in Orange, Dutchess, Ulster, and other Hudson River counties have arranged to hold a picnic and powwow in Newburg some time in August.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 19.--There are two Protestant Episcopal churches in this city. The up-town church is called St. John's, and its rector is the Rev. Lewis T. Wattson. The downtown church is called the Church of the Holy Spirit, and the Rev Francis Washburn is its rector.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 19.--Alfred M. Watson of the firm of Williams Watson, paper hangers, of this city, has left town, carrying with him $1,800 belonging to the firm. In the absence of the senior partner, John H. Williams, Watson collected all the bills due the firm that he could and then took the train for NewYork Tuesday. It is supposed that he sailed for England. He leaves a wife and child here.

Among the passengers of the Trave, which arrived yesterday from Bremen, was Mrs. John A. Logan. Logan, Jr., who went down the bay on a revenue cutter and was the first to greet his mother on her return.

MERIDEN, Conn., July 19.--The Meriden, Waterbury and Connecticut River Railroad met, with its first serious accident this evening. The 5:45 P.M. mixed train for Cromwell jumped a bridge over the Consolidated Road at what is known as Duffy Crossing, about a mile north of the city.

The Fay Typewriter Works are no longer in operation. They were formerly operated in the same building in which the Post Office is situated at Niverville, this State. John T. Lattimer was the prime mover of the complicated machinery of the concern.

LONDON, July 20.--The Gentlemen of Surrey concluded their second inning in the game with the Philadelphia cricketers with a score of 355. Mr. Read, who had made 105 runs in the first inning, batted out 130 in the second.

LONDON, July 20.--The Cunard Line steamship Servia, Capt. Walker, from New-York July 13 for Liverpool, passed Brow Head at 11 o'clock to-night. The General Transatlantic Line steamship La Bretagne, Capt. de Jousselin, from New-York July 13 for Havre, was signaled off the Lizard at 9 o'clock to-night.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 20.--The ten days' meetings of the Sunday School Assembly, which is now in session on the camp ground, are drawing to a close. This was the eighth day and was one of the most successful of the course.

LONDON, July 20.--At the Sandown Park meeting to-day the race for the National Breeders' Produce Stakes, for two-year-olds, at five furlongs, was won by Rathbeal, by Boulevard, Loup, by Mask, second, and the colt by Wisdom-Vanish, third.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 20.--The Minister of Justice has received and examined the evidence in the Burke extradition case. As, however, the law allows the prisoner a certain number of days within which he can make an application for a writ of habeas corpus, and as these days do not expire until the 26th inst., the order for extradition will not issue until that date.
TUCSON, Arizona, July 20.--Word has been received here of the falling of the Mexican Custom House at Sassily, Sonora. Twelve men were caught in the ruins, and three were dead when extricated.
The cable has already given some word respecting the work Col. Olcott has been doing in Japan as an American missionary of Buddhism.
VICKSBURG, Miss., July 20.--Particulars of a tragedy at Pantheon Burus, which occurred at 11 o'clock yesterday, have aroused much feeling here.
Scientific whist, or whisk, (as it was first called,) though owing its origin to the game of trump, derived from the Italian trionfo and French triomphe, may be said to have begun with Edmond Hoyle.

GRAFTON, Dakota, July 30.--Crops in the Canadian Northwest and along the Dakota line are in bad shape. Farmers are almost destitute, and some instances are reported where they are subsisting on field mice and gophers. In the Canadian Northwest proper the crops are all ruined.
The frantic screaming of railroad whistles in the Pennsylvania Railroad yards in Jersey City drew attention yesterday to a great volume of smoke that arose from a building beyond.
