LONDON, July 20.--Five-sixths of the amount of capital stock in the American Salt Company reserved for Great Britain has already been subscribed by shareholders in the Salt Union. A premium of 15s. is already offered on the shares of the new company. Lists will be opened in London on Monday next. Lists will be opened in New-York on the same day.

Valentine and Henry Brunn, brothers, had a quarrel last night in their rooms at 267 Avenue A. When Barbara Brunn, their sister, tried to separate them, Valentine stabbed her in the abdomen with a table knife. She was taken to Bellevue Hospital, and her wound was pronounced fatal. Valentine was arrested.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 20.--An Oakland evening paper asserts that the missing will made by Thomas H. Blythe, the deceased millionarire, a contest over the division of whose estate is now going on in the Superior Court here, has been found.

SARATOGA, July 20.--He who runs may read that Saratoga is rapidly filling up. The piazzas of the larger hotels are now full and will soon be crowded.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 20.--A distinguished trio sat in the lobby of the West Hotel this afternoon and chatted about men and things in general.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 21.--Bailey Willis, a son of N.P. Willis, the poet, has been spend ing a portion of the season here with his family at Surf Cottage. He is connected with the Geological Survey in Washington.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 21.--The Rev. C.C. Pinckney, D.D., preached a sermon, having a direct reference to the McDow trial, at the Grace Episcopal Church to-day, choosing for his text, "Whose sheddeth man's blood, by man shall his blood be shed."

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 21.--A new and sensational story of the elopement from Paris last month of George Hitchcock, Secretary of the American Art Jury, and Miss Agnes O'Halloran of St. Paul, a former pupil of his, was furnished to-day by the girl's family.

CHICAGO, July 21.--The telegraphic announcement that Major William Warner, Commander in Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, had issued a general order urging all posts to send as large delegations as possible to the National Encampment to be held in Milwaukee, has raised a breeze among members of the organization here.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, Rhode Island, July 21. --Hundreds of people are now enjoying Summer life here. The Casino, the music, the baths, the brilliant costumes, the bewitching drives, the handsome women, and the well-dressed men all lend attractiveness to the Pier.
There are few unmixed evils. The acquittal of New-York Boodler McQuade may yet result in his exiled brethren in Canada returning to their own country.

CHICAGO, July 21.--There were no new bills at the leading Chicago playhouses open last week, but business was fairly good all around. The theatres have a formidable competitor in the Thomas concerts, which are drawing thousands to the Exposition Building, and free concerts in the parks attract crowds.
Gen. Sherman arrived in this city Tuesday night. Yesterday morning at 9 o'clock Col. Woodruff's battery fired a salute of seventeen guns in honor of the General.

TRENTON, July 21.--The proposition of the State Committee, announced in THE TIMES one day last week, to make Leon Abbett Chairman of the approaching State Convention has aroused a world of speculation among the public men of New-Jersey. It is not a new thing for the ex-Governor to preside at a convention.

--It is said that F. Marion Crawford has decided not to write a sketch of Sir John Hawkwood, the English soldier of fortune, who attained much fame in the fourteenth century, and that Macmillan Co. have accordingly decided not to include Hawkwood in their Men of Action Series. This is to be regretted, as no good life of the man is accessible.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 21.--Capt. Taber of the steamer Charlie, while at Cuttyhunk today, was told that during the severe storm of Saturday a rowboat, supposed to belong to a yacht, went ashore at Cannapitsett Beach. A pair of shoes and stockings was found in the boat.

Dave Wambold, the sweet-voiced and merry minstrel of yore, and his wife have decided to live apart hereafter, each to go his and her own way at will. There is a sadder side to this separation even than is usual in such cases.

Most readers will probably wonder why William Dampier was chosen for a place in this series of English biographies. He is probably among the least known of Englishmen who once were eminent, and his career is scarcely one in which Englishmen of our time could take any special national pride.

BOSTON, July 21.--Lewis D. Boise, senior partner of L.D. Boise Son, whose son and partner has left for parts unknown, says that his son has had charge of the business for several years and they have got along unpleasantly together.
KINGSTON, N.Y., July 21.--Gov. David B. Hill and his private secretary, Col. E.L. Judson, with their host, Judge Alton B. Parker, will be up betimes in the morning.
A fine portrait of Louis Jacques Mande Daguerre, to whom our immediate forbears owe much for perpetuating their features in the daguerreotype, is printed in the August Harper's Monthly.

After the House had passed the Railroad bill this week a member went to his boarding place in ward 4 and surprised his host by calling for his bill. He was asked if he was not satisfied with the place.

CINCINNATI, July 21.--It was rumored yesterday that the saloon keepers had made a secret combine to defy the law by keeping open to-day. Never since the beginning of the attempt to enforce the Sunday law were the saloons so generally and so tightly closed as they have been to-day.

The annual cruise of the Atlantic Yacht Club having ended, those interested in yachting will now look forward to the incidents attending the cruise of the New-York Yacht Club, which will begin Aug. 7, when many of the yachts of this aristocratic organization will rendezvous at New-London Harbor.
PEEKSKILL, July 21.--The Twenty-second showed up well at guard mount this morning. The formation, with one exception, was excellent; the lines were even, the "butts" of the muskets well in.
Steamship Denmark, (Br.,) Rigby, London 17 ds., with mdse. and passengers to F.W.J. Hurst.

Thomas Reynolds, a tinsmith living at Mount Vernon, N.Y., went to the Coroners' office yesterday, thinking that possibly Kitty Doane who committed suicide a few days ago at 157 Third-avenue, was his cousin, Kitty McCormick, who went to Cleveland, Ohio, with a sewingmachine agent named Kibbler some time ago.

BAYREUTH, July 21.--The Wagner festival opened to-day with a fine rendering of "Parcifal." The attendance was enormous, hundreds being turned away from the doors. The King of Saxony and other royalties were present. There is an unprecedented demand for tickets.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 21.--A.L. Mohler, Assistant General Manager of the Manitoba Railroad, has just completed a thorough personal examination of the wheat crop along the lines of the Manitoba system, and has prepared a concise summary of the results of his investigations.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 21.--The first fruits of President Harrison's administration in this State, Col. John A. Tibbits of New-London, who will sail for the Bradford Consulate on Wednesday, and Sheriff John I. Hutchinson of Essex, who will assume the duties of the Internal Revenue Collectorship for the District of Connecticut on Thursday...
A good deal of curiosity and alarm was aroused yesterday in the neighborhood of the Battery by the sight of a yellow flag floating over Castle Garden.

Note has already been made in this paper of the literary festivities at Granada in Spain, at which Don Jose Zorrilla (who is not to be confounded with the celebrated agitator of the same name) was crowned the Poet Laureate of that country.

Charles H. Mathews, who has been identified with the firm of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau for the last ten years, has decided to resign his position as a member of Mr. Abbey's executive staff next month, and devote his time and attention to his own special theatrical venture...

WASHINGTON, July 21.--Corp. Tanner is not saying so much now as he was a short time ago about the determined efforts of big Democratic leaders "to jump on him," and the detailing of various persons to take turns in performing that interesting operation.

George Dorain, 16 years, of 122 North Secondstreet, and Michael Newman, 18, of 202 North Second-street, and George Butler, 19, of 194 North Second-street, Brooklyn, procured a rowboat and went out on the East River yesterday afternoon.

--The History of a Slave. By H.H. Johnston, F.R.G.S. New-York: D. Appleton Co. 1889.--The African anti-slavery cause has had no better document offered it for promoting the object it has at heart than the fictitious biography of a pagan negro of Central Africa, written by the young explorer Johnston, whose ascent of Mount Kilimandjars will be remembered.
LIMA, Ohio, July 21.--There is a movement on foot looking to the consolidation of all the natural gas companies in the Ohio and Indiana field and to put them into a trust.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 21.--Insurance circles in this city are considerably exercised over large claims for indemnities that are likely to be made by Frank W. Crandall or his beneficiary against a number of prominent life and accident companies.

One of Bangor's oldest physicians, when driving the other day, was accosted by one of the most charming little children on the east side, Mamie Weston. The doctor asked her to get into his carriage and said he would take her home, and the invitation was promptly accepted. On the way the young lady conversed with a sweetness and childish simplicity which interested the doctor greatly.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 21.--Edward Duchar, twenty-one years old, of 163 West Eleventhstreet, New-York City, was drowned in Pawtuxet River Saturday evening while bathing.

CHICAGO, July 21.--The announcement that west-bound rates from the Atlantic seaboard to St. Paul and Minneapolis would be advanced to the basis of 85 cents per 100 pounds by the "Soo" line has not been carried into effect.

MANCHESTER, N.H., July 21.--James Fullarton of Bedford sailed for Europe yesterday to claim an immense estate on the Island of Arron, comprising the lands of Kilmichael and Whitefarland, which have been entailed for several hundred years in the Fullarton family.
Fire broke out in the Tide Water Oil Company's wax works at Constable Hook, N.J., early yesterday afternoon, destroying property whose estimated value is about $30,000.

HOBART, Ind., July 21.--This morning, on the farm of Henry Hoffman, three miles west of here, a hired man descended a well to take out some meat which had been hung in it to keep cool, but had fallen to the bottom. He was overcome by foul air and fell in the water.

Officers are investigating the disappearance from the Milwaukee, Wis. Post Office of twenty-eight registered letters. Owing to the reticence of the detectives snd Postmaster Paul no details can be learned beyond the fact that the letters are missing. Postmaster Paul says he thinks that were mislaid, but the general impression is that there was a theft.

WHEELING, West Va., July 21.--Specials from the flood district near Parkersburg to-night give the following complete list of the drowned so far as known. It is thought that the death list will be much larger when the districts now cut off from the outside world are heard from:

A nicely-dressed boy of ten years of age was found crying on the corner of Seventeenthstreet and Tenth-avenue last night. He told a policeman that he was lost, and was taken to the Twentieth-street station.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, July 21.--Such fishing as was enjoyed by visitors here last week is seldom found anywhere. An old oarsman who has spent nearly his whole life on the St. Lawrence says he has seen nothing like it during the past twelve years. Every boat brought in fine strings of bass and pickerel, and it seems as though everybody had gone daft on angling.

HALIFAX, N.S., July 21.--Capt. Larsen and crew of seven men of the Norwegian bark Faerder, lost on Sable Island, have arrived here from Canso. The bark sailed from Newport July 8, for Halifax, with a cargo of coal for her Majesty's dockyard.

Two good races will be trotted at Fleetwood at 2 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, by horses of the 2:34 and 2:40 classes, for purses of $100 and $150, respectively, offered by a member of the Driving Club.
The Brooklyn Jockey Club announces the following stakes, to close Aug. 15 next, with Secretary H.D. McIntyre:

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 21.--In a match race for a private wager to-day between the sloops Fanny and Anaconda, from Newport to this place, the latter won by fifteen minutes. There was a splendid whole-sail breeze from the northwest, and smooth water after Point Judith was passed.
Something over 16,000 people and babies went to Glen Island yesterday, and the Captain of the police there thought that it was the "biggest" day of the season for this charming little place.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 21.--The shore walk has been thronged all day with crowds from cottages and hotels watching the coming of the Eastern Yacht Club fleet.
GUTHRIE, Indian Territory, July 21.--Register Lille and Receiver Barnes of the Land Office here have rendered a decision in the first claim contest case in Oklahoma.

Simon Lannigan, a plasterer and noted tough, living at 1,513 Second-avenue, after receiving his wages on Saturday proceeded to get drunk. Yesterday morning he was found in the hallway of 357 East Seventy-eighth-street delirious from liquor and pain.

A fatal accident which happened last night at the Gerlach apartment house, in West Twentyseventh-street, was due to the disobedience of the victim, Frederick Gullick, a waiter, who lived at 54 Barrow-street.

It is announced that Postmaster Slade of Norfolk is in Washington on business "which has for its prime and central object the removal of Commodore Brown and Constructor Bowles of the Norfolk Navy Yard." Since when do a Postmaster's functions extend to the control of naval affirs? Respectfully referred to Postmaster General Wanamaker and Secretary Tracy for an answer.

Another good day's racing at the Brighton Beach track to-day is a certainty, and, if it is as good as that of Friday last, it will be good enough for any one. The entries and weights for the several races are as follows:

Those who were privileged to know Mrs. Pierce Butler during the years she passed near Lenox, Mass., will turn with much expectation of a mixed sort to a novel whose title gives a hint of its being American in its scenery and whose first pages make that hint a certainty.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 21.--Eddie Roe, an English boy, while swimming in the Cumberland Sound with fifteen companions from Fernandina, was struck by a shark which bit off the calf of one leg. Roe was taken into a boat at once, but bled to death before medical assistance could be obtained. This is the first instance known of a shark attacking a man in these waters.

CHICAGO, July 21.--The Farmers' Review this week will say: The majority of our crop correspondents report an excess of rain during the past week, which has interfered considerably with the harvesting of wheat and inclined oats to rust and lodge. The great present need is dry, hot weather to bring corn forward and enable the farmers to cut and harvest grain crops.

PHOENIXVILLE, Penn., July 21.--Arnold Francis and a boy named Kimes were killed this morning by the bursting of a separater at the Kimberton Creamery, three miles from here, on the Pickering branch of the Reading Road.
ROUND LAKE, N.Y., July 21.--The week past has been known here as Oriental week, and the edifice known as the Flowery Orient has been the centre of interest.

BOISE CITY, Idaho, July 21.--The Constitutional Convention has not yet given much encouragement to the advocates of woman suffrage and prohibition. Committee reports are coming in slowly.
A resident of One Hundred and Fifteenthstreet tried to settle the little German streetband problem all by himself a few days ago. He is fond of music, but likes it in its proper place and time.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 21.--Two prisoners-- W.A. Smith and Richard N. Mansfield--broke from the county jail last night, going through the slate roof.

BOSTON, July 21.--At the Grand Council of the Steam Railroad Men's Protective Union to-day delegates were in attendance from every local union in the order. The Constitution, ritual, and secret work were revised and quite a number of important changes made in them. The advisability of the Steam Railroad Men's Union attaching itself...

One of the most serious defects in the feminine mind is the inability to deal with machinery. It is a rare thing to find a woman who really grasps the idea of the mechanical contrivance so as to set it to rights if it goes wrong.

After having written a thousand-page book and still failed to convert the world to his Baconian doctrine, Ignatius Donnelly has concluded to take the stump in support of his theory. We are inclined to think that this is a sagacious movement.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 21.--The papers in reference to the extradition of Burke have been carefully examined by the officers of the Department of Justice and reported by them to the Minister to be perfectly regular.

The physical changes which take place in the oceanic bodies of water have always attracted the attention of the students of nature, and the great maritime nations have naturally taken the lead in the study of these phenomena.

SOUTH HAVEN, Mich., July 21.--The steam barge J.P. Farnam, Capt. L.G. Vosburg, owned by L.P. J.A. Smith of Cleveland, from St. Joseph to Escanaba, light, caught fire aft at about 3 o'olock yesterday afternoon. The flames spread so rapidly that all efforts to get out the boats were unavailing. The mate was seriously burned about the hands and arms in the effort.

PARIS, July 21.--The Marxists marched in procession to the cemetery of Pere-la-Chaise today and laid wreaths upon the graves of the dead Communists. Herr Liebknecht and others delivered orations at the tombs of Boerne and Heine.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 21.--Gen. B.F. Butler, who is here on his yacht America, called on Mr. Blaine this morning. Mr. Blaine was in the midst of his preparations for church. Gen. Butler left his card and drove back to the wharf, where his launch awaited him, without seeing Mr. Blaine.

A number of people gathered at the Church of the Strangers, in Mercer-street, last evening and listened to an address on the scope and aims of the United States Army Aid Association by the Rev. J.H. Young, the Financial Secretary of the association.

The New-York State Chess Association is planning to give a midsummer handicap chess tournament at the Packwood House, Skaneateles, N.Y., Aug. 27, 28, 29, and 30. The Tournament Committee, of which Mr. E.H. Underhill of Albany is Chairman, will meet at the hotel mentioned on Aug. 27 to arrange the details of the tourney.

At last it looks as though the Merritt Wrecking Company would succeed in carrying out its contract to raise the 15,000-ton iron steamer Atlas of the Atlas Line, which was sunk on Oct. 28, 1888, off the foot of Barclay-street, North River, by a collision with the ferryboat Central.
KIRKSVILLE, Mo., July 21.--About two years ago James Sylva and Miss Buckalew, daughter of a well-known citizen of Kirksville, were married and removed to Keokuk, Iowa.

John A. Renwick and Frank Renwick manufacturers and dealers in furniture on North Howard-street, Baltimore, Md., trading as Renwick Sons Saturday made an assignment for the benefit of their creditors to Daniel M. Henderson. The trustees filed a bond for $20,000.

LONDON, July 22.--A dispatch from Erzeroum, to the Standard says: There is an unusual movement of Russian troops between the Turkish frontier and Kutais, Tiflis, Alexandropol, and Erivan. It is estimated that 80,000 men are already concentrated, and more are coming."

Mr. Sheppard Knapp of the carpet firm of Sheppard Knapp Co. complained at the Charles-street police station yesterday that water from the heavy rain of Friday night and Saturday morning had flowed through the curbing into the basement of his store at 102 West Fourteenth-street, and damaged the stock of carpets which was stored there to the extent of over $10,000.
The outlook for a large supply of peaches throughout August is not very flattering. Indeed, it is almost certain that there will be a shorter supply than there has been for five or six seasons.
CHICAGO, July 21.--The suit of Chapman against the United States Express Company, Thomas C. Platt and others as Directors of the company, for $50,000 damages, has peculiar features.

Just after the train that left New-York at midnight of Saturday on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Road had passed Newark the engineer saw the body of a man lying in the two-foot space between the track and a picket fence that guards the roadbed.
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 21.--The schooner yacht Siren sailed to-day for Newport and NewYork. The sloop Mistral of New-York sailed for Brant Rock, in Buzzard's Bay.

The somewhat brusque treatment of numerous Republicans, who, having lost their places in the Federal service under the last Administration, as they assert, on account of their politics, have sought reappointment from Mr. HARRISON, has created a good deal of feeling in office-seeking circles.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 21.--There are thousands on the camp grounds. Saturday's arrivals were numerous, and to-day's worshippers filled to overflowing the dozen or more meetings held in the Temple Tabernacle, Chapel, and Auditorium.
Evidences that an attempt had been made to burn his house and saloon at 342 Atlanticavenue, Brooklyn, were found by Charles Schaefer yesterday morning when he got up for the day.
Only the oarsmen who work steadily in their boats from early Spring and get their arms and faces so tanned that they are practically sunproof were out on the Harlem River yesterday.

Dr. Behr, the celebrated botanist and entomologist of the Academy of Sciences, has been in Auburn during the past week. While visiting F. Closs's ranch here he discovered two new species of butterflies. He also found that the common plant about here which we call the coffee bush, the foliage of which somewhat resembles that of the olive, has never been botanically described and named.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 21.--The chestnut yearling colt by Ten Broeck, dam Belle of Nantura; the brown yearling colt by St. Blaise, dam Lovelle, and the bay yearling colt by Tympanum, dam Creda, have been sold for $4,500, by G.D. Wilson of this place to J.F. Donnell of New-York City.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 21.--The Sunday law had its designed effect for the first time to-day since its attempted enforcement, and Kansas City was as dry as prohibition Kansas.

The cause of the fire is unknown.

The Rev. Charles Spurgeon, son of the famous London preacher, who has been making a trip across this continent and who intends sailing for home shortly, made an address to several hundred men in the big hall of the Young Men's Christian Association, Twenty-third-street and Fourth-avenue, yesterday afternoon.
YANKTON, Dakota, July 21.--The little village of St. Helena, on the Nebraska side of the Missouri, ten miles below Yankton, is in a state of excitement over a ghastly discovery made there yesterday.

DETROIT, July 21.--The Detroit Driving Club will hold a great trotting and pacing meeting here, beginning next Tuesday. There are 129 entries in the various classes, and they come from nearly every State in the Union.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 21.--Late to-night William Brady, aged twenty years, and William Brookes, two years younger, between whom there has been enmity for some time past, met in the lower section of this city and renewed their quarrel.

CHICAGO, July 21.--The Inter-State Commerce Railway Association will make another struggle for its perpetuation on Wednesday next and will endeavor to adopt such a course as to meet the competition of the Alton and at the same time punish this road for withdrawing from the association.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 21.--To-night's beach meeting in the Fifth-Avenue Pavilion was conducted by the Rev S. Edward Young of the Westminster Presbyterian Church.
LONDON, July 21.--The steamship Galileo, (Br.,) Capt. Magee, sld. from Hull yesterday for NewYork.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 21.--Probably no other given community of 330,000 people in this country is restrained more by the laws governing the observance of the Sabbath day than Pittsburg and Allegheny City.

PARIS, July 21.--At the session of the Labor Congress Mr. Bowen explained the nature of trusts. Resolutions were passed calling upon Governments to oppose monopolies of raw materials and the necessaries of existence, and urging the working classes to organize against trusts. The next congress will be held at Brussels in 1891.

LONDON, July 21.--During the past week there was no demand for discount which was quoted at 1 and . Money was abundant. On the Stock Exchange business continued to dwindle. There was absolute stagnation in speculation.

RICHARD WANSER is the name of the man who took eight tons of weakfish out of Jamaica Bay with a net last Thursday.

CHICAGO, July 21.--The Executive Board of the Knights of Labor assigned A.W. Wright, J. J. Holland, and John Devlin to hear complaints and appeals of individuals and assemblies. The court, as it is called, was in session at the Sherman House to-day. Two or three cases of minor consequence were decided.
Gen. John M. Schofield, Major General Commanding the Army of the United States, after a somewhat interesting experience in house hunting in the fashionable localities of the "West...

The Anarchists hired a hall at 198 Avenue A to hold a meeting yesterday in order to hear charges against John Most, but, as on Saturday evening, the proprietor of the hall informed them that he had been forbidden by the police to allow them to meet in the place on Sunday...
Yesterday was the dreariest driving day that the season has yet brought to the old horsemen who congregate on Seventh and Central avenues.

NIAGARA FALLS, July 21.--Hundreds of people crowded the southern shore of Goat Island and the Three Sister Islands this afternoon to witness the effect of the trip down the river and over the Horseshoe Fall of the barrel that Carlise D. Graham had announced that he would set adrift. At 3:30 P.M. Walter Odell, a Central conductor, set the barrel afloat.

About eighteen months ago a circular was issued from the office of the Attorney General addressed to each county and each District Attorney in the State, directing the criminal prosecution of every citizen who had rendered property for taxes at less than a cash valuation.

Great success has attended the study of fishes that spawn in fresh water. Millions of eggs of different kinds of fish that belong to North America have been sent to Europe, hatched at the State hatcheries of Germany, France, and England, and begun to people European rivers and lakes with food and game fish.
HILLSDALE, Mich., July 21.--W.W. Johnson, a wealthy farmer living about two miles south of this city, was approached about ten days ago by a man who wanted to buy his farm.

Most of the time of the Central Labor Union yesterday was spent in quarreling over a letter which secretary Barr had received from Mayor Grant inviting the Secretary of the Central Labor Union to attend the business men's conference on Thursday with regard to the proposed World's Fair.
DEER PARK, Ind., July 21.--President Harrison heard a sermon to-day by the Rev. E.D. Meade, Episcopalian, on the duties of business men as Christians.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, July 21.--The Territorial Convention has been adjourned until Aug. 20. The proceedings yesterday were harmonious. Committees on Organic Law, the Judiciary, the Legislature, etc., were appointed. It was decided to partition the Territory into twelve counties. The names recommended for two of the counties were Harrison and Cleveland. Between the present time and Aug. 20 the committee will meet and prepare their reports.

CHAUTUAQUA, July 21.--The Secretary of the Literary and Scientific Circle gives some interesting facts and figures. The circle has graduated 18,000 members since its establishment by Bishop John H. Vincent in 1878. So rapid has been its growth in recent years that to-day nearly 90,000 undergraduates are registered, divided into classes as follows:
BISMARCK, Dakota, July 21.--The Constitutional Convention has been given a genuine surprise by the presentation of a complete Constitution which will be considered during the present week.

The Catholic Total Abstinence Provincial Council met yesterday afternoon in Paulist Hall, on West Sixteenth-street, between Ninth and Tenth avenues, and passed a series of resolutions censuring the Brooklyn Commissioners of Excise for their "ill-advised and indiscriminate" granting of licenses in Brooklyn.

CUTLER, Me., July 22.--The Spanish steamer Eduardo, Capt. Larrauri, which left Boston in ballast Saturday afternoon for St. John. N. B., struck at low tide on Old Man Island, two miles south of Cutler Harbor at midnight Saturday, during a dense fog.

ALBANY, July 22.--The American Brewing Company of Rochester filed a certificate of incorporation in the Secretary of State's office today. John Luther, Christian Haller, Otto C. Popp, Frederick W. Baetzel, Fletcher M. Thrasher, Quinbert C. Schwart, and Albert H. Loebs are the incorporators, with a capital of $175,000, for the manufacture and sale of beer and ale.

None of the School Commissioners--Gallaway, Guggenheimer, or Schmitt--whose presence was so much desired at the meeting of the Commissioners in condemnation of the public school site at Mulberry and Bayard streets, yesterday put in an appearance.

Third Engineer Baxter of the National Line steamship Denmark does not like snakes. A little experience which he had on the last westward trip of the steamer has confirmed for good and all this natural and inherent dislike.

ATTICA, N.Y., July 22.--This village is in a state of excitement over the trouble between the Attica Mills, the largest business enterprise here, and Loomis Sons, the principal bankers. It arose from a trifling matter, but has assumed the proportions of a first-class suit, damages to the amount of $100,000 being talked of.

The Passenger Department of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company announces that passengers holding first-class limited tickets of any description will be allowed to stop over at Cresson Springs during the season, as long as desired, up to Oct. 31.

Yesterday saw the last remains of the once formidable District Assembly No. 49, Knights of Labor, leave Pythagoras Hall, which has been their headquarters for several years. The furniture and fixtures in the lodge rooms, ballroom, and co-operative store were sold at auction under direction of Receiver Michael Breslin.

BOSTON, July 22.--The steamer Kanawha, which arrived below Saturday from Newport News, grounded on the Upper Middle while making the harbor. It is thought she is leaking. No attempt has yet been made to float her.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., July 22.--Papers are being prepared here for another large distribution of the relief funds. The body of an unknown woman, who is supposed to have been a passenger on the day express, was recovered yesterday at Coopersdale. She had black hair and wore a ladies' hunting-case gold watch with a charm the shape of a bucket.

MONTREAL, July 22.--Col. W. E. Cowe, Lieut. Col. Charles E. Thompson, Major T. M. Smith, Quartermaster S. C. Swan, and Capt. G. B. Newton of the First Regiment, Connecticut National Guard of Hartford, Conn., have arrived in this city to make arrangements for the visit of the regiment to Montreal in October next.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 22.--Information received to-day from Capt. Buddinton of the whaling schooner Sarah W. Hunt, dated Faval, June 28, says a boats crew in command of Mate John Sharp of New-London was lost off East Greenland while fast to a whale, which suddenly "sounded" and carried the boat and crew down.
There was a large attendance yesterday at the Brighton Beach race track, where six races, including a steeplechase, were run off with the following results:
An educated Englishman, arrested for intoxication in Hoboken last night, was locked up as "Lord Lenox, aged fifty, of the Hoffman House." He passed the night in a cell.

A considerable number of people gathered last evening in scattered groups all along Fifthavenue in front of St. Patrick's Cathedral and looked expectantly up at the graceful white spires which shot up into the sky.

The young man who gave his name as Thomas Reynolds and promised to call at the Coroner's office yesterday and complete the identification of the suicide, Kitty Doane, as Miss Kitty McCormick of Cleveland, Ohio, did not appear, but the young lady did.
Charles H. Heath, a prominent and influential citizen of Montpelier, Vt., died suddenly at Barre, in that State, yesterday. Mr. Heath was born in Woodbury, Vt., fifty-nine years ago.

Travelers who visit Chamonix this season will be astonished, on approaching the village by the Geneva road, to see some extensive earthworks at the foot of the mountain side on the left of the valley.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 22.--The new Vassar College Gymnasium is nearly completed. It will be ready for occupancy by Sept. 1. It is built of rough brick, with the usual trimmings, and will cost $25,000. It is situated between the main building and the observatory. It is 100 feet in length and 82 feet in width.

W. Bourke Cockran came into his office yesterday morning to assist in resuming the hearing in the electrical execution case, with one of his fingers done up in part of a kid glove and his hair cut very short. The impression was general that he had been having a little fun with...
SITKA, June 22.--The Territorial Board of Education here has just concluded its work of selecting teachers for the schools supported in whole or in part by the Government in Alaska.

The Rev. Father Anthony Farley of St. Mon ica's Church, Jamaica, L.I., and a part of his congregation are at odds. He has been pastor of the church thirty-five years. At the 9 o'clock mass Sunday morning he somewhat surprised his congregation when he said:

Judge O'Brien, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday signed the articles of incorporation of the New-York Yacht Racing Association. Its objects are the encouragement of yachting and the adoption of uniform rules.

Frederic G. Eldridge, who has been for many years widely known in financial circles, first as a member of the Stock Exchange and of late years as President of the Knickerbocker Trust company, died at the Hotel Vendome Sunday morning from heart disease.

Ex-Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States William M. Strong is making a tour of California, in company with his two daughters. He has just returned from a visit to Yosemite Valley, and is making a short stay at the Palace Hotel in this city, where he and Justice Field find much pleasure in each other's society.

Messrs. Eugene Kelly and C. M. Fry of this city, the guardians of the Southern heiress, Miss Mary G. Caldwell, whose reported engagement to Prince Murat was cabled from Paris some two weeks ago, received letters from their ward yesterday confirming the news and asking their approval of the match.

Peter J. Dolan, a contrator, of 501 West Fifty-fifth-street, George Vix and Jacob Vix, builders, respectively of 349 and 350 St. Nicholas-avenue, were arrested yesterday by Detective Sergeants Von Gerichten and Kernan of the District Attorney's office on bench warrants issued under indictments...

ANNAPOLIS, July 22.--Commander Harrington's testimony that he gave Saturday afternoon was approved by the court, which stated that his official report of the stranding of the Constellation was mainly correct.

Gilbert M. Speir, Jr., Dennis A. Spellissy, and Charles M. Claney, Commissioners for the condemnation of a school site on the northwest corner of Ninety-third-street and Tenth-avenue, met yesterday and rendered their final award of $79,000 for the property Tax Commissioner...

BISMARCK, Dakota, July 22.--Harris of Burleigh to-day introduced a legislative apportionment bill, providing that the Senate shall consist of thirty-five members and the House of Representatives of seventy members.
ALBANY, July 22.--W. J. Wilcox, for the Lard and Refining Company of New-York, has filed a certificate with the Secretary of State of an increase of capital from $250,000 to $600,000.
WASHINGTON, July 22.--An exhaustive report has been made to Postmaster General Wanamaker by the commission appointed by him to investigate the New-York Post Office and its seventeen branches.

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., July 22.--The situation here is growing alarming. A mob of strikers ordered a crew of graders to quit work, and they did so. Mayor McRae, accompained by the militia, ordered the crowd to disperse; they refusing to do so, he placed six of the leaders under arrest.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 22.--A heavy grain train on the Erie Railroad broke into three sections at Summit, one mile west of here, this morning.

Leonard Biener, a young barber, who lived on One Hundred and Twenty-first-street, near Second-avenue, and worked for Ben Wager at 1,834 Park-avenue, was drowned from the fishing excursion steamer J. B. Schuyler, at Cholera Banks, yesterday morning.
LONDON, July 22.--The Metropolitan Cricket Club presented a very strong team against the Americans to-day. Mr. W. G. Grace and other well-known amateurs are members of the team.
"The Department of Instruction" at the Paris Exposition (if nothing interferes with plans made) will contain a group of windows by Mr. John La Farge that will not be inappropriately placed there.

Lawyer David M. Neuburger, a prominent County Democracy man, was arrested and taken to the Tombs Police Court yesterday on a warrant issued by Justice O'Reilly charging him with grand larceny. In January last John F. Maguire bought the saloon...

BOSTON, July 22.--The funeral of Count L. B. Schwab took place this afternoon from Minot Hall, corner of Springfield and Washington streets, and there was a large attendance. At 1:30 the Rev. Raphael Lasker began an eloquent tribute to the Count, speaking warmly of his public-spirited efforts in the war and firm...
Without the Bible and the classics to draw from, what would the unimaginative do for names! How convenient are Babylon and Jericho, Bethel and Joppa for villages, Hebron and Carmel for mountains!

Science may give to posterity the fairy power of Puck, who could put a girdle around the earth in less than forty minutes. Already it looks at least as feasible to us to perform this feat as it would have to the Plymouth colonists to send a message to a friend in Liverpool and receive a reply within twelve hours.

At its meeting to-day the Board of Aldermen will be asked by the Mayor to pass an ordinance for the better government of street musicians. The terms of the ordinance have not been decided upon yet, as the Mayor wishes to avail himself of...

The House and Real Estate Owners' Association of the Twelfth and Nineteenth Wards recently asked Mayor Grant to amend the rule, made by Mayor Hewitt, that ash and garbage barrels must be kept within the stoop lines of the houses.

COVINGTON, Ga., July 22.--Last night, about dark, Dan Malone, a negro, 22 years of age, attempted to assault a respectable white woman, Mrs. Rachel Skinner, living six miles iron Covington. Her screams brought assistance, but the negro escaped. Subsequently he was captured and identified, and confessed his guilt. This morning, as he was being brought to town, he was taken from the officer by sixty masked men and hanged.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 22.--The people of Ocean Grove were astonished to see a wagon moving unmolested through the streets of the town on Sunday for the first time in the history of the Grove. The fast-barricaded gates were opened and an undertaker's wagon was allowed to enter the town and remove the body of a man who had died in an Atlantic-avenue house.

PEEKSKILL, July 22.--Heavy banks of mist hung over the valley of the Hudson to-day, and the rays of the broiling sun seemed to increase in intensity as they were reflected from the glaring pavements in the State Camp. When the sun was the hottest and the reflection greatest, 100 men left camp under command of Capt. Thurston for grand guard duty.

The ease of conscience with which the average civilized man, otherwise very considerate for the feelings of living creatures, will kill fish has not perhaps been discussed with as much fullness as the merits of the case seem to require.

DENVER, Col., July 22.--Millionsire John Allen, the New-York hotel man, and Prof. E. H. Platt of riding-school fame, rode into Denver at noon yesterday on jaded bronchos and leading mustang ponies. They left New-York May 14 bound for the Golden Gate and have made the journey so far without the slightest mishap. They hope to reach their destination by October.

LONDON, July 22.--In the House of Commons to-day the Right Hon. W. H. Smith, the Government leader, laid on the table the report of the Committee on Royal Grants. The report recommended that the sum of 9,000 be added to the quarterly allowance of the Prince of Wales.

The consumption of claret in Edinburgh was so enormous a hundred years ago that during the French Revolution the Town Council, in passing a resolution that "the Bordeaux wine" should no longer be drank, either at their banquets or at private entertainments, regarded the measure as being likely to prove the ruin of the French trade.

A large crowd of people assembled in front of the Mayor's Marshal's office at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, and Marshal Englehardt, who has been enjoying his Summer vacation out of town, also came in.

SCRANTON, Penn., July 22.--The mine is the great motive power of the mines. His unlimited capacity for endurance, his disregard of life in the dark, and his ability to cope with the mischievous mine boy have made him a valuable factor in the great underground industry of Pennsylvania.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., July 22.--Foundry Crossing over the Philadelphia and Reading Road at Mahanoy City, against the unprotested condition of which more than one Grand Jury has protested, was the scene of a shocking accident this morning.
ELIZABETH, N.J., July 22.--Politicians are gossiping a great deal about the split between two leading Republicans, City Attorney Bergen and Councilman Victor Mraviag.

The Rev. Dr. Peters, who has charge of the University of Pennsylvania's Babylonian expedition, appeared rather unexpectedly in this city last Thursday. Secretary Burk was sitting in his office at the university on that day, and if he had been asked who of all his acquaintances he least expected to call no probably would have replied.
A good degree of success is reported by the Commissioners who have charge of the negotiations designed to open for settlement the surplus lands of the Minnesota Chippewas.
The matter of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge Trustees gaining possession of the property on Park-row just north of the bridge came up before Referee E. R. Olcott yesterday afternoon.
The vacancy in the field of the Ninth Regiment, which has existed for considerably over a year, was filled last night by the election of Capt. Solomon E. Japha as Major.
ELIZABETH, N.J., July 22.--The accounts of Gilbert R. Lindsey, Postmaster at Ranway, have been found $300 short. The discovery was made by a Government inspector.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 22.--Several persons were badly injured on Saturday while bathing. The storm of Friday night made the water so rough that bathing was dangerous.

Capt. Bell of the steamer A. B. Field, who was formerly an inspector of fisheries on the Atlantic coast, recently reported at Astoria that he had found a codfish bank about eight miles from Nestucca, which is near Cape Lookout, on the Oregon coast, about sixty-five miles south of the Columbia River. The cod were found in great numbers, and were large and of excellent quality.

On observing an American label pasted on a piece of my hand baggage he opened up a conversation with me. There is an air of prearrangement about the emphatic discussion now going on between some of the Republican organs and a few so-called Democrats and Democratic journals as to a great "struggle" that is to take place on the opening of the next session of Congress.

The Hungarian who with five tickets won half a million florins, the amount of the five prizes in a lottery at Temesvar, gave his name as Melchiof Farkas, and said that he was a landed proprietor.

The Games Committee of the National Association of Amateur Athletes met last evening at the clubhouse of the Manhattan Athletic Club on Fifth-avenue and changed the date of the association's swimming championships from Aug. 17 to Aug. 21 on account of the tide and the games of the Prospect Harriers of Brooklyn, which will probably be held on the former date.
Dr. Bolus (at a consultation)--Well, gentlemen, my opinion is that the patient cannot live a week.
A cable from Berlin received yesterday by a Produce Exchange firm does not make the European wheat-crop situation any brighter.

ALBANY, July 22.--The Hartwood Park Association, formed by Jacob R. and John R. Stine of Brooklyn and others, capital $25,000, filed articles of incorporation in the Secretary of State's office to-day. It proposes to establish private parks for the propagation of game and erect therein private dwellings and a clubhouse on lands in Sullivan, Orange, and NewYork Counties.
The funeral of the late Herr Hasenclever, formerly one of the leading Social Democrats in the German Reichstag, took palce on Sunday last in Berlin.

About sixty years ago a man by the name of Reynolds, who was acting as clown in a circus then performing in Gorham, was thrown from his horse and so injured that he died in a very short time, and was buried in Gorham Cemetery.
COTTAGE CITY, Mass., July 22.--The Regatta Committee of the New-York Yacht Club has decided to accept the offer of cups for a race Aug. 12, off Martha's Vineyard by the Martha's Vineyard Association.
WASHINGTON, July 22.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased $23,700 four and a half per cent. bonds at 106 7/8.

TORONTO, July 22.--The Orangemen of Canada celebrated on July 12 the anniversary of the battle of the Boyne by processions, bands, speeches, and feasting. These public gatherings were held principally in the provinces of Ontario, Manitoba, and New-Brunswick.

Col. Fellows arrived at the District Attorney's office yesterday morning before 11 o'clock, a very early hour for him. He was in one of his grand, gloomy, and peculiar moods, wrapped in the mantle of his own greatness, and disinclined to talk with ordinary mortals such as reporters.

ROME, July 11.--Some pointed inquiries were addressed to the Ministry in the Italian Parliament, during the debates of the last week of June. Tha interpollations were the more surprising that they originated in the Senate, a conservative body, which is usually very reticent about foreign affairs. Signor Pavenzo, a Liberal Senator...

TOPEKA, Kan., July 22.--In a previous dispatch I have spoken of the radicalism which has served to intrench prohibition in Kansas and which promises to keep it in operation indefinitely. Outside of Kansas one finds no counterpart of this spirit. It seems to be peculiarly a product of the soil. It is as near akin to Puritanism as anything I can think of.

The death of Pearson S. Halstead was announced on the Produce Exchange yesterday. Mr. Halstead had been a member of the Exchange since its foundation and had been very prominent in the provision trade for many years. He was seventy-eight years old. He died suddenly yesterday morning at his residence, 131 East Seventeenth-street. He had been in business for years at 200 Forsyth-street.

CHICAGO, July 22.--Chairman Finley of the Trans-Missouri Division has issued a circular imposing fines and penalties upon no less than seven of the lines under his jurisdiction for noncompliance with the rules. The lines in question are the Union Pacific, the Rio Grande Western, the St. Louis and San Francisco, the Fremont, Elkhorn and Missouri Valley, the Rock Island, the Missouri Pacific, and the Denver and Forth Worth.
Yesterday was not a good day to inspire speculators with much bull confidence. Quotations were very soft, and the room traders were able to carry on their hammering processes undisturbed.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22.--Philadelphia and New-York played a see-saw game this afternoon, which abounded in numerous slovenly and brilliant plays. The visitors had the monopoly of the errors, however, and they were rather more costly than those made by the Phillies.

Probate Clerk Tinney, in the Surrogate's office, was surprised yesterday when Helen Georgina Mack, accompanied by Mr. Andrews of Andrews Purdy, offered for probate the will of Washington Irving Bishop. Miss Mack secured a divorce from Bishop in March last.

How happy are the Mussulman students at the University of Fez! True, they have to rise at 2:30 A.M. in Summer and at 5 A.M. in Winter, and their labors are not over till 9:30 P.M.; they have but one holiday in the week, and on that they are expected to practice total abstinence both from studies and from food.

CHICAGO, July 22.--The Times to-morrow will say: "It is stated upon pretty good authority that the Wisconsin Central will give notice of withdrawal at the next meeting of the InterState Railway Association, and if it does, the other Northwestern lines are pretty sure to follow.

A party of representative workingmen, all Americans by birth of naturalization, will arrive here to-morrow from the West, and will sail in the afternoon by the City of Rome to visit the Paris Exposition and other places of interest in Europe.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 22.--The Minisink Valley Historical Society had its semi-annual session to-day in commemoration of the one hundred and tenth anniversary of the battle of Minisink at Caudebec Park, on the Port Jervis and Monticello Railroad.

John Murphy, famous as a rider and trainer of trotting horses, died yesterday morning at Howe's Hotel, Coney Island Boulevard, after an illness of several weeks.

NYACK, N.Y., July 22.--The heroic act of a woman this morning has been an interesting topic of conversation here to-day. Mr. O. M. Bogert, a well-known broker of New-York City, who is spending the Summer in this place, was at the South Nyack station at an early hour this morning waiting for his train.

Congressman William C. Wallace of Brooklyn, who has been anxiously looked for by those local Republicans who want a slice of the Federal patronage, arrived from Europe on the Aurania yesterday, but he had no comforting news to distribute. He could talk of nothing but his trip, and the delegation of office seekers soon left him.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 22.--A tail-end collision occurred at Rock Glen, near Warsaw, between an Erie freight train and a Lehigh Valley coal train at 4 P.M. to-day. The engine of the Erie train and twenty-two cars were derailed.

Mrs. Hogan, wife of the aeronaut who made the probably fatal experiment with an air ship last week, arrived late last night from her home in Jackson, Mich. She will remain with a cousin at 21 Troutman-street, Brooklyn...

A continual source of pain to Mayor Grant is the slowness with which the contracter is building the City Hall staircase. The Mayor fears that at the present rate of progress the work will take months to complete, and, meantime, he will have to dodge in...

A Summer school for teachers was opened in Ellenville, N.Y., yesterday. Over thirty teachers are in attendance. The tutor is Prof. Lawton. He is assisted by School Commissioner Douglas, Miss Sarah E. Mackey, and Miss L. Lawton. The course includes daily lecturee for instruction in methods of teaching and classes in all branches requisite for teachers' certificates of the first, second, and third grades.

The F. G. Faulkner Company, dealers in iron pipes and fittings at 41 Dey-street, has notified the creditors that it will wind up business. Frank G. Faulkner, the President, has been deposed by the Trustees, who were dissatisfied...

Some time before the celebration of the Washington centennial trouble developed in the Twenty-second Regiment. The inciting cause of the disturbance was the endeavor to force the State service uniform upon the organization.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 22.--It is reported from Chicago that Sam Bryant, the well-known turfman, will sell his interest in Proctor Knott and Come-to-Taw to his partner, George Scoggan, Bryant will at the same time sell out all his other race horses. Next year he will again come upon the turf and with an entirely new stable. The sale is to take place after the Saratoga meeting. Knott's next race will be in the Omnibus Stakes.

Public Works Commissioner Gilroy yesterday appointed Alexander C. Chenoweth an assistant engineer in his department at a salary of $3,000. Mr. Chenoweth has been an assistant engineer on the new aqueduct at $1,800.
LONDON, July 22.--The steamship Glenshiel, (Br.,) Capt. Donaldson, from Japan and China ports for New-York, passed Malta to-day.

The steamer I.T. Rhea carried up nearly 500 people to the Hermitage yesterday, while about 100 went by train. Members of the Ladies' Hermitage Association were present to receive the guests, and entertained them in a manner...

Letters continue to be received by Mayor Grant, accepting the invitations to the meeting to be held in his office on Thursday afternoon, at which the advisability of holding a world's fair in this city in...

The Rev. Edward E. Rankin, D. D., died yesterday at Newark, N.J., in the seventieth year of his age. His family was one of the oldest and best known in that city. His father was not only a successful merchant, but an ardent churchman as well, and he raised a large family whose influence has been widely felt in the Presbyterian denomination.

Gatting, the druggist, who owns a farm adjoining his father's, and who now uses his father's farm for raising stock, to ask him what he had heard of the wonderful depression in things in Prince George. He showed us a letter from his father, dated July 17, in which the following reference is made to the phenomenon:

Just as George L. Weidman of 1,211 Broadway was about locking his candy store, early Sunday morning, he noticed thick volumes of black smoke pouring from underneath his show window. By the time the engines arrived the space under the show window was a mass of flames.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 22.--The schooner Franklin, Capt. Rose, of this port, arrived here this morning with a party of survivors rescued from the worst disaster which can come upon a vessel at sea. They were the passangers, officers, and crew of the steamship Lorenzo D. Baker, of Boston, Capt. Wiley, which was burned at sea July 15, twenty-five out of twenty-seven lives having been saved.

With the thermometer climbing toward the nineties and an atmosphere heavily charged with humidity, the conditions were about as favorable as possible yesterday for the rapid development of a serious menace to the city's health at the scene of Sunday morning's livery stable fire in East Eleventh-street.

A letter containing notes of deposit was places in the mail box at the corner of Libertystreet and Broadway on June 24. It was directed in a clearly legible hand to "Bayside, Queens County, N.Y.," and below this was written "Flushing Township."

SANDWICH, Mass., June 22.--Cape Cod has in the person of Capt. James Keene a man who has seen as much hard service in foreign climes as any mariner now living, and his adventures as regards the coolie traffic, when narrated by him, are exciting in the extreme.
CHATHAM, Mass., July 22.--Two tugs towing a derelict, probably the schooner Bushrod W. Hill, before reported, can be seen from this place bearing east about fifteen miles.

Mayor Chapin of Brooklyn yesterday approved the action of the Aldermen in providing for the appropriation of $4,500,000 for the extension of the water-works system and then issued a long message praising the Aldermen...

GENEVA, July 1.--In the organization of their system of highways, stage-coach lines, and railroads, joined with the various functions of the Post Office, and in the organization of their army the Swiss have exhibited a genius for system, an enlightened conception of the duties of the State, and a sedulous care for the rights of the citizen under a democracy.
Chief Engineer Elbridge Lawton, United States Navy, retired, died at his home, South Boston, Sunday, from paralysis. The deceased leaves a widow and two children. He was sixty-three years of age.

Berlin has just had a most extraordinary sensational trial--curious, indeed almost without parallel, among the records of crime. The hangman has been accused of assassination and tried for his life. Of course it was a question of jealousy.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 22.--Grosvenor Lowry and Eugene H. Lewis of New-York, accompanied by eminent Canadian lawyers, arrived here to day. They came in connection with the Edison Electric Company's case. They will have an interview with the Hon. John Carling, the Minister of Agriculture, to-morrow. They are seeking a new trial on account of the cancellation of Edison's incandescent light patent.

HARTFORD, July 23.--The conference of Democratic leaders in Connecticut, which will be held at the Allyn House in this city on Thursday, will not be for the purpose of organizing torchlight processions twelve months prior to the opening of the State campaign, but will be ...

ALBANY, N.Y., July 23.--The Hudson Connecting Railroad Company to-day filed a certificate of consolidation with the Poughkeepsie and Connecticut Railroad, and both will hereafter be known as the Central New-England and Western Railroad Company.

The Aldermanic office acquired a new worth in the eyes of its holders yesterday, or rather, the Aldermen were made jubilant by the assurance given them by Corporation Counsel Clark that the Legislature, in combination with railroad lobbyists, had not been successful in depriving them of the right of supervision of the construction and operation of street railroads.

SING SING, N.Y., July 23.--Word has just been received here of a tragedy at Lake Mahopac, Putnam County. Chauncey M. Sniffen, aged twenty-eight, a prominent young man boarding there for the Summer with his wife, went out ...

PHILADELPHIA, July 23.--The American Iron and Steel Association has received from the manufacturers complete statistics of the production of all kinds of pig iron in the united States in the first six months of the present ...
MOUNTAIN LAKE PARK, Md., July 23.--The Woman's Christian Temperance Union InterState Conference closed its five days' session last evening.
The order and standard of the various events to be contested at the first annual individual general athletic championship of the Amateur Athletic Union are as follows:

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 23.--The Co-operative Brewery stockholders sold their stock to an English syndicate for $140 per share, an advance of $60, $50 being originally paid for each share. They clear $400,000 on the plant. It is understood that the brewery, which is one of the largest in the city, will be used as a bottling works.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 23.--The fight beween the Farmers' Alliance and the Jute Bagging Trust is rapidly assuming warlike proportions in the cotton-growing States. The alliance men have resolved to use no jute bagging for wrapping the present crop, but to use cotton bagging instead.

George M. Bersick, a broker of the firm of Randolph Bersick of 52 New-street, was arrested yesterday on a warrant issued by Justice Gorman on complaint of his wife, Mrs. Mary T. Bersick of 86 Grove-street, who charges him ...

WASHINGTON, July 23.--Yesterday's report that Secretary Noble had determined to get at the facts of the rerating scandal in the Pension Office was confirmed to-day by the official admission that a committee of three persons has been appointed to investigate the matter.

Harper easily holds its own with the number for August. Russian art, as seen at the Kremlin in Moscow, affords an excellent subject for Theodore Child, and the article is a main attraction of the number.
LONDON, July 23.--The Wesleyan Conference opened here to-day. The Rev. C.H. Kelly was elected President. The Chairman announced the sudden death of the Rev. John Brewster.

WASHINGTON, July 23.--The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day, in an opinion by Commissioner Schoonmaker, announced its decision of the case of the New-York Produce Exchange against the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company and others.

PARIS, July 23.--The trial of Gen. Boulanger, Count Dillon, and M. Rochefort before the Senate court has been fixed for Aug. 8. Gen. Boulanger and his colleagues have been given an additional ten days in which to answer the summons of the court before being outlawed.

A letter from Capt. George F. Hollis, United States Consul at Cape Town, Africa, to G.S. Page of this city stated that on a visit of the Captain, made last January, to the Transvaal he called on the President, Paul Kruger, who ...

Hugh Cullom, fifty-three years old, a discharged laborer of the Public Works Department committed suicide yesterday morning by hanging himself to the door of his bedroom, at 347 West Thirty-ninth-street. He leaves a widow and a grown daughter by a previous marriage.

PITTSBURG, July 23.--Judge Ewing held a special session of Common Pleas to-day to hear what there was to offer in the Flemmon case. Mr. Wurzell, on behalf of Flemmon, asked the court to postpone making an order surrendering Flemmon until to-morrow.

Alderman Carlin showed himself yesterday to be the champion of the humbugs who make nuisances of themselves in the public streets. He could not see why the organ grinder and the wandering trombone player should be suppressed.

Judge Bookstaver, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday reserved his decision on a motion made on behalf of Mrs. Henrietta L. Lane, daughter-in-law of Maltby G. Lane, for the appointment of a receiver to take the testimony ...

Mrs. Mary Brady, the only woman who was ever convicted in New-Jersey of being a common scold, was called up for sentence in Judge Lippincott's court on Jersey City Heights yesterday. The Judge lectured her and then sentenced her to pay a fine of $25 and costs.
SING SING, N.Y., July 23.--William Fitzpatrick died this morning at the residence of his daughter, Mrs. Hugh Riley, at Yonkers in his one hundred and sixth year.

SAVANNAH, Ga., July 23.--A child sacrificed to the pseudo Messiah who has been working among the negroes of Liberty County has just been discovered in a remote part of that county. The child was black. Its throat had been cut and the ears are missing.
MEADVILLE, Penn., July 23.--The St. Cloud Hotel was destroyed by fire last night. The guests escaped without injury, but several servants were badly injured by jumping from the windows.

BOISE CITY, Idaho, July 23.--The convention yesterday agreed to limit the State indebtedness to 1 per cent of assessed value of prop erty. Towns and cities are not permitted to incur indebtedness above revenue, but co-operate with capital in making improvements.

LENOX, Mass., July 23.--The cottagers were interested to-day over a hare and hound race, which was participated in by a dozen of the young yeople, including Miss Ives, Mr. Turnure, Miss Turnure, Mr. and Mrs. Carter, C. Gilmore ...
LONDON, July 23.--Mr. Parnell to-day again appeared before the special commission appointed to examine into the Times's charges against Parnellite members of the House of Commons.

DETROIT, July 23.--This was blue-ribbon day at the Driving Club Park, where the gates were thrown open for the inauguration of the Summer meeting. Many thousands took advantage of the generosity of the management, and when the races were called the grounds were ...
The third annual open lawn tennis tournament on the Cooper House grounds, at Cooperstown, N.Y., will begin this season on Wednesday. Aug. 14.

New-York is to have a new railway, but whether the motive power will be cable or electricity has not yet been decided. It will be known as the Jerome-Avenue Railway Company, and was yesterday incorporated in Albany with a capital of $200,000.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 23.--This was the annual Commencement. Day of the Sunday School Assembly, which has been in session for the last ten days on the camp ground. The annual celebration and Commencement of the Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle also ...
Dissensions in the Claf-na-Gael seem further from healing than ever as a direct result of Luke Dillon's alleged peace mission to this city.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 23.--The yawl yacht Heron of New-York, Capt. Walsh, with Messrs. Swift, Shaw, Woodruff, and Hawes of NewYork, on board, went ashore at Conanicut in a for last night. The passengers and crew escaped without injury. The yacht pounded heavily, leaked, filled, and was beached, being badly damaged.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 23.--Dr. W.S. Webb, President of the Wagner Palace Car Company, accompanied by Mrs. Webb, Mrs. W.H. Vanderbilt, Miss Webb, Miss Shepard, and J. Louis Webb, arrived here to-day in Dr. Webb's new one-hundred-thousand-dollar yacht Elfrida.
The Bergen Point Lawn Tennis Club will inaugurate its third annual tournament for the club cup this afternoon. With favorable weather it is expected to finish Saturday evening.
CHARLESTON, S.C., July 23.--Gov. Richardson has accepted Dr. McDow's resignation as Surgeon of the First Battalion of Infantry.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 23.--Edison, the inventor, is discussing the decision of Chief Clerk of the Patent Office Pope canceling the Edison patents for incandescent electric lighting, on the ground of want of jurisdiction.
BISMARCK, Dakota, July 23.--President Fancher of the convention to-day received the following telegram from Elliott F. Shepard of New-York, dated at Blue Mountain Lake, N.Y.:

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 23.--W.W. Harper of Georgetown, Ky., has lost by death the suckling colt by Elias Lawrence, dam Serubbing Brush, by Saunterer. He was valued at $1,500. Early Bird, a roan colt three years old, by Jay Bird, dam Beulah, by Harold, has been sold by Bowerman Brothers of this place to G.W. Leavitt of Boston.
HELENA, Montana, July 23.--A landslide on the Northern Pacific, which occured just this side of Miles City on Saturday, is one of the most extensive and disastrous in the history of the road.
TORONTO, Ontario, July 23.--Reports as to the condition of crops in Manitoba and at many points in Ontario are published. As a whole the reports are satisfactory.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 23.--The Government has had under consideration a petition of the solicitors of the owner of the United States fishing vessel Mattie Winship, recently seized off Sydney, C.B., for illegal fishing, praying for a settlement of the case, and the Governor General ...

UTICA, N.Y., July 23.--Commander Harrison Clark of the New-York Department, Grand Army of the Repubilc, has issued general orders favoring reunions of soldiers, county. State, and local, designating Sylvan Beach for the place of holding a central New-York veterans ...
BOSTON, Mass., July 23.--The steamer Kanawha, from Newport News, before reported ashore on the Upper Middle, will have to lighten to get off. Lighters are alongside.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 23.--The steamer Belgic arrived from Hong Kong and Yokohama this morning. Among the passengers were Li Ching Fong, son of Si Hung Chang, Chinese Premier, and Chew Shu Ylu, Chinese Consul General at Cuba.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 23.--W.B. Hundley of Armstrong Hundley, the owners of Spokane, arrived in St. Paul this morning. The object of his visit was not so much to be present at the inaugural meeting of the Twin City Jockey Club ...

A little chapel in Weaver-street, near the Larchmont Manor station, on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, has for the last few weeks been the hiding place of a lot of plunder, the proceeds of a burglary in NewHaven, Conn.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 23.--The State Senate got hold of the license bill to-day. The bill was adopted in the House Friday without any material change from the bill as repealed by the committee, the report having been surrendered to the Democrats by the committee, and the House having a big Democratic majority.
The United States Postal Service has again distinguished itself. On July 18, at 6 o'clock P. M., a letter was sent from the General Post Office in New-York City.

Conditions that are dangerous have been imposed upon the inmates of the crowded tenement houses in East Thirteenth-street, near Second-avenue, by the burning of the Empire Livery Stables on Sunday morning. In the pile of blackened debris that fills what was once the cellar 125 horses' carcasses were buried.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., July 23.--While the John Morgan, the supply steamer of the Edwards Dredging Company, was moored as the end of her wharf yesterday afternoon Engineer Frank Latham of New-London, Conn., and a friend jumped overboard for a swim.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 23.--Barkentine Moses B. Gomer, Capt. Azevado, arrived from Fayal this afternoon, having taken thirty-one days to make the passage. She had thirty cabin passengers and a full complement in the steerage, all being Portuguese from the island, all bound for California, where they will settle.
WICHITA, Kan., July 23.--E.T. Brown, a leading banker of this town, who was supposed to have been murdered on the 19th of last January, returned to-day, and is a mere skeleton and almost insane.

Marie Rosie Baereg, a pretty young German woman, was to have been married last night on Jersey City Heights to William Huffman, a cobbler. Her detention in a cell at the Library Hall Police Station on a charge of midnight burglary and arson prevented the celebration of the nuptials.
TORONTO, Ontario, July 23.--For some time the Delaware, Lakawanna and Western and the New-York Central Railways have been trying to make arrangements to get an entrance into Toronto.

PEEKSKILL, July 23.--The story in this morning's TIMES concerning the scandal in the Twenty-second Regiment and the charges preferred against Lieut. Col. Miller by Col. Camp caused a sensation.

Nothing quite so discreditable to the sense, the taste, and the temper of the Boulangist party has heretofore appeared as the appeal signed by the nominal head of the party, together with Count DILLON and M. ROCHEFORT, and issued from London.

PORT AU PRINCE, July 10.--Affairs at Port au Prince during the past week have assumed phases of every possible degree of alarm and terror. Hippolyte has been before the very outworks. He has been hurled back into the interior, only to again advance with impetuous rushes on the beleagured city.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 23.--S.S. Cartwright died in this city yesterday aged sixty years. He was a widower, and had lived for years in a garret.

The remarks of Mr. FELLOWS, reported yesterday, remove whatever doubt existed before that the prosecution of the "boodle Aldermen" has been abandoned. It would be unjust to blame the District Attorney, except indirectly, for this decision.

Postmaster William A. Cochran of Southold, L.I., during the present month has captured over two hundred opossums. Yesterday morning he captured thirty-nine. Suffolk County pays 50 cents for every one killed.
PHILADELPHIA, July 23.--The Phillies won by good honest ball playing the second of their series with the Giants to-day, and the baseball cranks of the Quaker City are beside themselves with joy.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 23.--News was received in this city to-day from San Francisco that the whaling bark Lagoda of this port, Capt. Tucker, arrived there yesterday from the Arctic Ocean, bringing news from the whaling fleet ...

OMAHA, Neb., July 23.--A court-martial convened at Fort Omaha yesterday for the trial of Lieut. Col. Fletcher of the Second Infantry for conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman. Last June, while Col. Fletcher was Acting Commandant at Fort Omaha, his wife left him, and ...
Thomas Hall of 116 Carroll-street, Brooklyn, created a sensation in Hobokan Monday night. Hall is an Englishman, fat, fair, and a decade past forty.

There was quite a gathering at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday morning to hear argument on the application of the Third-Avenue Railroad Company to the Railroad Commissioners for authority to substitute a cable for horses as the motive power for their cars over the line from the Post Office to Harlem Bridge.
WASHINGTON, July 23.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased $216,000 4 per cent. bonds ar 106 7/8 and $400 at 106 ; also $13,000 4s at 128.

James White, a young man of eighteen, who lived at 261 Myrtle-avenue, Brooklyn, died last night from the effects of a blow on the head, administered by Albert Giddings, an associate of his. White went home at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon and told his mother he felt sick.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass, July 23.--Commodore W.T. Weld's schooner yacht Gitana, with guests aboard, arrived here last night from Portland, Me., and sailed to-day for New-York. The schooner yacht Madcap. E.D. Bangs, owner, arrived to-day from Boston and sailed for Wareham. The sloop yacht Valhalla of Boston has arrived. She is cruising.

Stockholders of the Rio Grande Western have elected those Directors: W.J. Palmer, George Foote Peabody, New-York; D.C. Dodge. Denver; Joseph D. Potts, New-York; Barthold Schlesinger Boston: Charles J. Canda, Joseph C. Parish, J. Kennedy Tod, and Fred Olcott, New-York.

William B. Mercer, builder, of 96 Broadway, is reported to have left the city with considerable money which he received on a building loan, leaving many creditors in the lurch. He was known as a speculative builder and was engaged in two building operations, one on Eighty-eighth-street, between Ninth and Tenth ...

LONDON, July 23.--At the Liverpool July meeting to-day the race for the Liverpool St. George Stakes, for three-year-olds, at one mile and three furlongs, was won by Theophilus with Morglay second and Duneraggan third. The race for the Molyneux Cup, for threeyear-olds and upwards, at about six furlongs was won by Upset, with The Rejected second and Ixia third.

The recommendations of the commission which has been inquiring into the condition and needs of the New-York Post Office are an evidence of the neglect of the past in failing to make provision for the service as occasion required.
The stock market took a very sudden notion to go up yesterday. It was while the bear contingent howled loudest and made their direst predictions that the change came. The whole list was benefited.

BOSTON, July 23.--A second meeting of creditors of A.M. Herrod, boot and shoe manufacturer of Brookton, was held here to-day. The investigating committee reported that his liabilities amounted to $41,881; available assets, $29,576. A recommendation that Mr. Herred, pay 20 cents on the dollar was accepted.
Edward S. Brown, fifty-three years of age, of 1,224 Lexington-avenue, formerly an employe in one of the city departments, has been missing since July 13.

A gentleman entered a Second-avenue drug store last evening and asked permission to consult the City Directory, which the public has grown to regard as eesential a part of the pharmacopaeia as the blue pill or pain killer.
CHICAGO, July 23.--The Forth Worth and Denver Road, which recently withdrew from the Inter-State Commerce Railway Association, has already begun to cut rates.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 23.--George Downey, one of the colored men engaged in the prize fight that occurred here early Saturday morning, was arrested to-day, on complaint of Chief of Police Bailey, and placed under bail to answer ...
NYACK, July 23.--Talk about old toads, Upper Nyack can beat the record. While tearing down an old chimney in that place to-day the workmen were astonished to find imbedded in the ...
DENVER, Col., July 23.--An exceedingly heavy rain fell in this city last night between 10 and 12 o'clock, doing considerable to streets and flooding cellars.

The trouble began in the second race when Day, who rode Chaos, was so anxious to win that he fouled two other horses and was in consequence ruled off the track for life. He was however, permitted to ride Kempland in the last race of the afternoon, he having ...

BIDDEFORD, Me., July 23.--The sloop yacht Bohemian, worth about $1,500, is lying anchored in the river near Camp Ellis. No one is aboard and no trace of the crew can be found. On the pennant flying at the masthead is the letter B. She has been here since Thursday night.
SALT LAKE, Utah, July 23.--In regard to the party exploring the Colorado River with the view of building a railroad by that route to the Pacific coast additional particulars have been received.

The purchase of a couple more of houses by Cornelius Vanderbilt on the west side of Fifthavenue, in the block bounded by Fifty-seventh and Fifty-eighth streets, has revived the report that Mr. Vanderbilt, in accord with his desire ...

The old fight between the Southern melon growers and the railroads has been resumed. It waged very hotly last year during the entire melon season, and the Southern melon growers declared that unless the railroads became more ...
NEW-HAVEN, July 23.--The professors at Yale Divinity School will watch with interest the opening of the Hartford Theological Seminary to women, which will be done in September.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 23.--The idea that English capitalists will buy up and control the steel industry of the United States, as published this morning, has created considerable good-natured fun among some of the manufacturers.

The hearing in the case of Sanger against French to determine whether a partnership existed between Frank W. Sanger and T. Henry French in the representations of "Little Lord Fauntleroy," was continued before Referee Daniel G. Rollins yesterday afternoon.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., July 23.--An empty coal train, on its way from Camden to Trenton this afternoon, jumped the track at Smith's Turnout on the line of the Amboy Division of the Pennsylvania Railroad. Some of the cars were smashed and others were thrown into the Delaware and Raritan Canal. Travel is delayed and Passengers are now being transferred.

RED BANK, N.J., July 23.--Armstead Boling, a colored man, aged about twenty-five years, while out fishing in the river opposite Red Bank last night, fell overboard and was drowned. Boling leaves a widow. The body has not been recovered.

CINCINNATI, July 23.--When George Muth, confectioner, was brought before Justice Ermsten of the police court to-day for selling ice cream last Sunday he pleaded guilty. The Prosecutor suggested that the court regard that plea as a demurrer, and the court accepted the suggestion.
