The Sinking Fund Commissioners have not yet selected a design and plans for the Criminal Court Building to be erected on Centre, Elm, White, and Franklin streets.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 23.--The committee on the disposition of the Western and Atlantic Road, owned by the State, will report on Thursday. Mr. E.B. Stahlman, Vice President of the Louisville and Nashville, arrived here to-day.

The work of getting the Galena in shape for duty as relief of the Ossipee in Haytian waters is being pushed. An extra force of men has been employed in the Construction Department, and it is estimated that within three weeks the vessel will be ready for service--that is, so far ...

The Right Rev. George Franklin Seymour, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of the Diocese of Springfield, Ill., was yesterday married to Mrs. Harriett Atwood Aymar. The ceremony was performed in Trinity Church, where, eleven years ago, Bishop Seymour was consecrated. The officiating clergy were Bishop Potter and the Rev. Morgan Dix.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 23.--Miss Oppenheimer, daughter of M. Oppenheimer, the wellknown Liberty-street clothier, and a prominent Hebrew society belle of Allegheny, was killed at Harmony, Butler County, this morning.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 23.--The race for the Carroll Cup between the forty-footers of the Seawanhaka Corinthian and Eastern Yacht Clubs, which was to have been sailed here this forenoon, has been postponed an account of the dense fog. The cup will be raced for when the clubs reach New-port, where they will meet the New-York Club.

Neighbors reported to Policeman Short on Monday evening that aged Mrs. Ulrich had been abandoned by her children and lay dying of starvation in a dilapidated old tenement in Thorne-street, Jersey City Heights.

NEW-HAVEN, July 23.--Ex-Consul Thomas M. Waller has been in this city for several days working in the interest of the English brewing syndicate for which he is counsel. It is understood that as yet none of the New-Haven breweries have accepted his terms. Mr. Waller recently stated that he would return to England as soon as possible, and he will probably do so as soon as the organization of the syndicate is completed.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 23.--Four supposed tramps, John Foley, John Jones, Patrick Byrnes, and John McDonough, stopped a freight train at Bergen Point last night and attempted to take forcible possession of the locomotive.
NEW-HAVEN, July 23.--The Rev. J.A. Rodgerof the New-Haven Presbyterian Church recently presented a plan to his parishioners by which he thought the heavy debt of the church could be liquidated.
LONDON, July 23.--The steamship Port Caroline (Br.) sld. from Shanghai for New-York to-day. The steamship Australia, (Br.,) Capt. Spruth, from New-York July 6, arr. at Copenhagen today.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, July 23.--The decision of the Land Office ousting the "sooners," as those who entered Oklahoma before noon of April 22 are called, is causing excitement throughout Oklahoma as fast as the news spreads.
CHICAGO, July 23.--At the meeting of the Transcontinental Association to-day James Smith was elected Permanent Chairman. Mr. Smith was for several years the General Eastern ...

"Modesty be blamed! Modesty isn't worth a rap with this Administration, I tell you." It was a gallant Colonel of the Irish Republicans who spoke thus oracularly, and his remark was addressed to one of a horde of office seekers who lay in wait at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel all yesterday afternoon for Secretary Windom.

Capt. Grant of the Sixteenth Precinct, with the assistance of a number of his officers, has succeeded in capturing a gang of petty thieves who have been engaged in robbing flats in various parts of the city.

A regatta under the auspices of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club will be sailed on the Sound off Greenwich, Conn., on Saturday, Aug. 3, beginning at 1 P.M. The rules of the New-York Yacht Racing Association will govern the races, which will be between boats in the following classes:

ELLSWORTH, Me., July 23.--Senator and Mrs. Hale entertained at their home here to-day Sectary, Mrs., and Miss Blaine. M. Roustan, the French Minister; Mavroyeni Bey, the Turkish Minister; Col. and Mrs. McMichael, Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Brown, Major and Mrs. Palmer of Washington, Mr. Charles How, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Cummings, Mrs. Vail, Mrs. Patterson, Walter Damrosen, Mrs. Whelan, and Judge and Mrs. Wiswell.

Monday evening at a public gathering at Fairbush, near Somerset, Ky., William Baugh killed Green Flynn. Both were young men of good standing. Flynn and Baugh were wrestling when Baugh's brother struck Flynn on the head with a handspike, crushing the skull. Doctors Warren and Perkins removed the skull and found that death resulted from concussion of the brain. Baugh was arrested and taken to Somerset for trial.

Wall-street had another revival yesterday of the story that the Vanderbilts have bought control of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad Company. This time the tale hangs upon the fact that C.P. Huntington has sold another 100,000 shares of his stock to Drexel, Morgan Co. That banking firm, in fact, have been in ...

The hearing in the electric execution case yesterday was made more than ordinarily interesting by the testimony of Thomas A. Edison. The great inventor walked into Mr. Cockran's office early in the morning accompanied by Mr. Brown and Mr. Kennelly, his chief electrician, smiling and utterly oblivious of the presumed abilation of Mr. Cockran and the adherents of ...
Ex-Prosecutor Stevenson of Passaic County made a new application to Chancellor McGill at Jersey City yesterday for a new receiver for the Order of Financial Union.
Charles Pfeiffer of North Bergen, while shooting at a target, killed Isabella Wehnke, an infant in the arms of her mother, three-quarters of a mile away, a month ago.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 23.--John Rose one of the wealthiest men in Eastern Kentucky, but a notorious desperado, was waylaid and instantly killed by parties unknown at Clay City, Powell County yesterday.
A committee from the Boston clothing trades unions is in this city and has been investigating the condition of the clothing manufacturing trade here.
The Municipal Council of the Irish National League met last evening at the rooms of the Gaelic Society, 17 West Twenty-eighth-street, with President Gleason in the chair.

Frederick Carolin, who murdered his wife in April, 1888, and Charles Giblin, who shot Madeline Goetz, the wife of a baker in West Houston-street, were taken before the General Term of the Supreme Court, consisting of Presiding Justice Van Brunt and Judges Barrett ...
There is one point on which confidence can always be placed in Col. Fellows-- when he announces that he is not going to do something. He invariably keeps his word.
PARKERSBURG, West Va., July 23.--In the flooded district the waters have subsided and farmers can now see where they stand. Many have lost their all and will be compelled to ask for charity.
The examination of First Mate Evelyn of the steamer Finance, who was arrested for cruelty to William Gabrielle, was continued yesterday before United States Commissioner Marle in Brooklyn.

LONDON, July 23.--The Standard's correspondent at Rome says: "I am authorized to state that the principal reason for convening the recent secret consistory was the fact that the French Government had advised the Pope to quit Rome and had offered him an asylum in France.
DEER PARK, Md., July 23.--The work of the president to-day was mainly confined to the consideration of appointments to Post Offices, but, no commissions were issued.

Miss Alberta Gallatin, a granddaughter of Albert Gallatin of Virginia, one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence, has been engaged by Mr. Frohman for the Lyceum stock company. Miss Gallatin, though young, has starred in the South and West in Shakespearean comedy and is regarded as very talented.

Al Cridge, Stakeholder of the Sullivan-Kilrain prize fight, turned over the $20,000 to Sullivan yesterday afternoon at his place, 13 West Twenty-eighth-street. The money was all in five-hundred-dollar bills, and, after Sullivan had carefully counted them over, he thrust the roll into his trousers pocket.

LONDON, July 23.--Mr. Parnell, in an interview to-day, said that he and Mr. Sexton were mainly influenced in the matter of the royal grants by their respect for Mr. Gladstone, whom they were anxious to support.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 23.--It is believed that the Erie Railroad contemplates making the Jefferson Branch Road, now a subordinate part of the Delawara Division, an independent division, with official headquarters at Carbondale.

Most of the Republicans of the Fifth Assembly District, and a good many Democrats who would be pleased to help their Republican friends for a consideration, assembled in West Houston-street last night to be enrolled as members of the district Republican association.
Fire broke out at 6:30 o'clock yesterday morning in a row of two-story wooden buildings on the east side of First-avenue, near the corner of Thirty-ninth-street, which were owned by Henry A. Peck.
Judge J.M. Woolworth of Omaha is at the Gilsey House. Arch bishop P.A. Feehan of Chicago is at the Everett House.

RAHWAY, N.J., July 24.--The nineteen-yearold son of William Marsh, a resident of Unionstreet this city, has lost his reason from too much brain work expended on an invention. Symptoms of the malady first appeared some weeks ago and his parents consulted the family doctor. It was partly decided to remove him to an insane asylum, but for some reason this was not done.

At the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday all was activity on board the steel cruisers Atlanta and Yorktown, which are being prepared for sea. The Atlanta is ready to sail, and if nothing prevents she will proceed to Narragansett Bay to-day. The orders for the Atlanta and Yorktown were received yesterday.

SARATOGA, July 24.--The Saratoga race meeting opens to-morrow under more favorable auspices than any held here for several years. A number of owners dissatisfied with the condition of affairs at Monmouth Park are here, and all the best horses that have been racing in the West are at the track.

The New-York Produce Exchange is reaching out after business. Yesterday Chairman John Marshall of the Committee on Statistics and Information sent a letter to the grain trade in which he said that arrangements had been made whereby the Produce Exchange quotations, as soon as made, would be sent out to these points:

CHICAGO, July 24.--The ease with which a divorce may be procured in Chicago has long been a fruitful theme for the newspaper paragrapher. To-day another bar was removed. It has been the practice of the courts to hold that the applicant for divorce must be a resident of this State and must appear in person.
John Branton, a private in Company K, Thirteenth Regiment, Brooklyn, was arrested last night charged with forgery and theft. He stole forty-nine checks, aggregating $70, from Lieut. Rogers's locker.

Judging from the answers which have been received by Mayor Grant to his invitations to the conference to be held in his office this afternoon on the advisability of a world's fair in this city in 1892 about one hundred citizens will be present. Among the letters received yesterday was the following from ex-Controller Andrew H. Green.

The case of George Lacey and August Fischer, the dishonest drivers for Ferris Co., meat dealers, was before Justice Gorman yesterday, and two counsel appeared for the prisoners, two represented the people, and one the prisoners' bondsmen.
OTTAWA, Ontario, July 24.--Argument in the Edison case was heard to-day before the Hon. John Carling, Minister of Agriculture; the Hon. J.A. Chaplean, and Sir John Thompson.

Secretary Windom, Postmaster General Wanamaker and Supervising Architect Windrim of the Treasury Department spent several hours yesterday with Postmaster Van Cott, inspecting the Post Office building. Their purpose was to see for themselves what merit there might be in the recommendations of the recent commission in regard to enlargement and other changes in the building.
A few days since Frank Woodward of Albany, N.Y., who was visiting Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Smith in Fair Haven, received a peculiar present from California.

CHICAGO, July 24.--Last week Lena Lurie, a Polish Jewess, secured an injunction restraining Lazarus Silverman, the banker, from turning over to Ike or Robert Lurie more than half of $15,000 drawn on a winning lottery ticket. Mrs. Lurie claimed that Robert and Ike, her...
LEXINGTON, Ky., July 24.--For $2,000 the bay filly Eilewina, a yearling by Happy Medium, dam by Aberdeen, has been purchased by S.M. Smith of New-York City at the Fairlawn Stud Farm.

A dispatch from Washington announces that Col. Emmons Clark has written's letter to Acting Secretary of State Wharton, formally declining the position of United States Consul at Havre, to which he was recently appointed. Col. Clark says in his communication that he fully intended to accept the post and made his arrangements accordingly, but his friends and...

The dudes of this town must now carry their umbrellas with the handle toward the ground. This rule is inexorable. Their king has set the example. E. Berry Wall, he of the many suits, both tailor-made and lawyer-made, visited Wallstreet yesterday, carrying his fine silk umbrella with the handle trailing on the ground. The amateurs thereabout looked on in secret admiration.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 24.--Relatives of Mrs. H.G. Heron of Jonesborough, who is reported to be under sentence of death in Corea, have cabled to Seoul, but have received no reply. The publication was first made in a Knoxville paper Monday morning, and caused intense excitement throughout East Tennessee.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 24.--Mary Decler, a pretty girl of twenty, who lives in Frankfort, Conn., was found here to-day. She had followed Lewande's circus, being infatuated with one of the performers, a handsome Spaniard. The manager of the circus ordered her to leave and offered to pay her fare and she promised to go home, but to-day she still haunts the entrance to the performer's quarters. The man claims to have given her no encouragement.

WASHINGTON, July 24.--To-day's bond offerings aggregated $78,100, as follows: Coupon four and a halfs, $100 at 106 7/8; registered four and a halfs, $20,000 at 106 7/8, $2,000 at 106 7/8, $56,000 at 108 7/8, registered fours, $7,000 at 127 ; coupon four and a halfs, $700 and $1,000 at 106 7/8. All the offers were accepted.

HELENA, Montano, July 24.--Reports received concerning the state of cattle and crops throughout the Territory are much more favorable than was expected. Want of water is felt in many sections, but people have generally given the idea that things are much worse than was actually the case.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 24.--The annual meeting of the Woman's Home Missionary Society of the Methodist Church took place to-day in the Ocean Grove Auditorium, Mrs. Clinton B. Fisk presiding.

A circular has been issued to trades and labor organizations giving an account of a conference held among the leaders of the Knights of Labor, the American Federation of Labor, the Brotherhood of Firemen, and the National Mutual Aid Assciation of Railroad Switchmen, looking toward co-operative action in cases of strikes and other labor troubles in the future.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 24.--On Aug. 9 Mrs. Elsie James will be executed at Fort Smith, Ark., for the murder of a man seventy years old in Indian Territory. The date of her execution was fixed for June 18, but a respite was granted by President Harrison until the time above mentioned.

WINNIPEG, July 24.--An application was made in the Burke case this morning to the full bench for a rule nisi, calling upon the prosecution to show cause why the prisoner should not be released from custody. The order was made returnable to-morrow morning, when the matter will be argued fully.

At least one advantage has probably accrued to the city from the fact that the Department of Public Works has fallen into the control of Tammany Hall. A Tammany Mayor and a County Democracy Commissioner of Public Works were heterogeneous, discordant, and unfriendly elements in the Municipal Government.

The strange sort of policy in vogue at Monmouth this year is keeping the best horses from racing at the track. The Dwyer Brothers, whose horses Hanover, Kingston, Sir Dixon, and Inspector B. have been handicapped out of the races, have taken their entire string to Saratoga.

CHICAGO, July 24.--Col. Walter S. Babcock, a supposed, bachelor, died in August, 1887, at Gardner, Ill., from the effects of a pistol shot received under mysterious circumstances which have never been cleared up. He was on a visit to Miss Sarah Dodge, a Gardner spinster. He left an estate valued at $60,000 and his sister, Mrs. Hattie A. Martin, secured letters of administration thereon.

Persons who frequent the Mall in Central Park on Sunday afternoons know little of the amount of work which is done in the hours they spend in breakfasting in order to make the big pleasure ground tidy enough for their reception.
LONDON, July 24.--The New-York schoolship St. Mary's, Capt. Crowninshield, sailed from Madeira for New-York July 13.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., July 24.--The delightful old pier seems to have an especially strong pull upon Western people. They come here in larger numbers every Summer. At one time there were thirty-five St. Louisians and Cincinnatians at the Atlantic. One of the latest guests there was President O.D. Ashley of the Wabash Road, and family.

OLYMPIA, Washington, July 24.--The convention put in nine hours, with only one hour for dinner. President Hoyt handed the clerk a long telegram received from Elliott F. Shepard of the American Sabbath Union asking that a clause be inserted in the Constitution protecting and encouraging Sabbath observaance. It was referred to a committee.

BALTIMORE, July 24.--Overtures have been made to the Maryland White Lead Company of this city to join the Lead Trust. The company has not signified its intention of not accepting this proposition. As there are now about twenty-eight companies in the trust, leaving only two or three to come in, making a total valuation of the properties now in the trust about $15,000,000, the managers are hopeful of having every company in the trust.

Thomas C. Platt astonished every one yesterday by appearing at the office of the United States Express Company, of which he is the President. He had returned quietly on Tuesday night, and slipped down to the Oriental Hotel at Coney Island.

NYACK, N.Y., July 24.--There was much enjoyment at the Tappan Zee House, South Nyack, to-night. The occasion was a complimentary full-dress ball given by the proprietor. W.W. Palmer, to his guests, and the scene presented was one of brilliancy and gayety.

Judge Dugro, in Superior Court, Chambers, yesterday signed an order on application of Cockran Clark, requiring D. Lowber Smith to show cause on July 29 why a referee should not be appointed to assess the damages which Commissioner of Public Works Thomas F. Gilroy sustained by reason of the injunction which Mr. Smith obtained, restraining him from taking possession of the office and books.

Judge O'Brien, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday ordered that the default of Henry Ross, in the suit brought by Dr. J. Albert Kimball, should be opened on condition that Ross consent that the case go to a referee and pay $10 costs of the motion. A judgment and execution will be allowed to stand against him as security.

The Old Curiosity Club held its annual dinner last evening at Colombo's restaurant. The club is composed of art connoisseurs and amateur collectors, who meet every week to compare notes at an old English curiosity shop up town. Fritz Kaldenberg of F.J. Kaldenberg Co. presided.

Hugh Murray, county delegate of the Ancient Order of Hibernians and one of the oldest and best-known members of that organization, died yesterday at his residence at 130 Leonardstreet. He had joined the organization while still a boy in Ireland, and after his arrival here he became one of the organizers of the Ancient Order of Hibernians in this country.

SCRANTON, Penn., July 24.--The Central Colliery of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company in the western section of Scranton, was the scene of a double disaster today, the first being an extensive cave-in, which occurred at 5 o'clcok this morning, doing great damage to surface property and destroying...

Coroner Levy held an inquest yesterday on the death of Henry Eschen, the ice peddler, who was killed on July 6 by a fall caused by a blow struck by Frederick Schoop, a young butcher, in front of 565 North Sixty-seventhstreet. The evidence showed that Eachen went to the home of the Schoops intoxicated at 10 o'clock at night and raised a disturbance.

The office of consulting engineer to the Aqueduct Commission was abolished by that body yesterday afternoon. Col. B.S. Church, who had occupied it since last November, when he gave up the office of chief engineer, after holding it from the beginning of work on the aqueduct, will therefore be out of a job, on Aug. 1.

COPENHAGEN, July 24.--A great sensation has been caused in the highest circles of society here by the suicide of Count Sparre, a member of a prominent Swiss family, after he had killed his paramour. Count Sparre had for some time been carrying on an intrigue with Elvira Madigan, a circus performer on the island of Tansinge.

The East Orange Tennis Club's open tournament was finished yesterday. Sixty-nine entries had been received, perhaps the largest number for any tourney held in the United States, but it took only four days' play to bring the three events, gentlemen's, singles and doubles, and mixed doubles, to a close.

LONDON, July 24.--The game between the Marylebone Club and the Philadelphia cricketers was concluded to-day. Owing to the heavy rain of yesterday the wicket was in poor condition. The Americans made a weak display against the bowling of Grace and Nepean.

A well-dressed young man took a room at the Vanderbilt Hotel at 9 o'clock Tuesday night and registered as "M. Kearns, Hudson." He paid one night's room rent and was assigned to a room on the third floor. At 2 o'clock yesterday his bell rang violently, and when the bellboy went up to the room he found the occupant in a state of great excitement, calling loudly for a doctor and an ambulance.

ST. JOHN, N.B., July 24.--The second day of the Summer carnival was a great success. The Toronto cricketers is the match with St. John scored 171 in the first innings. St. John scored 52, and, being compelled to follow innings, had 5 wickets down for 71 when the game was called.
ALBANY, July 24.--The condition on July 1 of the twenty-one loan, trust, and safe deposit companies in New-York City, as shown by the books of the State Banking Department, was as follows:

On hehalf of several property owners in Flatbush, L.I., William J. Gaynor moved in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday for an injunction restraining the city from building a hospital for contagious diseases in the town of Flatbush.

PATERSON, N.Y., July 24.--Mrs. Margaret E. De Witt, an old lady living at 92 North Tenthstreet, this city, being lonesome, recently invited Marinus Bruckman and his brother, sons of neighbors of hers, to board with her.

The State of New-Jersey is honorably distinguished for standing upon the ancient ways, or a good many of them, such as executing murderers and voting for ANDREW JACKSON. The latest revival, however, in New-Jersey of a practice obsolete elsewhere is rather startling.

CHICAGO, July 24.--The straw board makers of the country have united in one mammoth company or trust. Mr. R.E. Newcombe of the Quincy (Ill.) mill acknowledges its existence, and states that its corporative name is the American Straw Board Company.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 24.--The fact was made public to-night that W.T. Davis, Secretary of the State Wheel which is in session here, is short in his accounts $2,103. Davis left the city, and there is no clue to his whereabouts, although detectives are at work on the case.

The steamship City of Rome of the Anchor Line, which sailed for Liverpool yesterday, carried the fifty representatives of the trades of this country who are being sent to the Paris Exposition by the Scripps League of Western Newspapers.

The regular weekly trotting races over the Jersey City track occurred yesterday and excited considerable interest. It looked like a return to the palmy days of the West Side Park to see eight well-matched horses start in a race, and the crowd was enthusiastic over the sight. The events were closely contested, and pool selling was lively, especially on the second race. The results are as follows:

A member of the Exhibitors' Ball Committee informs me that the number of cards taken at the door shows that 42,000 people were present at the Palais de l'Industrie last night. Of this number 36,000 people paid and 6,000 were invited guests. The greet ballroom was at no time during the evening unpleasantly hot or inconveniently crowded.

Marie Rosie Baehreg, the young woman who committed a midnight burglary aid arson at the house of Andrew Van Antwerp on Monticello-avenue, Jersey City Heights, Monday night, for a wedding dress, was arraigned before Police Justice Wauser yesterday.

These are the dog days, and as a consequence of the cherished superstition pertaining thereto mans dogs have a day at the Pound. The Pound is now situated at the foot of East One Hundred and Second-street, and the gas-producing neighborhood of East Sixteenth-street, where the yelp of the imprisoned cur was wont to break the stillness of the Summer solstice, knows it no more.

Judge Ingraham, in Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday handed down a decision holding that a receiver must be appointed for the firm of Pelgram Meyer, the big silk manufacturers of Paterson, N.J. Isaias Meyer, the sole remaining partner of the concern, in January, 1888, made a copartnership agreement with Herrman and Alfred Schiffer and died the following Summer.

A contract has been entered into by a Philadelphia firm of shipbuilders to construct for the Mississippi River and Ocean. Navigation Company of St. Louis one of the new type of twinhull and adjustable keel steamships, invented by A.M. Lucas, and described in THE TIMES of July 16.

Thomas F. Gilroy, Commissioner of Public Works, is likely to get himself and his party into trouble for his appointment of Thomas J. Curran as engineer of the boiler and engine of the building in Chambers-street occupied by the department. As clearly pointed out in last Thursday's TIMES, the appointment was made...

CHICAGO, July 24.--The Executive Committee of the Transcontinental Association this morning spent several hours considering the proposition of the Southern Pacific to allow the Canadian Pacific 6 per cent. of the coast traffic and abolish all differentials on that business.

BOSTON, Mass., July 24.--Gov. Ames is very ill at his home at North Easton. He is affected with heart disease, the exact character of which Dr. Cogswell will not disclose, but one which he says, with care and prudence, ought not to prove dangerous, provided the Governor holds himself aloof from any exciting influences,...

John A. Murphy of 34 Greenwich-street reported to the police of the steamboat squad at 9 o'clock last night the drowning of Michael Hogan, aged forty-eight, while bathing in the slip between Piers 8 and 9 North River. Murphy said that Hogan was somewhat under the influence of liquor.

Public Works Commissioner Gilroy yesterday dismissed Thomas Connolly, the foreman of the street-repairing gang to which Hugh Cullom, who committed suicide on Tuesday, used to belong. Cullom asserted that his discharge from the gang was caused by his unwillingness to pay assessments demanded by the foreman.

William Becker, a whitewasher, twenty-four years old, who lives at 413 East Thirteenthstreet, was terribly injured about noon yesterday, while at work at 41 Ann-street, by being caught in the machinery there. He was working in the basement of the building under an open street grating.

George W. and Pulaski Terwilliger, composing the firm of G.W. Terwilliger, retail dealers in shoes at 477 Eighth-avenue and 1,208 Third-avenue, filed an assignment in this city yesterday to Wilson Terwilliger, giving a preference to the Quessaic National Bank of Newburg for $24,000.

The company operating the largest woolen mill in Connecticut went into bankruptcy on the l6th inst., its creditors having refused to accept a settlement of their claims at 10 cents on the dollar, which appears to have been the best offer that could be made by the embarrassed manufacturers.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 24.--Jay Gould appears as plaintiff in a suit in the Federal court here, against the Little Rock, Mississippi River and Texas Railroad to recover $425,000.

Dr. R.H. Duncan, the surgeon of the steamer Colon, who was recently taken to Swinburne Island while suffering from what was supposed to be genuine yellow fever, was married yesterday afternoon to Miss Margaret Thompson, a daughter of Capt. William Thompson. The ceremony was performed at the residence of Capt. Thompson, 173 Hancock-street, Brooklyn.
Mr. George W. Childs yesterday received the following letter from Col. Fred D. Grant, United States. Minister to Austria, transmitting certain contributions to the Johnstown relief fund:

NORWICH, Conn., July 24.--The will of Thomas J. Evans of Danielson ville gives $3,000 for the high school in District No. 1, $2,000 to the People's Library of Danielson ville, and $5,000 to the Unitarian Church of Brooklyn, Conn.

CHICAGO, July 24.--A dispatch from Pittsburg says: "Within the last few days, at the suggestion of Mr. Leach, Surveyor of the Port of Philadelphia, the Pittsburg Appraisers have decided to admit English wool at 10 cents a pound instead of 30 or 60 cents, according to the classification, as heretofore.
PHILADELPHIA, July 24.--There is a suspicion in shipping circles that the Philadelphia bark Mary P. Kitchin, which had been given up for lost, is still afloat under the name of Kissan.
Mr. D.J. Whitney of the Society for the Prevention of Crime sent a letter to the Board of Police yesterday, in which he wrote:

BOSTON, July 24.--Mr. E.W. Burdett, Chairman of the Crapo Campaign Committee, and C. N. Clifford of New-Bedford, Mr. Crapo's law partner, were in consultation to-day at the headquarters on School-street. While they were there ex-Senator Howes Norris dropped in, as well as several other Crapo men from the cape, and all were assured that the boom of the NewBedford man was looking first-rate.

RONDOUT, N.Y., July 24.--A small dog owned by Isaac Gorta and a larger canine were seen swimming in Brown's Pond, near the Gross lime, here, yesterday afternoon. They came together and began fighting. Soon the smaller canine began to weaken, when its antagonist caught it back of the ears and held it under the water until it was drowned.

Many friends and relatives gathered in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, in Fourthavenue, yesterday, at the funeral services over the body of Frederick G. Eldridge, who was well known in financial circles and was President...

PEEKSKILL, July 24.--It was Capt. Thurston's tour as Officer of the Day, and he introduced an innovation in the State Camp which is bound to become popular, by detailing an orderly to accompany him on his rounds. The camp was in far better condition than it has been since the...

A dishonest employe of W.L. Strong Co., dealers in cotton and fiannel goods at 75 Worthstreet, created a good deal of excitement Tuesday forenoon at the Central National Bank, of which Mr. Strong is President. On Friday last, at one of the factories of the firm in NewHampshire, a clerk, whose name Mr. Strong requested should not be made known on account...

ELIZABETH, JULY 24.--Application was made to Chancellor McGill at Trenton yesterday by the Elizabeth town Gas Company for a writ of injunction to restrain the Metropolitan Company from laying gas pipes throughout the city.

TORONTO, July 24.--It is stated here this afternoon that Kitty Doane, who committed suicide in New-York, was quite probably Miss Mand Miller of Toronto, only daughter of a widowed mother, who lives with her son in the northeastern end of the city.

PHILADELPHIA, July, 24.--Mr. George W. Childs has received from Col. Fred D. Grant, United States Minister to Austria, a communication inclosing a contribution of $142 subscribed by the people of Carisbad for the suf ferers at Johnstown, a subscription of $40 from Col. Grant, and also one of a like amount from his mother, Mrs. U.S. Grant. In the letter he says:
PHILADELPHIA, July 24.--The conference of "brethren who believe in the Lord Jesus Christ," but belong to no denomination and worship in the Apostolic style, was continued to-day.

Wesley Sisson is just now realizing the truth of the statement made a few weeks ago in THE TIMES that "Fauntleroys," if their mothers are to be accepted as judges, are as thick as huckleberries on the outskirts of a New-England village. It has fallen to his lot to engage a boy or girl to play this part in Mrs. Burnett's piece in Australia, and he is besieged daily in his office...
Daniel C. Folk, an old man who escaped from the Marshall Insane Asylum at Troy on May 29, was the cause of a legal fight in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24.--The Philadelphias won their third straight game from New-York this afternoon by better all-around play. Keefe pitched the first two innings for New-York and in the second he was hit rather freely. He was relieved by Crane in the third.

LONDON, July 24.-Since Mr. Labouchere laid on the table in the House of Commons his motion to substitute for the report of the Royal Grants Committee an address to the Queen, stating that the sums given the royal family are already amply sufficient, and that if further supplies are needed they ought to be provided...
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 24.--The Northwestern Miller to-day says:

It is reported from Boston that the Directors of the Flint and Pere Marquette Railroad will meet on Friday in New-Bedford and will then declare a semi-annual dividend upon the preferred stock. Three per cent. is the probable figure. The net earnings for the first six months of 1888 were only $180,828.
LONDON, July 24.--At the Liverpool meeting to-day the race for the Liverpool Cup of 1,200 sovereigns, at one mile and three-eighths, was won by Veracity, Peller second, and Ringmaster third.

There seemed the promise of buoyancy in the stock market yesterday morning, but the prospect failed to materialize into anything substantial. A smart rally marked the opening quotations, but it was fleeting, and prices at the end of the day were, as a rule, only fractionally changed.

A large double truck loaded with coke, belonging to the Consolidated Gas Company, lost a wheel while passing 1,213 Broadway at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning. As the wheel rolled off the axle the truck swung around across the down track of the Broadway street car line.

CHICAGO, July 24.--A final decree was rendered to-day by Judge Blodgett in the Federal court in the long-pending litigation between the Bell and Cushman Telephone Companies. The Bell Company brought two suits against the Cushman Company for infringement of patent. The decree in both suits is against the Cushman Company. A fine of $1 is assessed against it, and it is ordered to turn over all of its telephones to the Bell Company.

Whether the street railroads in this city are to be permitted to change their motive power, and if so, what system of propulsion they shall use, depends upon the consent of the State Railroad Commission and of the property owners along the lines.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 24.--Prof. Johnston, the distinguished author and scholar of the College of New-Jersey, was buried here this afternoon with impressive ceremonies. President Patton and the Revs. Messrs. Duffield, Hinsdle, and Cooper officiated. The pall bearers were Profs. Osmond. Westcott, Hunt, Sloane, West, Winans, and Osborn, Trustee Pyne of NewYork, Prof. Scott or Rutgers, and J.F. Hageman.

Anthony Comstock has succeeded in demonstrating the fact that he is a better prosecutor of vicious persons than he is a detective, and the police of the First Precinct are criticising him for allowing an important criminal to get away when he was about to lay hands upon him.

The Windward Club, organized to encourage yachting on Jamaica Bay, will, for the third time in its history, give a series of races to be sailed off Ruffle Bar on Aug. 11, 18, and 25. They will be open to cat-rigged boats of the Bayswater, Brooklyn, and Canarsle Yacht Clubs and those which have their anchorage in Jamaica Bay.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 24.--The Meyer will case, in which Christopher Meyer's millions are at stake, was resumed to-day and the proponents conclude their evidence with the testimony of Fulton Paul of Hudson, N.Y., one of the witnesses to the will. The caveators will begin their case on Sept. 14, when the sensational testimony will begin. Nothing of any unusual nature was developed at to-day's hearing.

The house thieves who were arrested by the police of the Sixteenth Precinct were before Justice Gorman yesterday afternoon with Julius Weiss, a second-hand dealer of Fortiethstreet and Ninth-avenue, who had been arrested as a receiver of the property they stole.

The little farming hamlet of Armonk, in the town of North Castle, Westchester County, was shaken to its centre on Tuesday night by a domestic episode. Howard Ferris, a middleaged man, a shoemaker by occupation, some time ago married a young woman.

Col. Fellows's proverbially bad memory accounts perhaps for certain utterances and experiences of his which culminated yesterday in a visit to Mayor Grant to request a transfer of $3,200 from some other city department to the Department of Justice, for the purpose of paying expenses of the McQuade trial at Bailston.

SARATOGA, July 24.--Now that the law requiring the hackmen to move on is enforced it is being literally obeyed. Two long lines of slowmoving carriages for hire continuously parade up and down Broadway, making the spectators from the hotel plazzas dizzy in their contemplation of them.

DETROIT, July 24.--A lot of work was cut out for the judges of the Summer meeting at the Driving Park this afternoon, with two races unfinished and three regular events to be disposed of. The weather continued bright, but was quite cool as the day advanced.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 24.--The barns on Amos Partridge's farm, two miles from Richville, St. Lawrence County, were struck by lightning yesterday and destroyed, together with forty loads of hay, three horses, two hogs, and farming implements, harness, and wagons. There was no insurance. John Dawson was the tenant.

We have received from Messrs. HARVEY FISK SONS a circular letter, with the above heading, in which they discuss the proposition that the Treasury ought to buy bonds of the United States at any price necessary to secure them up to 136 for the 4 per cent. bonds.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 24.--Reports have been made to the Banking Department for the half year ended June 30 as follows:

PITTSBURG, July 24.--Another delay was granted by Judge Ewing in the Flemmon extradition case on the request of Flemmon's attorneys, who stated that the Supreme Court was considering the case, but had not as yet indicated its decision. Further respite was allowed until Saturday. The officers here from South Carolina will certainly know then whether they will be permitted to take their man or not.

FALL RIVER, Mass., July 24.--Two homing pigeons belonging to Joseph Stafford of this city, which were let loose at Amherst, Va., in competition for the George W. Childs Cup, were found in their coop at 6 o'clock this morning.

Information has been lodged at Police Headquarters of the loss of a considerable amount of jewelry, intrinsically valuable, but prized principally because of the fact of its being composed of family heirlooms.

Mr. M.J. Cotter's experience as special guardian of Miss Catherine Ann Tomney has not been pleasant. He was appointed guardian in 1885, for the purpose of selling some property in Second-avenue which belonged to her. He conducted the sale satisfactorily, and deposited the money in a trust company.

Commodore Walker, Chief of the Burean of Navigation, will leave Washington to-morrow afternoon for Newport. He will spend Friday at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and at Newport will inspect the training ship New-Hampshire, which is under his charge.

PATERSON, N.J., July 24.--A conference between the striking silk workers and their employers in this city on Tuesday night resulted in an offer by the employers to reduce wages 5 per cent. instead of 10, and to restore the old rates as soon as business should justify the advance.

R. Carman Combes has begun a suit, the complaint in which was filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday, to have his accounts as Trustee in Pennsylvania and Western Railroad Company affairs settled.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 24.--Cleveland opponents of the Standard Oil Company in the Ohio oil and gas fields say that the big trust is certainly engaged in an effort to buy up the control of the natural-gas lands of Ohio and Indiana. For natural-gas lands on which leases could have been secured a short time ago at $2 or $3 an acre $20 an acre has been paid by Standard representatives recently.

CHICAGO, July 24.--A peculiar case of insanity is that of Harry Munzer, which came before Judge Gary this morning. Munzer is about twenty-seven years of age, and never having indulged in the general practices of fast city young men, his features bore a decidedly innocent but intelligent expression as he entered the witness box.

CHICAGO, July 24.--Mayor Cregier and Congressman Frank Lawler will, Friday morning, go to Braidwood to meet the committee of relief in behalf of the starving miners. The Mayor and Mr. Lawler will ship two carloads of food there tomorrow, the Rock Island Road having offered to transport it without charge. Friday morning this food will be turned over to the committee for distribution.

Under orders from the Lighthouse Board Commander Frederick Rodgers of the Navy, in command of this district, on Tuesday changed the limit buoys of the old anchorage grounds to the positions designated by the new regulations.

About the hottest spot within the city limits yesterday afternoon was the back office of the F.G. Faulkner Company, at 41, Dey-street, where a meeting of its creditors was in progress from 2 o'clock until 4. Among those in attendance were representatives of the largest tube manufacturing concerns in the city, and they were anxious to learn what prospect there was of being paid for the goods they had sold to the insolvent company.

A meeting of the Long Island Amateur Rowing Association was held in the Mills Building yesterday to consider the protest entered by the representatives of the Nautilus Boat Club who rowed against the Varunas of Brooklyn in the junior four-oared shell race in the association's annual regatta on June 29.

Three letters came to THE TIMES yesterday on the subject of postal service in this city. Two of them were in the nature of complaint, such as has lately become common. The other was meant for praise. It was from a Worth-street merchant who has a Post Office box.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 24.--As sensational telegrams have been sent to the leading papers of the country by an irresponsible St. Paul correspondent concerning the Directories of 1889 for Minneapolis and St. Paul I desire to ask these same papers which have published the falsehood from St. Paul, to publish the truth from Minneapolis, which I send prepaid.

WASHINGTON, July 24.--The investigation of the rerating and other scandals in the Pension Office, which began under Secretary Noble'S orders yesterday, is not the only investigation the head of the Interior Department has found it advisable to direct.

A laborer named John Hatch died at Bellevue Hospital yesterday morning of a peculiar, comparatively rare, and almost invariably fatal disease, known to physician's as Ludwig's angina. Hatch, who was apparently a strong and vigorous man, had a tooth pulled on Wednesday of last week.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 24.--Drafts--Sight, 12 ; telegraphic, 17 .

J. Edward Addicks, the President of the Bay State Gas Company of New-Jersey, yesterday brought a replevin suit in the Common Pleas against the Adams Express Company to obtain possession of a package now in the hands of the express company, containing 500 unexecuted coupon bonds of the gas company, of the denomination of $1,000 each.

Regarding the mobilization of the fleet, Admiral Sir E. Commerell, V.C., Commander in Chief at Portsmouth, has just issued lengthy instructions relative to the forthcoming manoeuvres. They may be summed up as follows: On receipt of orders on the 16th inst. the battle ships and cruisers in the first division were to at once move alongside the deck yard,...

Ed Roberts and J. Dutra, two fishermen, caught a basking shark Sunday night. They were about four or five miles from the shore and had 200 feet of not out. The shark ran into the net and got tangled. Fighting furiously to get free, the fish only wrapped himself tighter in the folds of the net.

The books opened in Wall-street for subscription to the securities of the Salt Trust close to-day. Friends of the enterprise yesterday modified somewhat their enthusiastic predictions as to the bulk of money that investors here would put into it, but they insisted that there would be subscriptions abroad that would more than take up all that America didn't hold.

The Brighton Beach Racing Association not only had a larger crowd than usual at its track by the sea yesterday, but had some first-class sport so far as the flat races were concerned. Mr. George Engeman, President of the association, who has been confined to his house for some time with rheumatism, was at the track for the first time in two weeks.

Practically the last of the New-York sessions of the electric execution hearing was held yesterday morning at W. Bourke Cockran's office in the Equitable Building. All the witnesses for and against the new method of execution have given their testimony, but a short session will be held this morning at Mr. Cockran's office to...

LONDON, July 24.--At to-day's session of the Parneli Commission Mr. Moloney, an ex-official of the Land League, was examined. He denied all knowledge of any documents concerning the League except those which were in the hands of Mr. George Lewis, Mr. Parnell's solicitor.

"Mike" Dady's brother Timothy was discharged from the Brooklyn Navy Yard on Tuesday for refusing to work. He was recently given a job in the construction department through "Mike's" influence, and settled down to enjoy his sinecure.

The twelve-foot python which escaped from its cage during the recent voyage of the National Line steamer Denmark, now at the foot of Houston-street, and which has since occupied a berth among the bilge-water pipes below the engine room, has not as yet been found.

PARIS, July 24.--M. Duport, a Boulangist member of the Chamber of Deputies, last night attempted to make a speech at Pont l'Abbe, Finistere, but was attacked by a mob and stoned. A number of M. Duport's teeth were broken and his face was cut, and he was refused permission to proceed with his remarks.
GREENFIELD, Mass., July 24.--The new Sanderson Academy building in Ashfield was dedicated to-day. It was erected as a memorial to the late John W. Field of Washington at a coat of $10,000.

WOOD'S HOLL, Mass., July 25.--Ex-President Cleveland and R.M. Gilder are guests to-day of President Choate and the officials of the Old Colony Railroad Company. They occupy a special train with the Railroad Commissioners, who were inspecting the Cape Division.

The killing of a sick dog at 194 Grand-street an Wednesday was under peculiarly distressing circumstances, and the occurrence forcibly illustrated the ignorance of persons who keep dogs of their ailments and the untrust worthiness of a policeman's revolver. The animal, Prince, a large bull terrior, was owned by Henry Huffman.
WASHINGTON, July 25.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day purchased $499,600 4 per cent. bonds at 106 7/8 and $750 4s at 128.

WASHINGTON, July 25.--Secretary Noble's committee to investigate the manner in which pensions have been rerated under Corp. Tanner will find some interesting material when it takes up the papers in tho case of Senator Charles F. Manderson of Nebraska.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 25.--Forty exemployes of the Branford Lock Works left here this morning for Florence, Ala., whither they have been induced to go by Charles Foster, agent of a manufacturing concern in Trenton, N.J.

BOSTON, Mass., July 25.--In view of the probable visit of President Harrison to this city, the Executive Council has appointed a committee to make arrangements for a fitting reception. It is not known definitely just when the Presidential party may be expected.

LONDON, July 25.--The report of the Parliamentary Committee on Royal Grants, recommending that the sum of 9,000 be added to the quarterly allowance of the Prince of Wales and maintaining the right of the Queen to ask Parliament to make further provision for her grandchildren was called up in the House of Commons this afternoon.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 25.--The body of Miss Madge Crawford, late of Kittanning, this State has been smuggled out of Italy in a peculiar manner and is now on its homeward voyage across the ocean. Miss Crawford was the daughter of Dr. Crawford, now dead, of Kittanning. She was at one time a resident of the East End, and had a number of relatives in this city.

Lewis Brothers Co., one of the most important dry goods firms in this country, filed assignments of its business in this city, Philadelphia, Chicago, and Boston, in this city and in Philadelphia yesterday, to Cornelius N. Bliss of NewYork. The failure is the first important disaster from unmerciful competition and the general stagnation of the trade.

According to some of the dispatches from Washington in journals duite friendly to the Administration, Corp. TANNER'S is a most difficult case for Mr. HARRISON to deal with. The general impression now is that the commission that has been selected to investigate the affairs of his office, and ...

Last evening a meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union was held in the Astor House the result of which will probably be the immediate settlement of the strife which has bean carried on between this powerful athletic organization and the National Association of Amateur Athletes of America during the past year.

Eugene L. Richards, Jr., yesterday made a motion before Surrogate Ransom to have set aside the report of Referee L.W. Emerson recommending the removal of Adrian Van Sinderen as testamentary trustee of William Lawrence, and finding him indebtod to the estate to the amount of $63,000, or, if not set aside, to have it sent back to him for correction.

If enthusiasm and a unanimous feeling of activity can accomplish anything, an international exposition will commemorate, in 1892, the four hunderdth anniversary of the discovery of America by Christopher Columbus, and the celebration will be held right here in NewYork.

Two agents of the Oil City Tube Works, Oil City, Penn., were at Castle Garden yesterday hiring laborers. They secured nineteen in the Labor Bureau and thirty-one from outside labor agencies and took them on to Oil City last night.

Constable Clay Woolley of Long Branch was among the very early birds to reach the Monmouth Park race track yesterday. He had with him an unpaid coal bill for $18 50 which a Long Branch coal dealer claimed that a person named Gebhard had contracted, the coal having been delivered at the house of another person named Langtry.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 25.--A well-dressed young man, who gave his name as Fred Bangs, a head waiter living at 353 East Eighty-sixthstreet, New-York, was in this city last night in a very excited frame of mind.

RED BANK, N.J., July 25.--There has been a plague of mosquitoes in most of the inland towns of Monmouth County since Sunday morning. That morning the wind blew from the north and it is supposed that the insects were blown over the Navesink hills from Port Monmouth ...

Judge Bookstaver of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday decided that when Maltby G. Lane died the suit of his daughter-in-law, Marietta L. Lane, to hold him liable for her support on account of his alleged promise to do so expired, and has not yet been revived against Mr. Lane's executors.
CHICAGO, July 25.--No progress was made by the Transcontinental Association to-day toward settling the dispute between the Southern Pacific and the Canadian Pacific on the question of differentials.
The story of trouble in the Third Battery, Brooklyn, owing to the resignation of Second Lieut. Samuel D. Bell, was denied yesterday by Capt. Henry S. Rasquin and other officers.

The Spanish-American Commercial Union, an organization made up of about eleven hundred merchants and manufacturers doing business with Mexico, Central America, and the South American States, is taking a very active interest ...

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 25.--The grand guard that went out yesterday afternoon had a very exciting time before it returned to camp. The guard, consisting of 100 men, experienced a novel sensation by embarking in rowboats to cross Annsville Creek. It left the ferry at the foot of the bluff at 3 o'clock precisely.

LONDON, July 25.--The Philadelphia cricketers played to-day against the Gentlemen of Kent. The visitors went first to the wickets and made a total score of 177 for their first inning. The wicket was slow, and the play was rather uninteresting. The Gentlemen of Kent had made 89 runs, with 5 wickets down, when the game ...
LONDON, July 25.--The project of forming a syndicate of paper manufacturers here has been abandoned.

The bunglers are still at work in the NewYork Poet Office, ana hardly a day passes that evidences of their stupidity are not supplied to THE TIMES. Mr. M. Cohn, a business man of Cobleskill, this State, writes as follows:

The committee from the Boston clothing makers' unions that is at present in this city investigating the causes of the decline of that industry in Boston, visited more of the sweating houses yesterday.

DENVER, Col., July 25.--It is announced that the Denver, Texas and Fort North Road will to-morrovr make a reduction of 18 cents per hundred on first-class freight from Denver to New-York and the Atlantic seaboard via Galveston and the Gulf of Mexico.

The pretty home near the "Point of Rocks," at Fleetwood Park, in which John J. Murphy lived and kept watch over the famous trotters intrusted to his care, was the scene of his funeral yesterday morning, and both house and grounds were crowded with the many wellknown men of this city who admired him as much for his sterling honesty as for his wonderful driving and training skill.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 25.--The first match with rifles at the State range is the Governor's champion marksman's match for a badge presented by Gov. Green. It will be awarded the soldier making the best score in this match for the season.

The second annual picnic and game contest given under the auspices of the United Councils of the American Legion of Honor, a benevolent organization which embraces many theatrical and newspaper men, promises to be a notable event in the history of Sulzer's Harlem River Park, Gardens, and Casino.

A report was made to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday by Public Works Commissioner Gilroy to the effect that under present circumstances, it would be better not to put new pavements on Broadway, the Bowery, Eighth-avenue, Park-row, and State and Canal streets. At the same time he reiterated the opinion, expressed by him in his report to the ...

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 25.--The second annual International Bible Conference opened to-day on the camp ground. It will remain in session until July 30. To-day's meetings were presided over by the Rev. Dr. L.W. Munhall, the singing being in charge of Mrs. John J. Dowe.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 25.--The Democratic conference which was held here this afternoon was attended by leading men of the party throughout the State. The list included Carlos French of the National Democratic Committee, Congressman Washington F. Wilcox of the New-Haven district, ex-Congressman Vance of New-Britain, A.E. Burr of the Hartford Times, ...

Commissioner of Public Works Gilroy yesterday removed William Hamilton, one of the steam engineers employed in the department building in Chambers-street, and appointed in his place William P. Baker, the applicant for such a position whose name stood third on the eligible list of seven which was provided by the Civil Service Board in response to a requisition for five engineers.

The Monterey and Northwestern Railroad Company has been incorporated to construct a road from Monterey, State of Nuevo Leon, Mexico, northwesterly through the States of Nuevo Leon, Coahiula, and Chihuahua, by way of Venadit, with necessary branches. Among the Directors are Thomas S. Bullock and Francis C.B. Avery of NewYork and Victor A. Wilder of Brooklyn.

Judge O'Brien, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday granted an injunction on application of Charles W. Nickerson restraining George Crawford, Philip Hauseman, and Andrew Crawford from carrying on a livery stable at the corner of Seventh-third-street and Tenth-avenue ...

WASHINGTON, Penn., July 25.--An accident occurred this afternoon at Elwood's Crossing, on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, a few miles west of Washington. Mrs. William Irwin of this place, with her three little children and a ...

NEW-HAVEN, July 25.--The New-Haven Colony Historical Society will issue a unique book next month. It is a compilation of the epitaphs in the old Milford graveyard which bear date prior to 1800. The transcriptions will be literal, with the type representing as nearly as possible ...

The steamship Frederick Hendrick, which arrived yesterday from Port au Prince, brought word of still another terrible struggle near the Haytian capital. One man was slaughtered during the conflict and several others received severe bruises. The battle was brought about under the following circumstances:

Dr. Isaac Lea, aged seventy-five, a retired physician, committed suicide by shooting himself at his residence on Richmond road, Stapleton, S.I., last night. Dr. Lea, who had been ill for some time, became tired of life. On several occasions he expressed a desire to die.

The term of Charles R. Ingalls of Troy as Justice of the Supreme Court, Third District, terminates this year, for the reason that Judge Ingalls will reach the seventy-year limit. He was re-elected to the bench in 1863. This will make necessary the selection of a new Justice.

The last session in New-York of the electrical execution inquiry, held yesterday in Mr. Cockran's office, was a very long one, in which many witnesses were examined. Havana, July 20.--Owing to the increase this year in cane planting laborers are in great demand at wages ranging from $22 to $24 per month.

The real discussion over the grant by the British nation of a dowry to the daughter of the Prince of WALES on her marriage to a subject is conducted not in the press nor in the House of Commons, but in private conversation in clubs and in houses all over the United Kingdom.

The Iroquois Club, composed of members of Tammany Hall in the Seventh Assembly District, which has existed since last May under a temporary organization, met at the home of the club, 4 West Thirteenth-street, on Wednesday evening and elected the following permanent officers:

The Newark Water Board yesterday morning instructed Col. Price, their counsel, to do what he could to secure the enforcement of the temporary injunction restraining the Passaic city authorities from polluting the waters of the Passaic River by their contemplated sewerage system till the appeal shall have been heard.

A curious story comes from Orange, N.J., concerning Frank Hoyt, who was recently arrested for robbing the First National Bank of Hoboken, of which he was teller. The Rev. Dr. Storrs, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Orange, says that just after the death of ...

PATERSON, N.J., July 25.--An agreement was entered into to-day by which the English syndicate will obtain possession of four large breweries in Peterson for the round sum of $2,000,000. The breweries are those owned by Katz Brothers, Hinchliffe Brothers, Sprattler Mennel, ...

PITTSBURG, July 25.--One of the most important national conventions of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union that has been held for a number of years will convene in Cleveland on Aug. 6. At this meeting a consolidation of the union with a European society known as the League of the Cross, of which Cardinal Manning is the head, will be effected.

Tax Commissioner Coleman's persistent un willingness, as a member of the Board of Estimate, to accept without further inquiry the evidence presented by Contractor J.H. Sullivan that his firm completed the work of regulating and grading Seventh-avenue on July 1, 1870, instead of three years later, has resulted in saving $70,000 to the city.

SING SING, N.Y., July 25.--James Montgomery, a convict in Sing Sing Prison, who was sentenced March 25, 1887, to five years' imprisonment for burglary in the third degree by Judge Gildersleeve, died in the prison hospital ...

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 25.--The Burke ex tradition case name before the full court this morning, Chief Juetice Taylor and three other Judges being on the bench. Mr. Campbell, counsel for the prisoner, moved to make the rule absolute releasing his client and act forth many reasons why Burke should be discharged from custody.

The young man who committed suicide at the Grand Union Hotel on Tuesday night, having registered as Frank Sutton of White Plains, was identified at the Morgue yesterday as Elsworth Contant of Mount Kisco. He was a typesetter by trade, but becoming debilitated by consumption grew despondent.

LONDON, July 25.--Lord Dunraven has received from Gen. Paine a cable dispatch saving that no yacht has been chosen to defend the America Cup, therefore he will not send the Valkyrie to America this season.

NEW-HAVEN, July 25.--Disclosures in the New-Haven town accounts show that an indebtedness of $115,000 was not recorded in the books, and an error has been discovered in Town Agent Reynolds's report for 1888, by ...

SARATOGA, July 25.--The second quarter of a century of racing at the Saratoga Association track was begun to-day, and the meeting promises to be a good one, so far as sport goes, for over 500 horses, including some of the best in the country, are at the track. The features of the day would naturally have been the California Stakes at a mile and the historic Travers Stakes at a mile and three-quarters.

Perrin H. Sumner, a real estate operator at 45 Broadway, appeared before Justice Gorman at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on a summons issued at the instance of Edwin Zillick of 209 Bedford-avenue, Brooklyn, who charged that he had been defrauded out of $300 by Sumner.

FINDLAY, Ohio, July 25.--The organization of the Toledo, Findlay and Springfield Railroad was effected to-day with the following directory: W.T. Walker, Henry A. Brown, H.C. Hahn, Alfred Wilkin, and George sherman. The officers are: President--W.T. Walker: Treasurer and Secretary--H.A. Brown. T.P. Brown is contractor.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 25.--The Greenwich Yacht Club's catboat race, which is to take place here on Saturday, July 27, promises to be one of the most successful ever held on the Sound.

LONDON, July 25.--The Parnell Commission entered upon its long recess to-day. When the court met this morning Mr. Hardcastle, an accountant, was called to the witness stand. He stated that the books of the Land League which had been produced before the commission covered ...

Col. B.S. Church was indignant yesterday at the statements made by Aqueduct Commissioners Howe and Scott in explanation of their purpose to abolish the office of consulting engineer held by him. He said: "The attack made upon me was outrageous, and its object was apparently to discredit me before the world. I will take measures to defend my reputation."

HELENA, Montana, July 25.--This was the banner day of the convention, the occasion being the discussion of the Suffrage bill. Hartman offered an amendment that the voters must be able to read and write the English language.

Yesterday was blind men's day at the Department of Charities and Correction, and that institution was besieged by nearly five hundred blind men and women, most of whom had children or grown-up persons to lead them.

A naval court of inquiry was organized in the British Consul's office yesterday composed of Consul General Booker, Capt. George Farron of the ship Arklow, and Capt. George Wright of the ship Annie E. Wright. The case which came before the court for investigation was that of the complaint of Capt. O.B. Marshall of ...

The gunboat Yorktown leaves the Brooklyn Navy Yard to-day for the purpose of testing her guns in a battery practice at sea. It is understood that her Captain, Commander French E. Chadwick, has orders to carry out this practice in a heavy sea so that the tests will be as complete as it is possible to make ...
NORTH EASTON, Mass., July 25.--Gov. Ames rested fairly well during the night, with the exception of a few coughing spells, and is better this morning than at any time since his illness.

There's a big coffee leak down town, and Detectives Sheldon, Heard, and Wingarten of Inspector Byrne's bureau have arrested three men, and have a fair chance of knowing where 30,000 pounds of it went. It came about in this way: Banks Co. of 111 Wall-street discovered ...

ZANESVILLE, Ohio, July 25.--The Prohibition Convention to-day made the temporary organization permanent with the Rev. Dr. C.L. Work of Portsmouth for Chairman. The Committee on Credentials reported 444 delegates present. Only two counties were not represented--Auglaise and Carroll.

Assistant Engineer Charles G. Talcott of the United States Navy committed suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting himself through the head with a small revolver. He was attached to and serving on board the steel cruiser Atlanta, lying at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

The trial of Mrs. James Maybrick on the charge of poisoning her husband, which recently produced a sensation in Liverpool, England, will probably begin on Aug 1. Such at least is the information received by cable yesterday by Messrs. Roe Macklin, lawyers of 156 Broadway, who are looking after her interests on this side of the water.

The contest of the will of Congressman Peter Paul Mahoney was continued yesterday before Surrogate Abbott in Brooklyn, and Theophilus Raessie, proprietor of the hotel at Washington in which Mr. Mahoney died, and the Rev. Father James Mackin of Washington were placed on the stand.

Stephen W. Dorsey, who was Senator from Arkansas in the carpetbag times from 1873 to 1879, and has one of the most notorious rascals connected with the star-route frauds, was arrested yesterday, and is now in the custody of the Sheriff.

Nine men of brawn and muscle, composing the eight-oared barge crew of the Malta Boat Club of Philadelphia, were the guests of tha Nassan Boat Club on the Harlem last evening. Philadelphians may be accredited as slow.

LINNEUS, Mo., July 25.--The Howell-Hall murder case began here yesterday. Howell is charged with causing the death of Nattie Hall, the fifteen-year-old daughtor of Malinda Hall. Opening arguments were made and the taking of testimony begun. Joseph A. Howell came from Ironton, Ohio, and commenced teaching ...
The Argentine Government has commissioned Manuel Quintana and Roque Saenz Pena representatives to the International Congress which will be held in Washington in October next.

The Castle Garden dead-lock was broken yesterday, a new President of the Board of Emigration Commissioners was elected, and the pay rolls for Castle Garden and Ward's Island were audited. To-day the employes will receive their pay for the months of May and June.

LONDON, July 28.--This was the golden wedding day of Mr. and Mrs. Gladstone. The Queen telegraphed a congratulatory message to the distinguished couple, and the Prince and Princess of Wales and other members of the royal family sent letters to them. The Prince of Wales also sent a gold inkstand to Mr. Gladstone.

It can he stated on the best of authority that the long-standing quarrel between the two brothers, Imre and Bolossy Kiralfy, is at an end, and that after the coming season they will join forces again and work together in the production of spectacular pieces in this city and throughout the country. The reconciliation is so complete that Imre has decided not to compete with his brother this season.

DETROIT, Mich., July 25.--The fine card drew a big crowd to the driving park this afternoon, the Merchants and Manufacturer's Stake of $10,000 being the event of the day. A desirable change was made in the judge's stand. D.J. Campau, President of the association, taking the place of S.T. Harris of Cincinnati as starter.

The disqualification of the Fanfan colt in the Seabright Stakes at Monmouth Park yesterday made considerable trouble for J.J. Gleason, who makes a 1--2--3 place book. No third horse was placed, because the judges couldn't tell whether the Cyclone colt, Routh, or Mucilage finished ...

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 25.--An insane tramp to-day called at the house of Andrew Reick, a farmer living near Dunellen, and, on being refused food, attached Mr. Reick with a club, knocking him senseless. He then attacked the farmer's wife, whom he severely injured. He escaped to the woods, but was captured shortly afterward and sent to the Somerville jail. He gave the name of Carl Smith.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., July 25.--News received to-day, for the first time since the flood from West Fork and Henry Fork gives a sad story of wreck and ruin. Every store from head to mouth of the forks are gone or ruined. Houses, fences, and crops are washed away and several lives were lost.

The refusal of Col. Emmons Clark to go to Havre as United States Consul has caused the members of the New-York Cotton Exchange to renew their efforts to have Consul F.F. Dufais, who was appointed by Mr. Cleveland, retained.
ALBANY, July 25.--New-York County has paid $500,000 on its general State tax to the Controller. This maker $1,500,000 thus far paid, with $1,000,000 still owing.

An autopsy, held yesterday on the body of James White, who was killed in Brooklyn on Tuesday by a slight blow on the head, inflicted by Alfred Giddings, disclosed the fact that the boy's skull was as thin as paper. It was of the consistency of tightly-strung catgut and had been dented by the force of the blow, causing congestion of the brain. It was almost transparent.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 25.--That Canada is to have a direct cable to Great Britain is all but a settled fact. Application is being made to the Government to guarantee bonds of the Canadian Cable Company to the extent of $500,000. The total capital required is $1,000,000.

Judge O'Brien of the Supreme Court has appointed George H. Richardson receiver of the firm of Hawkins Pearson, dealers in fraits amd vegetables at 188 Reade-street. Mrs. Mary J. Hawkins, the senior member of the firm, brought proceedings to wind up the affairs of the firm, which was organized last March.

CHICAGO, July 25.--The members of the Rathbone Sard Stove Works of Albany, N.Y., who were in Joliet, Ill., yesterday, looking over the ground for a site for their Albany plant, which they propose to move West, have returned to this city.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 25, via Galveston.-- The first train on the Monterey and Gulf Railroad reached Montemorelos yesterday.

QUEBEC, July 25.--The ship Lanarkshire, from Buenos Ayres, has been detained at quarantine, having had smallpox on board. The patients have been placed in the hospital. The ship will be fumigated. The tug Champion, which had her in tow, came up to port, but was ordered back to Grosse Isle to undergo quarantine.

FREDERICK, Md., July 25.--The monument to be erected on South Mountain to mark the spot where Gen. Reno fell has been completed and will shortly be erected. Ex-Gov Hartranft of Pennsylvania and the committee in charge of the movement will meet at Sharpsburg in a few days to complete arrangements.

Half a dozen young men clad in the uniform of the New-York Club touched the home plate in the fourth inning yesterday. This gave the Giants a lead which the Senators were unable to overoome, and the result was that the champions, after having their colors lowered in three successive games, finally won a ball.
ALBANY, July 25.--The Old Homestead Club, formed for social, mutual benefit, benevolent, musical, dramatic, artistic, anti lawful sporting purposes, has been incorporated.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 26.--A meeting of the stockholders of the Wabash Eastern Railway Company of Indiana was held here to-day for the purpose of voting upon articles of consolidation between the Toledo Western Railroad Company, the Detroit and State Line...

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 26.--Col. D.B. Henderson, Congressman from the Third Iowa District, in an interview expresses himself as believing that there will be an extra session of Congress called for Nov. 1, or thereabout.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 26.--The will of George W. Norton, the millionaire banker, lately deceased, was admitted to probate to-day. It disposes of property valued at $5,000,000. This is mostly real estate, situated in Kentucky. Texas, and Minnesota. After making charitable bequests, including $5,000 to the Baptist Theological School, he divides the estate among seven heirs, his wife and six children. His residence and home property he gives to his wife.

MORRISTOWN, Minn., July 26.--One of the worst storms ever experienced here came up about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Clouds moved in every direction resembling cyclonic clouds. Hailstones as large as eggs fell, accompanied by a heavy wind and rain storm. Two large barns were demolished and other buildings were unroofed.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 26.--The regatta of the Ocean Grove Miniature Yacht Club took place this afternoon on Wesley Lake in the presence of a large crowd of spectators. Four heats were sailed by the seven yachts competing, resulting in a victory for the Benjamin Harrison, whose owner, Charles Hall, received a valuable gold prize.

PHILADELPHIA. July 26.--Miss Kate Drexel, whose recent entry into a Pittsburg convent created a sensation, has given $25,000 for the erection of a college for the exclusive use of colored people. She has in addition agreed to pay the salaries of a pastor for the church...

Expressions of sympathy with the movement to hold a world's fair in this city in 1892, to commemorate the close of the Fourth century since Christopher Columbus put foot on American soil, are pouring into the Mayor's office.

Alderman M.J. Coffey, who has been the strongest candidate for the Democratic nomination for Senator from the Second District, Brooklyn, decided yesterday that he did not want the honor. He says he could not afford to spend his Winters away from his business. Assemblyman McCann may be Senator Pierce's successor.

MONTICELLO, July 26.--Smith Schoonmaker, proprietor of a large Summer boarding house at Black Lake, Sullivan County, died at his home on Wednesday from the effect of injuries sustained through being gored by a bull.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 26.--Superintendent of Public Instruction Andrew S. Draper has appointed the following local Board of Managers for the State Normal and Training School at Plattsburg: Rowland C. Kellogg of Elizabeth town, Alexander Bertrant of Beekmantown, Henry G. Burleigh of Whitehall, William C. Stevens of Malone, and Stephen Moffitt, Smith M. Weed. William P. Mooers, S.A. Much is heard in and out of Wall-street nowadays about English syndicates, their great schemes, and their endless purses.
DETROIT, Mich., July 26.--There was another fine day's sport at the Driving Park this afternoon for the close of the Summer meeting.

Joseph Walker Co., manufacturers of stamped linen at 104 Franklin-street have given a bill of sale to O. Jaffe Pinkus. It is said that they were pressed by a Creditor, and to avoid making an assignment gave the bill of sale. It is claimed that the creditors will be paid in full, and the business will be turned over to the firm again.

LONDON, July 26.--The match between the Philadelphia cricketers and the Gentlemen of Kent was continued to-day. The home players finished their first inning with a score of 209. Clarke of Philadelphia took four wickets for 44. Bailey of the same team took two wickets for 27.
HARRISONBURG, Va., July 26.--Very heavy rains have prevailed here. The water in the Shenandoah and its tributaries is rising, and another flood is feared.

BOISE CITY, Idaho, July 26.--The convention has finally passed the article on election and suffrage, which is intended as the deathblow to Mormon political power in Idaho. This has occupied much time for the past three weeks, and was the great question in dispute.

CITY OF MEXICO, Mexico, July 26.--Plans are on foot here for paying off at once at a fair rate of discount all sums owed American railway corporations for subventions, and it is likely this will be effected by a European loan for $35,000,000 gold at 5 per cent. It is known that bankers across the ocean are ready to take the matter up.
ITHACA, N.Y., July 26.--Mary Jackson, colored, died here to-day aged 105 years. She was brought here from Virginia many years ago.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 26.--The Tradesman has instituted an inquiry with reference to the value of negro labor in industrial channels in the South. The inquiries were sent to 300 leading Southern manufacturers, representing blast furnaces, rolling mills, miscellaneous iron works, mines, lumber mills, sawmills, Replies...

A party of explorers Thursday unearthed a number of human skeletons buried in the chalk bluffs ten miles east of Yankton. Dakota, on the Nebraska side. Fifty skulls and 200 headless skeletons were found, which local physicians pronounce to be the remains of white people children and adults. The indications are that they have been buried forty or fifty years. Further researches will be made.

They propose building a fish preserve and pleasure resort in the mountains...

SING SING, N.Y., July 26.--The Sing Sing Yacht Club had a special race to-day to try and settle some old scores between several crack cat-rigged yachts. The course was to and around the Tarrgtown Buoy and return, a dislance of twelve miles.

It is due to the Saloon Keepers' Association to say that it was not the action of their organization, but of a mass meeting of saloon keepers. Two British bark Lynnwood, which arrived Thursday night from Buenos Ayres, came into port in command of her first mate, A.D. Johnson. Two deaths had occurred on board in the forty-nine days' trip from South America, one of them being that of the bark's former commander...
