MALTA, July 26.--The British warship Sultan, which struck a rock and sank near here some months ago, has been successfully raised.

Under the new regulations of the Civil Service Commission, authorizing the publication of the eligible list, the aspirant for office in the classified service can not only ascertain his own standing, but the standing of those who were with him in the examination and who passed it with the required 70 per cent. to get on the eligible list.

The Coffee thieves, John Connell or Carroll, William O'Neill, and James Byrne, who from time to time took fifteen tons of coffee from H. W. Banks Co. of 111 Wall-street, were before Justice German yesterday.

James Ryan, a laborer living at 249 West Sixtieth-street, lost control of himself through jealousy of his wife, Mary Ryan, yesterday noon. He accused her of intimacy with Lawrence Duke, who lived in the same tenement. In his rage Ryan stabbed the woman in the head and neck with a pocket knife.

CHICAGO, July 26.--The well-known total abstinence advocate, Thomas A. Murphy, is in the city. When asked to-day what he thought of the prohibition movement which he has always opposed, Mr. Murphy said: "The prohibition cake is dough. I knew it would prove so and hope thery are beginning to find out you can't legislatate a man sober.

Lawyer John R. Dunn, who was sentenced to State prison for nine years and six months, was taken to Sing Sing Prison yesterday. Dunn was found guilty of having induced Cashier Scott of the Manhattan Bank to steal $185,000. After Dunn had received the greater part of the money he advised Scott to fly. The latter did so, but returned subsequently and was used as a witness against Dunn.

DEER PARK, Md., July 26.--The President was called upon to-day to parson an Indian woman who had been convicted of murder in Fort Smith, Ark. She was sentenced to be hanged July 17, but her sentence was commuted, and after looking over the papers with the Attorney General the President commuted her sentence to imprisonment for life.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 26.--Suit will soon be brought here by counsel representing heirs in Hungary and in Cleveland, Ohio, against the present holders of the estate of William Leidesdorff, one of California's pioneer merchants, who died in 1848. Barnum Bailey's agent, George O. Starr, signed a contract yesterday with the Anchor Line Steamship Company for the transfer of the Barnum Bailey show to England next Fall. By this contract the people connected with the show are to sail on the City or Rome Oct. 16 and the show is to be shipped on the Furnessia Oct. 19.
David L. Alien is over seventy years of age, and lives at 67 Jefferson-avenue, Brooklyn. On Thursday he became the victim of a confidence operator, and lost a valuable gold watch and a dollar bill.

LONDON, July 26.--Sir John Henry Puleston, member of Parliament for Devonport, gave a dinner in the House of Commons this evening to Mr. Robert T. Lincoln, the United States Minister; Mr. Chauncey M. Depew, Attorney General Webster, Sir James Fergusson, Under Secretary of the Foreign Office; Mr. C.T. Ritchie, President of the Local Government Board; Sir Lyon Playfair, Mr. Labouchere and others.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 26.--The Concord grape crop promises to be a partial failure in many localities. Returns received to-day from the principal points along the Hudson and inland show that mildew is seriously affecting the fruit.

LONDON, July 26.--The wedding presents received by Princess Louise of Wales were displayed at Marlborough House to-day. The total value is $150,000. The jewels alone are valued at $120,000. Mrs. Mackay sent a pair of turquois and diamond pendant earrings.

CHICAGO, July 26.--Douglas G. MacRae, editor of the London Financial Times, is in this city, en route for home after a trip through the Northwest. While in this country he has been acting as the agent of the British syndicate which has been making extensive purchases of American grain elevators.
The Bijou Opera House was unexpectedly closed last night, owing to nonpayment of salaries to the people engaged in the representation of "The White Elephant" at that theatre.

ROSELLE, N.J., July 26.--There was a lively scene in Justice Mulford's office in this village yesterday. A farmer named Woodruff had another farmor named Bull arrested for trespass, and so certain was he of convicting Bull that he had three constables in waiting to take him to the county jail. Gen. Foy was Woodruff's attorney, while Assemblyman Marsh apppeared for Bull.

A fine display of fireworks will be given tonight in Pain's fireworks in closure at Manhattan Beach, after the spectacle of the "Last Days of Pompeli." In addition to the Eiffel Tower and other set pieces Mr. Pain has arranged to discharge an extra quantity of the largest and most brilliant kind of skyrockets.

On July 17, 1888, the steamer Columbia carried 3,677 passengers on a trip to Rockaway, although her legal allowance was only 3,000. Two of her passengers complained to the authorities and brought suit against the company owning the boat. Yesterday Judge Benedict in the United States Court filed a decision fining the company $7,108.

The Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bride have found it necessary to renew a portion of the lower layer of planking on the roadways. In order to do the work travel will be suspended, but only on one road at a time.
NEW-HAVEN, July 28.--Yale University's wellknown need of funds to meet current expenses is impressed by the rapid increase in the number of entering students.

The fog was very thick on the rivers yesterday morning, and several close shaves and one collision resulted from the prevailing density. Under the circumstances it was lucky that a large loss of human life was not also credited to the fog's account.
Standing on a bluff at Tompkinsville, S.I., overlooking the bay and Narrows, is an old hostelry known as Nautilus Hall, which was built during the Revolutionary war or shortly afterward.

WINNIPEG, July 26.--The Burke extradition case was closed this afternoon, the counsel for the prisoner making long addresses on his behalf, their main objection being that evidence and depositions taken before Chicago courts could not be admitted as evidence in Canada.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 26.--The war between the rival gas companies of this city raged vigorously to-day. Street Commissioner Stratemeyer, who holds the key to the situation, was so badgered by the attorneys for the wrangling corporations that at last in despair he applied to the Mayor for instructions, as the City Attorney was out of town.

HARRISONBURG, Va., July 26.--The municipal election here resulted in the election of Woodson, the "License" candidate for Mayor, by 134 majority. Of the fourteen license. More than except two are in favor of license. More than usual interest attached to the election, from the fact that the City Judge and City Council had refused to grant any licenses after the people had voted in favor of granting them.

A week ago Manager Mutrie of the Giants prophesied that his club would be in the lead to-day. While Mr. Mutrie is a good manager he is a failure as a prophet.
WINNIPEG, July 26.--The American Consul here received the following letter to-day from Sitka, Alaska, dated July 11:

The special committee appointed by the Republican County Committee to reorganize the Eighth Assembly District Republicans so as to deprive John J. O'Brien of power has decided that it can re-enroll in twelve hours all the persons qualified for membership in the Republican association.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 26.--With respect to the gossip that has recently been current about the nomination of ex-Secretary of State Thomas F. Bayard as the Democratic candidate for Governor of Delaware, it can be truly said that the proposition meets with the hearty approval of the party throughout the State.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 26.--The second day's session of the Inter-Denominational Bible Conference opened at 10:30 o'clock this morning in the Young People's Temple, on the camp ground, with a Bible reading on the subject of "Demonology."

INDIANAPOLIS, July 26.--The State Board of Equalization concluded its labors yesterday and adjourned. The time of the board has been devoted almost exclusively to railroad assessments, and each of the roads has made a report of its holdings. All made pleas of poverty, and claimed that they were assessed too high, but the board took a different view of the matter and increased the total assessment from $64,231,727 in 1888 to $88,241,532.

CHICAGO, July 26.--Morris Ryan, Daniel Beckham, Edward Billstein, and Daniel Ryan were until a month ago wealthy dairy farmers, whose fat milch cows pastured on the extensive prairie lands of Jefferson. They are still dairy farmers, but their pastures and their cows have been annexed to the city of Chicago and have come under the provisions of its municipal code.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 26.--The Standard Oil Company is endeavoring to get control of the natural gas lands in Indiana, evidently with the intention of controlling the entire gas field ultimately.
LONDON, July 26.--Two-thirds of the total number of cotton spinners have agreed to limit their production to one-half the usual amount for one month.

PORT AU PRINCE, Hayti, July 18.--The tide of affairs during the past few days has been in favor of Legitime. Port au Prince is beginning to feel her strength.

HARTFORD, July 26.--The statistics concerning the Congregational churches in this State for 1888, which are now being arranged for publication by the Rev. William H. Moore of this city, indicate a high degree of prosperity in the denomination.

There was the usual crowd at Brighton Beach yesterday to enjoy the racing, which was good, as a whole. The waits between the races were reduced to something like reasonable time, and there was a decided improvement...

Gordon Pitt, a bright young man of seventeen years, swept the sidewalk in front of the store of his employer. John Thornton, at 223 Canalstreet, yesterday morning. An elderly woman was sitting on the steps with a baby in her arms, trying to obtain a bit of cool air for the little one.

Mrs. Mary Ulrich died at the City Hospital in Jersey City yesterday. She had been found in a starving condition in an ill-conditioned tenement on the Heights. She intimated that she had made all of her property over to her children...

PHILADELPHIA, July 26.--The bark Ivigtut, which arrived yesterday from Ivigtut, encountered a remarkably stormy and perilous passage, occupying in all forty-eight days, during which forty-seven icebergs were passed. She sailed on June 6, and on that day became fast jammed in an ice pack, the area of which could not'be determined from aloft.

Sixty granite cutters employed at Blissville, L.I., struck yesterday morning at the behest of the New-York branch of the National Granite Cutters' Union. Other cutters refused to strike.

BISMARCK, Dakota, July 26--A memorial to Congress praying or experiments by the General Government with a view to ascertaining whether or not irrigation for North Dakota is practicable was presented.

LONDON, July 26.--When the debate on the report of the Royal Grants Committee was resumed in the House of Commons to-day Mr. Bradlaugh said he found difficulty in discussing the question calmly when Mr. Balfour, outside of the House, denounced the objections as disgusting and sordid.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 26.--A newspaper deal was closed here this afternoon by which a controlling interest in the Evening Star was transferred by Messrs. Shaw Bennett to Col. Alden J. Blethon, present proprietor and editor of the Minneapolis Tribune. The arrangement will go into effect on or before Aug. 20 next.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 26.--The Rev. Thomas G. Strong has lost his reason and will be committed to the Binghamton Insane Asylum to-morrow. Dr. Strong was formerly President of Wills College, and has occupied prominent pulpits in this section of the State, where for many years he was one of the leading divines of the Reformed Church. His misfortune is due to softening of the brain.

A special race of thirty and thirty-five foot yachts for a silver punch howl offered by Mr. August Kohn of the New-Bochelle Yacht Club, will be sailed this afternoon over a seventeenmile course on the Sound, near New-Rochelle. The start will be made at 10 o'clock.

CAIRO, July 26.--Advices from the front state that three columns of dervishes are marching to reinforce the rebels. The columns are followed by caravans conveying provisions. It is believed that when these reinforcements effect a junction with the main body of rebels a grand attack will be made upon the Egyptian force.

Definite information regarding the condition of Lewis Brothers Co., the dry goods firm whose failure was reported yesterday morning, will hardly be available before the schedule, upon which work was begun yesterday morning, is ready.

PARIS, July 26.--The Civil Tribunal has decided that the Panama Canal Company cannot compel the holders of lottery bonds to pay the outstanding installments, but that the holders of such bonds are still liable to be called upon to make pro rata payments to the extent of a quarter of the nominal value of the bonds. Where installments have been paid in advance the company must refund the money.

CHICAGO, July 26.--Insurance agents are rejoicing over a decision rendered by Judge Clifford yesterday. The statutes provide that all insurance companies incorporated elsewhere than in thin State shall, as a condition precedent to doing business in this State, take out licenses.

Martin, and Milton A. Merwin on the bench, was one of extraordinary interest and importance to the keepers of honey begs throughout the country.
SARATOGA, July 26.--It was an extra day at the Springs to-day, and with Barnum's Circus as a counter attraction, the races ware slimly attended.

The use of ivy and Virginia creeper is becoming common in this city to cover the fronts of houses and make them seem in queer contrast to the surrounding desolation of red brick and brownstone. Most of the churches have this beautiful clothing of verdure, most notably Grace Church.

SHANGHAI, July 26.--The Yellow River has again burst its banks in Shantung, inundating an immense extent of country. There is twelve feet of water throughout tea large Governmental districts. The loss of life and property is incalculable. The Government authorities at Pekin are dismayed.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 26.--The schooner yacht Fredonia, from the Western Islands, with Commodore Forbes and party on board, arrived here this afternoon.

PRAIRIE DU CHIEN, Wis., July 27.--Severe wind, rain, and hail storm prevailed in this section of the State to-day. Trees, fences, and outbuildings were leveled, crops blown down and pounded into the earth, and other property damaged. It is reported the storm was even more severe in Eastern Iowa.

MARQUETTE, Mich., July 27.--The shipments of iron ore from the Lake Superior mines for the season have reached a total of 3,121,027 tons, this being 1,421,976 tons in excess of the quantity for warded by water at the corresponding period of last season. The week's shipments foot up 236,689 tons. The volume of shipments continues heavier than at the same time last year.

CHICAGO, July 27.--Probably the heaviest rainstorm ever known in Chicago descended upon the city to-night, accompanied by a high wind and lightning. Rain began to fail at 6 o'clock, and continued until 8:15. In that time, according to the Signal Service Office, 4.12 inches of rain fell.

CLEVELAND, July 27.--John Stricker, aged seventy-five years, has been arrested near Steubeuville for brutally abusing his children. It is alleged that he has been in the habit of hanging his sons and daughters up by the thumbs and whipping them with a hickory ramrod until their flesh was reduced to a jelly. There is great indignation against the old man among his neighbors, to whom he has been a terror for years.

RONDOUT, N.Y., July 27.--Officials of the large ice companies have been making a tour along the Hudson River inspecting the ice houses. They say that the cool weather has largely decreased the demand for ice in NewYork City and elsewhere. CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 27.--Chautauqua has now become a city of 6,000 people. The throngs of guests and the receipts are one-third larger than ever before in July. The fashionable resorts on the lake at Lakewood, Point Chatauqua, and Bemus Point are thronged.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 27.--The Beta Theta Pi Fraternity, established at Miami College in 1839, and one of the oldest Greek letter college societies in the United States, has been holding its fiftieth annual convention at Wooglin-onChautauqua, the fraternity's Summer home, this week.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 27.--Block Island should no more be classed as a shore resort than the Bahamas. It is so far removed from the nearest land that it loses all the climatic conditions of the main. Here, no matter which way the wind blows, the Summer gales are full of a salty life.

SCRANTON, Penn., July 27.--The ten-monthsold boy of P.F. Moran, proprietor of the West Side Hotel, died this morning after suffering intense pain from the effects of an insect's sting inflicted last Sunday.
CINCINNATI, July 27.--The murder of Dr. A. E. Jones, familiarly known as Col. Jones, is one of the most shocking occurrences that could have occurred in Cincinnati.

CHICAGO, July 27.--The Chicago and Calumet Rolling Mill Company, with headquarters at Chicago, was incorporated yesterday, with a capttal stock of $1,000,000. The incorporators are Jean L. Pfau, J. Louis Piau, and George Campbell. It is understood that the company will erect a large rolling mill at Calumet and make steel rails and fight the combination of the Joliet Steel and North Chicago Rolling Mill Companies.

MASON CITY, Iowa, July 27.--Wednesday night last in Elk Township, Clayton County, Wesley Elkins, but little more than eleven years of age, murdered his father and stepmother. Yesterday he confessed himself the parricide.

The vessel was loaded with fish scrap, used for fertilizing purposes. She went to pieces soon after striking. The Furbos was owned by B. O'Neil of New-York. The value of the vessel and cargo combined did not exceed $6,000.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 27.--Owing to the morning's heavy rains the attendance at the early meetings on the camp ground was small, but the clearing weather brought out larger crowds later in the day.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 27.--Gen. J. Madison Drake, commander of the Veteran Zouaves, is about to make a new departure in journalism in this city by starting a penny paper.

Dr. Norvin Green wrote to Postmaster General Wanamaker yesterday in regard to the discussion over the rate of 1 mill per word fixed by the Postmaster General as the pay for telegraphic dispatches for the Government during the fiscal year beginning July 1.

SHARON SPRINGS, N.Y., July 27.--City visitors continue to roll into Sharon at a rate which should bring joy to the hearts of the hotel men, and doubtless would, were it not for the fact that they already have more guests than they know what to do with. Just what becomes of the late arrivals is a mystery.

DELHI, N.Y., July 27.--D.H. Coulter of this village felt a worm crawling on his neck a day or two ago, and in his efforts to rid himself of it the worm was crushed. Soon after all his skin touched by the worm became so sore and inflamed that it was found necessary to call in a physician. Simple remedies were given, but no permanent relief was obtained until the rattlesnake remedy, whisky, was resorted to.

A small man, with a black mustache and a German accent, registered at the St. Clair Hotel, Washington and Concord streets, Brooklyn, on July 23 as A. Gandrer of this city. He appeared to have no business, and spent most of his time in his room.

SARATOGA, July 27.--The rain was not sufficiently heavy to prevent the races set for the day from being run off at the track here to-day. The attendance was light, however, and the betting correspondingly light. Following are the results of the races, scratches being numerous because of the storm:

PEEKSKILL, July 27.--True to its traditions, the Twenty-second Regiment passed its last night in camp in true soldierly fashion. Regulations were observed with precision, and the "good-night" call at taps witnessed the simultaneous extinguishment of lights in the company streets, and from thence on until reveille silence brooded over the encampment.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 27.--An important concession, which may prove to be the solution to the vexed Sunday transportation problem, has just been made by the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association to the New-York and Long Branch Railroad Company.

Clerks of the suspended firm of Lewis Brothers Co. were busy yesterday closing up their accounts and making an inventory of the assets. Inquirers who called upon the firm got very little information, as the partners avowed they had nothing to say until a statement had been prepared.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 27.--The Newport season is advancing at a rapid gait, and the end of the last complete week in July finds society still rather quiet.

Among the passengers by the City of NewYork arriving on Monday from Australia was Sir Arthur Hodgson. Sir Arthur will stay but a few days in San Francisco, and then take the overland train for New-York.

WASHINGTON, July 27.--To-day's bond offers aggregated $109,000, as follows: Registered fours-- $50,000 at 128 3/8, $10,000 at 129; coupon four and a half--$2,000 at 106 7/8; registered four and a halfs-- $37,000 at $108 7/8. $10,000 at 106 7/8. All bond offers except the fifty-thousand-dollar registered fours at 128 3/8 were accepted.
There was an exceedingly heavy and persistent rainfall, beginning at 11 o'clock on Friday night and continuing until 12:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

PITTSBURG, July 27.--It is given out here that the Sewer Pipe Trust is leaking badly. It has failed to make connection and prices have been knocked down. Sewer pipe is now lower than ever before in the history of the trade.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., July 27.--Further details of the disastrous flood in Wirt County have been received. The brother of Thomas Hughes, whose wife and children were drowned Sunday, has arrived from Pittsburg to assist in the care of his brother, who is dying from injuries received.

It appeared first, circa 1770-75, in the Town and Country Magazine, above the signature of Pygmalion, the writer (as his "Poems," 1778, show) being Charles Graham of Penrith.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 27.--Two hundred persons in the Twenty-third District of Wilson County have banded for the purpose of driving Mormon Elders and converts from that county.

For several years the Hawkins Zouaves of the old Ninth New-York Volunteers have received cordial invitations from the Third Georgia Regiment to join it in its annual reunions. The two regiments always had a fraternal feeling for each other after their several rather aggressive meetings during the war.

DANVILLE, Va., July 27.--Reports from the growing crop of tobacoo in the Bright tobacco region indicate that the crop has been injured by excessive wet weather, but with a favorable season it is believed a good crop of Bright tobaccos will be raised. The crops in this section have been failures for two or three years past.

Senator Jacob A. Cantor stopped in Albany Thursday and Friday. Tnen he went to Oneida, where he addressed the annual meeting of the Central New-York Hop Growers' Association. Mr. Cantor says that he has not decided yet whether to enter the race for the nomination for Secretary of State.

NEWARK, N.J., July 27.--Ex-Assemblyman and Alderman Harrington is in the bottling business in Newark. He was once President of the Bottlers' Association, but has fallen into disfavor.

LENOX, Mass., July 27.--This has been one of the gayest weeks of the season. The outdoor sports were begun by an exciting hare and bound chase, the details of which have already been given in THE TIMES.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 27.--If Bar Harbor is not to be ruined and blotted out from among flourishing Summer resorts, it will be by a special interposition of Providence rather than by the wisdom of some of the people who control her affairs.

The Democrats are to have a fight in Hudson County. Some members of the party not approving of the methods of the old County Committee have formed a new committee, and last night held a secret meeting in Jersey City. It is said that it is the intention to nominate an independent ticket this Fall, and to send a full delegation to the Gubernatorial convention.

"Let's go down and see de watermelyuns," shouted a colored boy to his comrade on Springstreet yesterday as a TIMES reporter passed along. He followed in their wake, and on arriving on the water front found that the arrival of a coasting steamer with a load of the fruit so acceptable to the colored man's palate was the centre of attraction.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., July 27.--Not content with sixteen sulphur springs in and around the village, with accommodations for seventyfive baths at a time, and a continual line of patients imbibing gallons of sulphuric waters, Richfield is to have a sanitarium.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 27.--Wednesday night a party of fifteen men visited the farm of Milt Barclay, sixteen miles east of Somerset, Ky., on the Mount Vernon road, and called out a negro tenant who was accused of stealing from the surrounding neighborhood.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., July 27.--Arthur Elwood, the sexton of the Presbyterian Church at Budd's Lake, was severely stung by bees yesterday.
BELVIDERE, N.J., July 27.--Elijah Parcells of Binghamton, N.Y., and Maggie Demond of Stroudsbury, Penn., were arrested here last night and locked up in the county jail on a charge of bigamy.

LONDON, July 27.--To-day, under gloomy skies that were better befitting October than July, and with flecks of rain in the chill air, the first of the new generation of the English royal family went to the wedding altar.

GILBOA, N.Y., July 27.--William Long of this village went shooting one day recently. He crossed the pretty Schoharie Creek that runs through the town, and then trudged along, climbing over more than one of the Catskill Mountain peaks in this vicinity.

HOTEL AMPERSAND, SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., July 27.--W.J. Ehrich, late of the well-known firm of Ehrich Brothers of New-York, died suddenly this evening at his Summer residence on Saranac Lake of heart failure. Mr. Ehrich had been in good health. At the time of his death he was in his stable, where he sank on the floor dead. He was forty-five years of age.

Yesterday's rainstorm resulted in a postponement of the races set down to be run off at Monmouth and Yonkers. The Monmouth programme will be run off on Monday and that at Yonkers on Tuesday. Entries and weights will stand at both tracks. The Monmouth postponement was a surprise to every one, the reason being that the storm had gullied the track so that it was so unsafe that trainers refused absolutely to run over it.

RED BANK, N.J., July 27.--Fishing in the North Shrewsbury River was never better than it is this season. The favorite fishing ground in this part of the river is between Robbins's Point and Guyon's Point. The fish bite best on the last of the ebb tide and the first of the flood.

Several hundred people were present yesterday at the Empire City Colosseum, Sixty-ninthstreet and Eastern Boulevard, and witnessed the ninth annual picnic and games of the Printers' Benevolent Association.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., July 27.--The Board of Managers of the Casino will contribute the use of that handsome structure and the services of Lander's Orchestra to the entertainment to be given on Thursday and Friday evenings, Aug. 1 and 2, in the Casino Theatre in aid of the building fund of the Pier Episcopal Church of St. Peter's-by-the-Sea.

ROUND LAKE, July 27.--Dr. W.T. Harris, who is known to the literary world by his connection with the once famous Emersonian school of philosophy at Concord, Mass., has been lecturing on "Psychology" thin week before the National Summer School.

PARIS, July 27.--The Cocarde, the Boulangist organ, publishes what it calls the first installment of the documents submitted to, and the depositions made before, the high court of the Senate, which is to try Gen. Boulaner.
LONG BRANCH, July 27.--Police Captain Banford, who was instructed last week by the Town Council to investigate the reports that gambling was actually going on here, made his report on Thursday.

The Rev. Charles Martin Niles, rector of the Church of the Ascension, Rockville Centre, L.I., has resigned his charge, much to the sorrow and regret of his people, to become the assistant minister in St. Andrew's Parish, NewYork City. Mr. Niles has during the last year built a new church and added large numbers to the congregation.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28.--The three-masted schooner Rillie S. Derby, from Philadelphia for Newburyport, with a cargo of coal, was run into and sunk off Duck Creek Flats. Delaware Bay, this morning at 3 o'clock by the steamer W. Whilldin, bound from Baltimore to Cape May. The schooner's crew were taken on board the steamer and landed at Cape May. The damage to the steamer, if any, is not known.
SARATOGA, July 28.--Proctor Knott, the twoyear-old champion of last year, pulled up lame in front after his work at the track to-day. The trouble is said to be a quarter crack.

The Philadelphia express train on the Central Railroad met with a peculiar accident at the Washington-street crossing in Jersey City yesterday afternoon. The new interlocking system is not in complete order and a regular switchman was in attendance at the switch yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 28.--The one hundredth anniversary of the storming of the Bastile was celebrated by the Socialistic and Anarchistic societies of this city to-day.

VIENNA, July 28.--A cyclone in Hungary, Transylvania, and Bukovina to-day swept over several thousand square miles of territory. Hundreds of persons were killed, the crops were destroyed, and enormous damage was done to houses and churches. The districts of Grosswardein, Szegedin, and Mohacs were completely ravaged.

The question is finally to be settled in the Pennsylvania courts whether the South Fork Fishing Club, whose poorly-constructed dam was responsible for the terrible loss of life at Johnstown and along the valley of the Conemaugh, is legally liable ...

The recent rains in Dutchess County have done so much for the pasture lands that they have spoiled the farmers. There has not been for many years so luxuriant a growth of grass and clover and the result is that the cattle have ...

Mr. Hamo Thornycroft has dispatched to Melbourne a replica of his statue of Gen. Gordon which stands on Trafalgar-square, London. By this time it has been erected on Eastern Hill in Australia's flourishing capital.
The first lawyer who came to Maine after the close of the Revolutionary war was David Davis, who moved from Massachusetts to Falmouth in 1782.

SARANIC LAKE, July 28.--This month closes with the record of being the gayest July ever known here. The weather has been clear and cool, and enjoyed very much by all. The boat, log, tub, and swimming races among the guides, gotten up by the guests of the Hotel Ampersand ...

--Henry Holt Co. make the interesting announcement that the lamented Prof. Alexander Johnston of Princeton left in their hands, ready for the press, a second "History of the United States," written on a plan somewhat similar to his already well-known text book, but suited to a shorter course and perhaps to less mature minds.

On the Anchor Line steamship Australia, from Naples, which arrived in port yesterday, was a package of freight that to those who knew its contents recalled a sad story. The package, a long pine box, was marked "Fragile. Handle with care. Plate glass."
PEEKSKILL, July 28.--"If they don't let me go to Peekskill to-day I'll sit in my tent and swear at every man who goes by."

Notwithstanding yesterday was gloomy, with little downfalls of rain at frequent intervals in the morning, the weather did not deter the oarsmen from coming forth upon the Harlem in all their gay toggery and athletic rivalry.

PITTSBURG, July 28.--John Yeldell has for two weeks been the most-talked-of colored man in the United States. He was arrested here on July 8, under the alias of the "Rev. E.F. Flemon," and is wanted in Edgefield County, S.C., ...

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 28.--No man in Illinois is busier during the present warm weather than ex-Gov. Jonn M. Palmer, who for the past two weeks has been engaged in attending old settlers' reunions, farmers' picnics, and county fairs to which he has been invited to address the multitudes assembled.

The efforts which the members of the Cotton Exchange are making to have F.F. Dufais retained in the Consulship at Havre are awakening much interest down town, outside as well as inside of the Exchange that is immediately interested.

This has been a season of disaster to those engaged in the production of fruit whose farms are within two or three hundred miles of this city. It has been many years since there has been such a concert of complaints from fruit growers; nor are they alone.

Soon after 11 o'clock yesterday morning there was a loud explosion, followed by an oil fire in the Tidewater Company's works at Constable Hook, N.J. One of a pair of large stills containing crude oil had exploded, setting fire to the oil in the still. Almost instantly the fire spread to the twin still adjoining, they being connected.

CINCINNATI, July 28.--The name of Col. Jones's murderer has been variously written-- Bligh, Bly, Blite, Blythe, and Blygh. He had several ways of pronouncing his name, but he can neither read nor write. His wife, however, who can read and write, writes it Blythe, and this spelling of the name is accepted by the police authorities.
The difficulty of appraising rightly the chances for the Home Rule Party in the House of Commons is always great, owing to a constant factor whose working can never be judged beforehand.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 28.--A special train containing reception committees consisting of the pastor and two Trustees of each Catholic church in the city and a large number of laymen met Bishop McQuaid at South Livonia, this afternoon, and he was escorted to the city, accompanied by Archbishop Williams of Boston. The Bishop was met at the station by the uniformed Catholic societies. Imposing ceremonies were held at the Episcopal church and St. Patrick's Cathedral.

A young man walked into a down-town cigar store last Saturday and called for some cigars. "What kind will it be to-day?" asked the proprietor. "Oh, three for a half," said the customer, and the cigars were given him.

DEER PARK, Md., July 28.--About 10 o'clock this morning President Harrison, accompanied by Attorney General Miller and ex-Senator Davis, drove over to Oakland and attended the Presbyterian church. The Rev. John S. Foulk the pastor, preached on the transfiguration of Christ. The news had got abroad that the President was coming, and the church was crowded.
Henry E. Abbey is at the Gilsey House. Miss Margaret Mather is at the Westminster Hotel. Col. Samuel Parker of Honolulu is at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel.

ALBANY, July 28.--Alphonse Montant of NewYork has filed a claim with the State Board of Claims for $9,278, which amount he avers he illegally paid into the State as commissions and taxes as auctioneer in selling imported goods. This tax was under the law of 1866, which he avers was repealed under a subsequent chapter some years later. There are about $40,000 in similar claims to be presented to the board before long.

For several reasons all the circumstances connected with the recent increase of Senator CHARLES F. MANDERSON'S pension and the award to him of $4,300 in back pay are properly the subject of public inquiry, and ...

Two athletic meetings have been called for this evening in the Grand Union Hotel. They are special meetings of the National CrossCountry Association, of which Mr. F. Ware is President, and the Adelphi Athletic Club.
Storekeepers in Brooklyn have been warned against a man who goes about purchasing bills of goods and giving fictitious addresses as to where the money would be paid.

LONDON, July 28.--Discount was easy during the past week at 1 for three months and for short. The Stock Exchange lean rate to next account is 2. There was a marked revival of business on the Stock Exchange during the week. Stagnation disappeared and in most departments there was a buoyant feeling.

Mrs. Emil Haberkorn, or Margaret Mather, as she is known to the public, arrived on the steamer Umbria yesterday, with her husband, after a six months' sojourn in Europe. Miss Mather expressed herself as delighted with her first trip across the water.

The Rev. Dr. Israel Derrick, pastor of the Bethel African Methodist Church at Flushing, L. I., is in an unpleasant position. Sheriff Golden of Queens County holds an execution against him on a note given to J. R. Ross of Wall-street, this city.

In the legal phraseology of the requisite marriage license, Emmons Blaine of the first part and Anita McCormick of the second part are to be united in marriage--but nobody knows just when. Anita McCormick is one of the prettiest girls in Chicago society.

The Chicago Times of to-day says: "Not only is the traffic department of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul road to be removed from Milwaukee to Chicago before the lapse of another month, but report has it that the general offices of the Wisconsin Central are also to be located in this city.
Mr. Henry E. Abbey, accompanied by Mrs. Abbey and Mr. Charles F. Chatterton, private secretary to Mr. Abbey, returned to America yesterday on La Bourgogne.

A small sailboat, containing four drunken men and a six-year-old child, upset in the East River near Jewell's Wharf, Brooklyn, about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and its occupants narrowly escaped drowning. They owed their lives to Patrolmen Harkins and McNally of the Fulton-street station and Capt. Hughes of the canalboat Nathan.

SAVANNAH, Ga., July 28.--The religious frenzy aroused among Liberty County's negroes by the lunatic who pretended to be the Messiah is bafiling every effort made to counteract it. Those who are possessed listen to no arguments or appeals of the whites, nor of the more intelligent of their own color.
OLD ORCHARD, Me., July 28.--The Christian Alliance Convention of Divine Healing in charge of the Rev. A.B. Simpson of New-York, is holding a ten days' session in the camp ground.
"Misfit Photographs for Sale" is the sign on a Michigan-avenue photograph gallery. The man who owns the place says he hit on that plan to get rid of pictures that people order and never pay for.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 28.--Charles S. Crysler of Independence, a noted politician of this quarter of the State and a well-known lawyer, is reported to be short in his accounts to the extent of $30,000.

BALTIMORE, July 28.--After his conference with Gov. Jackson at Salisbury, Detective Norris again appeared in Baltimore to-day. It seems that the Governor issued no warrant for Kilrain's arrest, and that the detective will be obliged to go back to Mississippi, as the Grand Jury of Marion County, where the offense was committed, has not yet found an indictment against the pugilists.

When one of the servants employed by Allen R. Hawley of 48 West Eleventh-street went into the cellar of the house yesterday morning to get some coal she discovered a young negro crouched behind the coal bin.
The Brighton Beach management have decided not to run in opposition to Monmouth today. The programme arranged for to-day has been set over to Wednesday, and entries will stand to that time.
NEW-HAVEN, July 28.--William Healy of Milford lost his life by a peculiar error on the Housatonic River shortly before 1 o'clock this morning.
There seems to be a growing conviction that the steamship City of New-York has been put in much better condition during the few weeks' overhauling she has been having recently.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 28.--Fortune has favored the Kansas agriculturist thus far this year. He found the soil in excellent condition at planting time, and bountiful rains during May and June served to keep his spirits buoyant.
LONDON, July 28.--Mitchell, the pugilist, was interviewed at Queenstown to-day on the arrival of the steamship Oregon, on which he is a passenger.

A joint resolution introduced by the Select Committee of the New-Hampshire Legislature to whom the Stark memorial was referred recommends an appropriation of $12,000, and that the Governor and Council be directed to cause a statue of Gen. John Stark to be erected in an appropriate place in the State House yard.

The road was as level and as springy as a carpeted floor yesterday, but the threatening weather kept so many people at home that the driving crowd was no crowd at all and the show of equipages so poor that even Gabe Case's Venetian ducks refused to leave the bosom of Cromwell's Creek to take their accustomed peep at it.

LIMA, July 28, via Galveston, Texas.--The sixty-eighth anniversary of the independence of Peru was observed with great enthusiasm. The ordinary Congress has been installed and continues an uninterrupted discussion of the Grace contract. The submittal of this matter to the Senate is expected daily. It has been delayed only by a trifling detail.

CINCINNATI, July 28--Not since the great riot has the police force of Cincinnati been so busy as to-day. From early morn until this hour every man on the force has been on duty, and three-fourths of them were concentrated in that somewhat indefinite but widely-notorious ...

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 28.--F.B. Misner of 44 Elmwood-avenue left a note addressed to Ernest K. Weaver, 276 Main-street, at the police station last night. Mr. Meisner stated that he found it tied to the foot bridge at Park Lake yesterday afternoon. The note is as follows:

PARIS, July 28.--Elections for members of the Councils-General were held throughout France to-day. Gen. Boulanger contests 451 cantons. He has been successful in Bordeaux, where he polled 3,316 votes, against 2,691 for his opponent. He was defeated in Montpellier and Rouen.
Steamship Anchoria,(Br.,) Campbell, Glasgow and Moville 10 ds., with mdse. and passengers to Henderson Brothers.

On Friday evening a number of lads, among whom was Severus Cole, a colored boy, of 445 West Twenty-sixth-street, were annoying Charles Krauss, a German barber, who keeps a small shop at 437 Ninth-avenue.
CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, July 28.--A cablegram from London announces that the State of San Luis loan has been taken there.
It is the second-hand bookseller who comes oftenest in contact with men's hobbies. Secondhand book dealers are in the way of picking up secrets, too.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 28.--There is much argument just now as to what issue the Democratic Party of Ohio should make its campaign on this year. The convention is only three weeks distant and the leaders think that there ought soon to be an understanding as to what the platform shall be.
The unfriendly critics of President Harrison fail, we think, to do justice to his controlling virtue of consistency. He does not profess one thing and do another.

WASHINGTON, July 28.--The controversy which has been general among the Masonic fraternity throughout the country respecting the Cerneau Scottish rite has culminated here in the issue of an edict by Harrison Dingman, Most Worshipful ...

Julius Rothe, the dishonest employe of Benjamin Caspary, the cloak manufacturers of 465 Broome-street, who when arrested on Saturday for robbing his employers made a desperate attempt to shoot Patrolman James Ryan of the Eighth Precinct, was arraigned before Justice Gorman at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 28.--The attendance at to-day's meetings was not as large as last Sunday, owing to the rain. The early morning meeting in the Temple attracted over seventeen hundred young people. Evangelist Yatman led the service, his theme being "The Resurrection."

It is a beautiful run to Gibraltar from Lisbon --just long enough to shake off the rustiness occasioned by a two-weeks' stay in port--and as the corvette goes bowling along under a cloud of canvas and full head of steam, dipping her gun muzzles at each swell as she heels to leeward, ...
Thomas Smith, a driver, thirty-five years old, who lived with his parents at 447 East Eightieth-street, is a prisoner at Bellevue Hospital on a charge of attempted suicide.

An interesting episode, which might have been productive of much more serious results than occurred, took place upon one of the ferryboats of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey yesterday, just as it was leaving the slip in Jersey City.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 28.--Frank Hewitt, a lineman in the employ of the Asbury Park Electric Light Company, received a severe electrical shock at 12 o'clock last night while fixing one of the lights and fell from the pole to the ground, a distance of twenty feet. He sustained severe internal injuries and was in an unconscious condition for several hours, when he recovered sufficiently to find his way home.
It was not until afternoon that the dreary downpour ceased at Coney Island, the sun deigned to show his features, and the first boat and train load of visitors arrived.
TRENTON, July 28.--One of the anomalies of the existing Gubernatorial campaign in NewJersey is the number of Republicans who are seeking the favor of the Republican Convention.

PARIS, July 16.--The national French fete day--so much like our own that it only adds ten days to mark its date--was celebrated with more enthusiasm this time than ever before, and there was no crowd anywhere and a vast amount of ennui partout.

The amateur photographers who are unable to take long trips with their cameras are certainly making good use of their holidays in visiting the pretty little bits of natural beauty that can be found near the city.

The latest attempt to solve the Federal patronage muddle in Brooklyn consists in pushing Willis and Nathan to the exclusion of every one else. Congressman Wallace has gone to Washington to tell the powers that the Brooklyn bosses will be satisfied with these two men, even if nothing else is gained.
Among the articles of incorporation filed with the Secretary of State at Albany Saturday were those of the Rockaway Park Improvement Company, Limited.

Whitfield C. Oliver, a good-looking mulatto, who enjoys the reputation among the colored people of the Nineteenth Precinct of being a "voodoo man," was a prisoner at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on complaint of George Day, a real estate agent of 42 West Twenty-eighth-street.
John Hodge, a lithographer at 61 Beekmanstreet, accused Louis Caman of embezzlement in the Tombs Police Court yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 28.--Commander Dennis W. Mullan, who arrived here yesterday, has been resting after the fatigues of a ten days' railroad journey. He has brought with him a number of fine photographs of scenes after the hurricane at Samoa and a silk printed testimonial from the citizens of Apia for saving the town from destruction by fire on Jan. 8, 1889. Commander Mullan will remain here in his native city for some time.

CHICAGO, July 28.--The week at the Chicago playhouses closed last night in a tremendous rain that left the theatres with the lightest business in the aggregate seen this season for a single performance. Two of the Summer attractions closed their season, and one new house was opened.

Mrs. Ada Walder, a German woman thirtytwo years old, went into the hallway of Frederick Rosenstein's liquor store at 43 Horaticstreet and demanded beer, but Rosenstein told her that she had more than was good for her, and had better go home. He noticed her fumbling with a package which she had taken from her pocket and seized her hand.

The large building on North Queen-street, Lancaster, Penn., owned by A.C. Kepler and occupied by Reilly Brothers Raub, hardware merchants, was gutted by fire yesterday morning. Loss, $40,000; insurance on building, $10,000; on stock, $27,000. David Beard, a fireman, was seriously injured by falling from a ladder.

The Newport Steeplechase Association announce two stake events to be run Sept. 21 and 23 under the auspices of the recently-organized club. These are the Rhode Island Hurdle race of two miles, of $50 each, one-half forfeit, with enough money added to make the stake worth $1,500, and the Newport Grand National ...

There has not been a funeral procession in many years in the Sixth Ward so large as that which yesterday followed the body of Hugh Murray from his home at 130 Leonard-street. Mr. Murray was County Delegate of the Ancient Order of Hibernians, and was interested in several other Irish societies.

The news comes from San Francisco that Augustin Daly has been confined to his room in the Palace Hotel for a week suffering from malarial fever. Mr. Daly is of such an energetic temperament that any illness which can keep him....

SCOTTDALE, Penn., July 28.--The muchtalked-of strike has at last been ordered by one of the largest labor conventions ever held in the Connellsville coke region. Nearly fifty delegates were present, representing almost all the works in the region. Master Workman Kerfoot of Subdivision No. 4, Knights of Labor, was chosen Chairman, and Cloyd M. Parker of the same organization Secretary. As was predicted, not a single coke operator was present to meet the conference committee.

WICHITA, Kan., July 28.--Soon after the disappearance of Banker Brown on June 19 last the report was started that he had been assailed by some one seeking vengeance in behalf of a woman who was a first wife, and that he had married a second before getting a divorce.

WASHINGTON, July 28.--There appears to be no let up in the distribution of the Federal patronage in North Carolina on the strict family plan already referred to in these dispatches, while the purpose of the powers that be to include in the benefits ...

Again Mr. Dixon Kemp, the great English yachting editor, has expressed his views on international yacht racing in the London Field. It appears that a correspondent of Mr. Kemp's paper has suggested that a challange cup valued at 1,000 should be provided in England for international yacht racing.
POUGHKEEPSIE, July 29.--Not long ago the store of George Vail, in Hibernia, Dutchess County, was entered by thieves and robbed of $1,000 worth of goods.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 29.--Bell Boy, the sensational four-year-old stallion, was given his first speed trial this morning, consisting of a half-mile dash, which he made in 1:10, the last quarter of which was covered in 0:34.

CINCINNATI, July 29.--Charles Blythe, the murderer of Col. A.E. Jones, was taken into the police court this morning, and, with very little ceremony, was ordered committed to jail to await the action of the Grand Jury. As he left the court room to go to jail he said: "I feel mighty bad this morning."

YORKTOWN, N.Y., July 29.--The station of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company was broken into last night and robbed of $300 in cash and several express packages. One of the packages was consigned to D.W. Merritt of this place. This package contained property valued at $200. It is estimated that the booty secured by the burglars amounted to $1,000. There is no clue to the thieves.
Prince George of Wales is to have command of the first-class Yarrow torpedo boat No. 79 during the coming manoeuvres. This is the fastest vessel in the British Navy.

BALTIMORE, July 29.--Civil Service Commissioner Theodore Roosevelt's visit to Baltimore last Saturday was so quiet that no particulars concerning it could be learned. Today, however, an outline of the testimony elicited by Mr. Roosevelt was secured, and the American will publish it tomorrow.

Rear Admiral Belknap, commanding the United States naval force on the Asiatic Station, reports to the departmet under date of July 8 as follows: The Omaha is at Yokohama. The Marion is at Yokohama; will sail July 11 for Kobe, thence to Chemulpo, relieving the Palos. The latter upon being relieved will go to Nagasaki.

An investigation by a jury and Coroner Lindsay yesterday showed that Capt. William Hall, who commanded the new steamer Spindrift, died from heart disease. Caps. Hall had expected to sail next week for London, and his vessel was lying at the foot of South Secondstreet, Williamsburg.

The "boss" of the Croton Aqueduct, Henry Marks, has met with a set-back. After whipping everybody who had the temerity to stand up before him he sighed for other worlds to conquer, and heard there was a rising boxer living in Mount Kisco.

NEWARK, N.J., July 29.--The Common Counoil to-night, by a vote of 22 to 7, passed the contract between the city and the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company for supplying the city with water from the Pequannock watersheds.
WASHINGTON, July 29.--While some of Gen. Mahone's warm adherents are talking very earnestly about making him the candidate for Governor of Virginia next ...

A distinguished army officer from a West India island who is stopping at a hotel in Unionsquare and looking after the interests of one of the disputants for supremacy in Hayti, asked his friends Saturday night to pat him on the back and congratulate him.

RICHMOND, Va., July 29.--Gov. Lee received a letter to-day from Commonwealth's Attorney Moore of Patrick County, in which the latter appeals to the Governor to aid him in punishing desperadoes who are guilty of lawless acts along the North Carolina and Virginia border. The letter says:
LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 29.--Over $1,500 was realized at the benefit given by the actors who are summering at Long Branch at the Ocean Theatre to-night for the Monmouth Memorial Hospital.

WASHINGTON, July 29.--To-day's bond offerings aggregated $127,100, as follows: Registered four and a halfs, $2,000 at 107, $100 at 106 7/8 $100,000 at 106 7/8, $25,000 at 106 7/8 ahd $10,000 at 106 7/8. All the offers were accepted except the $2,000 at 107.

LONDON, July 29.--The Massachusetts rifle team were received to-day by the Lord Mayor of London. The Lord Mayor toasted the riflemen and congratulated them upon the many successes they have achieved during their visit to England. Major Frost, in returning thanks on behalf of the team, said that the courtesy shown by the Lord Mayor to American visitors was proverbial.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29.--The Pennsylvania Railroad Company is receiving bids for an addition of 5,000 cars to its rolling stock. It is expected that the contract will be awarded as soon as all of the firms requested to make a bid have been heard from. This improvement to the rolling stock will involve an expenditure of $3,000,000.
Horsemen are loud in their praises of the new race course in Westchester County, which will be used for the first time at the coming meeting of the New-York Jockey Club.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 29.--The Fisheries Department has been notified of the seizure of the British schoonor Black Diamond by the United States revenue cutter Rush for fishing in Behring Sea. Particulars are expected by telegraph to-morrow.

BOSTON, July 29.--The announcement is made that a syndicate of English capitalists known as the Intarnational Gas Company is trying to secure control of the gas franchise of the city of Brooklyn, N.Y., and with every chance of sucess.

Cornelius F. Buys, a young man of twentytwo, who lived with his parents at 108 Fort Greene-place, Brooklyn, was struck by the boom of the yacht Beatrice off Bay Ridge yesterday morning, knocked overboard, and drowned.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 29.--The Trades Council last night, by a vote of 15 to 20, eleminated the Knights of Labor from their organization.

WASHINGTON, July 29.--The New-York Giants and the Senators played an intereating and wellcontested game here to-day, which was won by the former in the eighth inning, principally on account of John Irwin's error and the wildness of young Keefe, who, barring this inning, pitched a fine game.

FORT BENTON, Montana, July 29.--Forest fires are reportod in the mountains and along the banks of the Missouri for many miles below here. At Bowdoin the section house was burned and Miss Mattie Johnson, a school teacher, so severely burned that her recovery is doubtful. The Northern Pacific track east of Livingston was burned out for a short distance, but has been repaired.

CHICAGO, July 29.--Officer Sylvester E. Fish of the Thirty-fifth-street station was shot in the head at 2:30 this morning while attempting to arrest a burglar. Four shots were fired, one of which took effect.

The Hon. James F. Buckner, Collector of Internal Revenus at Louisville, Ky., for two terms under President Grant and one term under Hayes, is dying from a paralytic stroke received Sunday night at his home in Louisville. He was Speaker of the Kentucky Legislature forty yoars ago, a member of the State Senate, and the holder of other prominent official positions. He is seventy-six years old and wealthy.

Mrs. Eidel Beck, seventy-five years old, of 5 Hester-street, died yesterday of apoplexy. Several days ago she was struck on the side of the head by a cat thrown--it was said at the time-- by some boys who were torturing the animal in the street before the house.
BALTIMORE, July 29.--A sweet potato trust has been incorporated here. It is known as the Sweet Potato Supply Company, and its capital stock is $22,000.

Most of the engineers and first assistant engineers of tho Republican machine in this State were at the Oriental Hotel, Manhattan Beach, last night. The night was hot, and there was just sea fog enough to conceal their faces from one another as they talked.

DETROIT, July 29.--There was great astonishment in the community at Ann Arbor a few days ago when the Rev. Dr. Samuels Earp, Rector of the Episcopal church there, resigned to take effect Nov. 10. The only reason given was need of rest after twenty years of continuous work.
The generally poor condition of the growing crops of apples and beans in almost all parts of this State is causing a great deal of concern to the farmers and to merchants in this city.

The hullabaloo raised by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company over what it proclaimed as its discovery that the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago Railway was surreptitiously cutting rates has not developed into much of a Wall-street sensation.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 29.--The unknown ruffian or crank who has been terrorizing women in various parts of the city for the last six months by entering their bedrooms about midnight was again at his usual game last night.

The stock market had a murky time of it yesterday. The bear contingent was active, and abounding tales went round, proclaiming all manner of distresses in the railway world. Raids were made in every conspicuous quarter. Yet when the day was done only one stock of prominence showed a loss of consequence.

Rowland R. Hazard, who devised the underground railway system which the New-York District Railway Company has tried to make use of under Broadway, is in London promoting the interests of the London Central Subway Company.
Frank Sutherland and a lot of cigars that the Customs Inspectors said were smuggled, were found on the Battery yesterday very close together.
Ferdinand Hopp, a retired barber living at 437 East One Hundred and Sixteenth-street, was arrested yesterday afternoon on a warrant issued by Coroner Levy, charging him with ...

William Whitfield Tolliver, the young colored man who was sent to prison on Sunday by Justice Gorman, charged with being a "voodoo man" and having extorted $23 from Mary Kelly, a servant in the employ of George Day, at 40 West Twenty-eigth-street, was discharged yesterday on examination. His arrest was a mistake.
DUBLIN, July 29.--President Harrison has sent a letter to Lord Mayor Sexton in reply to the Dublin corporation's expression of sympathy for the sufferers by the Johnstown disaster.

AVON-BY-THE-SEA, N.J., July 29.--The name of this resort, which has been known as Key East, has been changed to Avon-by-the-Sea. The change was made by the popular voice of the residents, who have long objected to making their Summer resort a cigar advertisement. The name of the Post Office here has been changed, and all railway tickets hereafter issued to this place will bear the newly-adopted name.
LONDON, July 29.--The Philadelphia cricketers played to-day against the Gentlemen of Southampton. A hot sun and a "tricky" wicket caused poor scoring on both sides.

CINCINNATI, July 29.--The twenty-second aunual meeting of the Society of the Army of the Tennessee will be held here Sept. 25 and 26, Wednesday and Thursday. On Wednesday evening the oration will be given at the Music Hall.
The opening of the half-mile race track at Yonkers, which was to have taken place on Saturday, occurs to-day instead. The entries and weights for the several events are as follows:

WICHITA, Kan., July 29.--E.T. Brown, the banker, waa called upon by over 200 friends yesterday. He was taken for a drive by an intimate friend in the afternoon. In some way the Oklahoma question was mentioned, and he first learned that the country had been thrown open to settlement. It is said the authorities contemplate calling on him for a statement upon which to base their action.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 29.--The branch of the Shepaug Railroad from New-Preston to Lake Wauramaug is now assured. The four miles of track will cost about seventy-five thousand dollars, and citizens have complied with the company's request to contribute $20,000 and the right of way.

STANDING ROCK, Dakota, July 29.--The old warriors at the agency have been startled by the apparently-authoritative statement that the young Indians belonging to the Catholic societies are favorable to the treaty and will sign.

The worsted mills of Scheppers Brothers American and Diamond streets, Philadelphia, were closed down on Saturday, in consequence of the failure of Lewis Brothers Co. The firm, it is stated, employed over four hundred hands and manufactured both cotton and woolen goods, but pricipally worsteds.
The Corinthian Yacht Club has decided to sail several matches after the New-York Yacht Club's cruise, to determine if possible how to obtain a just rule measurement of yachts for time allowance.

RED BANK, N.J., July 29.--Notwithstanding the fact that they have been served with summonses for violating the Vice and Immorality act, in that they ran their stages on Sunday, some of the hackmen yesterday ran their stages between Deal Beach Station and Asbury Park.

An old man named Hermann Spitzgar was crushed between two wagons and in all probability was fatally injured on Park-row, opposite the entrance to the Brooklyn Bridge, about 10 o'clock yesterday morning.
ST. PAUL, July 29.--The races at the Twin City track to-day were run with those results:

Although the Freehold Stakes will be is a walkover for Firenzi at Monmouth Park to-day the Camden Stakes, for two-year-olds, and the Palisade Stakes, for three-year-olds, ought to furnish some good sport, even though the track will be very heavy.

The pier of the Hamburg-American Steamship Company was thronged with people yesterday who had come by invitation of the agents to inspect the new ocean prodigy, the Columbia.

PARIS, July 29.--The results are now known in 1,200 cantons. Gen. Boulanger has been elected in only twelve. The Conservatives have gained twenty seats. M. Wilson, son-in-law of ex-president Grevy, and M. Le Herisse, the well-known Boulangist, are defeated.

BERMUDA, July 22.--The schooner yacht Fredonia, (Eastern Yacht Club,) twenty-two days from Teneriffe, with her owner, Mr. J. Malcolm Forbes, and party of friends on board, anchored in Hamilton Harbor on Wednesday last. The Fredonia left Boston on May 24, and has been crusing about the Western Islands. She left for home on Saturday morning.

A dog darted into the stable of the North Hudson Railroad Company at Hoboken yesterday morning, snapping at everything that was in his path. Before his presence was noticed he had made a spring at Frederick Bruhn, a hostler, and planted his teeth in the man's arm.
It must be owned that this country contains more intense and soulful young things of both sexes and of all ages, in proportion to its population, than any other in the world.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29.--The steamer Thordisa, Capt. Hogarth, which arrived here from Carthagena July 15, was burned to the water's edge shortly before noon to-day in the Schuylkill River at the Point Breeze Oil Works, where she was being loaded with oil.

Dr J.J. Corcoran of 96 Franklin-avenue, Brooklyn, was called to 1,915 Bergen-street at an early hour on Sunday morning to attend a sick man. He found William J. Tate, aged forty-five, sinking very rapidly.

PORTLAND, Oregon, July 29.--J.H. Seward and James Switzer were brought from Harvey County this morning to appear before United States Commissioner Deady to answer to a charge of preventing an officer of the United States from performing his duties.

Ocean Grove, N.J., is just now rejoining in a new motive power for raising water to sprinkle its streets and make them free from the simoons of New-Jersey dust which have hitherto detracted from the charms of that religious place of pastime.
VIENNA, July 29.--The Wiener Allgemeine Zeitung asserts that a definite offensive and defensive alliance has been concluded between France and Russia.

MUSKOGEE, Indian Territory, July 29.--When the Creek Nation desired to negotiate for the ale of the Oklahoma country, Messrs. Ples, Porter, B.M. Hodges, and Isparechee were appointed delegates to represent the nation. They drew 10 per cent. of the purchase money and claimed they paid that as per agreement to ...

CHICAGO, July 29.--The Transcontinental Association met again to-day. At one point during the discussion of the dispute between the Southern Pacific and Canadian Pacific on the question of differentials, General Manager Stubbs of the former road, left the meeting in disgust, and refused to return during the day.

JUNEAU, Alaska, July 23.--The Albatross, with the Senate Committee on Indian Affairs, arrived here Sunday afternoon. They are on their return to Port Townsend, whence they will go at once to Portland, thence to the Flat Head Indian Reservation in Montana, and thence East.
The United States cruiser Yorktown, Commander French E. Ohadwick commanding, returned to the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday from her forty-eight hours' cruise at sea for battery trail.

PARIS, July 16.--Philosophers in bygone days covered many thousands of pages with their discussions of the true, the beautiful, and the good; but they hardly ever undertook to give these notable abstractions a local habitation as well as a name.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 29.--The official closing quotations for mining stocks to-day were as follows:

RALEIGH, N.C., July 29.--H.R. Hammond, a well-known traveling salesman, representing Adams, Buck Co., of Baltimore, dropped dead at the Yarsborough House, in this city, this morning. He was forty-five years of age and was in apparently good health. His death was caused by pulmonary apoplexy.
Mrs. Pauline Schrauer, the wife of Isaac Schrauer, an optician doing business at 212 East Thirty-fourth-street, committed suicide yesterday morning by taking carbolic acid.

A fine display of animal reasoning power was exhibited last evening at the Battery by a wellgrown Newfoundland pup. Its master had taken it and a full-grown dog of the same breed to the landing just east of Pier A, for the purpose of giving them a bath.

RAHWAY, N.J., July 29.--William H. Wright, for nearly four years window clerk at the Post Office here, was on Saturday night notified by the Postmaster that his services were no longer required. The announcment was a surprise to young Wright, whose father is one of the Freeholders from the city and has a strong political pull. Wright's successor is Stephen Perkins, a reporter on the Rahway Democrat.

PORTLAND, Oregon, July 29.--A syndicate of wealthy Portlanders has bought and proposes to complete a system of railways which will, give the Canadian Pacific a track into this city. B.Y. Thompson has just returned from the British possessions, whither he went to close a deal with the New-Westminster Southern Railroad Company.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 29.--Judgment has been rendered by the Supreme Court of NewJersey annulling the charter of the Deal and Squan Bridge Turnpike company, and the road, which is the only direct means of communication between this place and the resorts lying on the shore south of here, is being repaired and placed in first-rate order by the Town Committee of Neptune Township.

BOSTON, July 29.--Three alarms of fire and a great blaze gave promise of a very serious fire in East Boston to-night. Although in a bad location, the fire was confined to two buildings, which were pretty thoroughly riddled.

The steamship Anchoria, which arrived yesterday morning early from Glasgow, had one incident during the voyage which served to break the monotony of an otherwise uneventful trip.

The lamp and oil store of J.H. Compion, at 328 Grand-street, Brooklyn, was partially destroyed by fire yesterday, causing a loss of $2,500. While trying to put out the fire William Clark was severely burned. He was removed to the hospital.

LONDON, July 29.--Lord Randolph Churchill in a speech at Walsail to-day, strongly urged Conservatives to develop their latent energy and not to fall into the error of undervaluing their opponents' strength. He said that the bye-electrons had shown that the Opposition had more popular streneth than he, as a ...

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., July 29.--The Schooner George Savage Bartlett, from Kennebec with a load of baled, compressed sawdust for NewYork, ashore at Jamaica Island, failed to come off at high water this morning.

Mr. Edward Kaufmann, who is counsel for Arthur Levy Co., the London bankers who have a claim for over $100,000 against ex-Senator Stephen W. Dorsey, denied yesterday the published story that the latter had effected a compromise with his creditors.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 29.--The war between the gas companies of this city seems to be nearly ended, and the Metropolitan Company has apparently come out ahead, as it has resumed laying mains in various streets.

CHICAGO, July 29.--The police are investigating the suicide of Ida Steubenrauch, aged seventeen years, who lived with her parents. The girl's actions were so strange that she attracted the attention of a man named Cook.

RONDOUT, N.Y., July 29.--John H. Ireland, while fishing in Eastkill Lake, about a mile from Onteora Park, in the Catskill Mountains, to-day caught a trout weighing two pounds and three others of unusually large size

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 29.--The report published in the New-York papers of the forged resignation of Postmaster Hunter of Cornwall simultaneously with the appointment of a successor in Charles H. Wood has occasioned much comment in the district as to the means resorted to by the Republicans to secure a share of the public pap.

PORT JERVIS, July 29.--Sol. Hazelton and his daughter of Mill Rift, Pike County, Penn., on Friday killed twenty rattlesnakes near their abode. A portion were of the yellow variety. One of the reptiles had thirteen rattles. A dog that accompanied Mr. Hazelton was bitten by one of the snakes and died within a few minutes.

The three hundred and odd men employed on the Atlantic-Avenue Railroad in Brooklyn were astonished yesterday to learn that three of their associates had been discharged and nine suspended for some unknown reason.
OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 29.--The weather has been beautiful for outdoor meetings today, and all the sessions of the Interdenominational Bible Conference were well attended.

SNOW HILL, Ma., July 29.--A rainstorm surpassing all previous ones that have fallen this year in Worcester County began here early Thursday morning last and continued with increased fury throughout Friday.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 29.--The Coal Exchange, or Trust, of this pity is putting the screws on the small dealers of the place who do not belong to, the combination. William Webber has been served with a notice by the mining firm that supplied him with coal to the effect that he cannot have any more coal from that source.

A thorough examination of the condition of the Schuvikill River from ite sources to the point where the supply of water for the people of Philadelphia is taken has been made by the Inquirer of that city.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., July 29.--Herman Kobbe came to this country eighteen years ago from Germany and settled in this village. Two years later a daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Kobbe, and they named her Carrie. Desiring to give her a thorough education, in May last they sent Carrie to Bromberg to spend two or three years at school.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, July 30.--An action was begun yesterday in the District Court at Marion that will startle Masonic circles more than anything else, perhaps, of late years. Judge Preston of the Eighteenth Judicial District ...

RONDOUT, N. Y., July 30.--Mrs. Herrington is dead at Milton-on-the-Hudson. She said she was one hundred and two years of age, and the family Bible shows her statement to have been correct. She was a devout Catholic.

The Queen has been rather troubled with rheumatism and insomnia again lately. Her Majesty has been ordered to take scarcely anything besides whisky and Apollinaris, as it is found that that pleasant and wholesome combination is most beneficial to her. The black crutch walking stick has been painfully on evidence since the Queen's return from the North, but except for this her Majesty's health is as good as it usually is in the Summer.

The Yonkers Racing Association had a miserable day for the opening of its meeting at Lowerre yesterday. The rain came down in torrents when the first race was called and continued the entire afternoon.

BURLINGTON, Wis., July 30.--Nine persons were poisoned last night by eating dried beef shipped to local dealers by a Chicago firm. Four of the victims are precariously ill, while the others are on the road to recovery. Cats and dogs, who were given the meat, would not eat it.

Returned Tourist (thrusting his right hand in his trousers pocket)--Thanks! Custom House Inspector (sollo voce)--No, not here. Give me your address, and I will call on you to-morrow.

If the owner of the race course just made ready for the meeting of the New-York Jockey Club has laid a track, as is no longer denied, and built a fence on the Bronx and Pelham Parkway, he will be required to remove the obstruction forthwith.

In New-York yesterday was a day that was especially trying to the fat man who perspired uncomfortably and could not get dry, and to the citizen who had left his umbrella at home and who got caught in one of the passing showers that kept coming and going all day.

GRAND FORKS, Dakota, July 30.--United States Senator William M. Evarts of New-York was the author of the so-called Williams Constitution which was handed in for the consideration of the North Dakota Constitutional Convention.

SARATOGA, July 30.--The races here to-day were run over the heaviest kind of a track and during the rain. The sensation of the day was the defeat of Hanover by Los Angeles in the race for the Excelsior Stakes at a mile and a quarter, the Dwyer "crack" being anchored by the muddy going. As the Pittsfield express was passing by Pleasantville at 8:20 o'clock last evening, a woman who is supposed to be Mrs. William M. Howell, wife of a White Plains clothier, stepped in front of the train, and was killed. Dr. Swift took charge of the body. Coroner Hopkins will hold an inquest.

RICHMOND, Va., July 30.--A member of Mahone's State Executive Committee to-day expresses the opinion that the ticket to be nominated by the Virginia Republican Convention, which is to meet at Norfolk on Aug. 20, will be composed of three ex-Confederate Generals.
It won't do for Assemblyman Ainsworth's friends in Oswego County to vindicate him on the ground that the backset he received in Albany last Winter was the result of "jealousy of aristocrats."

YOKOHAMA, July 30.--A dispatch received today from Nagasaki states that a dreadful earthquake has occurred in the western portion of the island of Kiou Siou. The town of Kumamoto was destroyed. A great number of people perished. A vast amount of property was also destroyed.

The entries for to-day's races at Brighton are as follows: FIRST RACE.--Purse $500. for three-year-olds: beaten allowances. Three-quarters of a mile. Tipstaff and Wild Cherry, 115 pounds each; Monsoon, Kingstock, Mose K., and Raymond G., 110 each: Dr. Jekyll, Glory, Iceberg, Chapman, Forest King, Cracksman, and Dock Wick, 105 each.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 30.--The full court gave judgment at noon to-day in the Martin Burke appeal Judgments were delivered by Chief Justice Taylor, Judge Dubuie, and Judge Killam. They all concurred in finding that there were no grounds for reversing the action ...

LONDON, July 30.--The game between the Philadelphia cricket team and the Gentlemen of Southampton was continued to-day. The wicket was in much better condition than yesterday. Newhall of the American team played well for 21 runs.

ST. LOUIS, July 30.--A squeeze in corn developed in the local market to-day, though there have been fears felt for several days past that a corner was starting. When William Orthwein, of Orthwein Brothers, began bidding for spot No. 2 corn on to-day's cash call and finally rushed the price up to 36 , the fears became a certainty and the shorts began to look grave and feel nervous.
Mayor Grant not having returned from his trout-fishing trip to the Adirondacks, President Arnold of the Board of Aldermen presided over the meeting of the Sinking Fund Commission yesterday.

The survivors of the Tenth Regiment, NewYork Volunteer Infantry, (National Zouaves,) held a preliminary meeting in the quarters of Company G, Ninth Regiment, to make arrangements about going to Gettysburg on Saturday, Aug. 31.

BOONE, Iowa, July 30.--About 12 o'clock last night John A. Peterson, Deputy Postmaster at Mineral Ridge, Boone County, a small town eight miles north of this city, was awakened by some one trying to get into the store and Post Office. He saw a man reaching in a window that had been broken. Peterson fired, and the burglar dropped dead on the outside, shot through the head. An accomplice who was with him escaped.
LONDON, July 30.--In the House of Commons to-day the Royal Grants bill passed its third reading without a division. The result of the voting on the bill was greeted with cheers by its supporters.
